PARA.TAB: Mr ACTING SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) raised as a matter of privilege comments reportedly made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in respect of the Speaker, and me as Deputy Speaker. The honourable member quoted from provisions of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987, and he presented copies of media reports referring to the remarks allegedly made by the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: Section 6 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 abolished the previous offence of contempt by defamation by providing that words or acts shall not be taken to be an offence against the House by reason only that the words or acts are defamatory. It is still possible, however, for conduct, including the use of words, to constitute a contempt if it amounts or is intended or is likely to amount to an improper interference with the free exercise by a house or a committee of its authorities or functions or with the free performance by a member of the member's duty as a member.

The honourable member's complaint puts me in a difficult position in that I am one of the members who have been subject to the alleged attempted intimidation. Despite this difficulty, as Acting Speaker I am required to give a decision as to whether in my opinion a prima facie case has been made out. Having considered the arguments of the honourable member for Flinders, I have to advise the House that I do not believe anything improper has occurred or that there is evidence of an attempt to intimidate either the Speaker or me.

The House is indeed a robust place, and it is no doubt unlikely that any occupant of the chair will be immune from criticism outside the chamber in respect of his or her performance in the House. I believe, however, that it would only be in exceptional circumstances that criticism of the occupant of the chair would give rise to a substantive issue of privilege or contempt. I do not believe that on this occasion there is prima facie evidence of a breach of privilege or contempt, so I am not willing to allow precedence to a motion on the matter. I call the honourable member for Flinders, by indulgence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Speaker. I appreciate that so early in the day today we have had the benefit of your views on the matter that I raised yesterday. Given your remarks yesterday, I suppose that I was not surprised at the outcome. It is not a ruling that you have made, and that curtails our opportunities to take the matter further today. I am disappointed in the manner in which you have approached this particular issue. You say that you considered the arguments. With great respect, Mr Acting Speaker, you conspicuously did not consider the arguments because you did not give me an opportunity to put the arguments yesterday. You specifically said that all I could do was to table the documents supporting the submission. You specifically upheld a point of order from the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) which prevented my putting to you the case that I believed provided a firm foundation for the argument that I thought ought to have been considered by you in a more favourable light.

PARA.TAB: The opposition raised the matter yesterday not just in light of the particular remarks that were made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to you and, in his absence, to the Speaker but also in light of the conduct of question time and the government's approach to the proceedings of the House.

I suppose it has long been a complaint from oppositions that they do not get a fair go in the parliament. I suppose it is also true that the public has a fairly cynical view of our complaints about conduct of the proceedings. But the fact is—and you ought to know this, Mr Acting Speaker, given your family background—that standards in this parliament have deteriorated significantly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially on the opposition side.

—It is a classic remark from the boy—the Assistant Treasurer—over there that it is all the fault of the opposition. The fact is that the standards in this place are set by the Prime Minister. People talk about rule changes. No rule changes are required to lift standards in this parliament. That is the fact of the matter.

PARA.TAB: Do not accuse us of party political point scoring. It is a matter of great regret for every member of this House that the standards of this House have fallen in the way in which they have. It is true that a lot of parents would hesitate to bring their children into the galleries of this place and hear Mr Gutter, our Prime Minister, perform as he does. That is the context, Mr Acting Speaker.

Let me just remind members of some incidents last year. Following the 1993 election, we had a change in the speakership. I suppose we were hopeful and optimistic that a change in the speakership would see a lifting of standards in the parliament. I note that back on 4 May 1993 a newspaper article states that the new Speaker:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . proposed several changes to improve parliamentary procedures:

PARA.TAB: It was time the Government responded to a report by a procedures committee that had suggested limits be set on the length of ministerial answers.

SPEECH.PARA: An interesting reflection, given that ministerial answers have considerably lengthened in the last couple of years. The Canberra Times, in an editorial on the same day, 4 May 1993, had this to say:

The last Parliament was largely a farce because of the mismanagement of the then Speaker, Leo McLeay. Mr Keating's bonds with Mr McLeay meant that no amount of inept or partisan chairmanship by Mr McLeay could count against him. Mr McLeay will be replaced today by Stephen Martin. Mr Martin has an opportunity to restore the dignity of the chamber. If he is to take it up, it will be primarily by restraining the Government rather than by keeping the Opposition down. The great possibility coming from the Martin appointment is that he is the first Speaker in 17 years to have higher political ambitions. Whether he can achieve them depends on his performance; the more the chairman and the less the cheer leader, the more likely he is to prosper.

PARA.TAB: Not only his own career is in the balance. The Government has little to gain from abuse of the Chamber . . .

SPEECH.PARA: By the time we get to October 1993, this is what the Sydney Morning Herald has to say under the headline `Sidelining the Speaker':
The Federal Parliament is an institution which is run on precedent.
I might add as an aside: I refer to these third party comments because I know that they carry greater weight with a lot of people because they are independent comments. It continues:

Because of this, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr Stephen Martin, should resign from his position—in accordance with the Cope precedent—following the ruthless and humiliating action by the Prime Minister to use the Labor Party's majority in the House of Representatives to vote down new television broadcast rules which had been announced by Mr Martin only 18 hours earlier. The effect of the Prime Minister's action is to destroy the credibility of the Speaker's position. The implication is that the Speaker—who represents all MPs—must tailor his reforms to fit what is deemed to be the interest of the Government.

That was said in October 1993. My concern, and the reason we raised the matter yesterday, is that the reports of the Prime Minister's behaviour coming out of this week's caucus meeting fit exactly within the criteria and the concerns expressed by that editorial. In other words, the impression clearly is obtained that the Prime Minister exerts his influence and authority over you as a member of the caucus to ensure that he gets the results he wants in the parliament. That, of course, brings the parliament into disrepute.

PARA.TAB: I do not say much about the substance of the Prime Minister's concerns. It was quite incredible. It was a case of the wolf blaming the sheep for him to be attacking the Speaker. That says a lot about the arrogance of the Prime Minister. It just shows you how he has not learnt anything out of the Canberra by-election result on Saturday.

But, leaving that aside, our concern is with the proper functioning of the parliament and the maintaining of some order in and respect for the high office of Speaker. Not for our own party political interests but for the sake of a well-functioning democracy, it is important that the office of Speaker be accorded the respect which it is due.

I refer to your attendance at the caucus meeting earlier this week. The fact of the matter is that, when Sir Billy Snedden was the Speaker, he did not attend Liberal Party parliamentary meetings or caucus meetings. The reason he did not was that he was keen to ensure, as much as possible within our party political system, that he was seen to operate as an independent Speaker.

The one thing I would agree with the Prime Minister on—the sad truth of the matter—is that no Speaker since Sir Billy Snedden has matched the standards which he set for independence as the Speaker. That was the Prime Minister's remark. I would not suggest, however, that you take any notice of his injunction to you that people ought to be thrown out of the parliament more regularly. In fact, it was because he had a lot of authority and was held in respect by most members of the parliament that the then Speaker, Sir Billy Snedden, did not have to throw people out.

The figures in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning show that Billy Snedden, who was Speaker for seven years, threw out nine people, an average of nearly one a year. Harry Jenkins was Speaker for around three years and he averaged three a year. Joan Child was Speaker for 18 months and she averaged nearly one a month. Leo McLeay was Speaker for three and a bit years and he averaged one every three months. The current Speaker has averaged seven ejections in less than two years.

It is a sad reflection on the parliament and on the way the Labor Party treats the parliament that the standards have degenerated. A sort of philosophical underpinning of that is that the Labor Party has long taken the view that, if you get the numbers, basically it is a winner takes all proposition, that you can use your numbers and the end justifies the means.

You have never accepted one of the great principles upon which our democracy is founded; that is, the principle of the balance of power and a system of checks and balances. It is our view on this side of the parliament that the institution of the parliament and the way the parliament is run are a check and a balance against the abuse of executive power. Even though we may not have the numbers, we do have the conventions, the practices and the great traditions of this parliament to operate as a check against the abuses of people like the Prime Minister.

It is a sad day when we read in the papers how you have been bounced around the caucus by a Prime Minister so that he can dictate to you the way in which you operate as the Speaker. This goes right down to the swearing in of Brendan Smyth. I was told this morning about it and I presume it is the case—someone one can deny it if it is not. Brendan Smyth on Saturday won a great by-election. The precedent is that, if the writs are declared when the House is sitting, you get sworn in at 3 o'clock in the full glare of the publicity so that the Prime Minister can get up and congratulate you.

But, no, unlike Martyn Evans, for example, who came in at a by-election and who got sworn in at 3 o'clock with all the hoopla that went with it, the Liberal candidate is going to be sworn in at an earlier hour, at 12.30—very neatly divorcing his presence from that of the Prime Minister and the embarrassment that that would entail. I am told that is the precedent and that is what is happening.

I can only assume that from on high the Prime Minister has given somebody marching orders as to how he would like the parliament organised today to suit his political convenience. I do not draw on this as an example, but I would have to say that someone was very quick on his feet this week. I wondered at the time what was up—

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Acting Speaker. The shadow minister is speaking by indulgence that you have provided him in relation to the matters that you have spoken about this morning. He is now digressing from that issue to talk about other matters. I think he has now had the floor for in excess of 10 minutes by indulgence, and I would put it to you that, firstly, he should restrict himself to those issues that you have addressed yourself to and, secondly, he should be asked to resume his seat.

—Order! I make the remark that it is correct that I have given the indulgence. I make the observation that my indulgence is starting to be limited by my capacity to absorb the generous advice that the honourable member for Flinders is giving me. I hope that he has come to his last point and that he will conclude, because I think I have given him a fair go. He is starting now to transgress across even further territory than his submission to me yesterday. I just hope that he will now quickly come to a conclusion.
—Thank you, Mr Acting Speaker. I have to say that you have given me a fair go, and I do not mind telling you I am nearing the end of my remarks.
—I hope it is a quick conclusion.

—I conclude—as I was intending to anyway—with a reference back to the newspaper reports which brought this matter on in the first place. One in particular caught my eye. I did not read it out yesterday but the report in the Daily Telegraph Mirror, after further recounting the threats of the Prime Minister, said, `Caucus sources said the Prime Minister had been mesmerising and at his best.'
—This is sycophantic.
—It is sycophantic; it is sickening.
—I hope you are coming to that end quickly.

—I am coming to the end. The point I make to you, Mr Acting Speaker, is that we all know the Prime Minister is an aggressive personality but, ultimately, each and every one of us has certain responsibilities to our electorate and to the institution of the parliament, and we would like to see you exercise your full responsibilities. We are very concerned that this parliament's reputation in the Australian community has fallen to a new low. The incidents of the Prime Minister only give rise to concern in the public that rather than your high office being conducted in accordance with the great traditions of this place it is back subject to influence. There is that great quote of the Prime Minister about how he found Laurie Brereton on the street and he could put him back any time he wanted to.
—The honourable member for Flinders has stretched my indulgence.

—That is the fact of it. I conclude my remarks, Mr Acting Speaker. The fact of the matter is that we will come back to the issue. We have not been happy with the conduct of the parliament, and in particular question time, and we intend to continue to make this an issue until Mr Arrogance gives us and sets a higher standard.
—The honourable member should not use those terms.
—Mr Acting Speaker, with indulgence?
—No; I am sorry. If it is to take up these matters again, given the amount of time I have given by indulgence—

—Mr Acting Speaker, I wanted to put the case to you that the arguments that the honourable member for Flinders was about to put to the House were overruled; in fact he did not have the opportunity to put those arguments.
—The honourable member will resume his seat.

—Mr Acting Speaker, I have a question to you. It is on the same topic. I wish you to give me an assurance that you will take note of previous rulings, particularly of Speaker Child in regard to Mr Tuckey and me in regard to comments we made outside this place on the conduct of the Speaker, when you come to consider this matter again. The case is exactly parallel and, if we are going to have a standard set, I suggest to you that you have to consider this matter in its broadest context, or otherwise we will slag you and the Speaker in the same way as the Prime Minister does.
—Order!
—Why don't you set the standards?

—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell should take it quietly. The reference in my comments in reply in the case of the honourable member for Flinders yesterday was to changes in the Parliamentary Privileges Act. It is my understanding that that covers his concerns.
—So we can behave like the Prime Minister does.
—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell!
—It is open slather.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mitchell!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)notes that—
(a)the Taxation Administration Act 1953 makes it an offence punishable by 2 years imprisonment or a fine of up to $10,000 or both, for the unauthorised disclosure of a person's tax file number;

(b)Senator Baume during the adjournment debate in the other place on 23 March 1995 tabled documents concerning the taxation affairs of Dr Peter Macdonald, which documents also contained his tax file number;
(c)Senator Baume's only purpose in tabling these documents was to impugn the integrity of Dr Macdonald before the New South Wales State election in which Dr Macdonald was an independent candidate;

(d)Senator Baume, in seeking the leave of the duty Minister and the Senate to table the documents in question, did not draw attention to the tax file number identified therein, publication of which otherwise than under cover of parliamentary privilege would be a criminal offence; and

(e)the New South Wales Premier, Mr Fahey, has publicly stated that he had been aware of Dr Macdonald's taxation problem, understood the circumstances of it and had undertaken to Dr Macdonald not to raise the issue publicly;
(2)condemns Senator Baume for his—
(a)commission of an act, the disclosure of Dr Macdonald's tax file number, which would have been a crime if done outside the Parliament; and
(b)blatant indefensible disregard, for reasons of political advantage rather than any larger public interest, of the privacy of an individual; and
(3)calls upon Senator Baume to apologise for his behaviour to (a) Dr Macdonald and (b) the Parliament.

Clearly, from the terms of that motion, it is a very serious matter indeed. I think we all realise that parliament is a robust place and we expect to give and take a fair bit. I think, by any measure, the actions of Senator Baume last week in the Senate went beyond the reasonable bounds of behaviour; indulging in what, by any other person, would be a criminal action and, in fact, which may be criminal action by Senator Baume himself.

PARA.TAB: Last Thursday, in the adjournment debate, Senator Baume got up at 7.40 p.m.—right at the end of the parliamentary sitting day—and, in his terms, `dropped a bucket' on the Independent member for Manly in the New South Wales state parliament, Dr Peter Macdonald, just two days before the state election in which Dr Macdonald was a candidate.

The nature of the bucket was that there was a letter from the Australian Taxation Office to Dr Macdonald regarding his tax affairs which followed a tax audit. It was a private letter from the tax office to Dr Macdonald, advising him of substantial adjustments to his tax assessment for the years 1984 to 1988 which considerably increased his taxable income for all of those years, thereby requiring him to pay substantial additional tax. The letter from the tax office also contained his tax file number, divulgement of which is a criminal offence. Altogether, this was a particularly nasty, disgraceful and appalling piece of conduct.

Why did Senator Baume do it? According to his remarks in the Senate, he did it because he expected that Dr Macdonald's supporters were about to `drop a bucket' on the Liberal candidate for the seat of Manly in the election that followed two days later. He was simply retaliating in advance, as it were. In expectation that this was going to happen, he was making sure that he got in and had a bucket dropped on Dr Macdonald. Of course, no such bucket was dropped on the Liberal candidate. So the action that he was seeking to counteract in his explanation is an action which never occurred.

He acknowledged on ABC radio the next day that he understood the local paper, the Manly Daily, would be the source of this bucket job and that when he made his attack on Dr Macdonald in the Senate he was not aware that the Manly Daily was not going to proceed with its intention. So we have him assuming an intention on the part of the Manly Daily to do some heinous act in relation to the Liberal candidate and then saying that he was not aware that the paper was not going to proceed with this intention that he somehow assumed was going to be there. It all sounds very implausible.

Whether there was ever any such intention by the Manly Daily or whether it was just a trumped up cover for a cowardly attack on Dr Macdonald's integrity, the fact remains it was a heinous action for Senator Baume to undertake. Even if he had good reason for his expected belief about what may be about to occur—and he gave no evidence for that whatever—to put it at its very simplest: two wrongs do not make a right. In any case, the wrong he was seeking to counteract never occurred.

The nature of the wrong on Senator Baume's part is absolutely very substantial indeed. Let there be no doubt about the wrong perpetrated by Senator Baume: his actions engaged in by anyone outside this place would amount to criminal behaviour and may even amount to criminal behaviour by him.
I want to refer to two tax minutes from the Australian Taxation Office that I have received on this matter, and I am quite happy to table them if the opposition would like to see them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I have a copy now?
—You can. I seek leave to table them.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first of these is dated 24 March, is addressed to me and is headed `Use of TFN information by Senator Baume'. I will not refer to every part of it but I will refer to all the key parts. It says:

PARA.TAB: The taxation law creates certain criminal offences for the collection, use and disclosure of TFNs. These offences are capable of applying to any person. There are also provisions which prevent the use and disclosure of taxation information.

Section 8WB of the Taxation Administration Act 1953 makes it an offence for a person to divulge or communicate another person's tax file number unless there is authority to do so under a taxation or other Commonwealth law. The penalties for a breach of this provision are a fine of $10,000 or 2 years imprisonment or both.

The TFN guidelines issued under the Privacy Act 1988 provide a similar obligation not to communicate or divulge TFNs. A breach of the TFN Guidelines is a breach of the Privacy Act which can be investigated by the Privacy Commissioner.

Section 8XB of the Taxation Administration Act creates an offence for any person to communicate information about another person's taxation affairs in certain circumstances. Section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 creates a similar secrecy obligation to prevent taxation officers from communicating information about the taxation affairs of taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: It goes on:

The tabling of the information, which I understand included a TFN, by Senator Baume is prima facie an offence under section 8WB and possibly of section 8XB. However, I understand that parliamentary privilege would be relevant here and would prevent prosecution against the Senator.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, it is possible that offences may have been committed under sections 8XB or 8WB by the person or persons who divulged the information to the Senator.

I have commenced an internal ATO investigation to examine whether there has been a breach by ATO officers of the secrecy provisions in the taxation legislation referred to above. There is nothing at this stage to suggest an offence has been committed by a taxation officer.
I am considering whether the matter will be referred to the Privacy Commissioner, Australian Federal Police or the Director of Public Prosecutions for further investigations.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously this was a matter that the Acting Commissioner, whom this minute is from, of the Australian Taxation Office took extremely seriously indeed, pointing out that major offences of the tax act would be involved if this action was taken outside parliamentary privilege.

PARA.TAB: Four days later, on 28 March, I received another minute from the Australian Taxation Office, this time addressed to the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), but copied to me, which is quite normal practice. It is headed `Use of tax file number information by Senator Baume'. Again, I will refer to the key points. It says:

In particular, Section 8WB of the Taxation Administration Act 1953 makes it an offence for a person to maintain, divulge or communicate another person's TFN unless there is authority to do so under a taxation or other Commonwealth law. The penalties for a breach of this provision are a fine of $10,000 or 2 years imprisonment or both.

Following the tabling of the information by Senator Baume, the ATO immediately instituted an internal investigation into the matter. As a result of that investigation, I am satisfied that there is nothing to indicate that an officer of the ATO or any other Commonwealth Government Agency has breached section 8WB or any other secrecy provisions in relation to this matter.
There has, however, clearly been a breach of section 8WB and that breach has a number of dimensions:
a)the divulging of the information, which included a TFN to Senator Baume;
b)the maintenance (i.e., holding) of that information by the Senator; and
c)the disclosure of that information by the Senator.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, I understand that a number of journalists may have obtained the TFN before the Tabling Office disguised it in the document tabled. They may also be in breach of section 8WB by holding that information, whether they divulge it to any other person or not.

PARA.TAB: In the circumstances, I have decided to refer these matters to the Australian Federal Police (AFP) for further examination. Under established procedures a draft letter will be forwarded to the Treasurer for referral to the AFP through the Minister for Justice.

SPEECH.PARA: This is clearly a matter which in this second minute becomes even more serious. There is more emphasis on the fact that, simply by holding the information—obtained from whatever source—about that person's tax file number, an offence has possibly been committed. That is a very important additional development and one which Senator Baume would do well to take considerable note of.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume's action is obviously exceedingly serious. It undoubtedly amounts to disgraceful behaviour and, indeed, criminal behaviour, for which Senator Baume relies on parliamentary privilege for protection. His action amounts to criminal behaviour for which any other person could be up for two years in gaol, a $10,000 fine or both. In fact, the issue really is whether parliamentary privilege extends to cover Senator Baume for holding and maintaining this number.

Senator Baume's attitude to this has been to not apologise for the release of Dr Macdonald's tax information. He gave the excuse that it was only an intended retaliation for something that may have occurred but, in fact, never did. Senator Baume has expressed ignorance that the documents contained a tax file number. He said the documents referred to a file number and had `our reference' rather than `tax file number' or `TFN' on them. He said that, when he realised the documents contained a tax file number, he acted to have it removed from the documents—that is, after the documents had been tabled in the Senate and at least three journalists had obtained copies of them.

Clearly, Senator Baume should not have tabled the documents with the tax file number on them. In his desperation to drop a bucket on Dr Macdonald, Senator Baume was not concerned about the impact on Dr Macdonald's privacy. He should have realised that a file number from the tax office could well be a tax file number, and he should have removed it from the documents before tabling them. But he did not do so. It should also be noted in this connection that, just by receiving and holding the documents with the tax file number on them, Senator Baume would appear to have breached the Taxation Administration Act. Holding information is an offence and revealing it is another offence.

It is also interesting to consider who supplied this information. Senator Baume has not said how he obtained these documents, but whoever gave them to him was clearly acting illegally by holding Dr Macdonald's tax file number and revealing it to Senator Baume. Whoever gave that information to Senator Baume has committed a criminal offence. There is absolutely no doubt about that.

Apparently, the New South Wales Liberal Party knew of Dr Macdonald's tax assessment revisions a couple of years ago but, according to statements by Premier Fahey in the Sydney Morning Herald on 25 March and by Dr Macdonald on ABC radio, Dr Macdonald was given a clear undertaking that this tax issue would not be raised publicly. Of course, it all happened at the very last minute in this election campaign through Senator Baume's disgraceful actions. Under whose auspices was Senator Baume acting? Why did he do it? He obviously did it for political advantage. Was he acting entirely on his own behalf or was he acting with information of other people?

It is particularly important for this House to know, through this debate, what information the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) had about this matter. Everybody knows that Senator Baume is a close friend of the Leader of the Opposition. It is very important for us to know what the Leader of the Opposition actually knew about what Senator Baume was doing. Did he agree that Senator Baume should be able to undertake this criminal action? Or was it something he had never heard of?

Even if he had not heard of it beforehand—that is doubtful—why has he not said anything since? It has been one week since this happened and, as far as I am aware, there has not been one statement from the Leader of the Opposition condemning Senator Baume's actions. That is the most extraordinary thing. You would think that honest John would be very concerned about the fact that one of his parliamentary colleagues had undertaken criminal action in the parliament and had cooperated with people who had undertaken criminal action by giving him that information. You would think that honest John would be very concerned about that and would make a statement distancing himself, and the opposition generally, from such action. But has there been any such statement? No, there has not. There has not been any dissociation at all.

Here is the chance today, one week after the event, for the Leader of the Opposition to so dissociate himself from and to condemn Senator Baume. You would wonder why he would have to wait for this substantive motion to come before the parliament to do it but I invite him to come into this House and make that statement today so that we know, albeit somewhat late in the piece, that he is prepared to say that this is an action for which his parliamentary colleague should be condemned. He should join us in supporting this motion because he knows, as everyone opposite knows, that this action is so utterly reprehensible and indefensible that, in conscience, they should join us on this side in supporting this motion and should not seek to divide the House on it.

We have seen the most appalling and amazing developments in recent times. There were the actions of the member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), who is sitting up the back, in relation to the Aboriginal affairs document relating to the Hindmarsh Island bridge case. That was amazing: interference with other people's mail; photocopying eight kilos of documents clearly not his. We all know that the Leader of the Opposition keeps going around, saying that the member for Barker acted honourably. Acted honourably—photostatting eight kilos of somebody else's mail and then disseminating it all over the place! That was a disgraceful and clearly reprehensible action, and he is now rightly on the back bench.

Here we have another case of somebody else's mail being interfered with. This opposition seems to be breaking into people's mail all the time. How did they get hold of this letter, which was Dr Macdonald's personal mail? Is it going around breaking into people's mail all the time and then divulging it publicly? Leaving aside the divulging of the tax file number, the breaking in was a disgraceful enough action in itself because it goes to the privacy of the individual.

When the tax file number issue came before this parliament in 1988 there was an enormous debate about privacy. The opposition made a lot of noise about the need to ensure that tax file numbers would not interfere with individual privacy. It made a lot of noise about how it had demanded changes to the original proposal so that the privacy of the individual would be protected. Yet here is an opposition senator clearly quite prepared to disregard totally the issue of privacy, not only in relation to a taxpayer's tax commitment as decided by the tax office—which is disgraceful enough—but also in relation to the tax file number itself, which he revealed. Coming from an opposition that has expressed an extraordinary amount of concern about privacy, that was a disgraceful action indeed.

I hope the Leader of the Opposition will take advantage of this debate to come in and condemn Senator Baume for his action. If he does not, we can only assume that he agrees that Senator Baume is acting in an okay way and that he is not at all concerned about the criminal action of his colleague. That would be an extraordinary development and one which would condemn the Leader of the Opposition as a person, who, for all time, will be a joke when the reference is made to `honest John'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition rejects this motion. This is just a trumped up charge, and you know it. The fact is that the speech of the Treasurer (Mr Willis) showed it, because he had 20 minutes given to him and he spent seven on the substance of the matter and spent the rest trying to score a political point. That is how he treated it. You would have run this issue yesterday, Ralph, but you were so uncertain about the merits of it that you had to wait until you were told by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to get down into the House and get stuck into Senator Baume.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume is a widely respected and liked senator, with a good reputation. Let us face the facts. You are into Senator Baume for one reason, and that is that he has been on to the Prime Minister and his pigs for years and he has been absolutely under the Prime Minister's skin. That is the fact of it; that is the motive of it. It is just a piggery cover-up. Your only other motive is that you are so worried about John Howard's successful return to the leadership that you thought you would have a shot at him as well, just for good measure.

It was such a transparent, lacklustre effort by the Treasurer that it barely calls for a response. What a humiliating performance we saw from the Treasurer. This is just a payback for the fact that Senator Baume has been asking a very simple question: how come a bloke who has been on an MP's salary since he was 26 has been able to accumulate assets more relevant to and more likely to be accumulated by the get-rich-quick merchants of the 1980s? Explain how the Prime Minister can have millions of dollars worth of property in Sydney when he has spent most of his time in politics on a backbencher's salary. That is Senator Baume's crime. That is basically the charge behind this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The matter for debate is clearly defined on the front page of the Notice Paper. At this stage we have not heard the matter addressed at all. Eight minutes have gone. Would you ask the speaker to return to the debate.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Newell)—There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only three minutes have gone. We on this side did not come down in the last shower. We know when you guys are after one of ours and when you have a trumped up charge. I do start with that matter because people have to know the truth of the matter. The fact is that there is nothing in it. I am going to demonstrate, in an absolutely resounding way, why it is that this motion ought to be thrown out. It will not be, but the truth of the matter is that it ought to be. One pointer to the fact that this motion ought to be thrown out is that it could not get through the Senate. The proper place for this motion is the Senate. I see we have the two Independents in the House. Let me speak to them for a moment.
—How privileged we are.

—In respect of the member for Wills, it would be a privilege for me to spend my time speaking to him. I have more time for the member for North Sydney (Mr Mack), mainly because he is retiring. This motion simply could not get through the Senate because the Senate, after a fair-minded appraisal of the issues by the Independent senators, came to a different conclusion. I honestly thought the government would have amended this motion before bringing it into the House today.

PARA.TAB: By way of a preliminary point on the facts, which is important, the Treasurer was right to focus on only one issue. He focused on only one issue and that was the question of the tax file number. Nothing that the Treasurer said referred to the question of other documentation. Tax documents were tabled, not tax returns.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is totally untrue.
—No, the whole thrust of what you have to say is that it is an offence to disclose the tax file number. That is the basis of your argument.
—And to hold it.
—And to hold it, fair enough. I just make that point. This is not an argument based on a last-minute bucket job done by Senator Baume. It is not on the basis—
—Of course, it is.
—I have read the Treasurer's paper, and I listened to his speech. The whole basis of this relies upon a tax file number, which is an important factual point to get on the record at the start.

PARA.TAB: There are three reasons why this motion ought to be thrown out. Firstly, it is an abuse of process—and I will quote House of Representatives Practice in a moment to substantiate that point. Secondly, on its merits, I believe this motion is unworthy. Thirdly, the motives behind this motion are so transparent that I encourage the two Independent members to give it very careful consideration. To make a very strong point, I refer the member for North Sydney and the member for Wills to page 347 of House of Representatives Practice where it states:

SPEECH.PARA: A motion of censure of a private Member has been moved on only one occasion. The motion was agreed to. A motion has been agreed to censuring the Leader of the National Party, then in opposition, for conduct unworthy of a Member. On a further occasion a motion was put to the House condemning the Leader of the National Party for reflecting on the Speaker, but the motion was withdrawn, by leave, after the Leader had apologised for and withdrawn his remarks. On a number of occasions a motion of censure of the Leader of the Opposition, or an amendment expressing censure in the form of an alternative proposition, has been agreed to.
This is the particularly relevant point, gentlemen, and I encourage you to note it. The House of Representatives Practice states:

These are considered to be bad precedents. Such resolutions, as distinct from a resolution of the House suspending or expelling a Member, are of no substantive effect and are only regarded as an expression of opinion by the House. A motion in the form of a censure of a Member, such as the Leader of the Opposition, not being a member of the Executive Government, is not consistent with the parliamentary convention that the purpose of a vote of censure is to question or bring to account a Minister's responsibility to the House. Furthermore, given the relative strength of the parties in the House, and the strength of party loyalties, in ordinary circumstances it could be expected that a motion or amendment expressing censure . . . would be agreed to, perhaps regardless of the circumstances or the merits . . .

This whole process is to bring the executive to account. According to the House of Representatives Practice, this motion, if passed, would be bad precedent. There is only one precedent, and that is because the House in the past has not been prepared to use this process in the way proposed by the government. Regardless of the balance of the matter, I put it particularly to the Independent members that, whatever you think of the merits, a new process should not be hereby developed. The rules and conventions on this matter are absolutely clear.

PARA.TAB: The only other precedent which is worth referring to is the one in respect of a senator being the subject of such a motion from the House. On a trip to Singapore, Senator Sim made some remarks which were apparently racist in their tone. On that occasion, the House repudiated the sentiments of what the senator had to say. That is the only precedent that might be relied upon for this motion. As I say, that should be differentiated on the basis that it related to the sentiments which might otherwise be attributed to his remarks. In respect of process, if this motion is passed, this would simply be an abuse of process—and that is very clear authority.
Mr Cleary interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —They may mean nothing to you.

PARA.TAB: Mr Cleary interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Sure, the answer to that question is that the precedents give you a guide to the practice and conventions of the parliament. I do not put it any stronger to you. If you want to change the nature of the process which has been used to bring the executive to account, you are obviously going to do so. But, whatever you say, it is a substantial point.

PARA.TAB: The second matter goes to the merits of the issue. The motion, firstly, condemns Senator Baume. In fact, when the senators considered this matter with a more independent flavour to the debate, they changed that. They deplored his actions; that is true. But they referred to his negligence in tabling a document, whereas this motion refers to the condemnation of Senator Baume for his commission of an act. In fact, the Treasurer went further and said that it amounted to a criminal offence but for the parliamentary privilege. That is a gross exaggeration. In this country you are innocent until proven guilty.

The fact is, as I want to show in a moment, that the release of the tax file number detail was entirely inadvertent and therefore the suggestion which is behind this whole motion—the allegation that this was a deliberate act, a deliberate revelation, in breach of a Commonwealth act, of a tax file number—is totally false.

Furthermore, the resolution of the Senate and the motion in this House call on Senator Baume to apologise for his behaviour. He admits that the TFN was revealed and he has apologised for it. The precedent in this House in such circumstances where such a motion is before the House and the member then proceeds to apologise is that the motion is withdrawn. On that basis the motion ought to be withdrawn. It is quite clear. His letter of apology has been tabled and on that basis, in respect of the restricted matter of the TFN, this motion ought to be withdrawn.

The other thing which on its merits ought to be noted is that what happened in the Senate—the Treasurer failed conspicuously to mention this—is that Senator Baume spoke in the chamber and then sought leave of the minister at the table, the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), for the tabling of the document. She did not just peremptorily review the document; she studied it. Then she, on behalf of the government as the duty minister, gave the consent—the leave—for the tabling of the document. What Senator Evans said was—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what you would have done.
—I will tell you what Senator Evans said. He has completely removed the argument for this motion. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It certainly was not immediately apparent,—
he is talking about the tax file number—
with the kind of scrutiny that documents sought to be tabled are usually given by duty ministers, that the `file number' referred to in one of the documents was the individual's tax file number.
The point he is making is that the document did not say `tax file number'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It says, `our file number'.

—It says `our file number'. Thank you. So it did not say `tax file number'. But the minister looked at it in exactly the same way as Senator Baume did—he did not realise it was a tax file number any more than the minister did—and she then gave him consent. If Senator Baume has committed a heinous offence, quite frankly the motion ought to be amended and condemnation of Senator Crowley ought to be added into it. It is as clear as that.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that Senator Baume made a mistake—and he has apologised for it—and that that number should not have been disclosed. But he did not at the time realise that it was a tax file number. As soon as he was aware of it, he took immediate steps, without any prompting, to ensure that that document did not go any further. It really is as simple as that. This was an unfortunate but inadvertent disclosure of a number. It was not obvious on the face of the document that it was a tax file number. It was tabled with the consent of the government. The senator has done a reasonable thing in terms of attempting to curtail or limit its distribution. He has apologised to Dr Macdonald for this issue of the tax file number, and that basically ought to be the end of it.

The reason it is not the end of it is: firstly, you people want to abuse the processes of parliament; and, secondly, you are not prepared to accept that the proper place for this is the Senate where there has already been a resolution. Like the thugs you are, you are going to use your numbers down here to put through a motion which you could not get through in the Senate under independent and reasonable scrutiny. That is the fact of the matter. On that basis, this motion ought to be chucked out. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear The Hon G.

TALK.START.PARA: —How embarrassed you must feel! The first 15 minutes of your contribution in this House you lectured us about propriety, about how we should uphold the standards of this place, and the second 15 minutes you were trying to defend what is the indefensible. You know in your heart that what Senator Baume did in the Senate last Thursday night was rotten, it was grubby, it was underhanded and, for all intents and purposes, it is probably criminal as well. The holding of a tax file number, as the Treasurer (Mr Willis) has pointed out, clearly, on our advice, breaches the tax laws. An investigation will be held into that and we will see where the senator stands. I want to say a few things about the tax file number, the integrity of it, and the part it plays in the tax system.
—You can't think of anything to substantiate the motion.

—I can say a lot more than you ever said. What an embarrassing old performance you gave, racing through the Hansard and the House of Representatives Practice—anything but talk about what Senator Baume did. I do not blame you for that. I would hate to have to stand up as you had to and defend this—because it is indefensible, and you know it.The tax file number is the most confidential piece of information in a person's financial affairs. It is the number that identifies—

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Throughout this speech and throughout the previous speech the member for Gilmore has carried on a tirade of objections. They have been most unparliamentary. He has been using language that should never be allowed. He has been accusing people of being criminals, and it should not be allowed. I ask you to warn the member for Gilmore and tell him that he is not entitled to carry on the way he is at the moment.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Newell)—This matter is obviously creating some emotion on both sides of the House. I would ask members on both sides to restrain themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying, the tax file number is the most important and most confidential number you should have in your financial affairs. It underpins the integrity of the tax system. To divulge a tax file number, as the Treasurer has rightly pointed out, carries substantial penalties—a $10,000 fine and two years gaol. That is for the holding and disclosing of a tax file number. As I said, that will be investigated. Senator Baume, when the Australian Federal Police do come around, should answer their questions truthfully, and we will see how he comes out of it.

PARA.TAB: I have had experience with these things and I would like to relate that experience and the double standards held by the opposition when it comes to the disclosure of what it sees as privileged information. A number of years ago I sought some information from the then Minister for Health, Dr Blewett. I was inadvertently given what were said to be doctor provider numbers. There was a big hullabaloo about that. When I sought information from Dr Blewett, I never sought those numbers—I never got them—and I never disclosed any information from those documents.

But when Dr Blewett came into the parliament and said he had given me information from the Department of Health, there was a censure motion moved. It was moved by the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard. I went back through Hansard to see what standards he had then in his former role as the Leader of the Opposition. He said this:

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot think of a greater abuse of privacy, a greater abuse of privilege or a greater abuse of confidentiality than that which this Minister—
that is Dr Blewett—
has engaged in on this occasion.

In actual fact Dr Blewett never knew anything about it, because I went to a member of his staff. The point is that, even though none of this information was ever released publicly and the only thing the then Leader of the Opposition knew was that I had received some coded information from the Department of Health for which I had asked one of his staff, that was enough for the Leader of the Opposition to move a censure motion against the minister and me. A subsequent investigation into that matter cleared everybody of any allegations.

PARA.TAB: They were the standards set back then by the Leader of the Opposition. I want to look at the standards set since John Howard has become Leader of the Opposition. What we are looking at now is a totally different set of standards from that enunciated by the then Leader of the Opposition when he talked about my involvement with that information back in those days. Since Mr Howard has been the Leader of the Opposition, we have seen push polling in the Canberra by-election—one of the grubbiest, dirtiest election tactics you would ever see. Since he has been the Leader of the Opposition, we have had stolen documents being used by the member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) in this House. Worse than that, confidential information was distributed to all of the media in Adelaide and to defence attorneys who were challenging the Commonwealth. Now, while he is the Leader of the Opposition, we have this trafficking in tax file numbers in the Senate—all for grubby political purposes.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), said that all we were interested in was the tax file number. We are interested in more than that. We are interested in the whole ethos of the way in which this opposition is conducting itself. Those three instances that I outlined have all happened since John Howard became the Leader of the Opposition. At the next election, if John Howard is still the Leader of the Opposition, we will be in for the grubbiest, sleaziest election campaign in this country's history. You can see the way in which it is headed. Ever since he became Leader of the Opposition, we have had from the Liberal Party these underhand, dirty tricks all aimed at its opponents—but none of which, I venture to say, have been as sleazy as that which took place a week ago.

As the Treasurer rightly pointed out, what has Mr Howard said about this latest episode, about his friend releasing somebody's private tax details and tax file number? Not a word. The double standards are appalling. I turn back to Dr Blewett. Anybody who knew Dr Blewett would know what a principled man he was. What did Mr Howard say about Dr Blewett and the information given to me? In the conclusion of his censure motion against Dr Blewett, Mr Howard said:

SPEECH.PARA: He should resign and go forever from the front bench of this Government.

That is what Mr Howard said about Neal Blewett in 1988 when he was taking the high ground. What has Mr Howard said to Senator Baume? Nothing. I do not know why they call him honest John. I really do not know. It is dishonest John, because he has said nothing to rebuke Senator Baume for what he did. Thank goodness there is a streak of decency and a bit of justice in the world, because I see in today's paper that Peter Macdonald has been re-elected to the seat of Manly. So all of that was for nothing. Senator Baume sought some political advantage out of it, but he did not get it.

PARA.TAB: I would like to relay a story about the impact that this episode has had on the public. I received a call from a person in Manly who saw my name on the front page of the Manly Daily and the comments from my office in relation to this matter and the way in which the tax file number had been used. Last Sunday night, Senator Baume and the member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) sat together on a flight from Sydney to Canberra. This gentleman was sitting behind them. With Senator Baume's having performed this act, having dropped this tax file number and all of the information, you would think they might feel a bit embarrassed. You might think that was a bit below the belt and that the best thing to do would be to shut up. Did they shut up? Not on your life. They were bragging about it on the flight from Sydney to Canberra. They were laughing and saying what a great job they had done to put it up Macdonald and the Labor Party.

This bloke was sick to his stomach. He said that he felt like pouring a glass of beer over them. He reported the incident to my office. So people do get offended about these things. They do get offended when politicians traffic in personal information about people. They do get offended when the law is broken. They do get offended when politicians brag about it on aeroplanes. You would think that Senator Baume would have the decency, having performed this act, to just say, `I have done the act,' and maybe slink off somewhere to hide. But, no, not on your life; here he was bragging about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now he expects an apology to be given.

—You would never get an apology. I know the member for Throsby feels very strongly about this. Why would you ever get an apology about this? These guys are actually bragging about it. They think it is smart. They completely misunderstand the Australian people, because there is more than a streak of decency to Australians out there. They do not like these tactics. To the extent that the Leader of the Opposition by his silence condones these tactics, it paints him as a leader not worth having.

PARA.TAB: I turn to look at another matter. The fact is that while Mr Howard was Leader of the Opposition—and the Treasurer mentioned this—we had a serious debate in the parliament about privacy matters. No-one was more strident in standing up for the rights of privacy of Australians than the then Leader of the Opposition. We all remember the Australia card debate and the high ground taken by members of the opposition. The then Leader of the Opposition was poncing around the place championing individual rights, claiming that the card was going to be used by the government to control the lives of individuals and that it was a tool of Big Brother.

Why is the Leader of the Opposition not out there telling Senator Michael Baume that he should not be dropping tax file numbers? The simple fact is that what he says and what he does are two different things. The Leader of the Opposition will stand up for everything that is good, but when it actually comes to performing, when it actually comes to laying the cards on the table and rebuking one of his close friends, where is he?

When the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer he ran the taxation system of this country into the ground. He is still undermining the tax system but from a different direction. He is now condoning the release of tax file numbers in the Senate. You can say that with certainty, because he is not saying anything against the people who do it. This in his view might be smart politics. It sure beats generating policies. It is a lot easier to get up and assassinate someone's character rather than do the right thing and tell the people of Australia how you would run the country. But the simple fact is that it is no substitute.

As the Treasurer has rightly pointed out, the holding of a tax file number is clearly a breach of the law. This matter has been referred to the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) and the truth will out in the end. But Senator Michael Baume should not think for one minute that he is out of the woods on this one, because activities that he undertook outside of parliament will be investigated.

Let me just draw those themes together. Since John Howard has become the leader of the Liberal Party, the campaigning techniques of the Liberal Party have hit the sewer. There has been the push polling, this grubby tactic here last week, and the use and the distribution of stolen material in this House—all while he has been the Leader of the Opposition. I reiterate that, if he is still Leader of the Opposition at the next election, we will have the dirtiest, sleaziest campaign this country has ever seen. The writing is on the wall. The direction in which he wants to take the Liberal Party is clear.

The Leader of the Opposition is dishonest and he is two-faced about the standards on privacy matters. During debate on matters he will always take the high ground. He will always stand up for the individual and say that nothing is more sacred than a person's privacy—until it comes time to do something about it. What he should do—and he knows he should do—is to rebuke Senator Michael Baume publicly for what he did. Any decent leader would do that. If anything like that happened on our side, the Prime Minister would have us in the office so fast that our noses would bleed.

You cannot trust the current Leader of the Opposition near a tax office. He could not run a decent tax system when he was Treasurer and now he is undermining it by condoning, by his silence, the unauthorised and illegal use of tax file numbers. This clearly shows the standards of the Leader of the Opposition. He is clearly unfit to be the Prime Minister of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Mrs B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We know very well why the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) would not be in here participating in this debate, and we know why the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) can take the moral high ground—because the Leader of the Opposition acts in accordance with moral principles. Mr Keating is not here because Mr Keating himself has been the beneficiary of favourable treatment from the Australian Taxation Office. Let me refresh everyone's memory. A letter signed by Mr D.J. Cortese, Deputy Commissioner of Taxation, who incidentally signed the letter of comfort tabled in the Senate last week, reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Keating,
The purpose of this letter is to draw your attention to the need for you to file your 1986 income tax return which is now outstanding.
As recently discussed your 1985 return is also . . . overdue.
I appreciate how busy you have been but I ask that you now give urgent attention to the filing of your returns, especially that for the 1985 year.
Should you wish, your return can be posted marked for attention: Ms Yvonne Ellis, Liaison Officer, Priority Control Section, GPO Box 3523, SYDNEY NSW 2000.
If you wish to deliver your return, you could contact Ms Ellis on 236 7341 . . . or myself.
Your co-operation and early response would be appreciated.
Yours faithfully,
(D J Cortese)
DEPUTY COMMISSIONER OF TAXATION
The funny thing was, though, that in that same year 10,000 ordinary Australians got prosecuted for the same offence. Double standards? I think we are starting to see them.

PARA.TAB: The next double standard I might bring to your attention is the case of Mr Charles Wright. Mr Charles Wright, a well-known fund-raiser for the Labor Party, was described in the Western Australia Inc. campaign in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The other payments of particular concern were made to Mr Charles Wright, who operated a fundraising and business relations consultancy. He had done work for the ALP since 1976 in assisting with fundraising at the Federal level . . . Subsequently, Mr Wright made payments to Mrs Brush for which he was recompensed from the No. 1 account. In essence, Mr Wright was a conduit for $80 000 that was paid from the No. 1 Account to Mrs Brush. Mr Burke gave a similar explanation.

The reason I raise Mr Wright is that he failed to remit PAYE tax payments to the tax office for three consecutive years. I previously asked the tax office what its record was in being able to detect these things and it told me it was excellent. The funny thing, though, was that it was the same Mr Wright, the Labor Party fund-raiser—the one whose tax records show who the bagmen were for the Labor Party and who delivered from which companies—who got preferential treatment when, to put the facts down as they became apparent, the tax office put in a tax claim for this man's concern of $176,960.55 in unpaid PAYE. Funny thing—more preferential treatment by the tax office for Labor Party people.

PARA.TAB: A funny thing happened here. When the Fitzgerald inquiry was on, the tax office was asked for all the National Party people's returns. Quick as a whip, the Australian Taxation Office sent off those files to the Fitzgerald inquiry. Then we come to Western Australia Inc. It is Labor Party officials and politicians this time. Guess what! The tax office says, `Sorry, we can't send the files, because it has to be protected.' Double standards!

Then we come to the leaks themselves, and the most damning of them all relates to Mr Phillip Smiles who was the Deputy Treasurer of the New South Wales government. Amazingly there were details leaked about his affairs to the newspapers. There was no outrage about privacy; it was simply that the details were leaked about his personal tax affairs. There was no outrage at the time—except that it was, could we say, for grubby political purposes. There was the parliament on a knife edge. Had Mr Smiles been convicted of a criminal offence and forced out of the parliament at that time it would have meant there would have been a change of government; that there would have been a Labor government instead. So there was a very good political reason for leaking the details on Mr Smiles.

When I asked the tax office in estimates committee and Public Accounts Committee hearings about those leaks, what answer did I get? Dr Butterfield, who was in charge of doing the security checks, asked that a report be done, and he came back and said, `We were innocent; we didn't leak it.' I asked, `Where is the report? Could we see the report?' He said, `Oh no, section 16 of the tax act prevents me letting you have a look at the report.' I asked, `What happened to the report, Dr Butterfield? Did you actually read it?' `No,' he said. `Who makes the decision, Dr Butterfield, about whether or not a matter is referred to the DPP?' `Oh, I do, or the commissioner does,' he said. `I see. Did the commissioner read the report?' I asked Dr Butterfield. `Oh no,' said Dr Butterfield.

So we had a report; we didn't read it; we had the details leaked; we had the prosecutions commenced and—guess what?—not under the Taxation Administration Act, oh no, but under the Crimes Act because only then could you have been certain of having the government change hands. So what did we see then? We had a prosecution; we had a barrage of publicity. Nobody said, `What about Mr Smiles's privacy?' Nobody was concerned about the fact that his privacy had been breached. We said that this was a matter of importance for the public record.

How come we have one standard for Mr Smiles and another standard for Dr Macdonald? Let me remind honourable members that the amount of money involved in Mr Smiles's case was $11,000 or $12,000 and the amount of money in Dr Macdonald's case is $104,000. The Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) will be interested in this because Dr Macdonald has a very important medical practice, yet in the year 1988 he said he had an income of only $7,000. You can blame your tax agent, you can blame your accountant, but he actually had to sign off his figures himself. If he actually believed he had a taxable income of $7,000, then he should have been on welfare. In fact, the tax office made him pay another $40,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike Mr Sinclair, who got his father to do it.
—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I find the remark made by the honourable member for Gilmore offensive, and he should withdraw. He should apologise as well.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—I call on the honourable member for Gilmore to withdraw.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw.

—So we go back to the question of double standards. We had a debate earlier this morning and, when ministers stood up to defend the government's position, what did they say? They said that we were having a debate not about the fact that it was hypocrisy and two standards but on moral integrity. Well, we are. The fact of the matter is that we see patently every day that there are two standards exercised in this chamber. There was a request for a serious matter to be referred to the Privileges Committee by the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Reith) in this place. But, oh no. Were any of us surprised when we got the answer we got? Certainly not. We expected it, because that is the way business is conducted here—on double standards.

PARA.TAB: I go back and point out that in several cases in the New South Wales parliament since the election in 1992 we saw again and again the question of taxation being relevant to the electorate of New South Wales. How come it was relevant when it was Terry Metherell or Phillip Smiles? Let me ask this: in the business of so-called grubby political capital or grubby political advantage, who was it that ran television advertisements, during the election we have just completed, featuring Mr Smiles as somebody who had been disgraced? Mr Smiles was in fact acquitted on the criminal charge, the charge that was meant to trigger an advantage to the Labor Party when it was first raised. Then he was hounded by the likes of your confreres until he had to leave the parliament. Let me ask you why, then, it is not reasonable for Dr Macdonald's tax matters to be on the public record, when it was for those of Mr Smiles and Dr Metherell? It is the same issue.

I want to come to the question of the leaking of the so-called tax number. I want to read from the document that was duly tabled in the House. The letter is from dear old Mr Cortese, who is so good at giving letters of comfort to Labor Party people or their friends. At the top of the letter it does not say `tax file number' or `file number'; it says `our reference number'—`our' meaning the tax office. Pardon me, but I thought the importance of the tax file number was that it was allocated to us as individuals. I would expect such a letter to say `your tax file number', not `ours' meaning the tax office's number because that is not what it is. But that is what the letter says—`our number', meaning the tax office's number.

Of course, we can go back a little further in the history of the tax office to something that occurred in 1992 when the tax office itself leaked documents about individual taxpayers—inadvertently, it said, because it pressed the wrong computer button. It sent details of individual taxpayers, including their tax file numbers, to the wrong people. What action was taken? Was anybody prosecuted in the Parramatta branch of the tax office? Oh no; certainly not. What happened? Well, we sent in a little team to do an investigation and we asked the Privacy Commissioner to have a look. Finally, what did we do? We wrote a little letter of apology to the people concerned. Here we go again—more double standards. We have got plenty of them, have we not? We have got Paul Keating who was not prosecuted for failure to put in his return but who got a letter of comfort, whereas 10,000 ordinary Australians got prosecuted.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—It is absolutely true. Check the estimates hearings. We also have the double standards concerning Mr Smiles, Dr Metherell and Dr Macdonald. Somehow, it was supposed to be unfair for the electorate to be aware that Dr Macdonald had underestimated his tax affairs for six years, involving $104,000, and that is supposed to be kept private because it is not relevant in his case. But it was supposed to be relevant in the case of Mr Smiles involving $11,000 to $12,000 which was also repaid—a matter where he had to be prosecuted under the Crimes Act. Upon questioning, the tax office said that there had never been a prosecution under that section previously.

PARA.TAB: Then we have the matter of the other members of the Greiner government who were investigated by the tax office, just coincidentally, and again we finally got a backdown from the commissioner, saying, `Yes, it was correct.' So we have double standards, don't we? We have double standards when there is an error and, dare I say, unacceptable conduct from people on that side of the House. The weight of numbers is used in order to avoid the consequences of that act. Last week we saw the electorate make a decision about what it thinks about Mr Keating and his cohorts. Last week we saw the most unmitigated swing, a huge swing, against the Prime Minister, who said, `It's everybody else's fault but mine.' We saw a swing of up to 20 per cent in a safe Labor seat. The electorate made a judgment on what it thinks about Mr Keating.

I come back to the motion that was moved this morning. It was debated ad nauseam in the Senate. The Senate rejected the proposition of the government, so here we are, having another go. The fact is that you have given the opportunity to have laid bare once again the duplicity of this government, the dishonesty of its leader—the leader who gets rich while the people get poorer, the man who does not put in his tax returns, the man from whom we see double standards at every turn. This put-up job, as was said by the Manager of Opposition Business, to try to get Senator Baume is nothing but an exercise in duplicity and hypocrisy, as we have become quite accustomed to seeing in this place, and ought to be rejected. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mack Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The campaign waged by the Liberal Party against the Independent member for Manly, Dr Peter Macdonald, has been a massively expensive series of vicious distortions and character assassinations.

PARA.TAB: Character assassination of political opponents has a long and dishonourable history, but this effort has set a new low and a terrible precedent. The publishing of the tax affairs and tax file number of an individual for political advantage is something that every member should recoil from if only for self-preservation.

What has happened was not directed in the usual manner against a head-kicker from the opposite side of politics. It has been a vile and unprovoked attack against a decent, hard-working man of principle, a local GP who became interested in public affairs when he realised the large number of people in Manly being infected by sewage outfalls and tried to do something about it.

It culminated in the use this parliament by Senator Baume to vomit even more infectious sewage in a failed attempt to obtain political advantage. Senator Baume with his long record of similar actions has done more than most to bring the Liberal Party, this parliament and every elected member throughout Australia into public contempt.

What Baume did arose out of a long sequence of events beginning with Dr Macdonald's tax returns of a decade ago. A tax review was instituted as a result of an investigation into the tax accounting practices of a Manly accountant used by Macdonald and many other people in the Manly area.

On becoming aware of the investigation Macdonald voluntarily resubmitted his returns through a new tax accountant and fully satisfied the Australian Taxation Office. The tax office required only interest repayments on additional tax to be paid but no penalties were involved and the tax department noted the full cooperation of Macdonald and his new accountant. I have here a copy of a letter from the deputy tax commissioner confirming that, which I am happy to table.

That should have been the end of the matter but in late 1992 the tax office advised Dr Macdonald that former Premier Nick Greiner's office had Macdonald's tax details and his tax file number. Greiner's office had contacted the tax office claiming Macdonald's tax details had been sent there by mistake. Shortly after this, the self-styled head-kicker for the New South Wales Liberal Party, Michael Yabsley, sneered at Macdonald privately in the New South Wales parliament saying, `Why don't you pay your tax?'

In December 1993 the then member for North Shore, Phillip Smiles, who was later convicted of tax offences, rang Macdonald to let him know that he also knew about Macdonald's tax affairs. Many more snide remarks and rumours from local Liberal Party members in Manly correctly convinced Macdonald that an election smear was coming.

Macdonald obtained documentation from the Australian Taxation Office clearly setting out the position, fully exonerating him, and sent copies to Greiner and New South Wales Premier Fahey, assuming he was dealing with honourable men. On 2 December 1994 Fahey telephoned Macdonald and indicated that he had examined the documents and quite properly agreed there was no basis for any allegations or question of wrongdoing. He undertook to advise the Liberal candidate and his advisers to that effect. Again that should have been the end of the matter.

But a few weeks before the New South Wales election a reputable major poll had Macdonald comfortably ahead by about eight per cent in Manly. He would therefore retain the seat in what was going to be a very close New South Wales election.

The federal member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) took over the Liberal campaign in Manly about this time and, concurrently, an unprecedented campaign of vilification commenced. Three direct mail letters were sent to Manly electors savaging Macdonald, one signed by John Fahey and the other two signed by ministers Peter Collins and John Hannaford.

A further letter, organised and paid for by the Liberal Party, was circulated. It was signed by several parents of victims of horrific murders, implying that Dr Macdonald was supporting the perpetrators of such crimes. It is almost unbelievable that the New South Wales Liberal Party, for political advantage, would viciously exploit people in such tragic circumstances.

Then push polling commenced. Then came a further letter of character assassination to the electors. That was signed by Nick Greiner, a man who cannot accept that he was the architect of his own failure and who is consumed by a vicious desire for vengeance. The same letter was distributed in the other electorates represented by Independents—Bligh and South Coast. All this was on top of the usual massive campaign to be expected in a marginal seat.

Finally, at the last possible moment, the Liberal Party used this parliament, through Senator Baume, to smear Dr Macdonald in the full knowledge that he was totally innocent and in the face of a specific undertaking by the then Premier of New South Wales that Dr Macdonald's tax matters would not be raised in the election campaign. It is to the eternal credit of Peter Macdonald and the electors of Manly that this sickening parade of infamy was rejected, but I am afraid that Dr Macdonald would be less than human if what has happened does not colour his relations to the detriment of the Liberal Party, given the likely state of the New South Wales parliament over the next four years.

But, as the television advertisements say, `There's more.' And it gets worse. Not only has this sewage engulfed many members of the Liberal Party—including Greiner, Fahey, Yabsley, Smiles, the Liberal candidate for Manly and the federal member for Warringah—it is also now being reinforced and endorsed by the Liberal Party, both in this chamber and the Senate and by the Leader of the Opposition, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard).

The fact is that the documents illegally obtained from the tax office have been widely disseminated to many members of the Liberal Party, disclosing Peter Macdonald's tax affairs and his tax file number. The Australian tax office has clear proof at this stage that the documents were in Nick Greiner's office. As has been stated, it is a criminal offence punishable by up to two years in prison to use a tax file number and connect it to an individual or to divulge or communicate an individual tax file number to a third person. It also certainly means expulsion from state or federal parliament for any member convicted of or complicit in these breaches of the Taxation Administration Act 1953.

Senator Baume has used—or misused—parliamentary privilege in an effort to stay protected under his wet brick. He has, however, no parliamentary protection for his actions in relation to Dr Macdonald's tax file number and tax affairs prior to the tabling in the Senate; nor have his informants. Senator Baume has no recognised privilege which would entitle him to refuse to disclose his informant's identity where he is otherwise under a legal duty to do so.

The disclosure to Senator Baume of Dr Macdonald's tax file number not only was a criminal offence but, under the Privacy Act 1988, also attracts civil liability for interfering with Dr Macdonald's privacy. Under that act, Senator Baume's informant was a tax file number recipient who is prohibited from disclosure of tax file numbers and is required to safeguard access to the information.

Under section 98 of the Privacy Act, Peter Macdonald will no doubt be proceeding for an injunction in the Federal Court against Senator Baume to compel him not to continue interfering with Dr Macdonald's privacy.
