No doubt he will also commence proceedings for preliminary discovery against Senator Baume in order to disclose Senator Baume's source or sources so that he or they can be sued.

Proceedings for preliminary discovery will enable Dr Macdonald to discover the identity of the proper defendant or defendants in the action. The relevant Federal Court rule will enable Dr Macdonald to obtain an order for compulsory examination not only of Senator Baume but of any other person—such as Greiner, Oldfield, Fahey, the member for Warringah or the member for Bennelong—who might have knowledge of the facts.

This will enable Dr Macdonald to identify the informant and all the others through whom this tax file number has been passed. This could well lead to a number of by-elections, both here and in the state parliament. All that is in the future. The Liberal Party's actions in Manly have not only brought every member of this parliament into contempt but added to the public loss of trust in the institutions of the country. Do not make any mistake. The people of New South Wales did not put the Liberal government out because of their love for Labor or its policies. The Fahey government went because, in the public view, it was the greater of two evils. It went because of the sleaze factor.

The sleaze factor began in 1988, with the advent of the Liberal government, and saw the advent of the clandestine community polling organisation that funded dummy Independents to run out of Terry Metherell's office. It continued with controversies about jobs for the boys, peregrinations in Europe, tax cheating, illegal listening devices, sexual harassment, threatening phone calls, corruption of the public service, and the draining of millions of dollars from legal aid funds for politicians' court defences. This was not the result of any cross-party infighting; it was all the New South Wales Liberals' own work. It cost them a Premier and then it cost them government.

I am aware that the Leader of the Opposition has been privately appalled by what has gone on in the New South Wales Liberal Party since 1988—or so he says—but since he has assumed leadership of the federal Liberal Party there are signs that he, too, is being submerged in a rising tide of sleaze. With his silent support of push polling by the Liberal Party in both Manly and Canberra, his support of the member for Barker (Mr McLachlan)—who knowingly misled the House, falsely accusing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) of the sins he himself had committed—and his support of Senator Baume and the Liberal Party's activities in respect of the Manly election, he is now on the Greiner slide, sowing the seeds of his own destruction.

I can only appeal to the Leader of the Opposition to draw back from such things as the obvious negative strategy he has embarked on to win the next election, namely, personal character assassination of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). That strategy will degrade institutions and thousands of people throughout the country and, ultimately, it will be self-destructive. He must dissociate himself from statements such as those made by the leader of the New South Wales National Party, who, in respect of the Manly election, said:

SPEECH.PARA: In hindsight, I would have run a far more negative campaign . . . The negative advertising we did was good but I'd drive it much harder next time.

To endorse such statements by silence will lower the bar and sink political affairs to new depths, inviting even worse in the future. It is no coincidence that the non-major party vote in the New South Wales Legislative Council was a record 24.7 per cent in this election. It has climbed from 7.8 percent in 1978, the year of the first election of that body.

PARA.TAB: Not only should the Leader of the Opposition support this motion to condemn Senator Baume; he should also demand Senator Baume's resignation and personally apologise to Dr Macdonald and his family. If he does not do so, he demeans not only himself but his party and the millions of party supporters.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! The honourable member mentioned, before I occupied the chair, that he wished to table papers. Does he seek leave to do so?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott Mr A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise not just to defend a political colleague but to support a personal friend. We have to ask ourselves why we are actually doing this—why is the House debating this motion in relation to Senator Michael Baume? It is not because Senator Baume has done wrong but because Senator Baume has done right. It is not because Senator Baume has inadvertently tabled a tax file number; it is because Senator Baume has consistently got under the skin of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The people on my right are making far too much noise in this debate. I call them to order and remind them to follow the statutes of the House.

—The Prime Minister hates Senator Baume because of Senator Baume's consistent revelations about the Prime Minister's own conduct. The Prime Minister has taken every opportunity to victimise Senator Baume.

PARA.TAB: First of all, in an unprecedented way, he took out a defamation action against Senator Baume. That was most unusual. It was an attempt to muzzle Senator Baume's right and proper pursuit of the Prime Minister's financial dealings. We have had a Senate motion condemning Senator Baume. We now have a motion in this House because the Senate motion did not work. Today the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and other speakers threatened Senator Baume with police harassment because of what Senator Baume has done. That is an absolute disgrace and it shows that this government will do anything to victimise and harass people who ask reasonable questions of the Prime Minister.

The important thing for this House to consider is exactly why the government's minions and the Prime Minister's lap-dogs and poodles are here engaged in this half-hearted attack on Senator Michael Baume. The Prime Minister has no interest whatsoever in Dr Macdonald's tax file number. the Prime Minister is trying to punish Senator Baume for the things he has done to him.

Senator Baume's great crime, in the eyes of the Prime Minister, is that he revealed the Prime Minister's multinational pig joint venture. It was Senator Baume who first revealed that the Prime Minister's one-off $500,000 investment—where did he get the money from?—was going to give the Prime Minister an after-tax return of $2.5 million every year. Not even Kerry Packer could make that kind of money. Kerry Packer could not even make that kind of money when he was the Prime Minister's mate, let alone now.

It was Senator Baume who revealed that quarantine service officials were changing the rules or were considering changing the rules regarding the importation of pigs into this country, at the specific direct request of the Prime Minister. It was Senator Baume who revealed—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The debate is clearly defined in today's Notice Paper. He has been speaking for four minutes and has not addressed the debate yet.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was Senator Baume who revealed that, in April 1992, the Prime Minister had conducted private meetings with Danish pork officials who asked the pertinent question whether he was doing it in his official capacity as Prime Minister, was doing it to try to boost his own private income or was doing it as Australia's best known pig farmer.

PARA.TAB: It was Senator Baume who revealed that the Prime Minister's piggery broke every environmental rule in the book. It was Senator Baume who revealed the disgraceful actions of the Prime Minister in breaking the environmental rules that the Independents in this House are so concerned about. It was Senator Baume who revealed that workers at the Prime Minister's half owned piggery had not been paid their award wages. Workers employed by the Prime Minister had not been paid their award wages. When it was found by the New South Wales industrial relations department that this was the case, what did the Prime Minister's half owned piggery do? It sacked the workers. It sacked them for asking about their award entitlements.

Senator Baume has revealed that Labor's leaders do not live up to Labor's principles, and this is why he is being victimised by this House today. The government's motion is a thinly disguised attempt by the Prime Minister to hit back at the one man in this parliament who has consistently questioned the Prime Minister's integrity—and rightly so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get on and defend Baume. That's what you're here for.
—Order! The honourable member for Patterson has spoken too much and he will come to order.

—This motion is the latest manifestation of a Prime Minister who has gone absolutely feral—a Prime Minister who has been said by his own ex-colleague former Senator Richardson to have millions of Australians scratching their heads in wonderment as to whether or not he is still sane as he parades around the world conducting Mozart and redesigning Berlin in a single afternoon.

PARA.TAB: Ever since Kerry Packer went on national television to declare that John Howard was a decent, honest man who would make a good Prime Minister, the Prime Minister has gone slightly mad. But it was not what Kerry Packer said about John Howard that has made the Prime Minister mad. The real thing that has got under the Prime Minister's skin is the fact that Kerry Packer was asked a question about God and he answered it without once mentioning the Prime Minister's name. That is the real problem with the Prime Minister.

I used to think the Prime Minister had a Napoleon complex. I used to think he had a Bismarck complex. The fact of the matter is that the Prime Minister has a messiah complex. But the only messiah he resembles is mad King Ludwig of Bavaria, running around building castles in the air. The Prime Minister blames anyone and everyone for his predicament except himself. In the wake of the Canberra by-election, he has blamed ex-Senator Richardson, New South Wales Labor leader Bob Carr, John Della Bosca, and even the Speaker of this august institution, for his problems. Now, with this motion, he is trying to blame poor old Senator Michael Baume.

I turn now to the substance of this motion. Senator Baume tabled documents in the Senate, and one of those documents had on it `file number'. This document was examined closely for five minutes by Senator Rosemary Crowley, the government's duty minister. She weighed it, considered it, looked at it again and again and allowed it to be tabled. If anyone is to be censured by this House, it must be Senator Rosemary Crowley because she was complicit in this act of tabling the tax file number. She should be added to this censure motion.

As soon as Senator Baume realised his mistake he took immediate steps to rectify it. But before he had a chance to do so, two Labor senators had had access to this tax file number. If this tax file number has got out, if anyone has got hold of Peter Macdonald's tax file number, not only should Senator Rosemary Crowley be added to this motion but so too should the two Labor senators.

While we are talking about the release of confidential information, when Senator Crowley revealed confidential information about a very tragic incident—she has made a few mistakes lately, hasn't she?—what did she do? She did not do what Senator Baume did and immediately apologise; she stood there and tried to tough it out even when her senior minister in this House, the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence), had the decency to come in and apologise. If anyone is to be censured by this House for releasing information it must be Senator Rosemary Crowley, not Senator Michael Baume.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you know the number, Tony? Did you think it was a phone number?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! The honourable member for Gilmore will cease interjecting. He has spoken far too much and will remain silent.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting that when a similar motion was debated in the Senate, some of the Independents and some of the Greens refused to support it. They accepted that what Michael Baume did was entirely inadvertent, and I would invite the Independents in this House to do exactly the same thing. It is interesting, is it not, that Senator Chamarette has this day withdrawn a motion of censure of the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) that she tabled in the Senate, because it is her understanding now that one House should not censure a member of the other. That is a very fair understanding and one that I commend to members of the government and to my two Independent friends.

PARA.TAB: Let me turn finally to the substance of Senator Baume's claims in the Senate. Dr Peter Macdonald has been a consistent advocate of honest government. When Nick Greiner got himself into trouble, Dr Macdonald said he was guilty until proven innocent. When Phillip Smiles got himself into trouble over the Eastern Creek raceway, Dr Macdonald said he was guilty until proven innocent. Indeed, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Whether a man is innocent until he is proven guilty is not appropriate in this instance . . . if an element of doubt exists, the honourable member should be dismissed.

This is not my standard; this is Dr Macdonald's standard. This is the standard under which Dr Macdonald, not Michael Baume, has questions to answer. Senator Baume revealed that, in a five-year period from 1984 to 1988, Dr Macdonald's declared taxable income in no single year exceeded $7,191. Notwithstanding the fact that this man was able to declare an income that would have put him on social security, this wealthy general practitioner owns a $1 million-plus house in King Avenue, Fairlight, and four other properties in one of the most exclusive parts of Sydney.

PARA.TAB: Notwithstanding having declared an income which should have put him on the dole, he was able to afford last Friday to bring a Supreme Court action—and we all know how that much costs. I was told by the member for North Sydney (Mr Mack) today that Dr Macdonald is now bringing a Federal Court action, all on a declared income of less than $7,000 a year. Not even the member for North Sydney could believe that.

The fact of the matter is: everyone is entitled to pay no more tax than that which is obliged by law but people are not entitled to pull the wool over their own eyes. They are not entitled to allow themselves to be deluded about their own financial affairs.

Dr Macdonald is saying that it is all his accountant's fault; that it was his accountant's mistake that he filed these returns. Well, Dr Macdonald had to sign the document; the accountant did not sign the document. Dr Macdonald had to sign the document, and for five years this wealthy medical practitioner signed tax returns claiming that in no single year did he earn more than $7,000. Dr Macdonald's campaign slogan `Clean water, clean streets, clean politics' should have a new line added to it—`no tax', because that is Dr Macdonald's policy.

If Dr Macdonald says that this was an honest mistake, this House should believe him, just as it should believe Senator Michael Baume when he says that he made an honest mistake. Let me say this about Dr Macdonald's tax returns: oh to be so lucky as to have that kind of lifestyle and be able to declare $4,000 a year.

Dr Macdonald has done something which is rather common on the other side of the House. In signing his tax returns but not being prepared to own up to the contents, he has endorsed the cover but not the contents. Dr Macdonald is revealed as the Ros Kelly of Macquarie Street; the man who endorses the cover but not the contents of what he signs. This is the man who could still hold the balance of power in New South Wales—what a worry for the people of my home state! The fact is that he cannot manage $4,000 a year properly and we are being asked to believe that this man is entitled to play a crucial role in managing the $20 billion a year New South Wales budget.

As it happens, Dr Macdonald has quite a lot in common with our Prime Minister. He has acquired a great deal of property while earning a very modest income. When he made a mistake with his tax, he received a very nice, gentle letter saying, `Please fix this up.' He has a great deal in common with the Prime Minister.

The government has moved this motion in an attempt to destroy the career of Senator Michael Baume. Like so many things this government has done, this has backfired terribly, because the only career that has been damaged today is the career of the Manly Independent Dr Peter Macdonald.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak today for the many people over the years who have been smeared by Senator Michael Baume under parliamentary privilege. This is one of the most serious actions to take, to condemn a member of parliament. It is even more serious when this chamber moves to condemn a member in another place. I understand that never before has such an extreme move been taken. Indeed, I had to go back to 23 March 1972 to find a similar motion. This indicates the gravity of what has occurred. Indeed, if this had happened anywhere outside of the parliament, Senator Baume's behaviour in publishing this material, in particular the tax file number, would have been criminally punishable. The Taxation Administration Act 1953 makes the unauthorised disclosure of a person's tax file number an offence punishable by two years imprisonment or a fine of up to $10,000, or both.

PARA.TAB: Colleagues: imagine the posturing of Senator Baume if this had happened to anyone else. Those opposite who are here defending this motion are defending the indefensible. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) spent 15 minutes speaking to this motion and did not mention Senator Baume once. The honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) mentioned Senator Baume only at the end of his speech.

Often when members of parliament are in strife politically or socially, parliament being parliament this is used against them. But in all my experience of parliament it has always been used in a political way, except when Senator Baume has used it. Senator Baume always goes for the personal attack. Personal abuse and personal vilification are his stock in trade—kicking people when they are down.

What happened in the Senate last week on the eve of the New South Wales state election was so crude, so intrusive into someone's personal privacy and such an abuse of confidentiality that I believe that only by its being condemned by this chamber can parliament be restored in the eyes of the people. We are harangued often by those opposite. Indeed, in the first 15 minutes of business in the chamber today the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) was telling us how we had to lift our standards. Then he went on, as the first opposition speaker, to try to defend Michael Baume.

The Leader of the Opposition, Baume's good mate, is always telling us that we have to lift the standard and behaviour of this House. Indeed, the media is often critical of the behaviour of this chamber. No-one would deny that there is often robust exchange. It is also true that things are often said in the heat of the moment that should not be said.

Never in my 12 years of parliamentary life have I witnessed such an invasion of privacy, such a breach of confidentiality under parliamentary privilege. The action of Senator Baume has embarrassed the parliament, and unless action is taken we are all guilty. What Senator Baume did under parliamentary privilege, in the dying hours of the parliament, when the candidate he was attempting to smear had no chance of reply, is typical of the Baume attack. As Alan Ramsey said in the Sydney Morning Herald:

SPEECH.PARA: It was a brutal hatchet job on an opponent given no chance to defend himself. His accuser attacked in the dark, under parliamentary privilege, at the last possible moment, from 300 kilometres away. Macdonald, campaigning on home ground in Manly, knew nothing of what Baume had done until much later. Only the next morning did he get an equal chance to strike back.
It was a cowardly, sleazy and more than likely self-defeating act.

This, colleagues, is the well documented Michael Baume style. In 1977, in the last hours of the campaign for the state seat of Wollondilly, Senator Baume launched a vicious attack under parliamentary privilege on the Labor candidate for the seat, Bill Knott. Bill had lost part of his foot in an accident at the steelworks at Port Kembla some years earlier, and Baume said publicly and under parliamentary privilege how disgusting that a man who was an invalid pensioner should stand for parliament. Bill Knott made the wonderful reply that it was only his foot that had been amputated, not his brain—like Baume's had been.

PARA.TAB: In the last days of my own campaign in 1983 for the then seat of Macarthur, where Michael Baume was the sitting member, he arranged for the local newspaper to put out a scurrilous and false report hinting that I had misappropriated funds from my previous employment. This was totally without foundation. It was only when someone from the newspaper, so shocked at this sleazy action, leaked the story to me that we knew about it.

As at that time there was an electronic blackout I would not have had the means to reply to this scurrilous, dirty story. We had to take out a court injunction to stop the publication. Despite my frequent requests after the election for this newspaper and for Senator Baume to now publish the story, they have refused to do so to this day.

The same Senator Baume persuaded the member for Mayo (Mr Downer), then on Malcolm Fraser's staff at the time of the 1983 election, to telephone at taxpayers' expense the London School of Economics in London

SPEECH.PARA: to snoop on my university record. The same Senator Baume, who leaked details from my driving licence, which so mysteriously went missing in 1983, then arranged for confidential details of my house building application to be leaked to the local media.

PARA.TAB: Political candidates, if Baume is in the area, expect to have their house raided by the police on a trumped up charge. It happened to me in 1983 and to the member for Gilmore prior to the last election. The senator has never been averse to throwing around defamation orders. I have been on the receiving end of a couple of these, and he is well known throughout the Illawarra for serving defamation orders on people.

Consistently he has moved motions in the Senate concerning me and my staff, the member for Gilmore and his staff, and the member for Macarthur and his staff. This is the same Senator Baume who, in the lead-up to the last New South Wales election, raised false allegations in the House against the Labor candidate, Councillor Michael Samaras. This person, who takes the high moral ground on every issue, is the same person who opened an electorate office in the Wollongong area claiming that the local members were not doing a good enough job in representing the area, and promoting himself as a locally based senator—not that anyone ever saw him.

But when Michael Baume decided it would be politically advantageous to open an office in Camden to campaign against the member for Macarthur, and was foolish enough to put an article in the Illawarra Mercury indicating his desertion of the Illawarra was for political reasons, the Minister for Administrative Services rightly refused to waste $100,000 of taxpayers' money on moving Michael Baume.

Bear in mind that this is the same Senator Baume who wanted to have the Australian taxpayer waste $100,000 for his personal comfort. It is the same Senator Baume who was chair of the opposition Waste Watch Committee and who has consistently railed against what he claimed was a waste of taxpayers' money. This is the same Michael Baume who day after day takes the high moral ground in the Senate. This is the same Michael Baume whose good friend, the member for Bennelong, said on 23 February 1988 on the privacy legislation:

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot think of a greater abuse of privacy, a greater abuse of privilege or a greater abuse of confidentiality than . . . this occasion.
He went on:

What group in this community can possibly feel confident that if it gives this Government information, if it trusts the state . . . with any information about private affairs, that information will be kept confidential?

Why is the member for Bennelong so silent on the invasion of privacy by his mate Senator Michael Baume? Let the honourable member for Bennelong give us his views today on the abuse of privacy, privilege and confidentiality by his mate Senator Baume. During the censure motion in the Senate last Tuesday, Senator Baume said:
It should not be a political stunt or some kind of political get square, it must rest on principle.
Principle from Michael Baume! He went on to state:

PARA.TAB: This motion was conceived in malice, born in deceit and swaddled in falsehood.

SPEECH.PARA: This from the senator who has made the smear a political stunt and the political get square into an art form. He has made himself the master of the use of privilege of parliament to smear anyone where he thinks it is an advantage politically to the Liberal Party.

PARA.TAB: In case there is any doubt, Senator Baume knew precisely what he was doing and he did it for political advantage. His action was poll driven. It was driven by Liberal Party internal polling. Over lunch on Monday in this very parliament, Senator Baume boasted that, before his attack on Dr Macdonald, Dr Macdonald had a five per cent lead. That lead disappeared after the attack. It was a deliberate attack by the New South Wales Liberal Party using Buckets Baume to take the seat of Manly from the sitting Independent. This is the same Michael Baume who tried under parliamentary privilege to find muck in the investment of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the piggery and who made outrageous comments about the Prime Minister's purchase of a house. He is the same Michael Baume who, as chairman of the opposition Waste Watch Committee, had a Commonwealth car wait for him for almost two hours while he was at a dental appointment. He is the same Michael Baume who was involved with a failed stockbroking firm, Patrick Partners—the firm that cost thousands of pensioners their life savings. That is the high moral standard of Senator Baume.

I have no doubt, in his usual style, Senator Baume will now mount another vicious attack on me. In the 12 years that I have been a member of this parliament, I and my staff have been attacked many times by Senator Baume under parliamentary privilege. This is the first time that I have ever responded, because enough is enough. Senator Baume, by his action, has brought disgrace and discredit to this parliament. He has finally overstepped the mark. He will squeal about this attack, but he should remember that those who live by the sword will inevitably, in the end, fall by the sword.

Just to make sure that we are totally up to date in the election that the Liberals just lost in New South Wales, Senator Baume—on parliamentary headed paper—at cost to the taxpayer put a letter around to the electorates of the south coast. In the letter Michael Baume states:

SPEECH.PARA: This state election has significant implications at the federal level. This is a clear choice between responsible government under decent honourable leaders.

That is from the Liberal Party—a `decent honourable' member who has used this parliament to smear the name and the reputation of an Independent.I can think of no-one in this parliament who is more deserving of censure than Senator Baume. For 20 years he has used this parliament. Whenever the current leader of the Liberal Party wants someone to do a bucket job the call goes out, `Where's Buckets?' and, no matter how much grime, how much filth or what the smear is, Buckets is there saying, `Me, me, let me tip it.' They give it to him.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite come into this parliament and make speeches about standards and about the way we are perceived out there in the community, but old Buckets is up there and as one lot of filth is thrown he is running out getting another one. They run from the offices of the Leader of the Opposition and the Manager of Opposition Business and, no matter how filthy, how low or how much muck is in the bucket, they run and get Buckets Baume. In he comes. He runs every time. He will tip it.

Today is a delightful day because, after 20 years of seeing Buckets bucket good, decent people in the parliament and in the community, Buckets is getting his bucketful. It could not go to a more worthy recipient than Buckets Baume. I support this motion. If there is any decency left on that side, when it is put to a vote, all the benches on the other side will be empty and the benches on this side will be crowded. There is no-one more deserving of censure.
Mr Knott interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member for Gilmore has just reminded me, and it is very appropriate to our electorates, there have been some low people and some low actions, but to get lower than the good senator Michael Baume you would have to be a coalminer. I commend the motion to the House.
—The member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) says it all. The hypocrisy of the argument that the Labor Party is putting—
—How much did the telephone call cost?

—I will tell you about that. This is something that the House needs, above all, to understand. On 23 February 1988, the inarticulate previous speaker voted in a motion in the old Parliament House to defend the member for Canning, the now Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear)—who self-righteously and hypocritically spoke in this debate—who had released, contrary to section 130 of the Health Insurance Act, the Medicare provider numbers of a number of Australian doctors as a political stunt.
—He didn't even receive them.

—You wouldn't know. When it comes to dirty pool, the way you behave in relation to local councillors in your electorate is indeed dirty pool. The fact is that the member for Canning, the now Assistant Treasurer, was happy to breach section 130 of the Health Insurance Act to release the Medicare provider numbers. Then, when we moved a motion in this chamber, the member for Throsby, the member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) and, let us see who else, the member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland)—you, pal, will not be here; you are just a fleeting piece of light across the scene and you will be gone pretty soon—all voted in support of the member for Canning releasing confidential numbers contrary to section 130 of the Health Insurance Act. Here are their names on the Votes: ayes 72; Chynoweth, Cleeland and Hollis. Your names are all there. And there is Willis right down at the bottom. I am sure yours is there, Andrew. I will come to you in a second. Down the bottom of the page, who also voted in support of the actions of the member for Canning? The now Treasurer (Mr Willis). There is the name of Mr Willis down at the bottom of the list there. The whole lot of them are there. I am searching for the K's here. I have found the K's. The name Kelly is there. Remember her? But what is interesting about this vote is that on that occasion even the now Prime Minister (Mr Keating) voted in support of the member for Canning.

PARA.TAB: What is the point? The point is that this whole exercise is a complete and utter stunt. You people are absolutely desperate—I have seen it over and over again in the last 10 years—to manufacture a political issue out of nothing in order to make a cheap political point. This is one of the most common political stunts from the Labor Party. By the way, I think you will find the name Theophanous on this list as well. He is also part of the hypocrisy of the Labor Party.

What did Senator Michael Baume actually do? Are you people claiming that Dr Macdonald did not understate his income? Is that one of the claims you are making today? Or did he understate his income? Silence. You know the answer to that question is, first and foremost, that Dr Macdonald did understate his income.
Mr Chynoweth interjecting—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—The member for Dunkley will cease interjecting.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is pretty fanciful that a bloke can sign off on his tax return the sorts of numbers we have heard through this debate for his gross taxable income and then say, `I didn't know anything about it.' That was the Ros Kelly defence—remember Ros Kelly?—in relation to the environment document: `I didn't read it; I just signed it.'

PARA.TAB: That is an argument you people on that side of the House may be familiar with. It may not be an argument that the member for North Sydney (Mr Mack) is familiar with, but it is an argument that you have been happy to use and so you think that is an acceptable standard. I do not. It does not matter what accountant put together his tax return, he should have had the decency to make sure he knew what was in it. He should be held responsible for signing a document that was in the end misleading.

Then there is the issue of the tax file number. Senator Baume has been the first to admit that he inadvertently tabled the document with the tax file number on it. He has admitted that, just as the member for Canning tried to extricate himself, I seem to recall, from the releasing of the Medicare provider numbers. Sure, he inadvertently tabled the document with the tax file number on it. He apologised for the tax file number being tabled and took measures immediately to make sure that tax file number was not published—measures which were successful.

When he sought leave to table the document, he asked permission from the minister at the table, the notorious Senator Crowley, who we will return to in a moment. When it comes to low standards, tabling documents and giving material to journalists, what gall they have! Senator Crowley was the minister sitting at the table—the woman who has done so much damage to one family in the last few days. She has done so much damage that her senior minister has had to come into this chamber and apologise for her behaviour. So bad was it—

TALK.START.PARA: —It might have been silly, but it was not deliberately malicious.
—It was deliberate; it was quite deliberate. She quite deliberately gave that material to journalists.

—Order! The member for Wills will cease interjecting in his loud voice. I understand that this is an emotional debate and the chair has been fairly tolerant, but I will not be tolerant of people who continually yell out in a loud manner.

—The point is that Senator Crowley had five minutes to peruse that document. She did not identify on that document a tax file number, and agreed to its being tabled. As Senator Evans pointed out in the Senate, the reason she did not identify the tax file number on the document was that it was not obvious there was a tax file number on it. Sure, there were numbers on the document—there was a file reference number and there was a number with `file number' by it but not `tax file number'. Senator Crowley did not recognise the number as a tax file number and Senator Evans's excuse is, `It would have been hard for her to have realised that was the tax file number.' Hang on—that is a defence for Senator Crowley but apparently it is not an acceptable defence for Senator Baume. It was all very well for Senator Crowley not to recognise the number, but apparently—
—The Liberals had it for three years.
—Could you be quiet! You poor, sad creature.
—Did you see it in that three years?

—When it comes to Independents, I would have thought you would be one of the people in this room who would be a bit silent because the Liberal Party has just won a seat from an Independent in your area which gives us, thank you very much, a very good foothold towards wiping you out at the next election. At least we will have a little less noise, I would have thought, from a man who physically threatened councillors in his own electorate. But don't worry; you will hear a lot more about that in the lead-up to the election, pal—a lot more.

PARA.TAB: The point is that the standard acceptable for Senator Crowley, according to the Labor Party, is unacceptable for Senator Baume. This is part of the complete hypocrisy of the whole exercise, a point I think I convincingly proved with the assistance of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) by referring back to the 1988 incident involving the honourable member for Canning which, of course, you have all conveniently forgotten.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are back to push polling.
—You weren't here, maddie. You weren't here, you nut case, but the point I am making—
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Don't tell us you are not a nut; millions won't agree with you.

—Apart from the fact of what this man's opinion of me might be, it is against standing orders to vilify someone in this place. I would like to say what I think of him, but you would then throw me out of the place because I would have questioned his parentage.

—Order! There is no point of order, and you will remain seated. All members of the chamber who are still here will remain quiet, and that includes the honourable member for Gilmore, irrespective of points of order.

—I rest my case. The point is that this is characteristic of the way the Labor Party behaves. Let us just have a look at what you yourselves have done in campaigns over the years. During the last federal election campaign in the electorate of Adelaide when Trish Worth had been preselected as the Liberal candidate in that marginal seat, you were dead worried about losing. Of course, there was all the bravado—`We won't lose; we won't lose'—but you were dead worried about losing, and for good reason: you lost.

PARA.TAB: During that campaign the Labor Party got a state politician to stand up in the state parliament and make allegations that the honourable member for Adelaide was involved in some kind of financial kickback arrangement with a firm with which she worked at the time. It was totally unsubstantiated and totally untrue but, after all, with only a few weeks to go before the election you thought, `At least we can run a smear and hopefully some of the mud will stick'. The fact is that in Senator Baume's case what was said about Macdonald happened to be true. What was said about Trish Worth by the Labor Party was a bare-faced lie; it was totally untrue.

When we move across Adelaide to the electorate of Makin—and this is just Adelaide, where I happen to live—we find the same thing. A Labor backbencher in the state parliament, one of those you only ever hear from when mud is thrown which is totally untrue and unsubstantiated against the Liberal Party—and the honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan) is a great one for arranging these sorts of things as I will explain in a moment—stood up and made claims about the financial arrangements of the Liberal candidate in order to elicit this headline: `Libs in new candidate bombshell'. The allegations made by the Labor Party on that occasion were bare-faced lies—totally untrue and never substantiated. But you thought that was all right, did you? You thought it was all right, that that sort of behaviour was acceptable.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we don't think it is all right.

—You are not in the Labor Party, and the Labor Party moved this motion. The fact is that that is the standard that you apply, and you try to imply that people on the other side of the House would behave in the way you have. But we would not; we simply would not do that sort of thing. That is a cultural difference between the two sides of politics and something you really need to understand and remember.

PARA.TAB: In the Torrens by-election in South Australia we had the case where somebody on the staff of the honourable member for Makin went to the launch of the Liberal Party campaign and started asking questions while professing to be an Adelaide Advertiser journalist. He gave his name as that of an Adelaide Advertiser journalist, which was totally dishonest and totally deceitful.

What happened? The journalist whom he was professing to be happened to be standing beside him while he was professing to be that journalist. As a consequence, we thought that the member for Makin was going to sack the staffer. It is typical of the tactics of the member for Makin, the man who runs around the press gallery whispering smears, innuendoes and lies. He had one of his staff, pretending to be an Adelaide journalist, caught in embarrassing circumstances. So the member for Makin sacked the staffer—or did he? It was only for a little while and the staffer is now back on his staff.

They are the standards of the Labor Party. They are the standards that you apply, and you have the gall to come into this chamber and move this puerile motion today. Really and truly, the stench of the hypocrisy of it is simply revolting. There is no question about that.

In this instance Senator Baume did inadvertently table a document with a tax file number on it. He immediately took action when he realised his mistake to have the number taken off. These two people over here, the Independents, are not concerned about the tax file number, because they know that Senator Baume did it inadvertently, not deliberately. He would have no motive to do it deliberately. He would have no motive to table the tax file number but, of course, he had a motive to table the information.

The point that you two guys need to remember, as well as the rest of you, is that the information was true. So the truth does have a role in this place. Part of the truth of this debate is the hypocrisy of what the Labor Party is claiming here today. There is one standard for you and another standard for the coalition. That is the game that you have always been trying to play. The point about this is that the Australian people recognise what you are up to. They now know what you are up to. They heard your lies and deceit during the last election campaign and they know you are up to deceit and hypocrisy yet again. (Time expired)

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Before I call the member for McEwen, I will say again, to the few members in the House, that decorum shall be maintained and staff outside shall not be tempted to have conversations with them when they should not.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have seen what the opposition calls a defence of the actions of Senator Baume. They are trying to put up a defence for a set of circumstances which should again be spoken of in this House. What are the circumstances? Senator Baume obtained, from sources unknown, a letter which was a private communication between the Australian Taxation Office and an Australian citizen. It should not matter that Dr Macdonald is, or was, a candidate for public office. The fact is that Dr Macdonald is an Australian citizen and communications between the Australian Taxation Office and an Australian citizen are private and confidential. Nevertheless, that is the document that Senator Baume had.

PARA.TAB: It is not denied that Senator Baume tabled this document in the Senate. Hence the act which we are complaining about is proved. It is not denied by the defence that the act took place. What they say, though, is that there was no mens rea—what was done was a totally innocent act. There is mens rea and it is demonstrable that what Senator Baume did is part of an overall tactic of the Liberal Party led by John Howard. It is part of an overall strategy to bring this parliament into disrepute by unfairly attacking Australian citizens, whether they be members of parliament or otherwise. That is demonstrable.

In looking at these events, one can clearly see that the mens rea—the intent—is demonstrable. It is not an excuse for members on the other side to say that the date upon which Senator Baume tabled the document had nothing to do with anything other than an honest desire by Senator Baume to reveal a matter of public importance, because it was tabled on the Friday before a state election.

It was tabled to induce the voting public of New South Wales to think that Dr Macdonald was a person of low repute or of criminal proclivity. That was the only reason why Senator Baume tabled the document and then ran with the media story on Dr Macdonald's alleged breach of the law.

None of the people on the other side has given any explanation why Senator Baume would table it—none of them! Not one of these great defence wizards over here has suggested anything other than it was all right except for the tax file number. So they do not see anything wrong with an Australian citizen's private information being made public. Yet we now know that: the matter was resolved with the Australian Taxation Office; no charges had been laid against Dr Macdonald by the Taxation Office; tax had been paid according to law; and Dr Macdonald had neither committed any offence nor breached any Australian taxation law. We know that to be the case; we know that to be the fact—and the Liberal Party knew that to be the fact.

The Liberal Party knew because Dr Macdonald had written to the then Premier, Mr Fahey, advising him of what had occurred, advising him of the full circumstances. So the Liberal Party, which comes in here and runs a collective defence, was in possession of all details of the circumstances. Yet the day before the state election they chose, through Senator Baume—and it is the Liberal Party that is under attack here—to table that document.

There is a strong case that the Liberal Party has a tactic of going deep into the sewers of Australia and, indeed, it is going deeper and deeper into those sewers. To gain the evidence for this, look at a number of incidents that have occurred recently both in the House of Representatives and in the Senate. Look at the behaviour of the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) in this House when he used leaked material from the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission to attack former Senator Richardson on the so-called Operation Wallah. Despite the fact he could not prove his case, he nevertheless had no hesitation in standing up in this House and doing a bucket job.

Look at what occurred in the Senate. A Queensland member of parliament, Mr Grice, again relying on confidential, leaked material from the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission, let that information be used in an attack against Senator Ray, despite the fact that it was demonstrable that the information used by Mr Grice was false. Yet today we now have Senator Chapman with a notice of motion in the Senate which, if passed by the Senate, would require the National Crime Authority to give to the Senate all material or documentation it may or may not possess on this Operation Wallah.

The Liberal Party is saying, `These are good tactics.' But it is moving a motion that would create a criminal offence. If the Senate agreed to Senator Chapman's motion that the National Crime Authority produce documents concerning Operation Wallah to the Senate, the National Crime Authority would be in total breach of section 51 of the National Crime Authority Act which says that a person to whom this section applies, either directly or indirectly, who makes a record of any information or divulges or communicates to any person any information is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction or by a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment for a year or both.

It is interesting to look at the definition of who should not get it. A person to whom this section applies shall not be required to produce any document in any court. What does the word `court' mean? A court is defined in the section as being any tribunal, authority or person having power to require the production of documents. The Senate is clearly an authority having power to require the production of documents. Liberal Party members are again at it. They are deep down in the sewers, trying to force the commission of criminal offences by using the forms of this House.

It is part of a pattern. We have honest John Howard running around the countryside, accusing the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of behaviour which brings the standards of this House into disrepute. That is what he is saying. He is saying that the government and the Prime Minister behave in a way which brings this House into disrepute. Who abuses the forms of this House more often than anyone? Who ignores the standing orders of this House more often than anyone? It is certainly not the Prime Minister. Some people on the opposition front benches could well qualify as being those who have no respect for the forms of this House, the chair of this parliament or the laws of this country.

That is the way opposition members are behaving. The member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), as part of the overall strategy of the Liberal Party—led by honest John Howard—breached both decency and law. Yet opposition members came in to defend him. This is the norm. This is the pattern of behaviour the conservatives of this country are now running on. Let us not run away from it.

The member for Mayo (Mr Downer) came in here and said, `There is one standard for the Labor Party and one for us.' Let us see who breached those standards. Let us see who in this parliament breaches the law. Senator Baume broke the law—no ifs, no buts, no defence. The law clearly states that it is an offence to disclose the tax file number of any person. There are no ifs, no buts, no excuse and no argument about it—Senator Baume did break the law. Today Senator Chapman is trying to force the National Crime Authority to break the law. These are two examples of where the opposition members have total disregard and disrespect for the law.

Then, of course, there is the member for Barker, who has total disrespect, not just for decency, morality or feelings, but for law. Yet the member for Mayo says, `There is one standard for us and one standard for you.' Frankly, your standards stink. Your standards are appalling. Your standards have clearly been demonstrated in this parliament to be abhorrent. The standards of the Howard-led Liberal government are demonstrably illegal, abhorrent and leading you into the sewers. For your behaviour, you give a pale excuse.

What happened this morning when we convened in this House? On indulgence from the chair, the member for Flinders (Mr Reith) stood up and ran a case against the Prime Minister. Where was the case? What was the argument? It was fallacious and not in accordance with the forms and procedures of this House. Even at the very start of today's sitting, we had a clear demonstration of the total contempt you people have of this House and its proceedings.

I notice the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) sitting over there. Members should note my forecast. `Bucket' Katter will get up and go through Operation Wallah. He will use material leaked from the Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland—material which is not necessarily true—

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, there's been a court case!

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —He will use it in a way that will attack the reputation of people who are not in this parliament to defend themselves. He will demonstrate to the Australian people yet again the character of the Howard-led opposition because he will be doing it with the consent of that side of the House.

PARA.TAB: Not only do we have `Bucket' Baume but we will have another example of the sort of bucketing the Liberal Party does—I can see the member for Kennedy nodding his head—in just a few minutes. That will prove the government's case that these people have no scruples, no decency and no morality. They will use material that has been criminally obtained—use the bucket—and deny their criminality in so misusing it. They will not use information honestly and they will not give people a fair right of reply. That will be demonstrated soon by the member for Kennedy. But he will feel no shame—his father might—because he is part of the bucket brigade.

The Howard-led opposition stands condemned. The Australian public should listen to what the member for Kennedy is going to say. Frankly, the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission should be charged. It leaks like a sieve, and the person doing the leaking is Mark Le Grand. He should be brought to this House to justify his behaviour and that of the Criminal Justice Commission because there is something smelly, dirty and stinking about a law enforcement body that would leak material to politicians in this House in order to attack Australian citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me correct a number of things that have just been said by the member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland). Not an ounce of evidence was produced throughout the debate in the Senate—which, because of its length, will require members of this House to sit past midnight tonight—and no evidence has been produced here to link the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) with any activity relating to the motion before the House. Unless the government is prepared to produce some evidence—which it failed to do in the wake of the prime ministerial allegations about the Packer deal—it should stop talking—

PARA.TAB: Mr Chynoweth interjecting—

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! The member for Dunkley might bear in mind that the member for McEwen was heard in relative silence. When the member for Kennedy interrupted him I called him to order. I expect the same courtesy to be extended to the member for O'Connor.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add to what the member for Mayo (Mr Downer) said relating to the information I provided to him about this government's hypocrisy. Pre-February 1988, the then health minister—the former member for Bonython, Dr Blewett—in an effort to discredit doctors, gave to the then backbencher, the now Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), a series of documents which he proposed to use in his role as chairman of Labor's price watch committee. The now Assistant Treasurer was at that time running a campaign against doctors that was associated with this government's attempt to reduce the burgeoning cost of Medicare. As is always the case with such campaigns, the strategy was: attack the providers.

PARA.TAB: Blewett, either mistakenly or deliberately, handed over documents which, in the first instance, seemed to have come to him illegally from the Health Insurance Commission. Section 130 of the relevant act makes it illegal for the commission to pass on such things as provider numbers but that information was given either to Blewett or to members of his staff. He handed them on to the now Assistant Treasurer who used them publicly. They were caught.

Not only would those provider numbers give access to all sorts of details about what individual doctors have been charging; they would also give access to information about patients against whom doctors had been levying those charges and the services involved, which could relate to embarrassing sexually transmitted disease or whatever. But they got caught.

We came into this place and questioned the minister, and the minister admitted what he had done. We sought to censure him. The evidence of the attitude of the members of this House is, as usual, recorded in Hansard. The names of those who voted in favour of a minister releasing those medical provider numbers are all there. We called out a few before. R. J. Brown is one of the names there. That was his view. We have mentioned others, including Mr Chynoweth. Others have been mentioned before. They all came in here, notwithstanding their protest today, and voted in favour of the release of that sort of confidential information, notwithstanding that they passed an act, which includes section 130 that says it is illegal to do so.

So much for the morality of this particular challenge. In fact, those people voted that way. One who was caught with his fingers in the till was the Assistant Treasurer, and he came into this place and participated in the debate. It is unbelievable. All your names are here. That is one thing about this place—everything is on the record. That is how you voted. Let us put the morality of this issue aside. On both occasions the parties have claimed innocence. They claimed they did not know the gun was loaded. If the truth be known, both claims are correct. But that is not the point.

This is a day when we level charges and this is a debate where we level charges at each other. Words have been used in this place by the member for McEwen such as `the Liberal Party has sunk deep into the sewers of Australia'. In the history of Australia—from my recollections of the history of Australia—the greatest depth to which any politician has sunk deep into the sewers was when John Helden MLC rose in the upper house of the state parliament of Western Australia to attack two women on behalf of a constituent. The constituent had a long record of being a Labor Party hack. His name was Brian Easton.

There was a background to all of that. The two women being attacked were sisters. They were both government lawyers. One was the ex-wife of Brian Easton. At that time, the other was working for the Legal Aid Commission in Western Australia and had been appointed to represent the interests of women who had been defrauded by a woman called Robyn Greenberg, who conducted a form of building society called Western Women.

These women had been defrauded. They had been recommended to go to Robyn Greenberg for financial advice. Many of them came with the pittance of their divorce settlement or maybe the inheritance from the death of a husband and were told by a government instrumentality called Women's Information Referral Exchange to go down to Robyn Greenberg because she was a female financial consultant—a woman who had been through two previous bankruptcies—and take her advice as to how to invest their money. They did seek her advice.

She invested it for them and then stole the money. She is now in gaol for having stolen $3 million. These women were trying to recover from the government of the day, the then Labor government under Premier Carmen Lawrence, that money. They had a heap of evidence that they had been advised by a government agency to invest with Robyn Greenberg's Western Women. Just prior to this date, I think it was 22 November 1992 or thereabouts, and Helden raising these allegations of perjury against these women in the parliament, Margaret McAulay, one of those women, the lawyer representing the interests of these women, went to Premier Lawrence and told her that the case was insubstantial.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The people listening to the member for O'Connor's contribution have been waiting to see whether in fact his remarks are related to the matter under consideration. I think not. The member for O'Connor should be brought back to the substance of the issue.

—The member for Charlton raises a point of order that, clearly, I have been considering too. But, having witnessed this debate, a number of members have used the form of this debate to indicate points at which, in the history of the parliament, various parliamentarians have impugned the integrity of others. I presume that the member for O'Connor is about to link his remarks back to the debate. I am waiting for him to do so.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I also remind you that this is a censure motion and those rules of relevance do not apply. Furthermore, I have listened to the member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) and the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), and this censure debate has been wide ranging, as they always are.

PARA.TAB: The point I want to make is that, just days before these allegations were made, Margaret McAulay, the lawyer appointed by legal aid to represent the interests of these women—and I would have thought the member who just rose would have been rather interested in this—went to the Premier, Carmen Lawrence, to tell her that on her inquiries these women had an irrefutable case against the government, that they had been so advised and that the government should settle. Margaret McAulay told me she has never seen a person so angry as Premier Lawrence after receiving that advice. As history records, Premier Lawrence refused at any time to settle with those women. She was eventually out of office when the Court government took up the proper responsibilities of government and settled with them.

So much for the government's adviser on women's affairs. To protect her own party and her own government from the accusations of making a very bad mistake, she was prepared to leave women in poverty. But, of course, Margaret McAulay had to be punished. But then another embarrassment arose for Premier Lawrence relating to some $5,000 of travel money she had been given two years before but had failed to repay.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker—
—According to their squeals would you know them.

—I rise on a point of order. I know that this has been quite a wide ranging debate but if, in the process of the debate, there is an attack on an existing member of this House which impugns that person's integrity there are forms of the House which are—
—That is right. And you are right in the middle of one.

—Yes, but in that debate you do not try to impugn the integrity of another member unless you want to move a motion. If you want to move a motion, it is a different matter. But the reality is that not only is this not relevant but in fact he is trying to impugn an existing member. I think you should rule him out of order.

—Order! The parliamentary secretary raises a point of order on which I have already ruled. This is a wide ranging debate. I regret the form that it is taking but, because it is a wide ranging debate, I believe the member for O'Connor is within the scope of the debate. He may, however, like to link his remarks to the motion before the House.

—My linkage is the hypocrisy of these people today when, amongst their ranks, they now have a person who has behaved in this fashion. The point I am making is that that embarrassment was on the cards. The government needed a smokescreen and it proposed some form of attack on the then Leader of the Opposition, Richard Court, because there was also an allegation floating around that one of these women had attended his office and requested certain information relating to her ex-husband. It was clear from police inquiries that Mr Court had never given anything and had referred that lady to the public record of things he had said in parliament.

PARA.TAB: But the simple fact was that John Halden MLC brought down a petition which he knew to be false. Worse, he had actually been an adviser, counsellor or something in the Family Court and took to the parliament secret information from the Family Court. He could not make the claim he did not know the gun was loaded. He was an experienced person. He took information to the parliament which attacked a woman called Penny Easton, the ex-wife of Brian Easton. He brought down a petition attacking Margaret McAulay's sisters and accusing both of them of perjury when in fact both he and the Premier knew that the information that they had provided in the court was true.

What was the outcome of that? Penny Easton suicided. And what was the outcome for Mr Halden? He was found by a parliamentary committee to have acted dishonestly, trying to cover up for his then Premier. What happened to him? These are the standards of the Labor Party on these issues. He got promoted to the front bench by his then leader, Carmen Lawrence. Of course, Carmen Lawrence was up to here in it. She eventually admitted some knowledge, though she had correspondence directed to her office which, of course, in her typical fashion, she neither saw nor remembered. What happened to her? The Australian Prime Minister (Mr Keating) invited her to come over here and join his front bench.

They are the level of standards of those opposite. It was one of the most disgraceful episodes ever in parliament, a total abuse of parliamentary privilege, with lies. It was done for the wrong reasons, because it was purely political. It was done against women in all three cases. One only tried to protect some women's rights from the power of government.

What did the Labor Party do with the people? You promoted both of them. Now you are floating the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) as your next deputy leader instead of Brian Howe, a bloke who might not be all that smart and that quick but who at least has some integrity. At least if you ask him what happened last week he can still remember.

This is what you have done. You have come in here posturing about someone who inadvertently left a tax file number on a document which was absolutely true and who did make some attempts to rectify what he had done. Of course, your minister for health has told lies about the situation. She has denied knowing, when written evidence has said that she did know.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I ask that that be withdrawn. It is contrary to standing orders.
—Not in a censure motion.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! I do not need assistance from either the parliamentary secretary or the member for O'Connor. Reference to the minister for health as having told lies is invalid and should be withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw it. I am not going to argue at this stage.

—Michael Baume's disgraceful abuse of this parliament in tabling a tax file number in the Senate is not an isolated act. That is the thing that is most disturbing about this debate: it is not an isolated act and breach of privacy; it is part of a coordinated and sustained campaign of personal vilification and character assassination by the New South Wales Liberal Party. Members of the New South Wales Liberal Party have introduced the politics of the big smear, from the garbage bins of the Lodge—and the garbage man himself is at the front table—to the Hindmarsh Island papers affair, to push polling in Canberra. Some of the push pollers are in the gallery and the beneficiary of push polling, shamefully, is about to be sworn in to this parliament. There is also the member for Kennedy and his unsustainable slurs on Graham Richardson's reputation right through to the tax file number of Dr Peter Macdonald. They have one strategy and one strategy alone—

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The remarks made by the previous speaker are a reflection upon me and are totally incorrect. All of the things I have said have now been confirmed in three courts of law in Queensland.
—Order! The member for Kennedy does not have a valid point of order. I rule that it is an invalid point of order.

—Those opposite have one strategy, and one strategy alone: the politics of the big smear. Basically, in 1995 the Liberal Party has pulled down the shutters on policy development. At the last election it tried the big bang of Fightback. It tried the big bang policy, and it failed. Now it has moved to the big bang of the big smear, smearing the characters and personalities of those who stand in its way. This is an outfit that is absolutely bankrupt of ideas and replaces them with the politics of the big smear.

PARA.TAB: The Liberal Party and the National Party in the 1990s cannot beat their opponents on policy or performance. They cannot beat the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on policy or performance. In the state seat of Manly they could not beat Dr Peter Macdonald on policy or performance. Their only strategy—the strategy that has become the stock-in-trade of the Liberal Party in the 1990s—is to play the man, not the ball, to smear at any cost. No matter the personal hurt, the cost to the reputation of Australian politics or the cost to the reputation of this parliament, they will smear at any cost.

There was evidence of it yesterday in question time. Shamefully, opposition backbenchers went to the all-time low of trying to raise the Prime Minister's children as a political issue. The chief goon on the opposition side, its expert on the whoopee cushion and imitation spider, the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans), was right into it, raising the Prime Minister's children and his wife as a political question. Anyone's personal details are up for grabs under the big smear from the Liberal Party in the 1990s. No-one's privacy is safe. No-one's garbage bin can be left unattended at night, not so long as the Liberal Party has the garbage man, the iron bar, the goon from Cowan, raising these matters of personal vilification and character assassination.

This is the outfit that in the 1960s and 1970s thought it was born to rule Australian politics. But now, unable to match the ALP on policy or performance, it is a party of spoilt brats and pointy heads whose only purpose is to vilify and assassinate the character of its opponents. The really disturbing thing about this is that it goes right to the top. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was there in question time yesterday sniggering away as his goons on the back bench raised matters about the Prime Minister's children and family. He is in this up to his neck. He coordinates opposition strategy at question time. He is so close to Michael Baume, his best friend in politics.

When the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer in the 1970s and early 1980s, we used to follow the money trail to the bottom of the harbour, due to his neglect of the taxation system. Now, in the 1990s, we follow the smear trail from Senator Baume to the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott), the campaign director in Manly, right through to their close personal friend, the Leader of the Opposition. The smear trail, the smut trail in Australian politics from the Liberal Party, leads right to the door in this parliament of the Leader of the Opposition and his office.

Michael Baume is the Leader of the Opposition's best friend in politics. Yet the opposition leader will tell us in this debate and other places that he knew nothing about it. He knows nothing of these things happening in the Liberal Party. He knows nothing of the action of his frontbencher, the garbage man, rummaging through the garbage at the Lodge; he knows nothing of the actions of the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter); he knows nothing of the actions of the member for Cowan. Where is he? He must have been in Rio. He is the Ronald Biggs of Australian politics. He knows nothing about it. He was away in Rio. It is no wonder he was christened the rodent of Australian politics by none other than Andrew Peacock. The rodent is right in it, undermining the reputation of people. He is down there like any rodent would, in the gutters, in the sewers, in the garbage bins of Australian politics.

It is an absolute disgrace that the Liberal Party would pull down the shutters on policy development and anything to do with performance in Australian politics and get down with its leader, the rodent, in the gutters and sewers of Australian politics. No-one's privacy and no-one's personal details are safe from its examination and vilification in the Australian parliament.

It is absolutely absurd for Senator Baume to maintain he did not know the tax file number of Peter Macdonald was on the document. He must have known. Is he trying to tell the Senate that someone of his background, who spends so much time raking over personal details, who spends so much time studying private documents, would not have noticed that the document had on it the tax file number of Dr Peter Macdonald?

Even if we accept his absurd and ludicrous assertion that he did not know the tax file number was on the document, the point is that the tax file number is only there to protect the sort of personal information that Michael Baume tabled in the Senate. He had absolutely no regard, like the rest of the Liberal Party and the National Party in the 1990s, for privacy, for personal dignity and personal arrangements. He was prepared to use any method at any cost to bring down Peter Macdonald in the state seat of Manly. The Liberals could not beat him on the substance and what used to be in this country the mainstream of political debate.

This is the same Michael Baume who came to this parliament in 1975 after a seedy and undistinguished career with the infamous Patrick Partners. As we all know, under the present laws of the Australian Securities Commission, if any stockbroking firm now carried out what Patrick Partners did then, it would be charged. This was the shoddy practice of producing TV programs to induce people to buy shares with the offer of a bonus payment. He has not changed one little bit. Had the airing of Peter Macdonald's tax file details occurred outside the parliament, Senator Baume would have been charged and criminally punished for his act. The Taxation Administration Act 1953 makes it an offence punishable by two years imprisonment or a fine of up to $10,000, or both, for the unauthorised disclosure of a person's tax file number. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a return to the writ which the Speaker issued on 17 February 1995 for the election of a member to serve for the electoral division of Canberra in the Australian Capital Territory, to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of the Hon. Roslyn Joan Kelly. By the endorsement on the writ, it is certified that Brendan Michael Smyth has been elected.

PARA.TAB: Mr Brendan Michael Smyth made and subscribed the oath of allegiance.

TALK.START.PARA: —With your indulgence, Mr Acting Speaker, on behalf of the federal parliamentary Liberal Party and on behalf of the federal coalition, I would like to extend an extremely warm welcome to the newly sworn member for Canberra, Brendan Smyth. Our new colleague enjoyed the largest swing in modern political history in Australia. A swing which approximates to 17 per cent on a two-party preferred basis is bigger by three or four per cent than the swing in the Tasmanian seat of Bass in 1975 that heralded the end of the Whitlam government.
—No wonder Paul is not here.

—It is no wonder the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is not here. It is not without moment that the government resolved that, against the normal practice, the member would be sworn in at 12.30 p.m. rather than immediately before question time. Perhaps the Prime Minister would have found it rather uncomfortable to have witnessed his swearing in.

PARA.TAB: All I can say is that this is not so much a victory for the Liberal Party or a victory for Brendan Smyth; it is overwhelmingly a victory for mainstream Australia, which is demanding of its government a recognition of the difficulties under which mainstream Australia has been labouring now for a very long time. I know those opposite find this uncomfortable, but they are going to find the next eight or nine months even more uncomfortable.

In case they see the New South Wales result as some of kind of fleeting hour of triumph, let me remind them that, even in New South Wales, there are some very interesting statistics. At the last federal election, in New South Wales the coalition enjoyed 45.6 per cent of the two-party preferred vote. Last Saturday we got 51.8 per cent of the two-party preferred vote which, if you extrapolate that consistently, would give us 10 seats in New South Wales.

I know that this afternoon in his normal fashion the Prime Minister will have something to say about it. Well, I am getting in first on this occasion. I am saying something about the New South Wales result. But, more than anything else, this is an occasion to welcome the new member for Canberra. I wish him many, many years in federal parliament in the Liberal Party interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —And many happy returns.
—Many happy returns, and I promise him that he will not return to that seat after the next election, but he will return to a seat over on the other side of the parliament.

—On Monday I drew attention to the unauthorised disclosure of information in an article in the Australian Financial Review of 23 March 1995, which related to the report of the Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration on the inquiry into the impact of Australia's taxation regime on the tourism industry. Today the committee considered this matter and resolved that it did not constitute a substantial interference in the work of the committee. I therefore propose to take no further action.
—I thank the honourable member for his report back to the House and the actions of the committee.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —How appropriate it is, how symbolic that Liberal and National Party members should be congratulating the beneficiary of push polling, the new member for Canberra (Mr Smyth). How appropriate, in the middle of this debate about the shameful acts and behaviour of Senator Michael Baume, that this new member should be sworn in. It is so typical of the Liberal Party in the 1990s.

PARA.TAB: As the member for North Sydney (Mr Mack) pointed out earlier, it is not only a question of the ethics and possible criminal behaviour of Michael Baume; it is also a question of tracking down the smear and smut trail of those in the Liberal Party who assisted Baume in this act. Those involved in sighting and treating in the leaked tax documents may be guilty of a criminal offence.

We all know from this debate the identity of the campaign manager for the Liberal Party in the state seat of Manly. It was the mad monk; it was the bellringer of Manly, the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott). We all know that he has been at the bottom of too many rucks. We all know that the seminarians worked him out nice and early when they sent him out the door backwards. But he has been involved—much more than defrocked but totally implicated—in this campaign of smear and innuendo against Dr Peter Macdonald.

This House, in my assessment, not only should be censuring Senator Baume but also should be censuring the member for Warringah because the smear and smut trail in coalition politics is so clear to see. Michael Baume, a protege of the rodent himself, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), and the member for Warringah, a self-confessed and self-identified Baume protege, have been treating and dealing in illegal documents. The member for Warringah is totally and utterly obsessed with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on matters of tax and property.

It is of great interest to note his comments earlier in the debate and note that he is the best known monarchist and supporter of the royal family in this parliament. I get the impression, when dealing with these questions of tax and property, that he grew up in the 1950s and 1960s taking as his role model the royal family, who did not pay any tax at all.

The member for Warringah, on tax and property, is in it up to his neck with Eton West Pty Ltd as a trustee for the Abbott family trust and the Tony Abbott family trust—not one family trust for tax minimisation, not one device to minimise his tax, but two: Eton West for the Abbott family trust and the Tony Abbott family trust.
