How seedy, how hypocritical, how rotten of the member for Warringah to come into this House holding up Michael Baume as his role model, holding up the Leader of the Opposition as his role model—with the smut and smear campaign tracking itself all over the parliament right to the Leader of the Opposition's door—when, in his own arrangements, he is the beneficiary of not one but two tax minimisation devices: the Abbott family trust and the Tony Abbott family trust. This is not the time nor the place to provide the full details of the operations of those two family trusts.

TALK.START.PARA: —To be continued.

—But, as my friend and colleague the member for Throsby correctly points out, it is a saga to be continued. As long as the Liberal Party trumps into this parliament your Michael Baumes, your Tony Abbotts, your David Connollys and Richard Evanses—the garbage men and the goons of the Liberal Party—as the stock-in-trade of the Liberal Party in the 1990s dealing in the politics of the big smear, they can have one personal guarantee, shared right across the government backbench, and that is it will come back with interest. Those failures of the landed aristocracy in Australia, those drop-outs of corporate Australia who come into this place pretending they are angels, have a lot to hide in their own backgrounds.

PARA.TAB: They can be assured by the Labor Party that in debates like this we are not going to cop it any longer. We are not going to cop their failure to develop policy, their failure to develop ideas and their failure to debate matters of substance. We are going to hold them to account by their own standards on questions of tax minimisation, property dealings, rummaging through garbage bins and raising in parliamentary debate people's children and their spouses. We are going to hold them fully and totally to account for those sorts of standards. A party that cannot debate matters of substance in this parliament should not be allowed to get away with its own hypocritical and low standards.

On the evidence of this sorry saga, this smear and smut campaign leading right to the door of the Leader of the Opposition, tracked there by the member for Warringah and Senator Baume, each of them—Baume, Abbott and Howard—deserves to be denounced, deserves to be censured and deserves to be fully condemned by this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Does the member claim to have been misrepresented?

TALK.START.PARA: —In a grievous way.
—Please proceed.

—In the speech we have just heard from the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) he accused me of being a goon, dealing with smut, sleaze and any other word he chose to use. As evidence for that, he cited the fact that I raised the issue of the family of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his children in a question yesterday. That is completely false and I would like to take the time to read that particular question. I read directly from Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is it true that the Prime Minister was so impressed with the pomp and circumstance of guards of honour overseas that his own department and the defence department considered giving him one of his own? Is that because the old guard like Graham Richardson has deserted him? Is it to fight a rearguard action against his backbenchers? Is it because he does not think he is getting enough protection from the Speaker, or is it just another method of protecting him from the real anger of the Australian people? Minister, will the Prime Minister ask Priscilla designer and Oscar winner Lizzie Gardiner to design the guards' new uniforms? Will their badge contain the new Keating crest of the mortgage grindstone and a clock that keeps part time? Will the Prime Minister donate one of his former pigs as a mascot? Minister—
And then I was interrupted by the Acting Speaker, who talked about irony. I went on to say:
Doesn't all this ironical content just go to prove that in the real world the Prime Minister is considered an out of touch joke?
Nowhere in that particular question did I mention the Prime Minister's family or his children and, as a person with high regard for families, I would never do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation, having just been misrepresented by the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans).
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—You may proceed. But I would indicate to the honourable member for Werriwa that I was in the chair during his speech so I am conscious of what was said.

—I do not deny any of the words used in debate. What I do dispute is the recollection by the honourable member for Cowan. The truth is that as he was called to order by the Acting Speaker in the House yesterday he sat down and, as he sat down, he continued his question by saying, `Will the Prime Minister's children be used as mascots in the guard?' It was not recorded by Hansard because he had been called to order by the Acting Speaker of the House. He knows full well that he is now misrepresenting himself in this place.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly do.
—He may proceed.

—In his remarks the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) accused me of trading in smut and he threw my name in along with some other names. He accused me of being the garbage man at the Lodge. May I make the point that anything I have ever said in this House, or anything I have put in my press releases, has simply been the facts and nothing more than the facts. Reference has been made to the expenditure of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I do not think we are really dealing with a personal explanation here.

—I thank the parliamentary secretary for the instruction. The honourable member for Bradfield was indicating where he felt he had been misrepresented. I thought he had almost concluded that. I invite him to conclude those remarks.

—The point is that I was being accused of trading in smut. The understanding of `smut' is, although I do not have a dictionary with me, at best an inaccurate interpretation of facts. I am simply putting on the record that what I said was never an inaccurate interpretation of anything, but simply an indication of the realities of the Prime Minister's lifestyle and his cost to the Australian people.

—In rising to defend Senator Baume today, I might say that it amazes me that more people in this place have not read the following books: The Bold Riders by Trevor Sykes, John Pilger's book The Secret Country, and two other books, about what happened in this country during the 1980s. Trevor Sykes, a very reputable person in every way—I do not think anyone in this House would deny that—said in his book that $16,000 million was lost to some degree to the benefit of about 20 people whom he names in the book. During that period the banks lost $28,000 million. To give you an indication of where that money went and how this money was allowed to go to these areas, I will refer to a Time magazine article on corruption—not in Australia but in another country.

PARA.TAB: Let me hark back for one moment to the fact that the result of $28,000 million being lost by the banks during the 1980s by being loaned out to various people and the money then vanishing was that one in four farmers has gone broke and been forced off his land since 1986. Over 800,000 small business families in this country have been broken over the last eight years. In my electorate there were two suicides last year. One was a person being hounded by a bank; he had to shoot his cattle because of the drought and he then turned the gun on himself. The other was a young man, the son of a prominent grazier family in the area. Like every other family, they were finding it very tough. Only last week we had the deplorable case mentioned in the House by the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) where a young man who was about to be foreclosed on by the banks locked himself in his homestead. The reason that this is happening in Australia is that $16,000 million was creamed off by 20 men. If you go through the list of 20, you will see that about half of them were prominent beneficiaries of the Australian Labor Party. In fact, they served on committees to raise funds for the ALP; and I can name them in this House.

Let me turn back to the Time magazine article. It was an article about the corruption that exists in Indonesia. The Australian press is wonderful at casting aspersions on countries like Indonesia. This article says that it is possible that this person could have blown away as much as $200 million of public funds on a project. He had friends, maybe even in the ministry, who facilitated money from government instrumentalities to go into a petrochemical plant project. This was horrific. It demonstrated how endemic—and it was the worst case yet—corruption is in the Indonesian government. He may have got away with $200 million. It was alleged in the article that this was simply a device dreamed up to take money out of the public purse and put it into private pockets, and some of that money went back to government officials.

I refer to the petrochemical plant project, because that is what we are talking about today. We are talking about corruption, and those people who have the courage, aggressiveness, energy and surveillance to be able to stop corruption from occurring in this country, and Senator Baume is one of those people. I refer to the petrochemical plant project which is before the courts in Australia. It is not speculation; it is reality. Effectively, it involves two men: Laurie Connell, who was the head of fundraising for the ALP in Western Australia; and Dallas Dempster, another prominent bankroller of the ALP in Western Australia. To say that he bankrolled the ALP in Western Australia but not federally is to insult the intelligence of every person in this House.

Anyway, they had this great scheme for a petrochemical plant project. I am sure that they were definite about building it. They sold this project to the Western Australian government for $392 million. The liquidator moved in later on, as it did in just about everything in Western Australia, and liquidated the assets of the petrochemical plant project. The liquidated assets of the petrochemical plant project totalled $11 million. These two men had effectively pocketed $381 million. Indonesia is terribly corrupt, but in Australia, of course, we have a very clean government. We do not have that sort of thing happening in Australia. If that is endemic, and that is the worst example yet of corruption in Indonesia, all I can say is that it must be a very honest government compared with the government of this country.

I will move on and talk about Bell Corporation. The beneficiary of Bell Corporation now sits on the Reserve Bank of Australia where, undoubtedly, she was put by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I have it on very good authority that he used to stay with them when he was visiting Western Australia when Robert Holmes a Court was alive. Bell Corporation was sold to instrumentalities of the Western Australian Labor government for—depending upon which article you want to choose—$360 million, $465 million or $260 million.

It rolled over dead two years later and not a single cent was paid out to the shareholders in that corporation, which of course were the taxpayers of Western Australia. A delightful article, I think in Business Review Weekly, said that the stories about it were wildly exaggerated and that, in fact, the taxpayers had lost only $160 million to the owners of Bell Corporation which, substantially, was the Holmes a Court family—only $160 million!

Those are just two examples. I could sit here for the next half-hour and quote examples from these truly magnificent books which disclose what happened in Australia during the 1980s. I ask myself—and historians in future years will also ask themselves—why nobody in this place had the courage to stand up and say, `This has got to stop.' These were government instrumentalities, government banks. It was the job of the Reserve Bank of Australia to stop this from happening. That is why the Reserve Bank exists—to act as a watchdog in overseeing all of the banks in Australia.

Again and again in those books you will see reference to the fact that the Reserve Bank failed to take any action whatsoever. That was particularly glaringly obvious in the case of the savings bank of South Australia, as it was in all of these other cases. One must ask why the Reserve Bank did not act. Why did the people who were paid a king's ransom to oversee and stop this from happening allow $28,000 million of people's hard-earned savings to go up in smoke in deals of this nature?

Senator Baume has had the courage to speak out. He faces a very serious defamation action. Unfortunately, in Australia the defamation laws are different from those in any other country. We do not have a freedom of speech principle in our laws in Australia. I strongly commend the High Court action. Maybe one good outcome of the terrible events of the 1980s is the fact that the High Court has now moved in the Theophanous case to virtually abolish defamation action where matters of public interest are involved. So we are moving into the same situation as applies in the United States.

I rather enjoyed some of the comments that have been made. Ray Martin interviewed me and said, `How would you like these things to be said about you?' He referred to some of the things I had said about some other people, and I burst out laughing. That was not the sort of reaction he expected from me. I said, `That is extremely mild compared with the things that I have been called and the concerted attacks made upon me, my family, my character and my honesty over the last 20 years in the state house. And you must be the only journalist in Australia that is not aware of some of those attacks because they made the national dailies on a number of occasions.' As a minister and a member of the Queensland parliament I went through six separate investigations. No politician anywhere in the world has been more investigated than the National Party of Australia members of the state house in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —With good reason too—and you would be the first to admit it.
—I was expecting that. I welcome the interjection—a classic example of fools rushing in.

PARA.TAB: I think the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) earlier described Mark Le Grand as the `dirty leak' from the CJC. I have a friend, who happens to be a friend of a policeman, who had heard some information—and this is very serious stuff. He told me that Mark Le Grand had applied to tap my telephone and Senator Chapman's telephone. If Mark Le Grand was supposedly leaking to us, it would be very funny for him to apply at the same time for wire-taps on our telephones. That is how well informed the ALP is.

If honourable members read the newspapers in Australia, they would have thought that the Queensland government was a very corrupt government. For six years $65 million was spent looking up our toenails. At the end of all that the courts found that $26,000 had gone astray. After we spent $65 million, the courts decided that $26,000 had gone astray!

That was defined, Mr Acting Chairman. The leading case was the case of the Queen v. Brian Austin. Brian Austin went to gaol because he had used his government car for private purposes. He had used his government car to visit his kids at school on the weekend and on a number of other occasions. He had used his plastic fantastic to take people out to dinner. That was why Brian Austin, a human being, was put in a steel cage for two years of his life—he was sentenced to four years and he served two years of that sentence.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—I interrupt the member for Kennedy to point out that he is shifting my status from status I do not deserve as Acting Speaker to status I would like to be elevated above as Acting Chairman. The proper reference should be Deputy Speaker. I also invite him, in the concluding moments of the debate, to draw his remarks closer to the motion before the chair, if he could.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would love to have more time. Mr Deputy Speaker, the figure in Queensland was $26,000. The figure in Western Australia was $876 million. The figure in Victoria was $3,000 million and the figure in South Australia was $3,100 million. That is the story that the history books will tell.

PARA.TAB: I refer to articles in the Financial Review and the Australian. I do not know about any of these things, but those articles said that the Prime Minister owned half of a company that owned a piggery worth $80 million. The articles said that the Prime Minister had a $20 million interest in the piggery. A journalist said to me, `Oh, well, he borrowed the money.' I said to the journalist, `How much money could you borrow?' When I eventually forced him to name a figure, he said, `$200,000.' I said, `Right, you can borrow $200,000, but this bloke, on a take-home pay of $70,000 a year, can borrow $20 million!'

We are discussing the things which have been disclosed by Senator Michael Baume. If he is in trouble for disclosing secrets, then the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) should resign, for there could not be a worse example of invasion of the privacy of an ordinary, decent Australian family than was displayed by Senator Crowley, and yet no action has been taken against her whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. Mr Deputy Speaker. I would ask you to ask that, if the member is going to develop these hypotheses, he at least deliver them in a way that we can understand rather than with this convoluted drivel.

—The parliamentary secretary knows better than that. The member for Kennedy was responding to the chair's invitation to draw his debate relative to the motion before the chair. The member for Kennedy has the call.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, owns a multistorey building, a $3 million-plus home, half of VITAB, and numerous other assets around the countryside, and he acquired all that on a take-home pay of about $70,000 a year. That is certainly very interesting, is it not?

PARA.TAB: All the remarks I have made about Senator Richardson are on the public record in the courts of Queensland. People said that I came in here with unsubstantiated rumours and told lies, but it is on the public record, and yet David Thomas, who has done a lot of excellent work for me, is being prosecuted and so is Craig Nicholls, the resource officer. PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed works be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Maintenance dredging of Kedron Brook floodway, Brisbane.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1994-95 budget provided for the maintenance dredging of Kedron Brook floodway, at an estimated cost of $9.1 million. The Commonwealth owned Kedron Brook consists of an 8.5-kilometre long deep-water channel, passing through approximately 500 hectares of flood plain, linking the Kedron Brook with Moreton Bay. The dredge spoil is to be placed on low-lying areas of the old Brisbane airport site. It is proposed that the dredging works commence by August 1995, and be completed by June 1996. I table some supporting drawings and commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Scarborough House has not undergone any major refurbishment since it was constructed in 1970. The building's internal fabric is now at the end of its life, and its services are generally below currently required standards. The proposal is for the total refurbishment of the building and the upgrading of base building services, to a standard commensurate with current commercial office building standards.

PARA.TAB: The proposed new building will provide approximately 10,400 square metres net lettable area of office space and approximately 600 square metres net lettable area for storage. The estimated outturn cost for both the Scarborough House refurbishment and the new building's construction, including AIPO's fit-out cost, is $50.38 million. The project will be undertaken in two stages, with the construction of the new building scheduled to commence in July 1995 and to be concluded with the refurbishment of Scarborough House, which is to be completed by February 1998.

The committee tabled its report on 27 March 1995, recommending the refurbishment of Scarborough House and the construction of an annex building on the adjacent site, at an estimated cost of $50.38 million.
I thank the committee for its report and I commend this motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I am pleased to table Report No. 335—Finance Minutes.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts I am pleased to present Report No. 355—Finance Minutes. Report 335 contains copies of the two Finance minutes received by the committee during the 1994 calendar year. As many members will be aware, the Finance minute process is the mechanism by which the government responds to many of the recommendations contained in the committee reports. The only recommendations which are not responded to by a Finance minute are those which address policy matters. Recommendations of this nature are responded to separately by the government.

PARA.TAB: Each of the Finance minutes contained in report 335 has already been tabled separately, but they are reproduced here in an annual consolidation for ease of future reference. The Finance minutes deal with the committee's reports on:

SPEECH.PARA: an inquiry into the Australian Taxation Office; and
its reviews of Auditor-General's reports tabled in the period May 1991 to September 1992.

PARA.TAB: The Finance minute on Report No. 326—An assessment of tax was tabled in parliament on 20 October 1994, together with comments by the committee. Report 326 was the result of the first major public examination of the administration of taxation laws in Australia since the enactment of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. In its report the committee sought to introduce balance to a system which it saw as having grown to ignore the people it serves.

When tabling the Finance minutes in October last year I noted that the vast majority of the 88 administrative recommendations had been accepted and were being implemented. I can now advise the House that since that date the committee has taken steps to continue its interest and involvement in the reform process generated by report 326.

The first was to invite the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Michael Carmody, to brief the committee on progress in the implementation of those recommendations which had been accepted. The briefing took place in December 1994 and at that meeting Mr Carmody undertook to provide the committee with regular progress reports. The first of these reports is due shortly.

The other step we have taken is to announce a watching brief over the work of the tax law improvement project. The improvement project was established by the government in response to one of the key recommendations in report 326—that the Income Tax Assessment Act be rewritten and simplified. The improvement project has already produced impressive results with its simplified rewrite of the substantiation provisions of the tax law. Just yesterday the committee was briefed by officials from the improvement project on their proposed framework for the new income tax assessment law. The framework, which will be released for public discussion in late April, promises to be a major step forward in the process of producing clearer and simplified tax law.

The second element of the committee's watching brief is to examine the concerns raised by some in the tax profession that, because the improvement project is not authorised to consider policy matters, it will be unable to deal with the problems inherent in the current tax law. The committee intends to seek submissions from interested parties on this issue in the coming weeks.

The second Finance minute reproduced in the report I have just tabled is in relation to Report No. 330—Review of Auditor-General's reports, May 1991 to September 1992. Report 330 contained the results of the committee's review of the 72 audit reports tabled from May 1991 to September 1992. The committee is pleased to note that 10 of the 12 recommendations contained in the report have been accepted or accepted in principle by the relevant agencies.
One issue of concern to the committee arising from report 330 is an apparent inconsistency between:

SPEECH.PARA: information provided by the Department of Human Services and Health in response to a recommendation about the validation of nursing home funding;
information provided by the same department in response to the Senate community affairs committee's recent report on nursing home funding; and
the findings of a recent audit report on the same subject.
The committee has sought an explanation from the secretary to the department and will consider his response closely. I thank the House for its time.

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr O'Keefe, and read a first time.
Explanatory memorandum presented by Mr O'Keefe; ordered that the second reading be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
Consideration resumed from 29 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Health Amendment Bill 1995 amends the National Health Act 1953 to continue the benefits achieved in the last four years of the agreement with community pharmacy. The bill reflects the fact that both community pharmacy and the government recognise the importance of the current agreement in being able to make fundamental changes to community pharmacy, and the need to continue those changes. The current agreement has provided the incentives and the stability to allow these necessary changes to occur in an environment of cooperation and planning.

PARA.TAB: This agreement has provided assistance to over 600 pharmacists to voluntarily accept payment to hand back their approval to supply pharmaceutical benefits. In general, these pharmacies have been the smaller, less viable pharmacies which adversely impacted on the cost of supply of pharmaceutical benefits. The agreement has encouraged pharmaceutical services to be established and maintained in isolated areas. Over 400 pharmacies in isolated areas now receive extra remuneration to assist in meeting their higher costs.

The agreement has produced a period of stability during which government and pharmacy have not been locked in conflict over remuneration issues, a situation that has unfortunately dogged past relationships. This has given both pharmacy and government the opportunity to explore the beneficial role of pharmacy in health care for the community at a time when community health care is changing rapidly. Noticeable now is the recognition by the pharmacy organisations of the need to monitor the performance of community pharmacy and to measure the outcomes of their activities in health care. In other words, pharmacy is moving from a reactive to a pro-active service to the community.

The bill will allow these changes to continue while building on the experiences gained from the current agreement. Both the government and pharmacy agree that the number of approved pharmacies is now at about the correct level and that the closure and amalgamation payments should cease. The ratio of pharmacies per 1,000 population is now within the range of international figures, unlike the higher levels previously experienced. It is now a matter of continuing to encourage a good distribution of pharmacies rather than the clumping that has occurred in the past and that still exists in some areas of our capital cities.

To achieve this distribution, the current controls relating to the relocation of pharmacies are to be relaxed so that developing areas around the capital cities and other growth areas can be provided with appropriate pharmaceutical services. It is expected that these relocated pharmacies will come from the presently overserviced areas. To encourage the provision of pharmaceutical services in rural and remote regions, the incentives for pharmacies to operate in isolated areas will be continued under the legislation. The bill will permit simpler procedures for approved pharmacists wishing to sell a business or change the ownership.

In other cases, the valuable work and successes of the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority will be maintained. The authority will be reduced in membership and its name will be changed to the Australian Community Pharmacy Authority. It will continue to use the experience of hands-on pharmacists to advise the secretary on applications for new approvals and on relocations of approvals. The criteria for these considerations will, as is the case under the present agreement, be set out in a determination made under section 99L of the National Health Act 1953.

It is necessary to be confident that pharmacists who supply pharmaceutical benefits maintain adequate standards of practice. The bill will permit the secretary to apply conditions for holding an approval to supply pharmaceutical benefits, primarily applying standards of practice developed by pharmacy itself. The bill also introduced the ability of the minister to agree to professional allowances for specific professional pharmacy activities outside the pharmaceutical benefits supply functions. One such area is medication review of residents in nursing homes, a very important area.

At present, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal, in making a determination concerning the remuneration of approved pharmacists for the supply of pharmaceutical benefits, is required to give effect to any agreement in force between the minister and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia on this matter. This provision in the legislation is to continue in operation. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take up too much of the time of the House to discuss the National Health Amendment Bill, which the coalition does not oppose. The National Health Amendment Bill 1995—and I must say that I have noticed the name change—is the enabling legislation for the new pharmacy agreement between the Commonwealth and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, as the professional association of retail pharmacists. It replaces the agreement which has operated since 1991 under which the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority has presided over a major shake-out in the retail pharmacy industry.

PARA.TAB: The bill replaces the authority with a new Australian Community Pharmacy Authority which will make recommendations to the government on applications to supply pharmaceutical benefit items, the payment of allowances in isolated and rural areas and the payment of allowances for specific professional services. The bill will also end the financial assistance program which has operated under the present agreement to facilitate the restructuring process. I am advised that that process has seen the number of active pharmacists in Australia decline by about 10 per cent.

The coalition notes that this agreement will introduce two new allowances to replace the essential pharmacy allowance. These new allowances are the isolated pharmacy allowance and the remote pharmacy allowance. We see the importance of ensuring pharmacies continue to operate in areas which may not be as financially attractive as other locations. Therefore, we support these allowances.

The bill also introduces a professional allowance which will give some recognition of the professional activities of pharmacists outside the supply of drugs, such as participating in drug evaluation trials and the simple giving of professional advice over the counter. We welcome this wider conception of the role of pharmacists in our community—a role I wholeheartedly support and endorse. I should add that we also have no objection to the government's amendment extending the life of the new agreement by one year. This is welcomed by the industry, as the longer period will create greater commercial certainties for retail pharmacies.

In summary, we do not oppose the bill, because it is sound and, more importantly, it has been negotiated with the Pharmacy Guild over a period of time and is quite acceptable to the players involved. In this regard, the government is to be congratulated and I commend this consultative approach to the portfolio minister in respect of other areas of health that we will be debating in this House later today.

With this bill, however, the government has certainly fallen short of best practice in some respects. We are going to the wire with this piece of legislation as the new pharmacy agreement is still unsigned—I understand that this will happen later today—and the agreement itself comes into force on 1 April 1995. That is this Saturday. As a result, my office has received many queries from colleagues and from pharmacists themselves, particularly those who would be seriously affected by the sudden delay of the remote and isolated pharmacy allowance.

It is not good enough for the government to be bringing this legislation through the House 36 hours before the deadline. We are also aware that negotiations between the government and the Pharmacy Guild have been protracted, having opened as long ago as November 1993. Indeed, cabinet only approved the agreement last week. Meanwhile, thousands of pharmacists have been hanging on anxiously as the bureaucratic wheels ground on.

Finally, I am concerned at the way that this reflects on the government's treatment of this parliament. We are here now rubber-stamping an act of executive government, which still requires a major agreement to be signed. While I appreciate the cooperation that I have received from the office of the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) in relation to this bill, the government cannot walk away from the fact that it is operating, in the passage of this bill, on the assumption that the parliament will simply be a rubber stamp for the executive.

It reminds me of our debate last year on what is now the Employment Services Act 1994. In that instance, you may recall that the government passed enabling legislation to establish the Employment Services Regulatory Authority to oversee its job compact. Yet, on the weekend before the bill was debated, there was an advertisement in the national media seeking a chair for the authority—a position eventually given to one Joan Kirner. That advertisement appeared before the parliament had passed the legislation.

Also, the explanatory memorandum to this bill is simply unprofessional. A prose rendering of each provision of this bill, a mere jargonistic paraphrase, gives little understanding of the operation of these provisions. The general outline is little more than a very vague narrative. This is something which has been raised in this place before, by my colleague the member for Tangney (Mr Williams). I want to raise it specifically in relation to the explanatory memorandum provided by the Department of Human Services and Health which has been circulated in this place in the life of this parliament.

I urge the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous)—who has a respect for the processes of this place—to take this concern back to his minister and to make the point forcefully to the Department of Human Services and Health that it should get its act together. It may be a small thing, but it reflects the dim view that the executive arm of government has about the members of this place. I, and my coalition colleagues, simply say to the government that, whatever the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) may think, Australia is a parliamentary democracy and we in this place are the people's representatives. By showing disdain for the representatives in this place, the government shows disdain for the Australian people. It shows that disdain at its own peril, as shown by the swearing in of the new member for Canberra (Mr Smyth) today.
I will finish by moving, as a reflection of the coalition's concern, the following second reading amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, this House:
(1)notes that the Pharmacy Agreement to take effect from 1 April 1995, which is the subject of this Bill, is still being negotiated by the Government;

PARA.TAB: (2)notes that this is far from being the only instance of the Government legislating in anticipation of a set of circumstances which are still to be resolved; and
(3)condemns the Government for its continual treatment of the Parliament as a rubber stamp of executive action".
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been a very short debate on the National Health Amendment Bill, but I note that the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) has felt so strongly as to move a second reading amendment. I am rather surprised at that. He puts forward an interesting case. He says that he agrees with every feature of the bill, in particular with such very important matters as the question of pharmacies in isolated places, the special allowance and the professional allowances for pharmacists. I am also very enthusiastic about this new development. I have met with the Pharmacy Guild and with other pharmacists' representatives and they are all very happy with that.

PARA.TAB: It seems as though, on the basis of the second reading amendment, there is some misunderstanding on the part of the member for Chisholm about the procedure here. We had to have the framework in which to progress the negotiations. That framework is the bill. We have not assumed that everything is going to be concluded entirely in the context of the bill. All we have said is, assuming that to be the case in the general structure—we have not concluded the negotiations; we are going to conclude the negotiations after the bill is passed—that the passing of the bill will give us the opportunity. So I am not sure why he says that we have pre-empted the parliament and that the parliament is a rubber stamp. It is not a rubber stamp in these matters. As the honourable member well knows, this parliament is not a rubber stamp like some parliaments in the Westminster system, because we do have the other place, and at the other place the government does not have a majority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank goodness.
—Thank goodness, the honourable member says. You never know, in a few decades you might win government, but certainly not in the foreseeable future—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! The parliamentary secretary should remain on the subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member had a wide ranging—
—It wasn't wide ranging at all.

—The Senate has in fact passed this bill; so the majority of parties in the Senate have supported the bill. We are not in any sense taking it for granted or assuming the parliament to be a rubber stamp, especially at the moment having regard to the Senate. That is an argument that we simply do not accept, and I think that the honourable member is just trying to make a couple of naughty political points in the context of the current heated atmosphere.
—Of which you've never been guilty.
—I have not. Others have, but I have not.
—What about the explanatory memorandum?
—What is your problem with the explanatory memorandum?
—It is sloppy.
—It is not sloppy.
—Order! We cannot have a conversation across the chamber.

—The honourable member does not disagree with anything in the bill, with any of the arrangements, but he wants to try to make some kind of political point about the process. There is no political point to be made about the process. This has been a good process. I want to commend the Department of Human Services and Health for the great work which it has done in this whole area. This has been a tough process of getting a preliminary agreement, putting things in legislation and having negotiations. Even the honourable member for Chisholm has said that it is good that we have had negotiations with the Pharmacy Guild and with pharmacists. So I still do not understand what he is complaining about.

PARA.TAB: Fundamentally, this has been a very good process for pharmacists. It has been a good process for achieving a very positive outcome in terms of the health of the nation. I commend the department and all those involved in the office of the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) and elsewhere for the negotiations and in our getting to this point. I look forward to the conclusion of the discussions and negotiations in the next few days once this bill passes this House, as I hope that it will. After that, we will have a very good agreement in place, which I know many pharmacists throughout Australia are looking forward to.
