DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 28 February.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill reflects the continuing commitment of this government to securing legitimate title to traditional lands on behalf of the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory. The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 provides a mechanism whereby traditional Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory, referred to in schedule 1 of that act, may be granted to Aboriginal land trusts to hold title on behalf of Aboriginal people. Since the act came into operation in 1977 a total of 58 separate parcels of land have been scheduled under the act.

PARA.TAB: The effect of this bill would be to bring within the schedule to the land rights act that area of land which is the subject of the Hodgson Downs land claim. The Northern Territory government, the Northern Land Council and claimants in the land claim have entered into an agreement which settles that land claim. As part of that agreement the Northern Territory government agreed to request the Commonwealth to exercise its powers under the land rights act to grant the claim area, excluding the Hodgson River road and the Miniyeri community access road, to the traditional owners by scheduling that area under the land rights act. The result of such scheduling would be that no further hearing or report by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner would then be necessary in order for the Aboriginal people concerned to be able to have the full rights of enjoyment of their traditional lands in fee simple.

The government has the assurance of all parties to the negotiations that representative views of all Aboriginal people concerned have been obtained and their wishes taken into account. There are no financial implications arising from this bill. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, as the matter has been canvassed already in the Senate with exactly the same speech as the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) has given here, I certainly do not want to repeat what has been said. I just wish to add to what he has said, that it is under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 that the most gains have been made by Aboriginal people. This has certainly been the landmark legislation in the area of Aboriginal affairs and certainly land rights.

PARA.TAB: It was legislation enacted by the Fraser government in 1976 and since that time, as the minister has noted, there have been a number of parcels of land that have come under the act. The amount of land that has now passed to Aboriginal ownership under this act and separate from other acts is 536,000 square kilometres, altogether 40 per cent of the Northern Territory land mass. Certainly the Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory have gained momentously from this act of the Fraser government which followed the Woodward report.

However, I might add that, in contrast, not one Aboriginal person has gained anything from the Native Title Act to date. There have been seven determinations made under the act and all those have been made in favour of non-claimants. In passing I wish to contrast the effect of those two acts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bill we are discussing this afternoon is the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 2). The purpose of this bill is to add one parcel of land to those granted to Aboriginal land councils in the Northern Territory. The land is situated in the Mataranka region, south of Katherine in the Northern Territory. The land, with an area of some 3,232 square kilometres, is of cultural significance and contains a number of sacred sites. Known as Hodgson Downs, the area is under pastoral lease from the Northern Territory government and is used as a cattle station. It has a population of 240 Aboriginal people, and was purchased by ATSIC in 1991.

PARA.TAB: Because all interests in the property are held by or on behalf of Aboriginal people, a land claim over the station was able to be lodged under the provisions of the original act. In effect, this bill seeks to convert the title from the Northern Territory leasehold to Commonwealth freehold. Despite its opposition in principle to the lodging of land claims over Aboriginal owned cattle stations, the Northern Territory government in August last year agreed to a settlement of this land claim without the need for a hearing by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner.

This is a positive development for a number of reasons. Not only did the Northern Territory government do something which for once showed a bit of thought in dealings with Aboriginal issues; it also saved a considerable amount of time and money. Most importantly, however, it will enable the handover of title to take place while the elderly traditional Aboriginal owners are still alive, something upon which they place enormous importance.

As already noted, because all parties agreed to the station being granted to an Aboriginal land trust under the act, there was no need for a hearing by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner. Therefore, the only way for the station to be granted a trust was by means of an amendment to schedule 1 of the act. Therefore, this is a very clear and well thought out process and a very positive development, and this government is pleased to bring this bill before the House to achieve this purpose. In enacting this bill, the government sees the practical and positive manifestation of our policy towards indigenous Australians and the broader goals of our social justice policy.

I understand that the opposition is supporting this legislation and therefore there is not a lot of controversy with the bill. Although in the scheme of things in this House it may be seen as a minor piece of legislation, for the Aboriginal people concerned it is a very major and positive development, and I am pleased that we are able to pass it with bipartisan support in the House.

While we are talking about the issues of land and social justice, I would also like to take the opportunity of congratulating the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation on the great document that it released last week called Going forward: social justice for the first Australians, which is in response to the request that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made to the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation to come forward with some ideas about what it believes should be put in the social justice statement that the government intends to make later this year. I am very pleased that my friend and colleague the member for Aston (Mr Nugent), the Liberal Party representative on the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, is here because I wish to convey to him my personal congratulations on the important role he played in achieving this document. I must say that I think it is an act of bravery on his part that he has signed it on behalf of the Liberal Party, endorsing—

TALK.START.PARA: —Bravery is code for something else.

—I see. It is brave to have endorsed all of the recommendations in this report, because there are some quite significant recommendations. I look forward to the Liberal Party of Australia supporting the implementation of many of these recommendations. I am not sure which ones of these the government will pick up, when they will be picked up, and what the process is. The government, of course, has only just received the document and is considering it in detail, as we have similarly just received the ATSIC document, which is its submission to the government on the social justice statement and also contains some important points.

PARA.TAB: What I think is so important about this booklet—and if other honourable members of the House have not yet read it I would urge them to do so—is that it puts together in one very valuable document the way forward for achievement of reconciliation. This House has unanimously endorsed the principles and the objectives of achieving reconciliation between the indigenous peoples of Australia and the non-indigenous peoples of Australia and this document, Going forward, gives us the very clear pathway towards achieving that.

One might use the term radical for some of the suggestions in here which will provoke discussion and debate, which was the very purpose for putting them in the document. As a parliament and as a House we need to have our preconceived ideas challenged from time to time. We need to do a little bit of lateral thinking. I do not think enough lateral thinking occurs in politics in this country. This document sets forward some very important and valuable suggestions. It does not say, `Thou shalt do this. Thou must do that.' It is not a letter of demand or an ambit claim by Aboriginal people. It is meant to be a means of promoting and stimulating discussion and consideration of very important issues, and I think people need to understand it in that context and not just summarily reject out of hand certain suggestions that are made in the book, without really thinking about what they are trying to achieve.

In this parliament and in the greater public domain there has been a lot of debate and discussion about constitutional reform and the Prime Minister is on the public record stating the agenda that he believes should be achieved in constitutional reform. One of the important things that is set out in this booklet is the plea by indigenous people in this country, saying, `If you are going to consider constitutional reform, you need to also consider indigenous Australians.' If you read the constitution of Australia, it ignores the very existence of an indigenous people. In 1991 the High Court of Australia pulled us up and told us that the myths that we had based our constitution on had to be torn up; that we had to face the reality that when European people first settled in this country there was prior occupation and ownership of this country.

The High Court forced us to do that because this parliament failed in that respect. Now we are saying that, if we are going to give some real meaning to that High Court decision, we need to look again at the constitution. We need to write within the constitution a recognition of the importance in the current structures of government of the prior occupation of this continent. I as a member of this parliament respect and strongly support those structures, but they are built on ignoring the fact that there was a prior civilisation occupying this continent which had a very strong culture and a very strong identity, and it has rights. Our constitution needs to recognise the existence of these people and that they were the owners of this continent. These people need to have their rights respected and recognised in the constitution. That is a very important issue that I think we in this parliament need to take up.

The document also raises a few other issues which I am sure some people are going to be a bit hesitant or nervous about. It talks about the lack of any parliamentary representation for indigenous people. Only one indigenous person has been elected to the federal parliament of Australia, and that was a senator from Queensland who represented the Liberal Party, Senator Neville Bonner. In 94 years of national parliament, with 1,000 or more politicians elected to either the Senate or the House of Representatives, it is a disgrace that there has been only one indigenous person in parliament. It is a disgrace that all political parties—my own included—need to think about.

We need to accept the challenge this document has set us. We need to accept that our political structures and the way in which our political parties operate are very exclusive. They exclude a lot of groups. In the way they operate, in the way they select members and in the way they select representatives for political office, most mainstream political parties in this country exclude indigenous people. We need to address that. This document says that we need to work around the great undemocratic injustice that exists.

We as representatives of major political parties should get Aboriginal and Islander people into our parliament and our parties, standing not just for major indigenous electorates—and there are a few electorates in this country which you may believe an indigenous person should represent—but for major urban electorates where there may not necessarily be large populations of indigenous people. Indigenous people with qualities, merit and ability should be elected. But our processes at the moment operate to make sure Aboriginal people do not feel comfortable about our political parties. They do not join the parties, they do not work within the parties and they certainly do not stand for political office.

This document has suggested that, to correct that anomaly, that undemocratic symbol, we may need to consider reserving seats in the parliament for indigenous people. It is not saying, `You shall do it.' It is not saying, `We demand this right.' It is saying, `This is something you need to consider.' It is floating the idea and saying, `We want you to seriously consider it.' That there are no indigenous people in this parliament is a very clear symbol of the lack of fairness, equity and social justice in this country. We have 223 parliamentary representatives in the Senate and the House of Representatives. Not one of them is an indigenous Australian. Indigenous people make up some 1.65 per cent of the population of Australia and a representative proportion of them in the parliament would be at least three people, probably four.

This booklet is saying that indigenous Australians are entitled to have three or four members of the parliament. It is saying that if mainstream political parties are not prepared to look at themselves and do something about this situation, perhaps three or four seats should be reserved in the federal parliament for indigenous Australians. That is not a unique concept. New Zealand has tried it and, while there have been some problems—I am not sure whether it is the way to go—I would not reject the suggestion out of hand. There are certainly things about the present situation that we need to seriously consider because it highlights one of many anomalies that exist in our society.

Australians tend to pride themselves on being an egalitarian and fair society—basically, we are—but there is one huge anomaly in that image and that is our treatment of indigenous Australians. I have participated in many debates in this parliament about the way in which we need to go forward. My views on Aboriginal health, housing, land rights and opportunities for employment in mainstream occupations are all on the public record.

I urge the parliament to seriously consider the submissions made by the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation in this booklet, titled Going forward. Since it was not tabled in the parliament it does not appear on the Notice Paper as an item for debate. However, because it outlines the agenda set by the council, it would assist if members included it in their contributions in debates on Aboriginal issues.

On another issue relating to land and recognition of Aboriginal interests, I would like to spend a few moments to comment on the issue which cost the member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) his shadow portfolio. The way in which those events unfolded, backbench members of the parliament did not have an opportunity to comment.

I was greatly disturbed by what occurred. I will not use this opportunity to try to score cheap political shots—that is not my style—but there are some very serious fundamental issues which, as a parliament, we need to look at. One of those issues is about respecting the rights of other people.

This is the International Year of Tolerance. Unfortunately, I do not think our parliament has exercised much tolerance in the first three or four months of this year. What most disturbed me about the events that unfolded with respect to the secret letters and the matters associated with them was not only the opening of private mail—that has already been heavily canvassed—but also, and more seriously, the absolute contempt for people's sacred religious beliefs that was demonstrated.

To me, it was like someone walking into St Peter's Cathedral and spitting on the altar. It was that type of action and it should be viewed as being as contemptible as that action would be viewed. It was a sign that some people in this place are prepared to go to any lengths to score political advantage and will use anybody's personal, private, secret, religious beliefs or views to distort a situation to their own political advantage.

That is why the member for Barker should have resigned. I know that he misled the House and formalities demand that if you mislead the House you give up your position. That is the reason he gave for resigning his position. But he should not hold any further shadow ministry position because he demonstrated such a clear and total contempt for the religious and sacred views of another group of people in our society. For that reason, he should never seriously be contemplated for another senior position in the opposition. His actions demonstrated that he does not have the personal qualities that Australians want to see in someone making important administrative decisions about the affairs of people in this country.

This is an important piece of legislation. I am pleased the Northern Territory government has supported it coming here. It is an interesting development for the Northern Territory, particularly when one looks at some of the other things the Northern Territory government has said. The Northern Territory government does not have a good record in its administration of Aboriginal affairs. It gains significant financial resources from the Commonwealth but is not expending those resources appropriately or in the way in which they were originally allocated.

This is of little surprise when we hear statements from people such as Shane Stone, a member of the ruling party in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly. He said that all the problems in the Northern Territory were the federal government's fault because we like to support Aboriginal people and we have a view that is strangling business interests because we are actually trying to give the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory some opportunity to live in a reasonable environment and to develop and assert themselves. One must remember that the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory account for more than 25 per cent of the population in the Northern Territory. It is a great disappointment to read statements from Shane Stone such as:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the simple fact is . . . that if Canberra was to get their hoof off our throat and get rid of absurd policies like . . . the Northern Territory Land Rights Act . . . we could get on with the business of making a dollar . . .

This statement shows that this member in the Northern Territory does not even support his coalition colleagues who were, in fact, the ones who introduced the Northern Territory land rights act. He is prepared to try to destroy the rights of Aboriginal people to have ownership of land so that he can make a dollar. He is not interested in the rights of the indigenous people—the traditional owners of this country. He is just interested in making a fast buck for himself and for people like him. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Vaile)—Before I call the honourable member for Aston, I might remind honourable members that we are debating the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 2). I would request members to restrict their comments to the subject of the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) for his generous comments about me. I am not too sure they will help me much, but thank you.

PARA.TAB: Very briefly, with your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker, after your directive: the honourable member raised a matter about the member for Barker (Mr McLachlan). It seems to me that, without going into detail, if he believes we will advance the welfare of the indigenous people of this country by taking a more cross-party line, once that matter is over—and his resignation seems to me to have brought that matter to a close—it does not serve a lot of purpose to keep dragging it up again in the future.

The honourable member made a comment about the Northern Territory government. We could stand here all day and exchange comments about what the Goss government has or has not done. I know the government is embarrassed about that.

The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 2) is a very simple bill. For those in the gallery, it is two paragraphs and, although I have not counted them, there are probably a couple of hundred words. It is a very straightforward bill, at least superficially. It says that under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 a particular portion of land, by agreement between the Northern Territory government, certain Aboriginal people and the federal government, will be transferred to Aboriginal ownership.

This is the 59th or 60th piece of land that has been so scheduled under this act in the last 18 or 19 years. I think we in this place all acknowledge that transferring land is a critical part of Aboriginal culture. They have a special attachment to the land, but the legislation has far more practical and, in my view, more far-reaching implications.

The federal government, the Northern Territory government and the indigenous people concerned have all agreed on this issue, so it is not contentious, and we could pass the legislation fairly quickly through the House. But it is important to look at some of the underlying features that are relevant to this piece of legislation and like legislation in action. The legislation was passed by the Liberal government in 1976 when the then minister was Ian Viner, who, to the government's credit, was recently appointed as the Deputy Chairman of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, which council produced the report Going forward that the previous speaker, the honourable member for Moreton, referred to at some length.

When we talk about passing land to Aboriginal people, it is more than just handing over a deed or a bit of paper and sitting back and forgetting all about it. There are some fundamental issues here. All members of this House, without exception, and increasingly the general public, will understand that the indigenous people in this country—a small percentage of the population—are, by any yardstick, significantly disadvantaged compared with the rest of the population.

The average male life expectancy is 18 years less than the broader community—for women it is 15 years less—and there is overcrowding in houses. The parliamentary secretary at the table, the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon), the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), who is sitting across the chamber, and I have been to communities where we have seen 20 or 30 people living in quite small three-bedroom houses with limited sanitation and so on. There is an almost permanent unemployment rate in Aboriginal communities of 70, 80 and sometimes 90 per cent. You do not need a recession to make it bad in Aboriginal communities; it is a fact of life throughout life. Aboriginal women have diabetes at a rate eight times that of the general population. In many Aboriginal schools 50 per cent of the children will have middle ear infections. So they have a health problem and an education problem, because if you cannot hear you certainly cannot learn. One can go on with the statistics.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I am sure you will recall that only recently we had tabled in this place a comprehensive report by the Australian Bureau of Statistics which documented in really quite appalling and frighteningly awful detail the disadvantages of indigenous people in this country. We all understand that it is a significant problem.

One of the sad things that I have learnt in the five years I have been in this chamber—a number of measures have been put in place over the years to try to address some of these problems—is that, as I go around, I do not see any real evidence that the situation is improving significantly at all. Certainly, the statistics do not suggest the situation is improving at all.

I am concerned that the government, which I have acknowledged previously in this place has good intentions to try to resolve the problems, in the last 12 years it has been here has not been successful in the various things it has done to improve the lot of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. We have had a number of initiatives. Money has been spent, organisations like ATSIC have been set up and health, education and language strategies have been put in place, but the reality is that those things have not worked very effectively at all. Therefore, we need to look at some new ways of dealing with that situation.

In my view, and most Aboriginal leaders whom I talk to have a very strong feeling about this, we have to break the welfare mentality—the fact that we just hand out money and people take it, and often it is regarded as sit-down money, but they still have nothing to do with their lives; that they are still living in appalling conditions; that they do not have the infrastructure or the sanitation; that the local council does not empty their dustbins; that the attendance rates at school are appalling; and that there is alcohol and substance abuse. For example, in the Pitjantjatjara lands I saw four-year-old kids sniffing petrol. It is quite appalling.

Those sorts of things are going on all the time. We have to try to break this whole cycle of poverty and disadvantage, and we will not improve the situation while we take what I believe is a paternalistic view and just hand out money and think that that will fix it. We have to look at some underlying changes to our philosophy. For example, in the whole criminal justice system, a 15- to 19-year-old Aboriginal youth is far more likely to be in gaol or in custody in some shape or form than a non-Aboriginal of the same age. It has

SPEECH.PARA: nothing to do with the colour of the skin. In a country where there is disadvantage in terms of employment, health, education and all those things, Aboriginals are going to get into trouble with the law anyway. But in Western Australia an Aboriginal of that age is 50 times more likely to be in custody than a non-Aboriginal of that age.

PARA.TAB: We have had inquiry after inquiry. We had the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, with 339 recommendations. The government has allocated millions of dollars to implement those recommendations. The government, the opposition and the state governments have accepted almost all those recommendations, and we have had voluminous reports tabled in this parliament every year saying how much effort has gone into implementing those reports. But the reality is that the bureaucracy has gone mad but we are not seeing much change on the ground.

Therefore, it is important that we start to look afresh. It seems to me that we have to get installed—or reinstalled—into the Aboriginal psyche in some shape or form some self-esteem, some pride and some determination to try to help themselves. That is not to put them down. But we cannot just say to them, `Here is some money. Get on your way.' We need to have a number of initiatives in place that will involve the Aboriginal people in decision making and in decisions of how money is spent. They also need to be given help from the ground upwards. We need to put in place a number of preventative measures rather than trying to fix problems after they have occurred.

For example, in the health area, yes, we need health centres, treatment, doctors and all those sorts of things. But, rather than having national health strategies that come from the federal government and go via the state governments—with regional bodies and ATSIC involved in the act and political stoushes as to whether the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence), the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), or ATSIC via the minister, have control—we ought to be looking more at the simple things that will fit in with Aboriginal culture, and we should put some responsibility in the communities so that people's time is occupied and they will start to take an interest in their welfare. For example, perhaps far more money should be put into community nursing so that the nurse goes along to the house and makes sure that little Johnny is eating properly, that the hygiene standards are in place and that he has his jabs when the doctor tells him to, and so on.

A fundamental change of attitude is needed. We need to get back to some more simple, straightforward, basic approach to dealing with some of these matters, and we have to get the Aboriginal community itself committed to doing some of those things instead of always sending in outsiders. Obviously outsiders will be needed for training, but we need to get the bureaucracy out of the way and some practical action in place on the ground.

It is important to Aboriginal people, if we are going to get them to take a larger degree of responsibility at the ground level for a number of these matters, that we give them self-respect and pride, that we get them off alcohol, and that we give them things to do in terms of work. It is important, therefore, that we acknowledge some of the symbolic things that will restore that pride and self-esteem. The grant of land is one way, and that is what this bill is all about. But other things need to be done.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), referred to the report of the Council of Aboriginal Reconciliation Going forward. One of the things mentioned in there is that there should be a recognition, in the preamble to the constitution, of indigenous prior occupation and ownership of this country before European settlement took place. It is an historical fact. It seems to me that, when the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation was set up, just such a preamble was included in the legislation. I have not noticed the heavens fall in since that legislation was passed, and I very much doubt if the heavens would fall in if it was in the constitution preamble. But it would be an important symbol for indigenous people to have that sort of recognition. It seems to me that, unless you undertake a few important symbolic things as well as some of the practical things, then you are never going to get on top of the problems and issues that I have been talking about.

The previous speaker also referred to representation in parliament. The council did not recommend that there be separate indigenous seats in the parliament. It said very specifically that it was an issue that was raised by many indigenous people during the consultation process. It is an issue that, in consultation with the wider community, a number of people raised as well, and it is therefore something that needs to be looked at and understood, and perhaps debated. If there is general community and bipartisan support, then you would perhaps go to a referendum to give effect to that. But, if there is no general community support, the council says you would not proceed because it would be divisive—and that does not do anybody any good, particularly the indigenous people in this country.

There are a number of things in the report that emphasise the sort of thing we are talking about in this bill in terms of land and also indigenous people's basic rights—the same rights anybody who sits in this chamber would have. We all have normal expectations that our dustbins will be emptied, water supplied, our roads made up, sewerage facilities supplied—all those things—and, as citizens, Aboriginal people should also have those things. The report also talks about Aboriginal people having rights to acknowledgment as well. I do not think any of us, if we are treated as second-class citizens, would have the self-esteem to be able to get ourselves out of some of the practical problems that would then beset us, and Aboriginal people are no different.

When we pass a fairly straightforward, simple piece of legislation such as this, it is important to remember the underlying issues that are behind it. It is not just a question of saying, `Here is a bit of dirt that we are going to give to Aboriginal people.' That is important. They may live on it, they may work it, they may or may not make profits out of it, but it is part of an overall package of activity. It is an amendment to a piece of legislation of which the Liberal Party has always been proud—and justifiably so—and it is part of an ongoing battle to try to make sure that we do treat our indigenous people better. I certainly commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am also pleased to participate in the debate on the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 2). As the member for Aston (Mr Nugent) said, this bill, which we are in the process of considering at present, is probably one of the briefest pieces of legislation to become before the parliament. That of course belies the importance of it. It is extremely important.

PARA.TAB: The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mr Snowdon), who represents the Northern Territory—the area about which this piece of legislation is concerned—and the constituents that occupy that area, is at the table. The fact that he is in the federal parliament representing the Northern Territory with the overwhelming support which he has been able to gain and maintain indicates the way in which he and his colleague Senator Bob Collins are respected by the constituents which they represent so effectively in the Northern Territory.

As has been indicated, this legislation refers to the Hodgson Downs property in the Northern Territory. The purpose of this legislation is to transfer it to the Aboriginal people, the traditional owners of that land, and the people who occupy that land. I acknowledge that the reason this legislative approach is being used on this occasion is that it was possible to get agreement between the Northern Territory government, the Aboriginal claimants and the Northern Territory Land Council in order to undertake this process of having that land transferred to them.

It is an area of something in excess of 3,000 square kilometres. It is a cattle station south east of Mataranka in the Northern Territory. It was purchased by ATSIC in 1991. The property contains a great many sacred sites of significance and has a population of 240 Aboriginal people. It continues to operate as a commercial cattle station. The member for Aston, the Liberal member who preceded me, made a number of observations, many of which I would agree with and many of which I would not.

The member for Aston is one of the better informed members of the opposition in relation to Aboriginal people in Australia. He is one of those relatively few members of the opposition who have some sympathy for Aboriginal people, some understanding of their background and the circumstances which they face as a minority people who originally owned and occupied the whole of the Australian land mass 200 years ago. Some say the Europeans invaded; others say they settled. I do not think the question is so important. Certainly, the opportunity occurred 200 years ago for white Europeans to take from the Aboriginal people in Australia, sometimes under horrendous circumstances, land which those people had previously occupied and owned. I think it is to the credit of those three organisations that that agreement was reached.

It is not always the case that agreements between responsible people and responsible organisations in Australia are able to be achieved in order to achieve, in turn, a proper outcome for those people most affected by it. It is interesting that we are amending the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act, which was introduced initially in 1975 by the Whitlam government. That legislation followed the findings of a royal commission which was appointed by the Whitlam government in 1973. The royal commission was chaired by Justice A.E. Woodward and became known as the Woodward royal commission.

The findings of that royal commission were essentially incorporated in the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Bill 1975, which was introduced by the then Labor Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Les Johnson. In the process of introducing that legislation, Les Johnson said:

SPEECH.PARA: In the field of Aboriginal affairs, this is undoubtedly the most important legislation ever to be introduced into the Australian Parliament. While several States have moved towards the recognition of Aboriginal land rights, this legislation goes much further than has previously been contemplated in Australia. This Bill will give effect to the recommendations of the second report of the Aboriginal Land Rights Commission—the Woodward report—and grant land rights to Aboriginals in the Northern Territory. It will provide for freehold title over all reserves and certain other lands to be vested in Aboriginal ownership and give Aboriginals control over what happens on their land, including control over mining developments.

Major political changes took place after that, with the sacking of the Whitlam government at the end of 1975, and that particular legislation lapsed. Fortunately, it was reintroduced under the Fraser government by the then Minister Viner. The interesting thing is that, while the opposition continues to claim credit for many of these initiatives, an examination showed that it so frequently sought to thwart, frustrate and obfuscate—to place obstacles generally in the way of—significant initiatives being taken.

PARA.TAB: That October 1975 Labor land rights bill followed 15 months of investigation by Justice Woodward. It followed a further 18 months of consultation with Aboriginal groups. In the process of Labor dealing with that legislation, the coalition opposition, the conservative opposition, sought to refer the bill to a standing committee for a further report. That is typical: delays compounding delays. That has always been the tactic.

It disappoints me because I know that there is goodwill on the part of many members of the opposition in connection with Aboriginal people, Aboriginal interests and Aboriginal rights. But they make collective decisions which are intended deliberately to place obstacles in the way of significant initiatives being introduced and significant initiatives being achieved.

In June 1976 Mr Ian Viner introduced the Aboriginal land rights bill which followed on, as I say, from that Labor legislation which was initiated during the period of the Whitlam government. In November 1976 debate was resumed by a conservative coalition government and that government itself was responsible for introducing 42 amendments. A conservative coalition government introduced 42 amendments in 1976 after it became responsible for that legislation. We do not need much more evidence than that to prove the claim I make that, to a very large extent, the conservative coalition's position in relation to many of these issues concerning Aboriginals and Aboriginal interests would appear to be less than genuine.

Mr Deputy Speaker Vaile, I exclude you and those of your colleagues who participate so actively and so conscientiously in the consideration which this parliament gives to questions concerning Aboriginals from any of those comments about the opposition in general, about the conservative coalition in general. I exclude you personally; I exclude the member for Aston; I exclude the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl); and I exclude those other members who have worked conscientiously towards the achievement of justice for Aboriginal people.

We all remember Senator Neville Bonner. I rejoiced—as you did, Mr Deputy Speaker, I am sure—when Neville Bonner, a proud Aborigine, was elected to the Senate on a Liberal Party ticket. I then deplored the fact that Neville Bonner disappeared from the Senate when he was relegated to the third, unwinnable place on the Senate ticket by the Liberal Party as a result of the fact that Neville Bonner was speaking out for Aboriginal people, for people from his own race. No-one can deny that. It was a deliberate act by the Liberal Party to place Neville Bonner in an unwinnable position.

I think Ernie Bridge, a shadow minister in Western Australia, is the only parliamentarian in Australia at present of Aboriginal extraction—except perhaps in the Northern Territory—and he is a Labor member. Your Senator Neville Bonner is no longer here. The Liberal Party gave him an unwinnable third place on the ticket.

In 1976 when Les Johnson was responding to that legislation introduced by Ian Viner, he also referred to his concern that 42 government amendments had been introduced to its own legislation in order to delay it and to achieve whatever other objectives it had set out to achieve in connection with it.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I would just like to mention some of the comments that were made by former colleagues of you and your present colleagues in the conservative coalition. Mr Kevin Cairns, a former member of the Liberal Party from an electorate in Brisbane, said in relation to that legislation:
The Government has introduced this legislation knowing that there has to be social harmony, and that is enshrined in this land legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Billy Wentworth, who I think was going to attempt to rejoin the upper house in New South Wales—a direct descendant of the original W.C. Wentworth, who, together with his two mates, found a route across the Blue Mountains—was recognised and is recognised today as a person with a genuine interest in Aboriginal problems and Aboriginal people. He said in relation to that bill:

PARA.TAB: The Bill deals with traditional land and the rights of traditional Aboriginals are worth protecting. If we have any decency we will look to these people about whose land we are talking in this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Philip Ruddock, who was then the member for Parramatta and is now a frontbench member of the opposition—another Liberal member—said:

. . . something which I see as important and which Mr Justice Woodward saw as important, and that is a recognition of a fundamental principle to Aborigines—their sense of Aboriginality was their affinity with land.

Increasingly now that is being recognised. It was recognised in an important and historic way by the High Court in its Mabo decision. It has been entrenched in an important and historic way by this government in the legislation which grew from that, the land fund legislation, and every time that this present Labor government acts in relation to Aboriginal questions and Aboriginal land.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that there appears to be an impression that, right from the start of British and European colonialism—when they invaded, occupied and expropriated the land of native people, wherever that happened to be—there was a failure to recognise those interests. That is not so. Initially, to a very large extent, the rights of indigenous people, wherever they happened to live, were respected and were expected to be respected by those people who acted on behalf of the Crown. Let me give some examples. George III—who was the King of England towards the end of the 18th century, at the time that Australia was first `discovered' by Cook—in 1763 said:

And whereas it is just and reasonable, and essential to our interests, and the security of our colonies, that the several nations or tribes of Indians with whom we are connected, and who live under our protection, should not be molested or disturbed in the possession of such parts of our dominions . . .

SPEECH.PARA: George III, a British monarch, was making a declaration about the rights of native people in their own lands to be respected—not to be molested—by those people who acted for George III as the monarch of England. One of the instructions given to James Cook when he was sailing in the south-west Pacific and representing the interests of Great Britain was worded in this way:

PARA.TAB: You are also with the Consent of the Natives to take possession of Convenient Situations in the Country in the Name of the King . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I emphasise `with the consent of the natives'. One of the instructions Governor Phillip was given when he came out to make the first European settlement of Sydney Cove in relation to Australian Aborigines stated:
You will conciliate their affections.

He was not told to come here and authorise or encourage shooting expeditions against Aboriginal people of a weekend. He was not instructed to come here and encourage and facilitate the taking away of children from their Aboriginal parents. He was not authorised to come here and facilitate or encourage the poisoning of Aboriginal waterholes. Nor was he given permission to come here and encourage or facilitate the poisoning of flour which was then handed to Aboriginal people. No, he was not.

PARA.TAB: The following direction was issued in respect of South Australia as late as 1836. South Australia then was a British colony; subsequently it became a state of this Commonwealth.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Vaile)—I would remind the honourable member the bill is about the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —And I would remind you, with respect, Mr Deputy Speaker, as well that it is about Aboriginal land rights, and that is what I am talking about. Let me get this on the record. In relation to South Australia it was said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . provided always that nothing in these our Letters Patent contained shall affect or be construed to affect the rights of any Aboriginal Natives of the said Province to the actual occupation or enjoyment of their own persons. . . of any lands. . .

Yes, we are talking about land, Mr Deputy Speaker; I agree. We are talking about land in the Northern Territory, a territory of this Commonwealth, which traditionally has been owned, occupied and used by Aboriginal people and which is now being used as a cattle station by the 240 Aboriginal people who occupy it.

PARA.TAB: We are talking about an agreement that was reached between three responsible authorities, including the Northern Territory government, to ensure that the transfer of this land, which was bought by ATSIC a few years ago, could be made to those occupants, and it is to the credit of all those who participated in it. All of us in Australia, in a conscientious way and in a state of increasing awareness about the role and position of white Australians on this continent, increasingly are coming to understand in a more reasonable way the position that we occupy and the responsibilities that we have.

I will close on this point. When addressing many of these questions I have always made the point that white Australians today should feel no guilt about the historic realities of the past but that we need to accept them, to understand them, and to ensure that the inequities and the injustices which developed on this continent as a result of administration by white authorities over the last 200 years will not persist and that justice will finally prevail. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing this Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 2), I wish to review the role played by the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 in the ongoing debate on Aboriginal land rights and mining. At the outset I wish to state unequivocally that there is no benefit for Aborigines or other Australians in politicising this issue or in taking an extremist position. The sole aim of any person who enters the debate should be to move the issues forward.

PARA.TAB: In this regard no-one who has seen the survey of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander population recently released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics could fail to be moved by the implications of those stark facts. I remind the House that the report noted an unemployment rate of 38 per cent overall with a rate of 50 per cent for those Aborigines aged between 15 and 19 years. Of the 40,200 unemployed persons, 77 per cent had been unemployed for three months or longer, and over 50 per cent had been unemployed for 12 months or longer. Examining health related issues, the survey found that 17 per cent of rural Aboriginal households did not have doctors available at all, or that they were available less than once per month, while 54 per cent did not have access to dentists and 74 per cent did not have mental health services available.

It is a truism that there is no simple panacea to improve this utterly unacceptable situation. Aboriginal communities are diverse with very different needs and circumstances. For example, more than 50 per cent of the Aboriginal population across the Northern Territory, Western Australia and Queensland live in communities of 1,000 or less.

In those communities there are widely differing government jurisdictions and employment opportunities and many other historical, cultural and social factors contributing to their present situation. Such complexity defies simple analysis, yet it is my belief that the issues are becoming clearer, particularly as they relate to economic advancement for Aborigines. For instance, there is a clear perception among the community and decision makers that economic advancement provides a significant platform of opportunity to benefit Aborigines. The entitlement to the safety net of welfare assistance is a right that no needy Australian should be denied, yet beyond the safety net economic independence is the cornerstone of self-determination for any community.

The granting of land rights through the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 was a significant step towards economic advancement for Aborigines in the Northern Territory, particularly through mining ventures. This act established mechanisms for negotiating the exploration and mining of minerals on Aboriginal lands and the use of the resultant royalties for Aboriginal advancement. The act created Aboriginal land trusts to receive grants of inalienable freehold title to Aboriginal land, with property rights to minerals retained by the Crown. Land councils were also created to act as agents for the traditional owners on land matters and to negotiate terms and conditions for exploration and mining with an independent arbitrator if an agreement could not be reached. Equivalent amounts to the mining royalties returned to the Commonwealth or Northern Territory governments were to be paid into the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account.

Forty per cent of the funds obtained were to be divided between the land councils as general funds, with 30 per cent to be paid to the land council in whose district the mine was located, and intended for the affected Aboriginal community. The balance of 30 per cent was to be distributed between Northern Territory Aborigines as a whole, as payments to cover administration of the trust account and as further payments to the land councils if they could not cover their expenses from other payments. Anyone wishing to explore for minerals or acquire a mining interest over land granted to Aboriginal owners had to negotiate through the relevant land council. The act provided that the consent of the relevant land council and the Commonwealth minister was required before either exploration or mining was allowed on Aboriginal land.

Since its proclamation on Australia Day 1977, the act has been subject to considerable amendment. In 1987, in response to claims that the legislation was unworkable and was inhibiting resource development in the Northern Territory, the act was amended to remove the right of Aboriginal owners to veto mining if they had previously agreed to exploration. Amendments at the same time required traditional owners to decide on new mining proposals within 12 months, with the possibility of extension. If an exploration proposal was rejected, then no further applications could be made for five years.

In 1991, the Industry Commission, in its report on mining and minerals processing in Australia, examined the operation of this legislation as it applied to mining investment. In addressing the effectiveness of the legislation, the Industry Commission said:

SPEECH.PARA: The holding of land rights by Aborigines may lead to smaller levels of mining . . . activity in the Territory relative to those which would have occurred. However, provided Aboriginal landowners face appropriate incentives, it would be wrong to conclude from this that land and sub-surface resources were not being devoted to their socially optimal use. In this sense, the . . . real test of the workability of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 is not necessarily the amount of land under exploration, or the number of mines on Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory, but rather the extent to which Aboriginal landowners are able to freely exercise their ability to withhold or grant consent for exploration and mining.

The key point that I wish to draw out of this conclusion by the Industry Commission is that, for natural justice to prevail, the traditional landowners must be able to make a completely informed decision on an exploration or mining proposal. Thus they must be able to assess the incentives offered by the developer, negotiate on these incentives and then decide whether the benefits outweigh the possible disadvantages.

PARA.TAB: Looked at this way, the point of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act is to facilitate the negotiation process so that all parties achieve a positive outcome. So has the act achieved its goal? In 1991 the Industry Commission concluded that:

SPEECH.PARA: The current institutional arrangements for dealing with applications to explore and mine on Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory are not working well. . . Communication is poor and there is little trust.
While there is widespread agreement that the existing system is unsatisfactory, views on the causes of the problems and the possible solutions vary considerably.
This analysis is just as valid four years on.

PARA.TAB: For instance, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Marshall Perron, wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) at the beginning of February this year seeking discussions on amendments to the act, including mining leases. But this government is not interested.
On 28 September last year, the federal Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) wrote to the Australian saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Because of a range of significant developments since 1992, there are no plans to initiate further consultations over possible amendments to the Act.
This followed a commitment in April 1991, when the minister himself said the recommendations of the Industry Commission report:
would need to be considered by the Government in consultation with Aboriginal traditional landowners, the Northern Territory Aboriginal Land Councils and the Northern Territory Government.
The only action to result from this promise of consultation was the cabinet submission from the member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths), the then Minister for Resources.

PARA.TAB: As revealed in the Australian in September last year, the January 1993 cabinet submission recommended the implementation of most of the Industry Commission's recommendations. However, the submission was withdrawn at the last moment.

The significant developments since 1992 referred to by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs must surely include the Mabo decision and the advent of the Native Title Act. Yet these developments are reasons why the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 needs to be revisited. The Native Title Act provided an opportunity to institute a streamlined, national administrative system for land rights.
Instead, the Northern Territory now has two pieces of Commonwealth legislation addressing native title issues from different perspectives, and with no effective resolution of the overlapping issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you repeal them, though?

—No, we certainly would not repeal the veto. We want more negotiations directly between proponents of developments and the traditional landowners themselves. We certainly do not believe there are anywhere near enough negotiations between those directly affected and those who propose development.

PARA.TAB: The veto held by traditional owners in the Northern Territory is an issue to a great many people because they believe that the veto inhibits, if not prevents, this direct negotiation between traditional landowners and developers. I certainly would not abolish the veto, but I do not want to see the veto used to quash direct negotiations.
So the issue of uncertainty for Australian resources investment is very significant across the country. The mining sector confers enormous benefits on Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians alike.

In the Northern Territory the mining industry generates one-quarter of the territory's national product; employs three per cent of the work force; and has a turnover of around $1 billion per year. For Aborigines in the Northern Territory, some $300 million has been paid in royalties under the auspices of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act.

On a national level, it is worth reminding the House that the resources sector provides some $30 billion in exports, or half of Australia's merchandise exports, and employs 90,000 people directly with a further 400,000 in manufacturing and energy industries based on mining inputs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3 p.m. the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The member for Gippsland will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister agree with the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Bernie Fraser, who said a short time ago in Sydney that popular concerns that the Australian economy is in danger of lapsing into our old boom-bust ways, with the current account careering out of control, are legitimate concerns for policy makers at this time? Does the Prime Minister also agree with his statement that further tightening of monetary policy has to remain on the agenda, and that even a good budget would not necessarily rule out further interest rate adjustments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recently had Mr Fraser's speech communicated to me. I must say that I think it reflects all the balance and good judgment inherent in most things he does and says. In reference to the first question asked by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Fraser said:

ANSWER.PARA: These are legitimate concerns for policy makers at this time but—
and this is the part the Leader of the Opposition did not read—
I believe more than some others, perhaps, that they will be managed satisfactorily.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about interest rates?
—I think that he goes on to make a very balanced speech. If you tell me what page you are referring to, I will go to it.
—Would you like my annotated copy?
—No, it was embargoed for 1.20 p.m.
—It's 3 o'clock.
—It's 3 o'clock.

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.
—Do you want a serious answer or do you want to play silly games? What page are you referring to? Tell me what page.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat!

—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat and the honourable member for Mayo will sit quietly. The Prime Minister will answer the question and he will give his remarks through the chair.

—I can think of no better example of form rather than substance than the little stunt the Leader of the Opposition just put on here. I have read the speech and I have my own markings on it. There are a number of references to monetary policy and wages. Mr Fraser says he believes the government will introduce a good budget. He is correct in that. Mr Fraser said:

ANSWER.PARA: On the basis of current government projections, the budget deficit would decline from 2.7 per cent of GDP in 1994-95 to a surplus in 1996-97.
I am confident the government will deliver an improvement of at least this order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly. Earlier, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: Viewed in these terms, a good budget could be seen as easing the pressure for possible further monetary policy tightening. That is true. But even a good budget would not necessarily rule out further interest rate adjustments. For one thing, we could not be sure that such a budget would cause the economy to slow sufficiently, partly given the favourable effects it could have on confidence generally.
In other words, he is saying that a well delivered and well received budget will actually add to confidence itself, and that that may be a spurt to growth.

PARA.TAB: Why is he saying that? One of the reasons he is saying that is that he was Secretary to the Department of the Treasury in the 1980s. As the government kept reducing those big budget surpluses and cutting government spending, as that contracted from activity on the public sector side of the economy, it added to private sector activity because there was far more confidence about the economic settings. That is the point he was making there. It is a sophisticated point. That is why it got past you.
Mr Fraser also has some references to wages, which I agree with. He says:

ANSWER.PARA: I think some commentators assume too readily that there will be major slippage on wages.

I agree with him on that. The record has shown that this government has introduced a contestable economy in this country by removing tariff barriers and by introducing enterprise bargaining. We are getting natural growth in productivity and that is holding down wage costs. As well as that, we are seeing a general understanding by the work force about wages growth. Mr Fraser is talking about four to five per cent. When the Leader of the Opposition was last Treasurer, it was 16 per cent. Is it any wonder we were uncompetitive.

PARA.TAB: Let me make this point—I made it in a speech last night but let me make it again today—in the period between 1983 and now, Australia's international competitiveness has improved by 40 per cent. In the eight years between 1975 and 1983 it increased by nothing—there was no change in underlying competitiveness during the whole period of the opposition leader's tenure as Treasurer. In the years since, our competitiveness has improved by 40 per cent. So when Bernie Fraser makes—
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know you don't like the answers. I often say to you: you don't ask me many questions because you don't like the answers.

PARA.TAB: That is why, when Bernie Fraser makes a reference to four or five per cent growth, it is a reference by somebody who knows what that sort of decay in the economic system—the wages policy that was there under the former Treasurer—does. Let me conclude on this point: Mr Fraser's speech, in my reading of it, is a balanced assessment—
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I know, in just an hour, with everything else that I have to do, I have read it.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not like you, sitting idly over there, thinking up games or thinking how senators can drop people's tax information into the public arena—which is your long suit. Let me complete on that point.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Can he advise the House whether today's current account deficit figure is consistent with official forecasts? What do the components of the current account deficit indicate about future growth prospects?

—Today's current account figures for the month of February are quite consistent with the mid-year review forecast for the current account outcome for this year. As well as being consistent, we have an outcome which has some encouraging signs.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, it is five per cent less than for the previous month, which is a good development. Also, the composition of the factors that produced that outcome are quite encouraging. Merchandise exports increased by four per cent but merchandise imports increased by only one per cent. Clearly, the movements in that area are in the right direction for us.

In relation to exports, I make a couple of points. Firstly, the impact of the drought is showing through, particularly in regard to cereal exports which, in the last three months, are 43 per cent down on what they were in the same three months of the previous year. We are seeing drought having quite an impact in some areas of rural exports, particularly in relation to cereals.

Despite that, total exports for February were at their highest level ever. There are some encouraging signs in regard to non-rural exports. The figure for non-rural exports was the highest ever. For non-rural commodity exports, which have been trending down for the year to September of last year, we are seeing increasing signs that that is being reversed. We are seeing a pick-up in both volumes and prices.

The rise in imports of one per cent was entirely due to imports of capital goods, which went up by 13 per cent. That, of course, reflects the fact that investment is growing strongly. With a 24 per cent increase in investment now forecast—a figure that the opposition said was impossible to believe; it said that 14 per cent was impossible—we expect to see strong capital imports. That is what we have here. That is a good thing, because it means we have a greater capacity to sustain economic growth and employment in the future. It also means that we avoid high capacity utilisation ratios. If you have very high ratios, it means that there is a situation in which inflation can easily take off. Imports in areas such as consumption goods are down six per cent and imports of intermediate goods are down one per cent. So, on the import side, the general picture shows some degree of encouragement.

We want to have sustainable growth for the future. It means lesser growth than the five per cent to six per cent growth that we are currently experiencing—a point that Mr Fraser made in his speech. I can say in that respect—and since this is the last sitting day before the budget—that the budget will be designed to achieve a more sustainable rate of economic growth. It will be designed to achieve a better balance of demand and growth so that we do not have demand spilling over into imports. It will also be designed to achieve a structural improvement in savings in this country so that we can continue to experience substantial growth without a balance of payments constraint.

I make one other point. I notice the Greens have been saying that they will not cooperate with the budget, in the sense that they do not think we need to have a reduction in the deficit. They do not believe in the twin deficit theory. We are not pushing twin deficit theory here. We are not saying that it automatically follows that if you reduce the budget deficit you reduce the current account deficit, but we do say it goes in the right direction.

The key issue here is the savings investment balance. If you have strong investment, you need to have stronger savings. If you do not do that, you will certainly have a large current account outcome. In the circumstances we face with strong investment, it is crucially important that we improve our savings performance. That is what the budget will, in part, be designed to achieve.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, in 1987 you said, `The worst is over,' about the current account deficit. But since then Australia has been whacked with a further $130,000 million worth of current account deficits and our foreign debt has doubled to $162,000 million. In 1990 you deliberately engineered the worst recession since the Great Depression to solve the problem. With Australia now in the middle of yet another current account crisis, how will you try to solve it this time? Given that a long recession and a short recovery did not fix the problem, is it not a fact that a lasting solution to the problem is completely beyond your capacity to deliver?

—The current account deficit was six per cent of GDP in the Leader of the Opposition's second last year in office as Treasurer. Let me just correct the claim that he often makes about the recession. The deepest recession since the war was in his term as Treasurer. If you doubt that, just go to the Statistician and have a look at the loss of product during the last recession and the loss of product during yours. If you doubt it, it is simply a matter of record.
—John Kerin should answer it.
—Order! The Prime Minister is answering the question.

—In terms of the change, this is the first time, the first period, in Australia's history where rural and resource exports form the majority of our exports—the very first time. This is the first time when manufactured exports and services predominate in the Australian balance of payments and balance of trade.

PARA.TAB: That is an enormous structural sea change for Australia. It occurred by a shift in manufacturing production, manufacturing exports and exports generally which has improved our capacity in relation to the current account. The terms of trade have been running against Australia for a long time. That is, in the early postwar years the things that Australia traditionally exported commanded very high prices and the things it imported commanded low prices. Therefore, our standard of living rose. In the 40 years since the war, we have had a complete reversal of that: the things that command the high prices are the products with intellectual innovation in them and the things that command the low prices are the bulk traded commodities—agriculture and minerals—and this has seen our terms of trade fall dramatically.

It was the constant fall in those terms of trade that the Liberal Party, when in office, never picked up on. The Liberal Party made no change to our manufacturing structure to make the adjustment for when it happened. The salvation coming from higher exports and from the shift in the composition to manufacturing and services was delivered by this government. It was delivered by this government because, had we relied on the same composition of exports as John Howard was prepared to rely on from 1977 to 1983, Australia would be absolutely dead in the water. We would have a recession prone and massively interest rate ridden economy of the variety we have seen in other parts of the world.

The change was the belief on this side of the House that the notion that you could not have a competitive manufacturing sector sitting beside an internationally competitive primary exports sector was a nonsense and that, by a change in our education system—a change in participation in education and tertiary education and in research and development—our product innovation would rise and, with a 40 per cent change in competitiveness, we could find exports of manufactures and exports of services growing. That is why for the first time ever we now find ourselves no longer in the position where we are a majority rural and resources exporter. As a consequence, exports—

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, wind it up.
—You asked the question; you can listen to the answer. As a consequence, exports have risen from 13 per cent of GDP, way down the end of the OECD league table—
—Why don't you abuse him?
—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell is not helping.

—to 22 per cent. Exports have gone up from 13 to 22 per cent of GDP, that is, by eight to nine per cent of GDP—by $36 billion a year or thereabouts. Could you imagine the hole we would be in without that change under this government? Could you imagine the ambient economic climate if we were now exporting $30 billion to $35 billion less in terms of GDP, less in terms of those overall exports?

PARA.TAB: That is the sea change. The other sea change is that the proportion of our exports which now goes to our debt service component has dropped from 21 per cent to 11 per cent. We have seen our capacity to service our debt change dramatically as a proportion of our gross domestic product.

These are the two core matters that the Leader of the Opposition is quite happy to forget about. That is, he would not have had the wit or the capacity as an individual or as a party of government to make this enormous change in the nature of our export base to reinvigorate our manufacturing, tertiary and service sectors. The members of the opposition could never have done it, and they showed in office that they were incapable of doing it. That is where the fundamentals have changed. Another fundamental that is worth noting is that wage inflation is now under control. Last quarter's data show an overall annual increase of 4.1 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Speaker, under standing order 145. The question specifically asked what the Prime Minister was going to do in the future, not what had happened in the past. We have had enough of the ancient history lesson. Why does he not tell us what he is going to do in the future?
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. The Prime Minister is in order.

—Low inflation, low wages growth, a low level of strike activity—and still falling—are some of the other fundamentals of our competitiveness which make this change a climate change and not simply a one-off change.

PARA.TAB: I just say about the current level of the current account that the unsynchronised nature of the world recovery has meant that Australian demand for imports has picked up ahead of world demand for Australian exports. When that world economy gets into better synchronisation, we will have a better outcome. So let the Leader of the Opposition not dupe himself, even if he is prepared to dupe his party or the public, into believing that he ever had any solutions for dealing with the current account at source—a fundamental change in manufacturing services. Let him very clearly understand that the climatic change in inflation, wages growth, competitiveness, product innovation, education, manufactured exports and services is the only salvation for a country that let itself be lured into the dangerous position of relying exclusively on agriculture and mining, to our long-term detriment.
