—I ask the Prime Minister: Is he aware that the whole theme of the Liberal campaign for the Canberra by-election was, `Don't let Labor take you for granted'? Given that the Prime Minister's reaction this week has been unrepentant, I ask the Prime Minister: have you listened to the people? What was the message you heard? Will you now tell my new constituents, many of them former Labor voters, whether or not their interest rates and taxes will go up again?
—Mr Speaker—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Mr Acting Speaker, when we get past this guffawing hyena opposite, I will give an answer.
—Mr Acting Speaker—
—The honourable member for Warringah had better have a point of order.
—You have the situation well under control, Mr Acting Speaker.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Warringah.

—This is my first opportunity to see the member for Canberra. I am glad to take his first question, and naturally I congratulate him on his victory. Of course I do. I sat almost in the same position in the old parliament when I first came here.
—Oh, very interesting!

—I did. It is very interesting. It was 26 years ago, and I used to ask John Gorton questions. The burden of the question from the honourable member was about the consequences and impact of interest rates on his electorate. The matters that we debated earlier in question time—references to things said by the Governor of the Reserve Bank, the attendant outcome on inflation, his references to wages—are the core matters in respect of interest rates. Who has the policies to keep wages growth in this country consistent with low inflation?

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Not you.

TALK.START.PARA: —We got it there. Why would you say not us? The other question is whether, in terms of activity in the economy, the early, but I believe timely, increases in interest rates by the government to slow the recovery and make it sustainable have not in the long run been entirely in the best interests of the economy and the community at large. As a consequence of the things the Treasurer eloquently said earlier, the government will, between now and the next sitting of the House, bring in a budget. Both he and I have said that the import of that budget will be, we believe, to make further interest rate increases less likely.

PARA.TAB: There is only one way to low interest rates in this country; that is, through low inflation and a proper balance between the demand and supply sides of the economy. I cannot tell the honourable member—because he was not around at that time, obviously—this was never so under his party in office. The Leader of the Opposition, when Treasurer, had wages growth of 16 per cent, and he did not know what to do about it. When the last big wage round came through, Malcolm Fraser caught a plane to England to see the royal wedding; do you remember that? When wages blew out—they were right on the table—instead of staying and fixing it and dealing with it or doing his best, Malcolm Fraser jumped on the plane and went to the royal wedding. The wedding present we got was the 16 per cent wages growth which followed.

That is why interest rates peaked under the now Leader of the Opposition at 22 per cent. It is no mystery where the 22 per cent came from; it was the high inflation from the 16 per cent wages growth plus the real interest rate. When you compare that to 10 per cent or nine per cent interest rates today, or 8 3/4 per cent for bills, it is a far cry from anything the federal Liberal Party was able to deliver. I hope for your sake that your party can understand what the influences on inflation are and understand that no mayhem wages system will deliver wage restraint and at the same time, in the doing of that, produce high productivity which reduces wages costs and holds inflation down.

I think they are the central matters in the price and inflation equation. I hope that, as I did sitting in that place so long ago at his age, he can come and learn some of the lessons of economic policy as we saw the Liberal Party's disasters occur one after the other.

Let me give you this little bit of commentary on history: in the last year that the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer, he was the most worried person in the world. After we became the government he was the happiest, because all of a sudden the burden had shifted to some crowd who could actually do something about it. He works on the basis that if you stay here long enough the cycle will repeat itself. That is the one part of the lesson you should not take any notice of.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Is the minister aware of reports that unmet demand for higher education has fallen this year? Can the minister confirm these reports and advise the House whether this will impact on the government's funding commitments to higher education?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. Preliminary indications are that unmet demand for university places will be down eight per cent this year over last year. There are two significant reasons why that circumstance has come about: firstly, we have put more places into universities; and, secondly, there are far more jobs available for people to choose to go to.

PARA.TAB: The significant indicator is that, since 1983, the probability of a student completing year 12 and going on to university has doubled. It has gone up from 15 per cent to 30 per cent. It has gone up because of our policies. Our policies have been committed to massively expanding the higher education sector; policies that we will persist with and that we have developed without having to resort to up-front fees for undergraduate students.

Last election, the Liberals went to the campaign on a policy of fees and vouchers for funding universities. Their justification then was: `If we allow overseas students to pay for places, why don't we let our own students pay for places?' Where is the equity in the argument which says that our own people have to pay up-front to get into universities? Where is the equity in that?

This week we have seen a surprising about-face by the opposition in this direction because the shadow spokesman on higher education, Senator Hill, does not believe in fees any more. In a radio interview on 28 March, in justification of this position, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: Now that the situation has changed somewhat in that there has been a stabilisation of the number of students, there is not the demand now.
There is a simple point of contrast between that statement, which was made on 28 March, and what the Leader of the Opposition had to say just four days before. He said:
One of the big problems with tertiary education in Australia is that every year there are thousands of young Australians who are shut out of tertiary education and there aren't enough places.

His shadow spokesman said that we do not need to raise fees because there are sufficient places; yet he said four days before that there are not enough places. The message out of that is twofold. The first is that they will say anything to suit the occasion and the second is that, if demand for places does go up, the Liberal Party will resort to fees to fund them, because the only basis upon which it has ruled them out now is that the demand does not justify it.

PARA.TAB: The students also have another concern—that universities, through their commercial arms, are seeking by the backdoor to charge up-front fees. In the House yesterday I indicated quite clearly what our position was on that, but the shadow spokesman for the opposition, in relation to the backdoor approach, said that he has some sympathy for that position. Not only would the opposition bring back fees if demand rose, but it would allow far greater flexibility to the universities to charge for postgraduate fees.

The simple facts are these. The Liberal Party does not support growth in the higher education sector. It does not support equitable access to it and it does not support student organisations. Most importantly, on 23 February the Australian summed up completely the Liberals' position when it said:
The Liberal Party, however, has been without a semblance of a higher education policy since the sinking of the voucher scheme . . .

ANSWER.PARA: The Liberal Party is promising nothing to the future students of this country. Labor has delivered and will continue to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Last night you forecast that recovery from the drought is bound to increase our export revenues and, therefore, contribute to an improvement in Australia's horrendous current account deficit. Will you tell the thousands of farmers struggling to make ends meet in officially declared drought areas when the drought broke and when they can expect to see a turnaround in their fortunes? Given that in many areas of New South Wales, Queensland and Victoria the already horrendous drought is worsening, isn't your indifference more evidence that you still haven't got the message?
—I said `the recovery from the drought', which does not necessarily mean that the drought all over Australia is complete or over.
—It is actually getting worse.

—Why do you draw that? You draw it maliciously. You draw it for malicious reasons. Are you seeking to deny the fact that there will be a pick-up in export volumes from rural products over the course of the year? Of course there is going to be a pick-up in rural production. I see no value in the notion being put about to people that there has not been some relief with the rains we have had or that there is not going to be a pick-up in production; of course there will be.

PARA.TAB: It was only this government that put the real support in for people who were disastrously affected, by extending income support to farmers in exceptionally affected areas—as a consequence, from memory, 8,000 farm families have now availed themselves of that income support—that is, by removing the impact of the assets test for benefits, as we have not done in any precedent way anywhere else in the social security system. That was a quite revolutionary change and that was acknowledged by the farm community and the farm leadership.

The sole policy was fodder subsidy. That was his sole policy for the drought. It was absolutely bucketed up hill and down dale by all the farm groups and farm leaders, as if, whatever value it was, people could sustain themselves personally with a fodder subsidy which was only going to support those people who had some fodder to sell. As always, even in the depths of the rural depression coming from the recession, there could not even be a generous response from the National Party to them as individuals, or to their children going to school. There was nothing generous—only a hidden subsidy for the people who had some fodder. They were always working the government backhander, the policy backhander or the subsidy backhander, rather than thinking about the farm community as individuals.
That is what this government did. That is why we have had acknowledgment for it. That is why this question, as with all the others you ask, reflects poorly on you.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. It refers to the forthcoming review of the Commonwealth-state agreement on the National Training Authority. How much does the Commonwealth contribute to technical and further education under the ANTA agreement? What requirements does the ANTA agreement impose on the other signatories to the agreement? Have they met all those requirements?

—I thank the honourable member for Bonython for his question. The Commonwealth is committed to ensuring that all young Australians receive an education which is both full and relevant. We have already achieved Labor's goal of encouraging more young people to stay at school to finish year 12. One out of three students used to complete year 12; now three out of four do so. These young people are now demanding, quite justifiably, further skills. With around one-third of them going on to university, the Commonwealth has been determined to make additional places available for vocational education.

PARA.TAB: In 1995 the Commonwealth is contributing $695 million in basic funding for TAFE through ANTA. We also contribute growth funding. This year we are making $310 million available, which brings to $820 million the Commonwealth's contribution to meet growth in the TAFE system since the agreement was signed. However, this growth funding is dependent on the states and territories maintaining their effort. We do not ask them to increase it; simply to maintain it.
As the honourable member indicated, the ANTA legislation requires a review later this year. I have recently seen documents from one state which no doubt will be of great concern to that inquiry.

It is already established that South Australia has not maintained its effort. As a result, the ANTA ministerial council decided at its last meeting that a portion of South Australia's growth funding should be withheld. The South Australian Premier and Treasurer are now considering not what we would expect—that is, an increase in funding to make up the shortfall—instead, a pea and thimble trick to have the Commonwealth's own money counted as the state's contribution to TAFE so that, in turn, the Commonwealth will provide more money.
I have a copy of a leaked budget document from South Australia—
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—The document to which I refer, which I will be happy to table at the conclusion of my answer, says that payments from the better cities program for the construction of a college of hotel management at the Regency Institute of TAFE should be directed `through the department's accounting records'—that is, the South Australian Department of Employment, Training and Further Education's accounting records—`in order to further enhance ANTA qualifying expenditures'.

PARA.TAB: This plan would be a fraud on the many young people in South Australia who want a place in TAFE to gain the skills they need to compete for jobs and to contribute to the economy.Not one extra TAFE place would be created in South Australia by this sleight of hand. Not one extra brick would be laid at the college of hotel management because of this paper shuffle. It is a scam, pure and simple. No federal Labor government, having come this far in providing our young people with the education and the skills that they need to take their place in our economy and in our society, is going to let a state government steal their future. I table the document.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Anderson Mr J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I draw his attention to the comments made by the member for McEwen last night on radio 3AW when referring to the government's forest policy. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: It is in my view the most dismally handled issue that the Government had in its entire term of office.
Quite some achievement! I refer the Prime Minister to his remarks in the Sir John Monash Memorial Lecture last night when he said:
Good policy is not always popular—not at first, at least.

Prime Minister, when are you going to apply this dictum to your forest industry policy which has degenerated to the point where cabinet is considering the future of each of 509 forest coupes and has plainly substituted politics for good policy? Is it a fact that your failure to adopt good policy continues to frighten investors away from the forest industries and is a major reason why this nation recorded a forest products deficit of $521 million in the December quarter?

TALK.START.PARA: —It has always been a conundrum for those people who want to see the best of our native forests preserved and those who want to see a viable forest products industry to be able to see themselves sitting beside one another in harmony. There will never be, in this policy, in this whole area, the capacity to serve everybody's aspirations completely. But this government seeks to try to serve them well. The government has considered, over a substantial period of time, all the issues involved in representative reserve systems and how we might keep a decent representation of species amongst particular stands of trees. At around half past four this afternoon I will be saying something public about it. The cabinet considered it at length again today.

PARA.TAB: Part of the difficulty always in forest management in these terms is that the environmental imperative has been operated through the residual powers of the Commonwealth under the export powers. The Commonwealth is not a manager of state forests. It is because of this need to refer to state management systems and state managers of forests that there could never be within the Commonwealth a management system that would adequately serve the full expression of those powers. That is what this discussion has been about. With a lot of goodwill between ministers, departments and the states, we are seeking to come to the right conclusion about it.

This is in marked contrast to the coalition. When Mr McLachlan, as the former shadow minister for the environment, said recently that he was adopting a policy for the coalition against clear-felling of trees for land clearance, the Leader of the National Party, Mr Fischer, said he would not have a bar of the policy. He overturned it completely.

I also observe that the opposition spokesperson for the environment recently appointed by the Leader of the Opposition believes that the Commonwealth's external affairs power—its treaty power—should not be used in any way for environmental protection. That is, things like the Gordon below Franklin and the world heritage listings would not be there were we to see this person's view that the external affairs power should not be used.

So if the Commonwealth were not to use the external affairs power or its external powers in respect to exports, or export licences for woodchips, then its influence on forest policy would be very greatly diminished, and that side of the argument which seeks to have a representative reserve system in our forests and the preservation of native stands of trees could not be served. That is the key point.

It has only been this side of the House which has taken the view that there has to be a balance between this—that we do want to see that but at the same time get to the position where we can have reasonable forest agreements where there are, on a scientific basis, the preservation of large, adequate reserve systems for trees. As a consequence of that, it would mean that we would not in the future be going through a coupe by coupe analysis of export approvals.

But with the states tardy in coming into RFAs, regional forest agreements, there has been no recourse but for the Commonwealth to try to judge from this distance, as the non-operator of forests, which of these particular coupes can be made available for woodchips.

This was, of its essence, always a complex matter, it always has been and it will be until we have representative forest arrangements, RFAs, across the Commonwealth. And, of course, Mr Speaker, you already know that the state where this has been the heaviest industry, Tasmania, has not even signed the national forest policy statement—Premier Groom has not even signed the national forest policy statement.

So let us not have anybody from the National Party, of all people, asking us about forest management. When the member for Barker made a reasonable policy expression saying that they would not allow continued clear-felling of trees, the Leader of the National Party said he would not have a bar of the policy, he would overturn that in government.

That is where they are coming from and that really means, in terms of this debate, they disqualify themselves on the basis of not being able to add to the debate in any meaningful way how we might keep these important native trees and, at the same time, end up with a sustainable wood products industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister and the Minister for Housing and Regional Development. Yesterday, the government launched Greenhouse 21C, a plan of action for a sustainable future. Can the minister inform the House of what impact the measures in the statement will have on the urban environment—in which 85 per cent of Australians live?

—I thank the honourable member for his question which, in some respects, is complementary to the previous question. The government's concern with ecologically sustainable development with the environment goes to the green issues; it also goes to the so-called brown issues.

PARA.TAB: The decisions made and announced this week represented a very substantial step taken by the government towards achieving the target set for us—a target that will result in a reduction of 15 million tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions by the year 2000. As with other environmental issues, of course, that represents a balance between the interests of industry and what can be achieved at the environmental level. The package that the minister announced yesterday, I think, makes that balance in a way that has industry contributing very substantially through voluntary agreements.

It also has a substantial commitment of people working through rural based programs, particularly around Landcare and REEP, where something like $250 million will go into employing something of the order of 25,000 people in making their contribution through their programs to the reduction of greenhouse.

I want to emphasise very quickly, in answer to the honourable member, the importance of a longer term agenda which goes to urban issues. Fifty per cent of all emissions are essentially related to urban life and the way that we live in urban society.

So the solution to the greenhouse issue lies in energy efficiency in terms of industry and it lies in the billion dollar tree planting program across Australia. But it also will depend upon our capacity to green our cities. Urban forests and forestation programs within cities play a very important role.

Secondly, transport systems are important. It is important to see where improvements in urban public transport can contribute, just as the efficiency—or lack of efficiency—in housing can play a very important role and the Commonwealth, through the Commonwealth-state housing agreement, can demonstrate effective ways forward. Finally, what greenhouse is about is achieving outcomes over specific periods. We need to see how we can achieve that by working with the states in Commonwealth-state programs where Commonwealth funding is involved. Part of yesterday's announcement was to look at ways to legislate to ensure that, where we make contributions to major state programs, we look to the outcomes environmentally in terms of reducing omissions.

In its statement, the government indicated that it can achieve a great deal through the measures announced. But, in the longer term, we need to think more about what we can achieve through the urban environment. I think many people in the community will take very seriously the agenda in yesterday's statement. I encourage them to look at that part of Greenhouse 21C. It will be very important to environmentalists who operate with, are thinking about and are concerned with the brown agenda as well as the green agenda the Prime Minister referred to in terms of forests.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware of the wide reportage of his criticism of the Speaker and Deputy Speaker at the recent caucus meeting? Can the Prime Minister confirm these reports and also confirm that, at the same meeting, he set Sir Billy Snedden as the benchmark on how the Speaker should control the parliament? Does the Prime Minister also recall saying to Speaker Snedden in 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: You are corrupt, you are biased, you always speak in favour of the Government, you are of the Government and you have besmirched the office of Speaker.

PARA.TAB: You have been partisan and biased all week.

QUESTION.PARA: Is it not true that the Prime Minister needs a scapegoat for his appalling performance in parliament and that he is nothing but a thug on the matter of the Speaker, no matter who the Speaker is?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the language towards the end of the question was unnecessary. I ask the Leader of the National Party to withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw that aspect. I leave the question with the Prime Minister.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the caucus of the Labor Party, I made references to the management of the House and the performance of the House. I think that in the public debate—in which we are all participants—there should be a device for the dissemination of real argument and real information. We have had quite a bit of that today.

PARA.TAB: The interesting thing is that the question was put in the context of a debate about my parliamentary style. But my style does not go to things like push polling. My style does not go to things like using documents to assail the minister on something you know to be completely untrue. My style does not go to dropping tax information into a public debate. I notice that a letter the Leader of the Opposition recently wrote to the Department of Administrative Services states:

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Baume has responsibilities involving a very close liaison with me and my office. It would suit my convenience to have him as readily accessible as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 145, and I refer to Steve Martin's ruling on 15 March 1993, when he said that the relevant minister was playing politics with the question and that the answer was not relevant to the question. He told the minister to restrict his remarks to the question asked. I now ask you, Mr Acting Speaker, to uphold the ruling of Speaker Martin on that date and again on 26 May 1993, and the former rulings of Speaker McLeay. I ask you not to be intimidated by this Prime Minister, to call him to order and direct him to address his remarks to the question as asked.
—Order! The Prime Minister is answering the question. He has decided to answer it by contrasting styles.
—Mr Acting Speaker—

PARA.TAB: Mr McGauran interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Gippsland might wish to withdraw that remark, that reflection on the Chair.
—The reflection that `He's got to you'?
—Yes.
—I will withdraw it.
—Unequivocally.
—We can all stand a debate in this parliament about the way the House runs—

—Mr Acting Speaker, I asked you for a ruling on my point of order. You gave no ruling. If you decline to give me a ruling, are you telling this House that you decline to uphold those previous rulings?
—Order! By implication in my ruling, I find the Prime Minister in order.

—We can have a debate here about how the House is conducted. But it is pretty amazing that we can have a debate about the style of any of us in parliament when, in a period of eight weeks, a Leader of the Opposition has been into push polling, framing a minister, dropping tax information and doing all of these things—
—Mr Acting Speaker, I rise on a point of order—
—You don't like the answers but you keep raising points of order and I'll keep giving them to you.
—I hope you do, Paul. Why don't you censure me again?
—Order!
—Try that again, why don't you?
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition!
—I am having a conversation here.
—Order! Let's not have this discussion across the table.
—Mr Acting Speaker, standing order 85—

PARA.TAB: Mr Howe interjecting—
Mr Howard interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Deputy Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition will cease that conversation.

—relates to what the Speaker may do after having called the attention of the House to the conduct of a member who persists in irrelevant or tedious repetition of his or her arguments or of the arguments of other members. The Prime Minister is just reading from notes. He has already gone through this once in answer to this question, and he went through it earlier in question time. The member for Werriwa was reading from the same notes earlier today. The Prime Minister is just reading from Labor Party speakers' notes. If that is the best he can do, it is tedious repetition and you should ask him to sit down.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—I conclude on this point: that any reference I made to Speaker Snedden never implied perfection on his part because I do not think even he would claim that of himself.

PARA.TAB: There is something to be said for having a public debate in this country on how, in record time, a Leader of the Opposition has so besmirched the system by these tactics. Yet that is not the matter in the public debate.

We are debating matters without substance rather than the substantial matter of the Leader of the Opposition trying to introduce the immorality of the American political system into Australia, bringing with it his endorsement of the sort of tactics which I think most Australians regard as un-Australian and, need I say, unparliamentary. If the House of Representatives seeks to be able to transmit information and have a real discussion, this sort of noise and interjection, in which those opposite now specialise, and the disruption which is their principal tactic, will never become the stock-in-trade of a parliament that enjoys widespread support and respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. It concerns an electronic counting system for Senate elections. What progress has been made in implementing such a system?

—The question is very timely. In today's Sydney Morning Herald, cartoonist Moir very appropriately lampooned the slowness of the traditional manual counting method of votes in New South Wales elections. It is extraordinarily slow. We saw a similar performance in the ACT elections and also in the last Senate election. I am happy to announce that, in this day of the information superhighway, the AEC will soon be ready to implement a computerised scrutiny package which will greatly speed up the counting of votes in the Senate elections.

PARA.TAB: In essence, the new system is called `Easy count' and it will dramatically slash the time taken to complete the Senate count in each state. New South Wales, Mr Acting Speaker, as you well know, is the slowest state to count manually because of the number and size of the ballot papers. It now takes weeks of counting to produce a final result. The reason the Senate takes so much longer than the House of Representatives is the below-the-line ballot papers. There are some 180,000 in New South Wales that need to be laboriously checked. Some ballot papers take 15 minutes each to be checked. That is why the Senate count goes on and on for weeks after the expiration of the statutory 13 days that we have to wait for postal votes. But hopefully no more.

Under `Easy count' the AEC advises me that it will take the computer just two hours to do all those weeks of counting. The new system can be used in all states for the Senate. Party scrutineers will be reassured to hear that under `Easy count' a detailed audit trail of the entire counting process will make their jobs much easier. The keying in process for each ballot paper will be by two independent operators with the computer cross-checking any variation in their entry on the ballot paper. I think the House will be pleased to hear that the proposed change will not cost anything for the taxpayers. In fact, there will be a saving of $375,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer confirm his promise to the ACTU that any compulsory employee superannuation contribution will be accompanied by a taxation trade-off? If the Treasurer cannot confirm this, is this not just one more instance of the government plundering wage earners of up to $6 billion on top of their already rising mortgage interest rates in a clear attempt to remedy its mismanagement of the economy?

—Far from plundering wage earners, real wages have been increasing for the last several years, although members opposite probably have not noticed that. We have been looking at a situation of improving real wages and improving real household disposable incomes. In the last couple of years we have seen very strongly rising real household disposable incomes in which wage earners have been participants. We are not talking about a situation in which people are suffering declining real incomes and declining living standards. The substance of the member's question gets to issues which are probably more properly addressed when I next confront the House on budget day.
—Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—Are you staying for the MPI?
—I never do.
—Mr Acting Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—Please proceed.

—In this morning's censure motion against Senator Baume, the member for Mayo (Mr Downer) and the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) claimed that in 1988 I had breached section 130 of the Health Insurance Act. They were trying to suggest that what I did in 1988 was in the same realm as the criminal behaviour of Senator Baume in receiving and disseminating a tax file number.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Withdraw!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member might withdraw that remark and get to where he has been misrepresented and the correction.
—I withdraw `criminal behaviour' and substitute `if it happened outside the House it would be criminal behaviour'.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Withdraw it.
—I did withdraw it.
—No, you did not.
—Order! The honourable member for Flinders will sit down.
—No, I have a point of order.
—The honourable member will resume his seat.
—Will you allow me to take a point of order?
—No, just wait. The minister will withdraw unequivocally.
—I withdraw.

—Mr Acting Speaker, on a point of order: I invite you to uphold the standing orders. Under these circumstances, you should name the minister. You required him to withdraw and he deliberately refused your invitation to do so. I invite you to uphold the standing orders. You have very high standards for us.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. I am satisfied that the matter has been dealt with. The minister will go to where he has been misrepresented.

—I am saying that this is absolutely wrong. As the then chairman of the national price watch committee, I released information about doctors overcharging patients by more than $100 million above the schedule fee—information I thought would have been in the interests of hundreds of thousands of patients. I gathered that information from statistical records of a general nature, which were released to me through the minister's office by the department of health. The now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the then Leader of the Opposition moved a censure motion.
—You are debating the matter.
—No, I am saying—

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is not. It was against me and the then minister for health and alleged that I was breaching the health act. I want to say—
—Order! You will go quickly to where you have been misrepresented.

—I am. I am showing exactly where I have been misrepresented. I never released doctor provider numbers, the names of doctors or the names of patients. Never. At no stage did I solicit Medibank provider numbers, and I was never given them. Both the Solicitor-General and the Director of Public Prosecutions made it quite clear that there was no breach of the law. If the members who made the allegations think there is, I challenge them to provide them.
—Order! The minister will conclude. He has shown where he has been misrepresented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Indeed, grievously.
