INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The failure of the Prime Minister to deal with the disastrous current account problems after several years of claiming he had the solutions in place and that the worst was over.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —If there were ever any doubt in the Australian community as to the charge made against the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) by his former numbers apparatchik, Graham Richardson, a couple of days ago on the John Laws program—I raise the John Laws program quite deliberately because, if ever there were a direct line into the Australian people which the Prime Minister periodically uses, it would be the John Laws program because it has a very wide coverage—it would have been put to rest by what Graham Richardson said on that program. He said that the Prime Minister had well and truly lost the plot and that he was no longer listening to the concerns of mainstream Australia.

PARA.TAB: The ultimate demonstration of the accuracy of that statement was revealed today in the supreme self-delusion of the Prime Minister which lies at the heart of Australia's chronic inability to cure its current account deficit problem. For most of question time the Prime Minister invited the parliament and, through the parliament, the Australian people to believe that, when it came to parliamentary noise and the cut and thrust of parliament, he was an innocent abroad who was the victim of the rowdy tactics of the opposition and the incompetence of those in the chair. It is very instructive that at no stage did the Prime Minister deny reports of what he said at the caucus meeting about the incompetence of the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker. All he sought to do was to claim that it was all our fault.

The Prime Minister is very good at blaming other people for his problems. This week, which is only to Thursday, these are the people he has blamed for his problems: the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives; Graham Richardson; Bob Carr; John Della Bosca; Barry Jones; Ros Kelly; the voters of Canberra, that is 99,000 people; university students; the ACT Labor Party and the Legislative Assembly; the Sydney Morning Herald; the journalists of the Canberra press gallery; the televising of parliament; and, most of all—you will love this, Ralph—lazy ministers. The trouble is that he is doing 90 per cent of the work. The last time I remember another Prime Minister of Australia blaming his ministers for his problems, he lost the election eight weeks later. I think it is a very bad habit that the Prime Minister has fallen into.

The serious part of it—the real rub—is that, while the Prime Minister deludes, Australia burns. That is the rub. For 12 years we have put up with this hubris. We have put up with this man who is drunk with his own hubris and arrogance. We have put up with him day after day, month after month, year after year offering one more excuse and asking for just one more opportunity.

We all remember when he went on the John Laws program nine years ago and declared that, if Australia did not tackle the current account deficit problem, it would become a banana republic. That was a call to economic arms; that was how the Prime Minister later rationalised it. I do not think that was his original intention. He is very good at the ex post facto rationalisation—like suggesting that, when our vote goes up in New South Wales by six per cent, which extrapolated would give us a gain of 11 seats, it is a disaster. That is one of the most monumentally deluded rationalisations that I have heard from the Prime Minister. But he has done the same with the economy. Back in 1986 he said that, unless we cured the current account deficit problem, Australia would become a banana republic. Nine years later, three elections later, 25 broken promises later, the Prime Minister is still saying that our major problem is the current account deficit.

I ask you, Prime Minister: how long must the Australian people wait until you finally deliver on the promises you have made about curing the fundamental problems of the Australian economy? That is the simple question. The Prime Minister tried again during question time to run this fictitious line that, in some way, the current account deficit problem during the time that I was Treasurer was worse than it is now.

I happen to have been given a set of the statistics. It shows that, in the seven years the Fraser government was in office, the current account deficit at its highest point, which was in the second last year of that term of government, was 5.6 per cent of GDP. During every other year it was below four per cent of GDP. Let me tell you what has happened since Mr Keating has been either the Treasurer or the Prime Minister of Australia. In 1985-86 the current account deficit was six per cent, 6.1 per cent, 6.1 and 6.1; in the pre-recession period it was 6.1, 6.4, 6.4 and 6.4. On most occasions, it has been way in excess of what it was on any earlier occasion.

Today's current account deficit figure for February is $2.2 billion. For the first time in history, Australia has recorded four consecutive monthly current account deficits of over $2 billion. The current account deficit over the year to February is 50 per cent higher than it was for the corresponding period last year. This is the problem that nine years ago the Prime Minister said he was going to fix.

The reason why we have high interest rates in Australia is not only the size of the budget deficit but also that overseas lenders are charging a risk premium to lend to borrowers in a country whose current account deficit is the second worst in the OECD. Foreign investors regard Australia, when it comes to its current account deficit, as a bad risk. You cannot blame anybody—the Fraser government, foreigners, the British, Sir Henry Parkes or the prophet Moses—except yourself.

You have now been in charge of this country for 12 years and there comes a time of great political accounting. We saw a taste of your political future last Saturday right here in Canberra. That was a time of great political accounting, because what the people of Canberra said more than anything else was: `Prime Minister, we no longer believe you. We no longer trust you. We no longer have any faith that you can deliver solutions to Australia's problems. We want to send you a resounding message in no uncertain terms.' That is why they sent Brendan Smyth here with the biggest swing in modern political history in Australia. That is why, unless the Prime Minister stops sniffing his hubris herbs—until he comes down to earth and understands that ordinary Australians in the mainstream of this country are bleeding, and bleeding very badly—he will suffer the same fate as your Sue Robinson suffered just last weekend here in the city of Canberra.

You no longer have any credibility when it comes to the current account deficit. You said in 1987 that the worst was over. You said in 1988 that the policy would continue to lower the current account deficit and so restore Australia's sovereignty over its own affairs. Sovereignty is a very interesting subject. It is something the Prime Minister is interested in. He keeps telling us that, unless we become a republic, change our flag and do what other people want us to do with our national identity—not what Australians want us to do with our national identity—we are not a sovereign country.

What your Prime Minister has done in the last 12 years has been to more trade in and denude this country of real sovereignty than any constitutional set-up could possibly do. You have handed this country over to the foreign bankers of the world, you have handed us over to the bureaucrats of Geneva when it comes to the treaty making powers and processes of this country; yet you have the nerve to talk about national stature. Your Prime Minister has got the nerve to talk about Australians walking proud and tall in the world. I do not walk proud and tall in the world when I know that my country's foreign debt has gone to $180,000 million from a figure of $21,000 million back in 1982.
Mr Willis interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You ought not to feel very proud about it at all. The reality is that this country's economic situation, because of the negligence of your part-time Prime Minister over the last 12 years in his various positions, has become gravely weakened. You boast about how many jobs you created in the 1980s. You created a lot of jobs in the 1980s. But do you know how you created them? You created them by running the economy at an unsustainably fast rate. Any fool can create hundreds of thousands of jobs if he is prepared to go into debt to foreigners. That is what you did.

PARA.TAB: Mr Willis interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We did not go into debt to foreigners the way you have.
—You did.
—You talk about the sovereignty of this country—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—Order! The Leader of the Opposition might direct his comments through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, he is interjecting.
—Don't lecture me either, thanks.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, through the whole of the 1980s, the economy of this country was run at an unsustainably fast rate. You went into debt to an unacceptable degree in order to purchase an unsustainable increase in the number of jobs in this country. The net effect is that we still have in this country the most sustained level of long-term unemployment that we have had since World War II; we still have 800,000 Australians out of work; we still have an unacceptably high level of youth unemployment; and, on top of that, we have the highest level of foreign debt since the Great Depression. That is your legacy. That is your record. That is the achievement of your Prime Minister, Mr Deputy Speaker, over the last 12 years.

PARA.TAB: What the people of Canberra said last weekend, and what the Australian people are saying all around this country at the present time, is that they no longer believe somebody who in 1987 said that the problem had been solved; in 1988 said that the policies were working; in 1990 said that the problem was no longer with us; in 1992 said that the basic challenges had been met and overcome; and now, in 1995, went down to Monash University last night and restates the problem all over again. You could write out the year 1995 and you could substitute the year 1986. Nothing has changed.

Those on the other side used to talk about how the Bourbons forgot nothing because they learnt nothing. If ever there were a Bourbon of Australian economic management, it is the current Prime Minister, because the rhetoric has not altered. Yet he expects us year after year to go on believing what he is saying. The fact of the matter is that the people no longer believe what he is saying. That is why so many of your colleagues are quaking in their boots this week. That is why you got that 17 per cent swing against you in Canberra. That is why your caucus members ravaged your Prime Minister. That is why all of those people queued up to give their doorstops on Tuesday morning as they marched into this building and told the Prime Minister to start listening.

But do you think this Prime Minister is going to listen? Do you think anybody seriously expects the Australian public to believe that he is an innocent abroad when it comes to the rough-house of the Australian parliament? Do you seriously believe that anybody who asks the Australian people to think that he is put upon when it comes to parliamentary procedure could ever possibly summon a modicum of humility to say that he is sorry, to apologise to the Australian people for the fact that he lied to them and misled them, to apologise to the Australian people for promising them tax cuts at the last election, yet taking them away, and for telling them in 1987 that the current account problem was solved but admitting last night that the problem had not even begun to be solved? How on earth can anybody take such a person seriously? Yet, apparently, there are still some misguided people opposite.

Over the last 12 years the Australian economy has been progressively handed over to the bankers of the world. A Prime Minister who boasts about the importance of national independence has done more to pawn our real independence than any Prime Minister in Australia's history. I do not think the Prime Minister has learnt anything from last weekend, because I believe this Prime Minister is incapable of learning anything. I think his long record of failure over the last 12 years, particularly in relation to the current account deficit, is eloquent testimony to that proposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was interesting to hear the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) say that any fool can create jobs if he is prepared to increase foreign debt. When the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer, he certainly presided over a considerable increase in foreign debt, but he did not create any jobs. It takes a real fool to do that.

PARA.TAB: When the Australian people come to make their judgments about the relative performance of the Labor government versus its predecessor, they will do well to look at the record of the previous government. I am not going to spend much time on it today, but since it has been made an issue by the Leader of the Opposition let us just recall the fact that, when he was in office as Treasurer for five years, there was growth of employment of 52,000 a year and that under this government it has been 154,000 a year—100,000 jobs more a year.

That is an extraordinary record when compared with that of the Leader of the Opposition when he was Treasurer. He thinks he can persuade the Australian people to believe that he can run the economy better than this government, when he has a record which is appalling compared with that of the present government. Whilst he was producing one-third of the rate of employment growth, he was doing it with an inflation rate of 9.7 per cent per annum compared with the average rate over our 12 years of 5.4 per cent. So he produced about one-third of the job growth rate and about twice the rate of inflation. That is the kind of record that he has.

On foreign debt he is also saying that he is a bit of a cleanskin. That is not true. In fact, I can go to no better authority than a member of the Liberal Party, Mr Michael Warby, who wrote an article in Quadrant in May 1994. In the footnote to that article Michael Warby is described as a member of the Federal Council of the Liberal Party. In that article he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Fraser Government's performance was, to be blunt, poor.

PARA.TAB: The Fraser Government presided over the period when high inflation, mass unemployment and plummeting national saving rates became entrenched, and growth in living standards stagnated.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a member of the Liberal Party Federal Council giving a one sentence summary of the performance of the Fraser government, of which the now Leader of the Opposition was a minister all of that time and Treasurer for five of the seven years. He went on:

. . . on foreign debt, the Fraser Government can clearly be held responsible for presiding over the start of the growth in foreign debt, which grew from 11 per cent of GDP to 21 per cent in a mere two years from June 1981 to June 1983. This rate of growth of foreign debt has only been briefly approached, and never exceeded, under the Hawke-Keating governments.

So here we have a prominent member of the Liberal Party saying publicly the truth—that there was this rapid growth of foreign debt as a proportion of GDP. In the last two years of the now Leader of the Opposition's period as Treasurer of this country, he had this explosion of foreign debt alongside an economy which was going through the floor. He had it wrong every which way.

PARA.TAB: We have now a situation where the economy is growing stronger than any other country in the OECD. He had an economy which was going through the floor, going into recession—remember that 1982-83 was a year of recession—and soaring foreign debt. He had the absolute quintessential, awful outcome; and with that he had double digit inflation. This was an appalling end to the Fraser government. No wonder it got thrown out.

Of course, with the effluxion of time, people tend to forget all that, but it is very relevant to considerations of the relative weight that people should give to the two parties. This government certainly has been in office for 12 years and we will stand on our record over that period which, economically, looks fantastic compared with that of the opposition when it was last in government. It is a record which has produced for the Australian people a prolonged period—obviously there are ups and downs of the business cycle—of much faster employment growth than they ever had before under the Fraser government, much lower inflation and a tremendous reduction in industrial disputes.

There have been some current account problems which we have been grappling with over that time and still are, as the Prime Minister said in his speech last night. We have not just been sitting there saying, `Here is a problem that the Australian nation has and we are not going to bother doing anything about.' We have been addressing that problem we inherited from the previous government of a structure which simply was not taking the Australian people anywhere. We were a developed industrial country with a Third World pattern of exports. We relied on things that you can grow and dig up out of the ground rather than value added commodities, goods or services for exports.

We were overwhelmingly Third World in our pattern of exports, and that meant that we were facing a long-term decline in our terms of trade. We had to grow and dig up more and faster just to stay in the one place. As the end of the Fraser government period shows, as I already demonstrated, there was an inability at that time to stop a considerable increase in foreign debt. The terms of trade were adverse and we were facing a situation where Australia was going down the gurgler because we had a structure which simply was not suited to maintaining living standards—certainly in a relative way and maybe not even absolutely in the longer term.

As well as producing those major changes on employment, inflation, industrial disputation and productivity improvement, this government has been about making a major structural change to the economy, which particularly shows up in the export field. We said we had to get away from the high protection policies which had been pursued in the past, bring protection down and make our manufacturing and service industries much more competitive so that they can compete and are not so reliant on commodities which are subject to supply and demand on world markets. Although they will always be important to us because we have that enormous comparative advantage in those areas, we simply can no longer rely on them.

We had to structurally adjust the Australian economy in a major way to make our manufactured exports and service industries internationally competitive. That meant reducing tariffs, which meant a higher propensity to import. As tariffs keep coming down, obviously more imports keep coming in. This also means that our industries have to become more efficient or die. They have clearly become much more efficient.

Manufacturing industry is now able to produce not 10 per cent of exports, which it was back in 1983-84, but 17 per cent of our total exports. We have seen a very rapid growth of exports of manufactured goods. We will see a lot more of it in the future. That is of tremendous benefit to the Australian nation, because the price of manufactured goods on world markets is much better, when taking into account the long-term trends, than the price of commodities without much value added. It is very important to us to pursue that course.

We have seen service industries increasing their exports markedly as well. We have near balance on the services side with exports and imports. Tourism is the obvious example of a tremendous growth in an export industry. There are others: education, health and so on. These are major changes.

The accusation of the Leader of the Opposition that the government was sitting there and unable and not willing to address the current account problem is massively untrue. No government in the history of this country has addressed that issue more than this government has. Certainly we do have a high current account now—at least that part of his speech is right—in comparison with most other developed Western countries. We are also growing faster than most of those countries. We are doing it at a time of drought. That drought is knocking some $2 billion off our exports. We are growing at a time when the rest of the world has not been growing rapidly. The prices for and volumes of our non-rural commodities have not been good. They are starting to pick up now, as the rest of the world lifts its game. Obviously that is a good portent for next year.

Today's figures, as I said at question time, show quite a deal of encouragement in that regard. We can look forward to an improvement in exports of non-rural commodities, and rural commodities for that matter, as, hopefully, the drought does completely break and the rest of the world has higher activity, and prices for commodities continue to increase. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics expects a nine per cent increase in commodity exports next year, or about $5 billion. That is clearly a great plus for the current account next year.

At the moment we have a combination of high growth and very high investment, which is capital intensive and which puts pressure on the current account. Temporarily we have this high figure. As the Prime Minister said in his speech last night, these long-term trends are encouraging for the future. The efforts which we have made to bring about the structural adjustment and develop manufactured exports in a big way are exceedingly important to the future of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has not been good enough.

—It has been a damn sight better than you could ever do, that is for sure. It is important for us to produce those improved manufactured exports. We have seen some major demonstrations in recent times of how that can be done.
—Waterfront reform? It has stalled.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—Order! The Treasurer should address his remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am trying to help him. He is trying to find a piece of paper.

—I am trying to find a piece of paper. We have had a lot of micro-economic reform and a lot of reform to improve productivity. We have seen productivity increase considerably. The Leader of the National Party said that the waterfront reform has stalled. We have seen a much better performance on the waterfront under this government than under previous governments, that is for sure. Productivity is improving quite strongly now. That productivity improvement is something which is helping us to maintain the faster exports of commodities.

PARA.TAB: It is absurd to suggest that this government is not addressing the issue of the current account. It is absolutely doing so. Part of that process is to improve national savings. This government has taken the major step towards the development of superannuation in this industry. That superannuation through the SGC is a major step forward in improving our national savings performance. The Fitzgerald report expected it to improve national savings by some two per cent in the longer term. That is a very important addition to national savings.

We have said that we will be pursuing an improved structural performance in the budget. You will have to wait until the budget to see exactly what that involves. I had already given that assurance to the House earlier today at question time. I repeat it. The budget will be about, in part, a structural as well as a short-term improvement in the national savings performance. We will be looking to reduce the deficit and so reduce public sector dissaving and improve national savings. That is important when investment is growing so strongly. We will also be trying to ensure that we improve the long-term structural performance on savings. That is what the nation has to do in the end if it is to bring about a major improvement in its current account performance.

Obviously, the problem has developed over a long period. The structural change in the economy over the last decade or so is a key element in ensuring that we can overcome that problem and that we can grow strongly without a current account limitation. It also requires us to have that major improvement in our savings. Savings improvement will be something which we will be demonstrating that we are very much about in the forthcoming budget.

It is pretty rich indeed for the Leader of the Opposition to try to lead the House to believe that any government can create jobs like we have been creating them so long as it is prepared to see some increase in foreign debt. That is a most amazing statement. He could not do it; he could not increase employment, but he could increase foreign debt more rapidly, as Mr Warby has shown, than this government has done at any stage that it has been in office.

TALK.START.PARA: —What utter rubbish!

—That is what Mr Warby said in that article. He is absolutely right. In two years foreign debt went up from 11 per cent to 21 per cent of GDP when John Howard was Treasurer. That is what happened. The growth rates under us have been nothing like that. John Howard is the record foreign debt increaser in the history of this nation. For him to lecture us on that subject is abundant hypocrisy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is considering a matter of public importance brought forward effectively by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). It relates to the failure of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating):

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to deal with the disastrous current account problems after years of claiming he had the solutions in place and that the worst was over.
I will deal with the matter of the drought, the matter of the national debt and matters arising from the comments of the Treasurer (Mr Willis), and I will make some comments of my own.

PARA.TAB: Very sadly, we have reached a stage in this country at which the recovery is very fragile indeed. The drought is worsening. On the matter of the national debt referred to by the Treasurer: at no stage when the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer of this country was the national debt anywhere near $25 billion. It was a great deal lower. In terms of ratios, it was in a better shape. To quote from the official documentation of the government, today that national debt is $162 billion—a sixfold increase in net debt terms or in quantum terms.

Whichever way you look at the economic performance of this government—to take up the Treasurer's challenge—there is one other thing which the official ABS statistics show. It is a very sad statistic. The gap between rich and poor over the 12 years of federal Labor government in Australia has got greater. They are not my figures; they are the figures of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. It is at arms-length from the government and even at two arms-lengths from the opposition. Those figures show that the gap between rich and poor is the true legacy of Labor. How left wing members can dare show their faces in this House and support this government in these circumstances, when they face the social inequities arising from the outcome of the Prime Minister's policies as Treasurer and now as Prime Minister, is shameful. It is an awful legacy; it is one which you will pay the price for. You did pay the price for it in the Canberra by-election last Saturday. I congratulate the new member for Canberra (Mr Smyth) for taking his seat in this place.

The Treasurer also referred to structural adjustment. It must be some little time since he sat down with the shippers of this nation because, whilst with the introduction of the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority there was initially a degree of improvement, the truth is that that has dropped off in the last 12 months. Shipper after shipper, freight forwarder after freight forwarder, will tell you that the ports of Australia in terms of efficiency are lagging behind best international practice by a country mile. We are lagging further and further behind, for example, one of our competitors in many commodities—New Zealand. The taxpayers had to pay millions of dollars as part of an equation to bring about waterfront reform, buy-out, termination packages and the like, only to find that the situation today is worse, not better. Waterfront reform improvement existed for about five minutes. Now the sky is starting to fall in.

There are several high jump bars that Australians should apply to the Prime Minister because he will never get over them. They will never believe the Prime Minister again when he says that he will bring home the bacon. They will never believe him again on the matter of taxation. They will never believe him again on the matter of interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't trust him.

—And why should they? The member for Dawson says that you cannot trust him in terms of his intention. You certainly cannot trust him in terms of the output of his policies. Today's current account deficit figure confirms absolutely the sentiments expressed by the Leader of the Opposition when he said that with this government you get five minutes of sunshine and then the sky falls in. We all know how much that line gets up the nose of the Prime Minister. We all know how much it gets up the nose of those opposite. We all know why that is so—because it is the absolute truth.

PARA.TAB: We all know that the current account deficit problem was the reason given by the government for the last recession. Remember that one? The greatest since the Depression. We now have a current account problem again. So what do we have to look forward to? Another recession caused by higher interest rates—is that what this government has in store for us again? I hope not. The fact is that yesterday the Prime Minister said that eventually the current account deficit would decrease. How is it going to decrease? What policy prescriptions does this government have? What levers will it use to bring down the current account deficit? Again, the government is reaching, as it did three times late last year, for higher interest rates. That seems to be about the only lever it knows. That is why it got savaged properly in Woden Valley and elsewhere last Saturday. By the way, the truth about the New South Wales election results is that 11 federal seats held by Labor would fall to the coalition if Saturday's New South Wales voting was repeated at the federal level—and I think it will be.

Mr Deputy Speaker, if you do not believe me about interest rates going up, I refer you instead to the government's own advisory bodies. The House should be aware that ABARE, the government's agricultural research economics body, has forecast that the prime business lending rate will average 11.5 per cent for farmers in the next financial year, 1995-96.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they said it was a low interest rate regime.

—Do you know what that means for farmers? That means a rate of 15 per cent once risk margins and charges are added in. In other words, as the Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Anderson) correctly points out, the government has totally misled the Australian people with regard to the actuality of interest rates facing farmers who are facing drought at this time. It is small businesses as well as farmers, in country towns and regional centres right across Australia, who are paying through their agony at this time as a consequence of those economic policies.

PARA.TAB: I have in my hand a map showing the state of Victoria—parts of the electorates of the member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) and the member for Mallee (Mr Forrest). I will visit the electorate of the member for Mallee on Monday; I will be attending a mini-summit on the drought at Sealake. The Deputy Leader of the National Party will travel to Bendigo a few days later. I want to commend Tooheys for adding to the drought relief fund. It is showing very clearly that Victoria is suffering the agony of drought as we speak. Sixty per cent of New South Wales is suffering the agony of officially declared drought, as opposed to those areas on the edge, as we speak.

I concede that coastal New South Wales has had good rains. There has been progress and bright prospects in some areas. I refer to the sugar industry, wine grapes this season in parts of Australia, the rice industry and the dairy industry in parts of Australia. I am the first to talk up those prospects because we need those exports; we need that confidence.

What broke my heart, and the hearts of farmers and small business operators, was hearing the Prime Minister say last night that there was going to be a bounce back from the drought, as if it were already over. In the Sir John Monash Memorial Lecture last night, with regard to the current account deficit, he said, in an insensitive way, `You'll have to put up with what I've got to say. This is what I'm going to say: there's going to be a bounce back in exports as part of drought recovery.' It was only after we prodded him today, on the floor of this House, that he eventually acknowledged that for so many the drought is not over and that for so many the drought is getting worse.

If he had listened to his Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) on the matter, who warned two weeks ago that for so many the drought is not over, then we might have had a more realistic assessment from the Prime Minister—a more realistic assessment of our prospective export performance, a more realistic change, alteration and review of exceptional circumstance provisions which are denied to so many across Australia. Not one Victorian farmer has eligibility for exceptional circumstances provisions; many in New South Wales do not and some in Queensland do not. That criteria has to be, and is being, reviewed—again, too slow, too little, too late.

On this matter of public importance, it is time for the government to account for its 12 years of disastrous economic policy and to admit the price so many thousands of Australians—in large cities and small, on the farm, so many families—have suffered under the hands of a Keating Treasurer and a Keating Prime Minister. It is time that he admitted that he has failed to bring home the bacon; that he has failed with regard to his taxation policies and his interest rate policies; that he is, in fact, a failure as Prime Minister of this country. He is one of the most arrogant and divisive prime ministers of this country and the sooner we go to the polls and he is dislodged from the Lodge the better for all our sakes. (Time expired).

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia does have a serious current account deficit problem but it is important that we do look at the issue in some detail rather than just the rhetoric that we get from the other side. The figures that were released today did contain some encouraging signs. We still do have a serious problem but they did contain encouraging signs. For example, there is a substantial increase in the percentage of merchandise exports. Today, Toyota Australia announced a $400 million per year contract to supply left-hand drive Camrys to six countries in the Middle East: the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Oman, Kuwait, Bahrain and Qatar. This will be 16,000 units in 1996, increasing in the following year to 20,000 units. That will allow that new plant to operate at full capacity. So there are good signs in the export area.

PARA.TAB: It is also worth taking into account that there are a number of factors which are, in effect, inflating the current account deficit at the moment, the drought being the most obvious one. Other factors are: lower commodity prices, following on the recession internationally, which are starting to rise in many cases and will continue to rise; the fact that we had a bit of an expenditure burst in the latter part of last year which flowed into imports, which I would see as a flow-on from the recession; and, finally, the burst of business investment which the Treasurer (Mr Willis) gave further details of in question time today. This clearly has been pushing the current account deficit a little further than it otherwise would have been, and it will gradually return to a level of equilibrium.

Yes, we have a problem but the magnitude of the problem is nothing like what has been suggested by the opposition. It needs to be put into some serious context. The context is nearly six per cent economic growth. There has been rapid employment growth, with 500,000 jobs having been created since the government was re-elected in 1993, a year ahead of the target that we set and which many ridiculed as simply impossible. There has been a 40 per cent increase in competitiveness since the government was first elected in 1983 and a 24 per cent increase in business investment. Real incomes have risen; irrespective of the sort of stuff that is said by some on the opposition benches, it is a fact. Low inflation has been sustained. The Australian dollar is still reasonably stable in the middle to low US70c range. There is clear evidence of structural economic change. This latest information, with respect to the contract signed by Toyota with countries in the Middle East, is yet another very good example of that.

The latest example is the car industry, which the opposition would have removed all assistance from as a result of its Fightback package and let go to the wall—a car industry that is proving that it can both produce well and export.

Yes, we do have economic problems. But, looking at the total picture, we have economic problems that most Western governments would kill for by comparison with the sorts of difficulties they face with their levels of foreign debt, budget deficit, unemployment, inflation, interest rates and the like. In the total picture, we are outperforming virtually all other Western governments.

What is the opposition's position? All it is able to do is grab the latest set of economic statistics, look for a bad one, pull that out and wave it about. All members of the opposition are able to do is grab the latest set of economic statistics and bleat about one bad figure. No analysis. No policy. Nothing is asked of them.

What will they rule out? Will they rule out any interest rate increases should they become a government? What is their policy on savings? Do we have any policy from them about Australia's savings? Not one word! What will you do? What is your position on all of these issues? Where is your strategy? Let us hear some of it instead of the populist rantings that we get time after time.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—Order! The honourable member should direct his remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was using the term `you' generally, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I take the point. Populism has its place and we are all guilty of it, to a degree, from time to time. But this is the party of John Hewson. This is the party of economic credibility. This is the party of serious policy. This is the party of Fightback. Where are they now? Where are their policies now? Where is the substance now?

PARA.TAB: Their position is: `We support lower interest rates.' Their position is: `We support lower taxes.' Their position is: `Oh, no, we don't support any specific cuts in government expenditure. In fact, we can probably dream up a few additional items of expenditure'—including such nonsense as pensions for everybody at an additional cost of $5 billion. At the same time as all this, they are going to cut the current account deficit by some sort of magical process.

Something very strange is going on over the other side, Mr Deputy Speaker. You might have noticed that today, when the Leader of the Opposition, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), walked in, he looked a little bit taller. There was a distinct pout in the lips, the bum was sticking out a bit more, the chest was sticking out a bit more and there was a little bit of a blue tinge in the hair. Do you know what is going on? The opposition leader is turning into Andrew Peacock. John Howard is turning into Andrew Peacock! The great problem for the Liberals is that the legacy of Andrew Peacock—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Melbourne should call members by their correct titles.

—My apologies—the opposition leader is turning into the former member for Kooyong. The Liberal Party has had the former member for Kooyong's legacy hanging around its neck throughout the 1980s and now the 1990s even when he was not the leader. In 1987 he flirted with the Joh for Canberra campaign to help undermine the campaign by the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). In 1993 the Liberals decided to stay away from Andrew Peacock and, for a change, have a serious policy, but then they ran an Andrew Peacock election campaign and they lost.

PARA.TAB: Now we have the hard man of the New Right, the member for Bennelong, coming along. What is he doing? He is turning into a souffle. He is becoming Andrew Peacock.

Now we hear, `There will be no big bang on industrial relations'; `We'll retain Medicare'; `Bulk-billing—that's okay,'; `Asians? They're okay now.' I have no doubt the honourable member for Bennelong will be seen in every Chinese restaurant in Australia between now and the next election, but that will not fool anybody. `The monarchy and the republic? We'll have a think about those sorts of things.' `Oh, we didn't really support the third runway.' `The land fund? No, we weren't really opposed to that sort of stuff.' `Yes, we're tolerant conservatives.' Nobody will be fooled by that sort of stuff at all—nobody.

Here we have the champion of the New Right, the self-styled most conservative leader that the Liberal Party has ever had. What is he doing? Running away and hiding from every policy debate that is before this nation. He cannot run and hide forever because he is a man of the past, he is a man with a past and he is a man whose time has passed.

On this issue he is a man with a past—like on every other issue. As was pointed out earlier in this debate, when he was last in office as Treasurer our current account deficit was about 5 1/2 per cent of GDP—roughly the same as it is now. Where is the distinction? What is the difference?

The difference is this: there was 10 per cent plus unemployment; 10 per cent plus inflation; business investment was dying; and interest rates were substantially higher than they are now. The total picture—and this is the emphasis that I place in this debate—was dramatically different from the total picture that we have now.

It is relevant to make these comparisons. It is true that a fair amount of time has gone by since then. Nonetheless, these comparisons are relevant. When he was in charge he had a current account deficit as bad as the contemporary current account deficit. But where were all the other good economic indicators that this government has been able to deliver? Where were the sorts of economic indicators that the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) sneers at? Like the 500,000 new jobs that have been created. Like the prolonged low inflation. Where were those economic indicators in the early 1980s?

We have a leader who has turned himself into a policy fraud. The honourable member for Bennelong had some integrity in the 1980s because he stood for a hard right position, he articulated it and he kicked some heads in his party in order to do so—one of the reasons why the honourable member for Goldstein is here and not his predecessor. But now he is running away from it and descending into pure, populist nonsense and today was a very good example of precisely that.

Instead of engaging in the substance of the debate, instead of looking at the detailed factors of our current account deficit problem, it is pure, unadulterated populism. No serious economic analysis. Unlike his counterpart in Victoria, Jeff Kennett, when the election is called he will not be able to get away with going to the electorate with no policies. The member for Bennelong will not be able to get away with just simply presenting himself and saying, `Australia's got problems, and here I am. Aren't I wonderful? Please vote for me.' That will not happen.

When his policies are open to scrutiny he will be in trouble because not only will people have a track record to judge him by but they will have the real policies—what the Liberal Party really stands for—to look at.

So, when looking at the current account deficit problem, yes, it is a problem. But you have to look at the total picture. You also have to look at short-term factors that are exacerbating the problem and that will alter. You have to look at the track record of the people opposite and see how much credibility they have in dealing with this issue. The answer is: not very much at all. To the extent that they had any credibility at all, it is rapidly dwindling as a result of the stance that they are taking.
