TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: The tariff proposal which I have just tabled contains an alteration to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Customs Tariff Proposal No. 3 (1995) formally places before parliament, as required by law, a tariff alteration made by notice published in the Gazette during the recent recess of parliament. The alteration is operative on and from 17 March 1995.

PARA.TAB: Following the government's acceptance in 1991 of recommendations contained in Industry Commission report No. 9 on the commercial tariff concession and by-law systems, the terms of item 31 in schedule 4 were revised. This concessional item allows the duty-free importation of aircraft parts, materials and test equipment for use in the manufacture, repair or maintenance of aircraft, with the exception of goods used for the servicing of aircraft.

By a broad application of the current conditions, it has been possible to import, duty free, most goods used in aircraft. The government has now decided to restrict the coverage of this item by excluding textiles and goods made of textiles for use on aircraft. This initiative will remove the competitive advantage previously accorded imported goods over locally sourced goods. It will also encourage the use of Australian raw textile materials. A summary of the alteration contained in this proposal has been prepared and is being circulated for the information of honourable members. I commend the proposal to the House.
Debate (on motion by Dr Kemp) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before interruption of the debate, I was speaking about the major contribution to the Northern Territory and Australian economies that the mining sector makes, and how this benefits Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians. Consequently, the question of access to land for exploration is one that will concern all Australians. In this context, it is instructive to review the status of exploration licences over Aboriginal freehold land under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976.

PARA.TAB: As of 31 January this year, the Northern Territory minister had given consent for applicants to commence negotiations on 606 exploration licence applications since the proclamation of the Commonwealth act in 1976. Of the 606 licence applications, a total of 51 have been granted under the Northern Territory Mining Act. A further 14 have received approval by the relevant land council and the federal Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and are awaiting grant. As well, 157 proposals for exploration have been vetoed, leaving 211 currently considered by the land councils.

I do not dispute for a moment that many of these applications will have had complex implications and that their consideration and negotiation are no doubt subject to unforeseen delays and difficulties. But, with only 8.4 per cent of exploration proposals granted, one has to at least question whether the act is providing Aborigines and other Australians with the opportunity to take advantage of the benefits of mining ventures. This is especially so when you consider the high risk and low rate of successful commercial discoveries from mineral exploration.

As I said earlier in the debate, the 1987 amendments to the act were intended to ease the situation of land access for mineral exploration by removing the right of Aboriginal owners to veto mining if they previously agreed to exploration and by imposing time limits on the decision process. Unfortunately, there is significant doubt as to whether these amendments actually benefit any of the groups involved in the process. On the surface, the amendments seem to provide more certainty for mining interests in that they have a clear decision time frame and are not faced with the possibility of having invested heavily in exploration only to find the mining denied.

The traditional owners have to make a decision to allow exploration and mining before the results are known. At times this makes revenue, employment benefits and disadvantages from mining very difficult to accurately quantify—sometimes impossible. Traditional owners will tend to be more hesitant to allow exploration on their land, resulting in fewer and more complex agreements. There are undoubtedly cases where a less constrained negotiation would have resulted in an agreement and the benefits of mining accrue to all parties. The opportunity to go the extra mile and reach a negotiated outcome beneficial to both parties is vital to the goal of Aboriginal economic independence and a healthy resources industry. In 1991, the Industry Commission commented:

SPEECH.PARA: Negotiations without artificial external constraints would seem far more likely to result in mutually satisfactory agreements which adequately address the main concerns of both Aborigines and those of developers.

To my mind, there is no question that negotiation is the key to unlocking the benefits of mineral wealth for Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians. There is a vital need for greater freedom for negotiation between the traditional owners of land in the Northern Territory and mining interests.

PARA.TAB: In advocating this, I am not suggesting that the powers of traditional owners of land in the Northern Territory to determine their future and the future of their land should be weakened. The Commonwealth and Northern Territory governments have a duty of care to ensure that such negotiations are effective, fairly conducted and of benefit to all parties directly involved as well as to the wider community. To achieve this goal, it is imperative that all parties have as clear an understanding as possible of the implications of their actions and any agreement that may be reached.

In the last few years, the power of negotiation and communication to cut through decades of mistrust has been impressive. For example, in 1993 the mining company Zapopan and the Jawoyn Association reached agreement over native title issues for the proposed $100 million Mount Todd goldmine, which is 50 kilometres north of Katherine in the Northern Territory. The successful conclusion of the negotiation process provides an important model for resolving other issues of this nature and followed a lengthy history of claims around the site.

In 1978, a traditional land claim was lodged on land in and around Katherine by the Jawoyn. When the land commissioner presented a report on the claim in 1987, the area of the Mount Todd mine was specifically excluded from the grant of land. Shortly after that report, two repeat land claims, which included the Mount Todd area, were lodged.

Following the Mabo decision in 1992, Zapopan sought legal opinion on the effect of the decision on the proposed mine, recognising the possibility of further native title claims to the area. Then, in November 1992, ongoing discussions between the company and the Jawoyn Association, which had been primarily concerned with employment and contract opportunities, became focused on the issue of land rights.

With legal advice that a repeat land claim would fail and that there was a limited chance of success for a native title claim, Zapopan chose not to pursue its interests aggressively but, instead, to seek a resolution through negotiation and discussion with the Jawoyn Association.

The Mount Todd result was truly a win-win situation for all concerned. It is worth commenting that the issue of land rights and native title was resolved in only three months of discussion between the parties, which compares very unfavourably with the delays experienced under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act and the Native Title Act. I have no doubt that outcomes, such as those of the Mount Todd negotiations, have resulted from an increased awareness by developers of the importance of issues of native title and Aboriginal advancement, while Aborigines see the economic and social benefits of employment, infrastructure and income that result from successful mining ventures.

One very pertinent issue associated with the successful Mount Todd agreement is the topic of representation of the traditional owners of land in negotiation with mining companies. At present, the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act requires negotiation to be conducted through the appropriate land council. In recent times, a number of traditional owners have queried the activities of the land councils in representing their interests. While I do not want to pursue it at this time by detailing their claims, I note the difficulty of effective negotiation occurring when there is disagreement of this nature.

It is heartening to see the progress made by the mining committee of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation in achieving mutual understanding of the position of miners and Aborigines on mining matters. As a result, a new committee—the Joint Council on Aboriginal Land and Mining—is to be established. A further significant development in this regard has been the decision by Aboriginal groups to join the Northern Territory Chamber of Mines. The Jawoyn Association joined the chamber last year and, recently, Yirrkala Business Enterprises and the Gagadju Contracting Company became members. I look forward to further developments such as these in finding the common ground for Aborigines, miners and the community to benefit from mining on Aboriginal land. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to participate in the debate on the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994. The explanatory memorandum states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 provides a mechanism whereby traditional Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory referred to in Schedule 1 to the Act may be granted to Aboriginal Land Trusts to hold title on behalf of Aboriginal people. Since the Act came into operation in 1977 a total of 58 separate parcels of land have been scheduled under the Act.

The amendment arises from a settlement agreement reached between the Northern Territory Government, the claimants to the Hodgson Downs Land Claim (No. 139) and the Northern Land Council. This agreement includes a clause in which the Northern Territory Government agrees to request the Commonwealth to effect the grant of an estate in fee simple in the land which was the subject of the Land Claim.

I will pass over the less than appropriate comments that the preceding speaker in the debate, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), made after question time today, but I will look with interest at the Hansard. I do, however, note the comments he made in this debate on successful negotiations between Aboriginal communities and mining companies, although I doubt very strongly that, had we not put the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 into place, we would still be a very long way off having any sort of effective recognition of the rights of Aboriginal people. We certainly would not have had it from the opposition members in this parliament.

PARA.TAB: This issue has a very long history. A couple of weeks ago the High Court upheld the Mabo decision over a claim by the Western Australian government. In fact, the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) was visiting my electorate when that news came through. Then there was the presentation to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of two significant reports.

The first was a report by the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation titled Going forward: social justice for the first Australians. The second, titled Recognition, Rights & Reform: a report to the government on native title social justice measures, was presented to the Prime Minister here at Parliament House on 27 March by the Chair of ATSIC, Lois O'Donoghue. We have also seen the conclusion to a number of consultative processes that have been endorsed by this government and which precede the native title legislation that was passed in this House at the end of 1993.

I have said previously, and I repeat, I anticipate being in this House for a lengthy period—well past the next election—and, I dare say, will be participating in a number of important pieces of legislation. But there is no legislation of which I would feel more proud to have been associated with and to vote for than the native title legislation that this House endorsed, and which was passed, after much recrimination, in the Senate towards the end of 1993. I believe history will indicate that what the government did on that occasion was very important.

More recently we have seen the passing of the second part of our commitment to justice for Aboriginal people—the land fund bill. The social justice measures we are now considering, which are pertinent to the Recognition, Rights & Reform report, are also part of our continuing commitment to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
When the Prime Minister received that report from Ms O'Donoghue on Monday of this week, he said that what pleased him most about receiving the report was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the fact that we are seeing the public manifestation of the esteem that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people hold for themselves, have always held for themselves, but which in other times when that sense of justice and sense of decency in the country has not focussed on their concerns such a report like this would never have appeared.
Then, referring to the Native Title Bill and the land fund bill, he said:

It was a great victory for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and for social democracy in this country when the High Court held its validity—seven judges to nothing—a couple of weeks ago. And then on its heels, of course, we bailed up the opposition with their manipulative approach in the Senate to try to destroy the integrity of the Land Fund Bill and despite the Leader of the Opposition's cockiness when faced with the prospect of an early poll—
and, I might say, a double dissolution—
he caved in and passed it. So, we got the double of the century in a week. Seven to zero on native title and the Land Fund Bill.

These were very important landmarks. The Prime Minister further commented in his speech that there have been many people advising him to get back to the mainstream issues, the real game of interest rates and the economy, as if we had left them. We are not like President Ford. We can walk and chew gum and do a few other things all at the same time.

PARA.TAB: While the Prime Minister has committed himself to the issues of great concern to not only Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in this country but also the whole community, and which affect our international reputation on these issues, at the same time he has presided over a government—as it was shown earlier in the MPI debate—that has produced 560,000 new jobs in less than two years. This government has produced the best productivity this country has had for a long time, and the lowest inflation and interest rates compared with the previous Liberal government.

It is very important to make this point to the wider community. It is absolutely vital that the Australian people understand the importance of social justice for Aboriginal people. I want to acknowledge the contribution of the member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), because he was the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs during the time of the development of this land rights legislation for the Northern Territory—one of our earlier commitments.

While there may be many differing comments that one hears in the electorates and various communities around the country—criticisms of what we as a government have done on Aboriginal land rights—there is a prevailing sense of justice and fair play in the Australian psyche which acknowledges the importance of these measures if we are to go forward as a nation and if we are not to deny our past, the injustices of the past and the injustices of the present day. This legislation is part of that.

I will now take the House back a little to 1988. It is always helpful to see how far we have come in terms of where we were at the time. In an earlier speech on the land fund bill, I mentioned the issue of the motion that was aimed to be presented to the opening of the new parliament. Honourable members may well recall that we were unable to get bipartisan support because the church leaders had actually suggested a form of words that would relate to the issue of social justice for Aboriginal people. The resolution, after much consultation with the opposition at the time, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives/Senate—
1. acknowledge that:
(a) Australia was occupied by Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders who had settled for thousands of years before British settlement at Sydney Cove on 26 January 1788;
(b) Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders suffered dispossession and dispersal upon acquisition of their traditional lands by the British Crown; and
(c) Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders were denied full citizenship rights of the Commonwealth of Australia prior to the 1967 referendum; and
2. affirms:
(a) the importance of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture and heritage; and
(b) the entitlement of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders to self-management and self-determination subject to the Constitution and the Laws of the Commonwealth of Australia; and

3. considers it to be desirable that the Commonwealth further promote reconciliation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander citizens providing recognition of their special place in the Commonwealth of Australia.

Although this motion had already been modified to accommodate opposition concerns—that is, references to legal recognition of land rights and to the desirability of a compact were dropped—the joint party meeting of the opposition on the morning of the debate endorsed supporting the motion only if the entitlement of self-determination already qualified by the words `subject to the Constitution and laws of the Commonwealth' were further qualified by the words `in common with all other Australians'. Father Frank Brennan said in his book Self-determination for Aborigines—limits and powers of November 1991:

At best, the proposed amendment was ambiguous suggesting that the entitlement to self-determination was universal but exercisable discretely by separate groups. At worst, it was ruthlessly assimilationist suggesting that self-determination could be exercised only collectively by all Australians. . .
The amendment was not accepted and the opposition did not support the motion.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, time and time again in debates in this House we have heard much of the same from members of the opposition on all the great social issues regarding justice for Aboriginal people. They have had to be dragged—to coin a phrase—kicking and screaming towards the issue. That is a great shame.

Let us go back to another moment in 1988 when, at the Barunga festival in the Northern Territory, the Barunga statement was read and some of its items adopted by the then Prime Minister. I have made no secret of the fact that one of the legacies of the previous administration was that we did not fulfil our commitments to Aboriginal people. But the position in that statement is telling because of the things we have resolved and the position we are at now.

The other thing it does is exemplify the fact that Aboriginal people, because they have occupied this land for thousands of years more than our miserable 200, have never lost sight of their claim of ownership to the land, their cultural and spiritual identification with the land and their resolution to maintain that in spite of all that has been inflicted upon them. I feel the Barunga statement is worth reminding ourselves of. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: We, the indigenous owners and occupiers of Australia, call on the Australian Government and people to recognise our rights:
To self-determination and self-management, including the freedom to pursue our own economic, social, religious and cultural development;
To permanent control and enjoyment of our ancestral lands;
To compensation for the loss of use of our lands, there having been no extinction of original title;
To protection of and control of access to our sacred sites, sacred objects, artefacts, designs, knowledge and works of art;
To the return of the remains of our ancestors for burial in accordance with our traditions;

To respect for and promotion of our Aboriginal identity, including the cultural, linguistic, religious and historical aspects, and including the right to be educated in our own languages and in our own culture and history.
The statement then goes on to point out the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and various international covenants. It goes on:
We call on the Commonwealth to pass laws providing:
A national elected Aboriginal and Islander organisation to oversee Aboriginal and Islander affairs;
A national system of land rights;

A police and justice system which recognises our customary laws and frees us from discrimination and any activity which may threaten our identity or security, interfere with our freedom of expression or association, or otherwise prevent our full enjoyment and exercise of universally-recognised human rights and fundamental freedoms.

We have not achieved all of that; there is no doubt about that. But it is helpful to know that this government, particularly under the leadership of the Prime Minister, has been determined to deal with the issues raised in the Barunga statement. I will now read from the up-to-date report Recognition Rights & Reform. It states:
This report is about recognition, rights and reform.

It is about recognition of the unique place of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in Australian history and society today. It is about the rights of Australia's indigenous peoples. It is about the further reforms necessary to secure and underpin those rights and to ensure they can be exercised and enjoyed by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.
It further states:

Our focus is on institutional, structural, collaborative, cooperative reform. It is about a fundamental shift from welfare to basic rights, from dependence to autonomy, from government assistance to power. Central to the social justice agenda is self determination.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have never wavered from where they knew their rights should be, in spite of all that dispossession has inflicted upon them. We now have a considerable responsibility to put in place those institutional arrangements which, in spite of all our efforts, have never been met by state governments.

PARA.TAB: This fact was picked up by the Northern Territory Central Land Council back in 1991 when ATSIC was being developed in response to the Barunga statement. The Central Land Council report on the infrastructure provision in remote Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory, August 1991, on pages 116 to 117, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the success of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act making it possible for Aboriginal people to regain control of their traditional lands, NT Government opposition to land claims and the existence of guidelines which prevent the delivery of services to small remote communities, limit the extent to which access to land can achieve meaningful improvements in the living standards of remote Aboriginal people . . . if health conditions, in particular, show no improvement because of poor water supplies, for example, then the ability of the community to take control of its own affairs will be seriously weakened.

The government's focus now will be to try to right the wrongs, having given rights and access to land through the High Court Mabo decision on native title and the land fund bill in spite of opposition from those opposite and a lack of leadership from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard).

PARA.TAB: The opposition leader has shown a disastrous inability to come to terms with a position of moral integrity on Aboriginal land rights. We saw an example of that most recently in the Hindmarsh Island debacle. He sat on his hands knowing full well that his then shadow minister for the environment, the member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), had perpetrated many wrongs in his misuse and misappropriation of those documents. The opposition leader came into this House with the current opposition spokesperson on Aboriginal affairs, the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), and sat on his hands and did nothing. He did not show any leadership. He did not sack his frontbench person. Finally, when public furore forced the resignation of the opposition spokesperson for the environment, the Leader of the Opposition said he was an honourable man. In fact, the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party (Mr Costello) has said, `We must have him back in the shadow ministry because we cannot afford to lose his talent and ability.'

Unfortunately, this is the sort of moral integrity that we always get from the Liberal-National Party coalition in spite of the several good people on the opposition benches—usually on the back benches—who have the best interests of Aboriginal people at heart. There is only one government that will work with the Aboriginal people to get to the future: a Labor government. The Aboriginal people know it and the media know it. On any assessment of the debate, we have always given moral leadership and effective legislative leadership. This amendment is further evidence of that. We will not leave Aboriginal people behind. We will make sure that they get their justice, infrastructure and enough support to make land rights work for them in the Northern Territory and elsewhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 2) because the Aboriginal lands are of great interest to me, in particular because my electorate contains the Pitjantjatjara and Maralinga Tjarutja lands. Further, I spent a significant amount of my early life in the Northern Territory working on various pastoral properties and enjoying the tropical way of life in Darwin. Various members of my family are still spread in that fine state. I have a continuing and abiding interest in that part of the world.

PARA.TAB: As some preliminary comments, I would like to try to put a regional Australian's point of view on Aboriginal matters. We must be very careful that we do not get caught up too much in our own rhetoric. We must be very honourable in the way that we conduct our affairs regarding the original inhabitants of this fine country of ours, because I have a feeling that too many times in the parliament Aboriginal people have been exploited for political purposes. At a time in our history when we must aim for a cooperative and integrated society based on non-racial grounds, we must be very careful that we bring the whole country with us in any reforms or any changes that we make.

In speaking as a regional Australian, I would like to remind the House that Aboriginal people inhabited every square kilometre of this land. Yet, in the native title issue, we find that it is only ever regional Australia that gets caught up in the practical detail. We do know that only five per cent of Aboriginal people—if, indeed, five per cent are fortunate enough—will have an opportunity to access land through the native title legislation. We also need to look at the white people who live in regional Australia because, there again, we have a minority group. There are perhaps 10 per cent or five per cent of white people living in regional Australia who will be in any way affected by the issues of land.

In the case of the Northern Territory, we know that 40 per cent of the land mass—like the 30 per cent of my own electorate, which effectively is 30 per cent of South Australia—is controlled by Aboriginal people. Any decisions made by high courts or parliaments of Australia—and, indeed, any judgments that are made by the majority of our people—impact disproportionately on regional Australia. I do not think that that fact is acknowledged.

I was fortunate enough this morning to spend a bit of time with Justice French, a name familiar to many of us now and certainly to all of us in this House. When asked in a perfectly friendly and cordial meeting how many native title claims had been put forward, he said he thought that about 60 had been put forward and 35 had been accepted by the tribunal, but none had been finalised—that is, none had finally come to fruition and been accepted as native title leases.

So the grand vision that sometimes plays a little too much on the lounge rooms of our capital cities and a little too often on the urban comfort zone, and which a little too often exploits Aboriginal people, is a process which almost totally ignores regional Australia and most of its inhabitants. As someone who has lived in regional Australia all his life, I feel very acutely that it is too easy for white Australia simply to pass Aboriginal issues back to regional Australia.

I welcome the opportunity to put those preliminary comments on the record. If we are going to genuinely live together in this country in harmony and on a non-racial basis, where we are all accepted as equal, we must acknowledge that regional Australia is carrying a disproportionate share of the burden.

This bill seeks to add another parcel of land to the Northern Land Council at the request of the Northern Territory government. It is a considerable piece of land and is already owned by the Aboriginal community.

With the Pitjantjatjara Land Rights Act 1991, the Pitjantjatjara lands that I mentioned earlier were returned to the Aboriginal people during the Fraser government years, at the initiative of the state Tonkin Liberal government. The Pitjantjatjara lands, as I indicated earlier, cover about 15 per cent of South Australia, from the Western Australian and Northern Territory border down to Marla at the top of the Maralinga lands, taking in numerous distinct communities, including Pukutja, Umuwa, Mimili and Fregon. The Maralinga Tjarutja takes in a similar amount of country.

It has been my pleasure to visit these lands on many occasions and it has proved a very interesting and educational experience. I am proud to be well acquainted with many Aboriginal people living and working in these areas. One of my particular interests concerns those people struggling to make a living from the land there. The land is harsh and dry but can sustain significant pastoral pursuits and other industries. There are many teachers, health workers and other professionals based in these lands. I have enormous respect for their dedication.

The disturbing aspect of the Pitjantjatjara lands is that the Aboriginal communities living there continue to live in what are considered Third World conditions. Basic health care and cleanliness are still major problems.

Earlier I mentioned that regional Australia is carrying a disproportionate share of the burden. In my work with the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, I visited a significant regional community in Western Australia. I would like to counsel a note of caution before we get into Commonwealth-state divides and too much political acrimony is engendered in the debate.

This committee, when visiting the west, went to a local government area, or shire, as it is known there, which has about a 50 per cent Aboriginal population base. About 90 per cent of the intake of the district hospital is Aboriginal. There is a 50 per cent Aboriginal population base but a 90 per cent Aboriginal involvement as clients in the hospital. A whole range of issues flows from that, but the main point I would like to make now is that the state is at the front line of providing that service. It is no good—no good at all—for the Commonwealth to engage in constant carping criticism of the states when the states are expected to pick up a disproportionate share of the burden. We need to look at the task, break down the boundaries—whether Commonwealth, state, local or Aboriginal—and see how we can best cooperate. The whole debate has a long way to go.

Despite the fact that the federal government believes that returning land to Aboriginal communities will somehow solve their problems, we can see from the example of the Pitjantjatjara experience that land alone is not a solution. The Maralinga Tjarutja lands provide their own unique story because of the British nuclear testing that took place there in the 1950s and 1960s. I visited Maralinga last month with the parliamentary Public Works committee to assess the first stages of the clean-out process. That is in 1990s terms. Of course, there have been significant clean-up operations since the tests of the 1950s and 1960s. This is, hopefully, the finalisation of that process.

The British government has acknowledged that it has a responsibility for the effects its testing had on the area. It has made an ex gratia payment in recent times, and that agreement is to be welcomed, but the effects which the testing had on the Aboriginal communities of that region can never be fully redressed. We can only look to the future and help the traditional communities take control of that land again.

The Pitjantjatjara and Maralinga lands in Grey are not dissimilar to the lands of the Northern Territory in administration and in scale. Both these large parcels of land are owned by Aboriginal people. Unfortunately they have not always had a happy past but, hopefully, they will have a much happier future.

My underlying concern with Aboriginal lands is that the communities that live there must be given every fair opportunity to develop the land and to genuinely take control of their own lives. There are, no doubt, hundreds of reasons why this has not taken place to any significant degree in the Pitjantjatjara lands and the Maralinga Tjarutja lands. Some of these go right back to the root problems of European habitation of our country, urban paternalism and, as I have mentioned already, the inability of the Commonwealth and the states to focus sufficiently well on the issue. Sadly, too often, there is also too much political exploitation of the Aboriginal issue.

I come back to the Pitjantjatjara lands. There are fundamental differences between what the Aboriginal community wants and what the government bureaucracy delivers. Many homes were built on the lands. However, a lot of the homes that I have seen have been destroyed or vandalised or are uninhabited. While there have been numerous calls for greater spending on Aboriginal housing, we must first ask ourselves why past housing in areas such as the Pitjantjatjara lands was destroyed or was inappropriate. Some good work has been done but we must apply the research in a very practical way.

In speaking to people on the housing issue, I know that the housing provided was not exactly what the Aboriginal people wanted. There is still plenty of room for much improved communication in planning those homes. I offer this example. Many traditional Aboriginal people like to sleep outdoors. When some of the homes were built, families found they preferred to sleep on the front porch. However, the front porch, if there was one, was not always located on the right side of the house. For example, it may have faced the hot sun. This is one example of homes not being suitable for the Aboriginal way of living. It needs to be reinforced time and time again that practical solutions do exist and that it is for all of us, to the best of our ability, to make sure that we apply those practical solutions.

It is extremely important that, before the government goes gung-ho into handing out funding, Aboriginal communities are consulted from the outset and asked exactly what they want. I believe the failure to do this is one of the reasons we have seen very little improvement in certain areas from the millions the government has spent.

There are those who will say that the situation in some areas has grown worse over the years. I am insufficiently knowledgeable to be able to judge because I have been in this office for only two years and it would be too arrogant of me to make a judgment as to whether it is better or worse. I know that there is much to be done.

The issue of Aboriginal deaths in custody is well documented, and that in itself has been investigated. Being a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs gives me a better understanding from my perspective.

While governments are willing to provide funding, they are not always willing to go that one step further to ensure the best management support. A number of people in my electorate have raised the subject of Aboriginal funding, including members of the Aboriginal community. They are the people that I am most keen to listen to. There is a deep concern that certain people are keeping tight control over funds, and from time to time there is rorting. The more important part about some of the side issues—we have to keep focusing on the core issue; that is, improving the lot and making sure that we spend our money well—is that we recognise that in a country as wealthy as ours funding will always be limited.

As people working and living in the lands say to me, `We cannot waste money, scarce resources, we have to target them in the most appropriate way.' I will not dwell on the recent issue of ATSIC and the Ombudsman, but we should not be too frightened to make sure that accountability is in our mind, particularly in the commercial operations—and I think this is improving over the years—and we should apply strong accountability in the expenditure of the financial resources available.

In conclusion, while this bill proposes a non-contentious amendment, because all relevant parties are in agreement that the parcel of land near Katherine should be granted to the traditional owners, this is an opportunity to reflect on the issue of land and its relevance to improving other aspects of the Aboriginal community's lives. It is obvious that we still have a long way to go. It is important that the federal government—and I speak most sincerely from a regional Australian's perspective and as someone that I hope has a practical application in life—does not dwell too long on the grand statement. It is important that we do not dwell too long on the political rhetoric but that we get down to it and look at the issues in a practical way; that we do not exploit these Aboriginal people for political purposes but genuinely work in partnership with them.

We have the wit and the capacity in this nation to do that. We will be judged in the generations ahead for the way that we have been able to cooperate, the bipartisan way in which we have been able to address the issue, and the way that we have been able to acknowledge that those of us who live in regional Australia, and I keep coming back to that, do bear the very significant—I will not say `burden', because for me it is a privilege to know the Aboriginal people—practical consequences of the management of many of these issues.

I urge the government to recognise that there is a willingness in the community to apply in a practical way solutions, support and a genuine recognition of the fair go, and I am sure that if we do apply ourselves appropriately we will make progress.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon The Hon W.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to contribute to the debate this evening which addresses an amendment to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976, and in particular deals with the scheduling of land under the act and recognises the ownership of Hodgson Downs as a result of a land claim process by the people there, having purchased the property some time earlier.

PARA.TAB: I address my remarks to the question of Hodgson Downs because it is important that we understand the significance of this particular block of land for Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory which, of course, is in my electorate. The first thing that should be said is that Hodgson Downs is an extremely important ritual centre for the whole of the Roper River area. For those of you who are unfamiliar with the Northern Territory, that is an extensive area of country to the east and south-east of Katherine in the Northern Territory.

The dreamings that pass through the property make it very important for the whole of the Northern Territory. In cultural terms, in sacred terms for Aboriginal people, it is of primary importance. The dreamings were recorded in the early days and have maintained their importance through the years of settlement, and indeed some might say theft, of Aboriginal land by non-indigenous Australians in the past.

Sadly, a number of the people who were very well known as ritual leaders, both women and men, have died between the preparation of the claim and the negotiations which settled it. Unfortunately, that seems often to be the case. There are and there have been claims outstanding in the Northern Territory for over a decade primarily—not in this case, but in most cases—as a result of the resistance of the Northern Territory government to the rights of Aboriginal people under the land rights act.

What they have done is try to frustrate any attempts by Aboriginal people to obtain land under the act continually, which has often meant that primary claimants—principal claimants—have passed away during the period from the lodgment of the claims and the claim being finally settled. That is sad and an indictment on the CLP government of the Northern Territory.

In this instance some of the people who died were members of the Roberts and Farrell families. Sir Philip Roberts and Silas Roberts are two of the well-known people associated with the lease who have passed on. Both of these men were very significant individuals in the Northern Territory, whether in the context of Aboriginal society or non-Aboriginal society. Both men are immensely important in their own right with standing across the community.

In this particular instance, the Northern Territory government cooperated in the settlement of the claim. I am not exactly sure of the number of times that the Northern Territory government has taken challenges to land claims either to the Federal Court or the full bench of the High Court, but it is in excess of 30 and it has not won very many—less than five. It is an important precedent that the CLP in this instance has cooperated with the settlement of the claim. I acknowledge that approach by it. But I would not get too carried away with it, and I will explain why in a moment.

Hodgson Downs was purchased as a pastoral lease and then claimed by Aboriginal claimants. As a result of the claim process it became Aboriginal land under the land rights act, thus our amendment this afternoon. What is significant is that Hodgson Downs has not operated as a pastoral lease since the 1960s. That in itself is important, and I will come to that in a moment.

Why it is important is that there can be no argument by opponents to land rights, some very conservative vested interests in small sections of the pastoral industry. That the granting of this lease will have a negative effect on the Northern Territory cattle industry is clearly, patently, untrue.

The great importance of this amendment today is that the strength of the spiritual attachment to the land has been recognised and respected in the legislation. That respect was incorporated in the legislation, which significantly was prepared initially by the Whitlam government and subsequently, although amended by the Fraser government, put into force by a conservative coalition government in this country. The Fraser government needs to be congratulated for having the foresight to carry on the work of the Whitlam government to pass this piece of legislation, which was based on recommendations of Justice Woodward in his royal commission report. For those on the opposition benches who have reservations about the importance of Aboriginal land and how it should be dealt with, I commend to them their reading of that report.

I have already alluded to the attitude of the CLP government in the Northern Territory to the land rights act and to the practice of Aboriginal people purchasing pastoral leases and, in some cases, seeking to convert them to inalienable freehold title under the land rights act. I think we as a nation need to be concerned that, despite the very many good words I have heard this afternoon from opposition members in this place, there are conservative political leaders in this country who do not share the views expressed by the opposition and who have sought to disparage in the most insulting way the efforts of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory to acquire land and then transfer its title.

A disingenuous concern has been expressed by the Northern Territory government about the ability and desire of Aboriginal people to purchase pastoral leases. Indeed, in his address to the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association, which was put out in a press release on 6 May 1994 in the lead-up to the Northern Territory election, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Depending how you are situated, there seems to be good times and bad times for the cattle industry.
Note this particular point:
[I]f you're in Central Australia and you haven't recovered from the drought, or are surrounded by properties that have been taken over by Aboriginal interests, it's hard to find a silver lining.
He further states:

Now for more bad news. We've heard on the grapevine of a push for Aboriginal Benefit Trust Account reserves of around twenty million dollars to be used to buy up pastoral properties [for Aboriginal people].

I, as a non-Aboriginal Australian, as a Northern Territory citizen, as a citizen of this country, am concerned at those sorts of views being expressed by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. When discussing the issue of social justice in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly on Tuesday, 10 May 1994, and when referring to issues relating to the provision of services to meet the disadvantage of Aboriginal people in this country, the Chief Minister said:
Is it social justice that provides benefits to some based on racial ancestry which others pay for but are not entitled to?

That is the attitude of the Northern Territory Chief Minister—an attitude which, frankly, I regard as racist; an attitude which is replicated in his statements time and again about the issue of land rights. That attitude is not shared by some of our opponents here. I was delighted this afternoon to hear the member for Aston (Mr Nugent), when referring to this land rights legislation, which was passed after development by the Whitlam and Fraser governments—and they deserve due credit for it—say that the Liberal Party is proud and justifiably so of it. His pride, his satisfaction, his endorsement—and I hope the endorsement of the shadow minister, the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus)—are not shared by the CLP or by Marshall Perron.

PARA.TAB: I will read what the Northern Territory Chief Minister said about the land rights act. I ask the shadow minister to take note of this. Mr Perron said:

SPEECH.PARA: There should not be one law for one group of people and a completely different one for others.
He said that his government would be `vigorously pursuing' the right of territorians to be equal with the rest of Australia when it came to land rights.

PARA.TAB: The Northern Territory government has made it very clear that it does not support the key aspect of this legislation, which is the right of Aboriginal people to withhold consent for development on their land. That is the key aspect or centrepiece in terms of Aboriginal control. An article in the Australian of 10 May 1994 states:
The Northern Territory's Chief Minister, Mr Perron, yesterday challenged the validity of sections of the federal Aboriginal Land Rights (NT) Act and in particular Aborigines' right of veto over land.

SPEECH.PARA: What Mr Perron does not know and what he ought to know is that there is no mention of the word `veto' in the act in any event. His views are shared by others in the Northern Territory government. The erstwhile pretender to Perron's throne as chief minister is Shane Stone. He said in the legislative assembly of October last year:

. . . that if Canberra was to get their hoof off our throat and get rid of absurd policies like the 3 mine policy, and the Northern Territory land right act, with Mabo legislation across the top, we could get on with the business of making a dollar . . .

I ask the shadow minister, who is sitting in the chamber, whether she supports these views or whether she will step away from them. Will she walk out of this chamber and say that she supports the views of the Northern Territory Chief Minister, or the views of the erstwhile chief minister Shane Stone, or the views of other members of the CLP government in relation to the land rights act? Or will she support the member for Aston, who proudly speaks of his endorsement of this particular bill? I am waiting with bated breath, and I doubt that I will ever know.

PARA.TAB: We know of the association that the CLP in the Northern Territory has with this opposition. I ask the shadow minister to ask her colleague Senator Grant Tambling—Grant Rumblings—what he thinks of this legislation. Does he support your view, if you have this view? If that is not your view, what is your view? Do you have a policy or not in relation to this particular piece of legislation?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I bring to the attention of the parliamentary secretary that there is a proper way to address people across this chamber. He is not using that proper form.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—I ask the honourable member to please observe the courtesies of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most certainly. I am just referring to the shadow spokesperson, Mr Deputy Speaker—if she has such a thin skin. She should ask the opposition whether or not it endorses the policies of its CLP colleagues in the Northern Territory. That is very simple. It is not a hard question. Just walk outside and say whether or not you do, or say it in here on the public record. I doubt that you will.
—She's walking outside now. You should go and join her.

—Quick, go and make a public statement. I know what it will be. I am sure that, if she does support Marshall Perron, she will not tell us, and that, if she does not support him, she will not tell us that either. That illustrates the dichotomy which opposition members find themselves in. Their colleagues in the Northern Territory do not support their position. But they will not tell the Northern Territory CLP what their position is. They will not tell the CLP that they will not tolerate the stunts being pulled by them in the Northern Territory. As I think the member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) said this afternoon in this chamber, the opposition will support the right of people to withhold consent over mining on their land. The Northern Territory government needs to be told this to see whether it will espouse the same principles, to see whether the Northern Territory Chief Minister will retract his previous statements.

PARA.TAB: Comment has been made in this debate in this past week about reports, particularly about Mick Dodson's second report as Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner. He makes particular reference to the issue of land acquisition. I think it is important that we understand this in the context of this debate because this was about the purchase of a property which was ultimately transferred into Aboriginal title as a result of a land claim process. Mr Dodson states:

SPEECH.PARA: Aboriginal land acquisition programmes, for instance, are constantly being criticised—
we know they are, by the Northern Territory CLP government, as I have already illustrated, and by sections of industry—
for not being primarily directed towards maximising monetary profit . . .
That is Shane Stone's line. Mr Dodson continues:

Such criticisms indicate a failure to understand or respect the fact that Indigenous peoples may place just as great a value on their social and cultural wellbeing as they do on economic gain. What is at issue here is the practical application of the right to self-determination and, specifically, the non-Indigenous system's willingness to surrender control of the way in which Indigenous peoples manage and develop their resources.
He goes on to make a comment on the assessment of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission's land acquisition package. I quote from that assessment:

There was very high satisfaction with the movement of kin to remote properties, considerable satisfaction with the levels of harmony achieved, and on cultural matters, high satisfaction with the establishment of outstations, the protection of significant areas of land and with culturally appropriate schooling.
That is very important. I just want to quote from the report of Pat Dodson from the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation in which he says:

A number of general principles can be derived as to what rights Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people would wish to see recognised, in the legal framework, so that there is appropriate empowerment to ensure that these rights can actually be accessed by indigenous communities and organisations. These principles might be set out:
.the right to own and control their cultural and intellectual property—
a fundamental right and one which we should all endorse—
.the right to protect sacred and significant sites;
.the right to own and control management of lands which are conserved in whole or in part because of their indigenous cultural values;
.the right to benefit from the commercial exploitation of indigenous flora and fauna;
.the right to camp and hunt or gather for personal or family use in conserved land and marine areas; and

.the right to participate in the commercial harvesting of native resources of the land and sea where previously the granting of rights, licenses or quotas have had the effect of excluding indigenous individuals or communities.

That range of issues is in part directly addressed by the Northern Territory land rights legislation—a very important piece of legislation. I would think it is one of the key pieces of social legislation passed in the history of this parliament and passed on a bipartisan basis. It was initially developed by the Whitlam government and finally passed by the Fraser government, based on the reports of the Woodward commission.

PARA.TAB: It is something which is being supported in this chamber by the opposition. It is something which, most significantly for the people in the Northern Territory, for those people who are subject to this legislation, is not supported by the conservative Country-Liberal Party government in the Northern Territory. That should concern all Australians. If we are to strive towards reconciliation, if we are to accept difference and diversity, if we are to accept the importance and significance of Aboriginal cultural and heritage values and if we are to accept and take pride in the spirituality of Aboriginal heritage, what we should be saying to the Northern Territory government is: `Get your act together. You're an international embarrassment. You're a shame on Australia for not supporting this very key piece of social legislation,' which, as Pat Dodson has said, gives people a priority.

It is something which I know is supported in the good hearts of many of our opponents in this chamber, but something which is significantly not supported by the government with the primary interface in terms of the provision of services for Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory. It is a shame that the CLP cannot live up to the standards that the Australian community requires, but it should not be a surprise to us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I would like to say some relatively brief words in summing up the debate that has ensued in respect of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 2) before the House. I note that the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) made a very important contribution highlighting the policies of the Northern Territory government as they relate to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act.

PARA.TAB: I should say for the record that my recollection is there are some 30 Federal Court or High Court challenges that have been launched in respect of intended grants or in respect of land claims hearings under the Northern Territory land rights act by the Northern Territory government. Of those 30 legal actions, my recollection is that, at best, only one-half of one of those cases has, in fact, been successful. What we have seen is tens of millions of dollars of public money over a very long time used to thwart the finalisation of land claims. Regrettably, that process of frustration has led to the death of a great many traditional owners who have not been able to see the ultimate return of their traditional country. To those of us in the parliament who have been privileged to be either directly involved, as ministers or as observers, in the return of traditional land under the Northern Territory land rights act, it is a deeply moving experience. I do not think I have been to one single land title return where the traditional owners have not wept with a mixture of joy and sadness on that occasion. Often, the sadness is because of those who are no longer with them to witness that great occasion.

Having said that, it is important to put on record that this is a very positive piece of legislation and a very positive development that we see the land council, the Northern Territory government and, indeed, the Commonwealth parliament unanimously coming together to settle and resolve one of the outstanding land claims. This is how we, as a nation and as governments, should transact business and regulate our dealings with indigenous people. If we can settle claims, if we can negotiate a successful outcome, it is a far better approach than litigating at great cost to the whole community, including the non-Aboriginal community, and at great personal cost.

One of the things I have been very pleased to be deeply involved in during my time as a minister is trying to address the backlog of land claims under the Northern Territory land rights act; that is, those claims where there has been a land commissioner's report but no decision has been taken in respect of a return of the country. It happened through various reasons—I do not think it was the fault of any minister—that some of the land claims had been effectively outstanding for the best part of a decade or more. We now have a position where we are virtually up to date with all the land commissioners' reports. With minor exceptions, they have now been acted on, proper decisions taken and the land returned. That is how the land rights act should work for indigenous people and for the wider community.

The member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) made an important contribution on behalf of the coalition. What he said, in response to a comment I made in the course of his speech, was that the coalition was committed to the retention of the veto under the Northern Territory land rights act. That, of course, was the very issue which led the member for Mayo (Mr Downer) into the troubled sands of the central Australian deserts in the course of last year. It was the issue of whether there was going to be a repeal of that veto provision or not that regrettably caused him and the wider community so much confusion. Today, we have an important statement from the shadow minister for resources and energy, the member for Gippsland, committing the coalition to the retention of that veto.

The member for the Northern Territory is right to raise the issue of the stance of the Northern Territory government. I do not know whether the shadow minister's comments will be reported in the Northern Territory News in the morning or whether they will be in Saturday morning's paper that greets the Chief Minister with this news. But I would hope that the comments by the shadow minister for resources and energy would, for all time, end the threat that has been hanging over the heads of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory that their rights would in some way be eroded if, in the distant future, if ever, a coalition government came to power. So at least in that respect I think this debate has been important.

The debate has also been characterised by a large measure of cross-party cooperation. We should not be ashamed about that. As parliamentarians, and often protagonists, we should not be worried that on this occasion—shock, horror—political parties and members of parliament agree. We are agreeing about some important principles. The return of land to its traditional owners is a very important measure of social justice.

We need to find far greater areas of common agreement. There is very much a need for a return to the greatest degree of cross-party cooperation in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs that we can possibly achieve. I do not think that Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islanders want to see a bitter divide in this parliament on indigenous policy.

I remind the House that during the first three years I was in this job the then shadow minister, the member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), played a very constructive role in the coalition—and I give him credit for that—in achieving a large measure of cross-party cooperation. It worked well for him as the shadow minister and it worked well for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Regrettably, after the 1993 election, the coalition took a very big step away from that cross-party cooperation.

It is not my intention to recanvass what has sometimes been described as the Mabo debate, which was a pretty sad and sorry time in Australian political history. The Mabo debate concluded in the most dramatic way by a 7:0 decision by the High Court of Australia in upholding the validity of the Native Title Act. We now see a genuine sea change in the attitudes of not only key people in the community but also very significant sections of the Australian mining industry.

This change was reflected in the statement by Mr Leon Davis, the managing director of CRA. When he recognised the significance of the Native Title Act, he indicated that his company could work with that legislation and, of even more significance, he indicated a commitment to negotiate with Aboriginal people. Again the shadow minister for resources highlighted the importance of that negotiation. He spoke of the agreement that had been achieved in respect of the Mount Todd goldmine in the Northern Territory, where the NT government negotiated with Aboriginal people and with the company in question, Zapopan, with the support of the Commonwealth. We had an outcome there that gave the title of that land to Aboriginal people and got the goldmine off the ground, but very importantly it gave Aboriginal people an economic interest in the region and in the development of the mine proposal. This need to move to equal negotiations with and mutual respect of Aboriginal people in the mining industry is one of the most important agendas for corporate Australia.

Until Mr Davis made that statement, CRA, to be very frank, did not have a recognised good public track record in dealing with indigenous people. It is sad, but I think it is true to say that. I am so full of hope that Mr Davis's statement will be further reflected in the range of initiatives and policies taken by CRA that will make that company a pacesetter in the Australian mining industry in its dealings with indigenous people. I think the statement is a bona fide one and one that comes with considerable commitment from the chief executive.

I want to say a couple of other things before I finish up. There have been some very significant developments elsewhere in trying to achieve a greater degree of cross-party cooperation. In this parliament today we had formed a group called `Parliamentarians for reconciliation'. Its conveners are Senator Reynolds from Queensland and the member for Aston (Mr Nugent), a former shadow minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. I hope that that group can play a constructive role in the parliament in building cross-party cooperation. That does not mean that issues of principle are not going to be defended, fought for and upheld. I think, if we do have rational debates about issues of policy, it is possible to get that very large measure of cross-party cooperation. It gives me no joy whatsoever to have issues of Aboriginal affairs policy the subject of bitter division.

I thank the House for its generosity in allowing me to explore a number of related issues mostly raised in the course of debate. Another important area where we need to work with great wisdom as parliamentarians and to approach in the most constructive and open-hearted manner possible is the important issue of social policy, the third stage of the response to the High Court decision in the form of the social justice package. There has already been a report from ATSIC advocating proposals; there will be a report from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner; and there is a report by the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation.

I commend to the House and to all those who might be listening to this parliamentary broadcast the significance of that document. It is a unanimous document supported by Democrat, coalition and government members on the council and a wide array of Australians—Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal—that really sets out a potential agenda for constructive and sensible social reform in this country.

If we can get behind the broad thrust of that document—by all means let us have a discussion about particular issues that some of us might not support at a particular point in time—if we are open-hearted in the way we approach it and if we show respect to the processes of further consultation and negotiation and strive for the greatest degree of cross-party cooperation, we will be doing the same service to the nation as a parliament that we did in initiating unanimously the reconciliation process itself.
Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you for the opportunity to conclude the debate. I thank individual members for their contribution, and I feel confident that the legislation will pass the House unanimously.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Tickner) read a third time.
Motion (by Mr O'Keefe) agreed to:

DEBATE.TITLE: WEAPONS OF MASS DESTRUCTION (PREVENTION OF PROLIFERATION) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 6 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear The Hon G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill now be read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Weapons of Mass Destruction (Prevention of Proliferation) Bill 1994 will assist the government in ensuring that Australia is fulfilling its treaty obligations and its citizens do not contribute to the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction in any part of the world.

PARA.TAB: Controlling weapons of mass destruction is one of the most important security challenges facing the post-Cold War world. The issue is a high foreign policy and defence priority for the government. International recognition of the horrific results of the use of weapons of mass destruction—nuclear, biological and chemical weapons and their missile delivery systems—and concerns over the destabilising impact of the proliferation of such weapons have resulted in several major achievements in addressing this problem. Of greatest importance are the multilateral treaties either banning or restricting the proliferation of such weapons, principally the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, the biological weapons convention and the chemical weapons convention, which is not yet in force.

In addition to these global treaties, and reinforcing their objectives, are other measures which have been taken to stem proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, WMD. In concert with other similarly minded countries, the Australian government has maintained a range of export controls aimed at preventing the transfer, directly or indirectly, of goods and technology, which could be used in the development of WMD, to programs known to be or suspected of posing a WMD proliferation risk. These controls were developed by international export control regimes of which Australia is a member—the nuclear suppliers group and the Zangger committee (nuclear), the Australia group (chemical and biological) and the missile technology control regime (missile delivery systems).

Australia's export controls on goods, including technology in a tangible form, are covered by the Customs Act 1901 through the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations. Exports of dual use materials and technology, equipment and technology which have both commercial and military uses, are controlled under a series of these regulations.

It is not possible to identify and describe, for regulatory purposes, all items that might be used in a WMD program. Some items may be identified but, because of their widespread commercial application, it would be impracticable to control them under the customs regulations: once in regulations, all exports of these items would require a permit, which would create an unnecessary administrative burden on the licensing authority as well as for industry. However, the government would still want to have the authority to stop such items from being exported to a destination considered to be a WMD proliferation risk.

The customs regulations also cannot control the supply of goods and technology by an Australian overseas or the provision of services or other assistance to a WMD program. Services or assistance could for example take the form of a consultancy contract to provide technical, operational or management advice to a WMD program; financial assistance; brokering the supply of materials; or specialised training. It would also cover the transmission of information by telephone, fax and other forms which cannot be covered under the customs regulations.

A number of similarly placed countries have responded to this problem by the development of the catch-all or safety net provisions as an element of the barriers to WMD proliferation, for example, the United States and Germany. Although it can take different forms, essentially it works in two ways. It puts an onus on a person not to export goods or provide a service or other assistance intentionally or recklessly to a WMD program. It also provides the government with a mechanism to prevent the export of goods or the provision of a service or other assistance to an actual or possible WMD program. While there is a wide range of goods and services that can be used in a WMD program which have legitimate commercial uses and are not specifically controlled under existing legislation, it would be inconsistent with Australia's strong support for the international non-proliferation regimes and strong opposition to WMD proliferation for the government not to have all necessary authority to prevent the provision of goods and services to WMD programs.

This is not a theoretical problem for Australia. There have been several cases in recent years where Australian companies have inadvertently become involved in activities which could have assisted WMD programs, and these activities were not specifically covered by Australia's existing non-proliferation legislation. Fortunately the companies involved were cooperative and ceased the activities in question when the government informed them of its concerns. We cannot, however, conclude from the positive outcome in those cases that this will always be the case in the future, particularly in the face of the possible financial inducements on offer from those associated with the WMD programs; hence the need to provide clear legislative backing for the government's comprehensive WMD non-proliferation policy.

The prohibitions under the bill would apply where the person involved knows of or suspects the connection with a WMD program. The bill provides for a ministerial certificate to be issued prohibiting relevant activities in cases where government authorities are aware of the risk of the potential contribution to a WMD program, but the exporter is not aware of the connection or has ignored or not appreciated warning signs. An important element of the bill is the provision for a mechanism to be established for companies and individuals to obtain written guidance from the government on the risk, or not, of a particular planned transaction contributing to a WMD program.

This legislation is not meant to be the prime or sole barrier against possible Australian assistance to the proliferation of WMD. The customs regulations, information programs and persuasion will continue to serve an important function. The legislation would be used only when other measures fail or are unavailable. It would also serve to underline again the government's clear commitment to prevent Australian assistance to proliferation of WMD.
I commend the bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is worth reiterating for the benefit of the House part of what the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) has just said which goes to the heart of the rationale for the Weapons of Mass Destruction (Prevention of Proliferation) Bill 1994. I quote in part from what the Assistant Treasurer has just said:

SPEECH.PARA: Controlling weapons of mass destruction is one of the most important security challenges facing the post-Cold War world. The issue is a high foreign policy and defence priority for the government.
He finished by saying—and I think this is a point that we need to reinforce:

This legislation is not meant to be the prime or sole barrier against possible Australian assistance to the proliferation of WMD. The Customs Regulations, information programs and persuasion will continue to serve an important function. The legislation would be used only when other measures fail or are unavailable. It would also serve to underline again the government's clear commitment to prevent Australian assistance to proliferation of WMD.

With those comments by way of background, the coalition supports the general thrust of the bill. However, we do have some reservations about the mechanics of one or two clauses of the bill, especially in relation to the bureaucratic demands imposed by it. I will come back to those specific items a little later.

PARA.TAB: As the Assistant Treasurer said, the general purpose of the bill is to restrict trade in any materials likely to be used in weapons of mass destruction, the so-called WMDs, which describes nuclear, biological and chemical weapons capable of resulting in mass destruction of the population. The bill does so by levying penalties for export of goods which may be used for the construction of such WMDs, with a couple of strong qualifiers that it only covers exports where a person believes or suspects on reasonable grounds that goods will or may be used in a WMD program, and also that its broad framework allows normal exports and allows for clarification by the minister if doubt exists.

I suppose the basic question that we should all be addressing this evening is: why, therefore, should all Australians support this bill? I suggest that there are five reasons why we should do just that. Firstly, it recognises a general repugnance of any proliferation post-Cold War of such weapons. Secondly, it signals a very specific commitment to the associated international treaties. Thirdly, its strong theme strengthens and reinforces our attitude to an indefinite extension of the non-proliferation treaty at the NPT review and extension conference in New York next month, between 17 April and 12 May. Fourthly, it exemplifies Australia's commitment to regional stability by showing the strength of our own commitment to non-proliferation. Finally, it is very consistent with last year's defence white paper. I take the opportunity to refer to that defence white paper, specifically to pages 108 and 109, under the heading `Non-Proliferation and Arms Control'. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: Effective controls on the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and ballistic missiles contribute significantly to Australia's security. Twenty years or more of sustained negotiation between the then superpowers and in multilateral forums have led to the development of an unprecedented array of non-proliferation and arms control regimes (particularly the Strategic Arms Limitations Agreement and the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, the Treaty Banning Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces, the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty—
which I referred to a moment ago—

the Chemical and Biological Weapons Conventions, and the Partial and Threshold Nuclear Test Ban Treaties). However, with the end of the Cold War, economic growth and strategic uncertainties have increased the potential for proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. As a result, non-proliferation issues are at the forefront of international security concerns.

PARA.TAB: Australia shares a global interest in reducing the risk of countries acquiring or using weapons of mass destruction and ballistic missiles. We have a strong direct interest in ensuring that such weapons are not acquired by countries or terrorist groups which could use them against Australia. While the mere acquisition of these weapons would not indicate a threat to Australia, their existence within reach of us would complicate and add to the cost of our defence. Furthermore, if one regional country acquires weapons of mass destruction or missile capabilities other regional countries may respond, possibly by developing matching capabilities. Such a sequence would destabilise regional security and further complicate defence planning. The best way to prevent proliferation is to establish effective global regimes, such as the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, the Chemical Weapons Convention and the Biological Weapons Convention. Australia will continue to support and if possible strengthen these regimes, and ensure they are fully implemented and effectively verifiable. Defence will continue to promote and implement regional non-proliferation and arms control measures.
