A key priority is limiting the proliferation of ballistic missiles. The Government will continue its efforts to make the Missile Technology Control Regime an effective mechanism for this purpose, and will seek the broadest international commitment to controls on developing and exporting ballistic missile technology. Our involvement in international processes will be complemented by continued efforts to secure acceptance of, and adherence to, this Regime within the region.

SPEECH.PARA: In this context, it is appropriate that we should review Australia's track record on these issues. I point out, for those who are not aware of it, that we are party to three international treaties concerned with the control and reduction of weapons of mass destruction. The Treaty on Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons—the so-called NPT, which I would like to comment on in a little more detail later—was ratified by Australia on 23 January 1973, and was substantially implemented by the Nuclear Non-proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987. We also have the Convention on the Prohibition of the Development, Production and Stockpiling of Bacteriological (Biological) and Toxin Weapons and their Destruction. This was ratified by Australia on 5 October 1977, and was substantially implemented by the Crimes (Biological Weapons) Act 1976.

PARA.TAB: Finally, we have the Convention on the Prohibition of the Development, Production, Stockpiling and use of Chemical Weapons and on their Destruction, which was ratified on 6 May 1994, but has not yet come into force internationally. It will be substantially implemented by the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act 1994, which will come into force on a date to be proclaimed or upon the convention coming into force. It is therefore quite unambiguous that these three treaties and their associated legislation place limits on the use and transfer of chemical, nuclear and bacteriological material.

In addition, Australia is involved in four relevant international groups which aim to control the international transfer of weapons grade materials. The first of these groups is the Zangger committee, which was formed in the early 1970s by countries which supply nuclear materials and which have developed a list of equipment, the export of which should be subject to safeguards. The overall aim of this group is to develop controls on the export of equipment for use in the production of special fissionable material. The second of these groups is the nuclear suppliers group, which was formed in 1974. This group has developed guidelines for the export of nuclear related equipment and technology which is aimed at preventing the proliferation of nuclear weapons.

The third group is the missile technology control regime, which was referred to in the extract I read into the record from the defence paper of last year. That group was established in 1987. It comprises a group of countries which have agreed to a basic set of guidelines on the export of missile technology, and these guidelines are incorporated into national export regulations. Finally, there is the Australia group, which was established in 1987 to facilitate a chemical weapons treaty. It deals with the export of material for the making of chemical weapons until such a treaty comes into force. It has also developed a list of chemicals which require export controls.

It is therefore pretty clear that Australia's record is very good. We have met our international obligations arising from treaties and international group involvement by enacting important legislation—as I have just indicated—to deal with such nuclear chemical and bacteriological material. Export controls have been imposed also through the Customs (Prohibited Export) Regulations under the Customs Act 1901. Clearly, we are playing an important role in these matters.

Turning to some of the more significant clauses of the bill, at international law, Australia would not have jurisdiction to legislate in relation to things that happen outside Australia unless it had this connection with Australian citizens, residents or companies. To this end, clause 6 of the bill provides that the bill will apply not only to actual acts or omissions in Australia but also to actual acts or omissions done outside Australia by Australian citizens, people who ordinarily reside in Australia and bodies incorporated in Australia.

Clause 7 sets out the constitutional basis for the bill. It draws on four areas: the external affairs power, under section 51(xxix), to the extent that it gives effect to the three conventions I referred to previously; the defence power, under section 51(vi); the corporations power, under section 51(xx); and the trade and commerce power, under section 51(i). Clause 9 provides that, where a person supplies goods to another, believing or suspecting on reasonable grounds that the goods may be used in a program for the development, production, acquisition or stockpiling of weapons of mass destruction—the so-called WMD program—a person is guilty of an offence punishable by imprisonment for a maximum of eight years.

Clause 12 refers to the issuing of a ministerial notice if the minister does not believe or suspect that the goods may be used in a WMD program. Clause 13 specifies that a person is not guilty of an offence if the supply of goods is authorised by a permit granted under that particular clause. Clause 14 allows the minister to send out notices prohibiting a person from exporting the goods or services. The minister may issue such notices only if he or she has reason to believe or suspect that the goods or services might be used to assist a WMD program and the minister considers a permit could not be given under clause 13. Such a notice lasts for 12 months. It is an offence for a person to knowingly supply or export goods or services contrary to a notice. The penalty for this is imprisonment for a maximum of eight years.

Clause 15 attributes the belief or suspicion of a director, employee or agent acting within his or her authority to the relevant corporation, unless the corporation proves that it took reasonable precautions and exercised due diligence to avoid the conduct. If a corporation is convicted, section 4B of the Crimes Act 1914 allows a court to impose a fine upon it of up to five times the maximum fine which could be imposed on an individual.

This raises the issue of our reservations about the bureaucratic demands and potential legal risks of the bill I referred to in opening this debate. The bill imposes additional burdens on companies to become aware of the ultimate use of goods or services that they might provide or export. Although the criminal provisions require a level of intent of belief or suspicion, a jury could attribute suspicion to a company if it held or had access to information which indicates that the goods or services might be used for a WMD program, even if nobody in the company had actually turned his or her mind to it. The company must also take care that none of its directors, employees or agents hold suspicions without alerting the responsible person in the company. Otherwise, the knowledge of the director, employee or agent could be attributed to the company, and this could result in conviction, a fine and confiscation of the goods.

The bill makes provision that a company in an uncertain position over the so-called end use can at least apply to a minister for a statement upon which it can rely. I point out to the Assistant Treasurer that this burden on companies needs to be balanced against the importance of limiting the capacity of countries to construct weapons of mass destruction.

The coalition therefore hopes that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) will recognise these potential difficulties and ensure that an awareness program arising from this bill is provided to the commercial sector generally and, more specifically, to those industries likely to be affected or with the potential to be affected. We suggest also that the minister disseminate a list of materials and destinations likely to represent cause for concern, although I appreciate that the Assistant Treasurer did make one or two of those points—albeit briefly—in his second reading speech. With those caveats, the coalition supports the bill and its underlying commitment.

I would like to say a few words about the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons—the so-called NPT—which provides the international framework for preventing the spread of nuclear weapons. The NPT, along with the UN charter, are the key documents on international security. The NPT was concluded in 1968 and entered into force in 1970 after ratification by the United States, the Soviet Union and the United Kingdom—the so-called depositary powers of the treaty—and 40 other states. One of the broad objectives of the treaty is to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons to states other than the five states which had already developed nuclear weapons in 1968. These states are United States, the Soviet Union—Russia has since acceded to these obligations—the United Kingdom, France and China. Other objectives are to facilitate peaceful nuclear cooperation between treaty members, and to work towards general and complete nuclear disarmament.

In the coalition's view, the NPT has become vital to global and regional security. It provides essential assurances for international trade and cooperation in the peaceful uses of nuclear energy. Without the assurances offered by the NPT and the system of International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards, distrust of nuclear intentions would feed regional security problems. Without the assurances offered by the NPT, international nuclear cooperation would dwindle.

Projections in the 1960s were that 20 to 25 states would have developed or acquired nuclear weapons by the 1980s. Despite challenges to the non-proliferation regime, it is a measure of the treaty's success that such fears have not been realised.

Australia ratified the NPT in 1973. Current membership is an impressive 174, reflecting the treaty's success in establishing a norm against nuclear weapons proliferation. Parties include all five of the original nuclear weapon states, as I have already indicated, and most states with advanced nuclear programs, regrettably with Israel, Pakistan and India remaining notable but increasingly isolated exceptions.

The NPT provides for five-yearly conferences, which have been convened since 1975, to review the operations of the treaty and to make recommendations about its future implementation. This review process will be an important part of the 1995 conference in New York and, despite disappointing progress on disarmament during the Cold War years, the review conferences have nevertheless provided a forum for the international community to continue to maintain pressure on the nuclear weapon states to stop nuclear testing, to halt the arms race and to start nuclear reductions. But much more productive has been the work of successive review conferences in strengthening other key provisions of the treaty, including safeguards, peaceful uses of nuclear energy and nuclear supply, and recommendations for complementary nuclear agreements and arrangements.

Let me make it very clear to the House that the coalition believes that the NPT makes a vital contribution to international peace and security, as do all ASEAN, Indochinese and north Asian countries and all South Pacific Forum—except Vanuatu—members of the NPT. It has provided the framework for the smooth development of the nuclear industry in the region and a firm foundation for the long-term planning and major investments required by nuclear technology. It has facilitated regional nuclear cooperation and trade, as well as trade and cooperation with countries outside the region.

The honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) might be interested to hear that this side of the House strongly supports the indefinite extension of the NPT in New York in May of this year. We believe that the indefinite extension of the NPT is the best guarantee of the continuation of the international and regional security benefits provided to date by the NPT.

We also support urgent conclusion of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty of indefinite duration. We want to see a thorough review in New York of the operation and effectiveness of that treaty. We want to encourage NPT members to see the conference as an opportunity to shape the environment of the next century so that we can achieve the nuclear-free world we all seek. We do not want to be looking back at what was and what was not done over the past 25 years with the constraints of the Cold War.

I note and acknowledge some of the reservations and criticisms of the NPT: that the treaty is discriminatory, dividing countries into nuclear haves and have-nots, and should be rewritten; that nothing serious has been done about nuclear disarmament and there are more nuclear weapons today than in 1968 when the treaty was negotiated; that indefinite extension will legitimise the status of the nuclear weapon states for ever; that the International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards are ineffective, as demonstrated in the case of Iraq and North Korea, and do not prevent proliferation; that the NPT has not delivered access to nuclear technology for developing countries and suppliers have imposed export controls which hinder the economic development of developing countries; that nuclear smuggling is the new challenge—I do not think anybody would disagree with that—and demonstrates the ineffectiveness of the NPT, with which I hope the House would disagree; and that the NPT has been a failure because it has not attracted the support of key threshold countries such as India, Pakistan and Israel.

Nevertheless, the coalition believes that the New York conference provides an historic opportunity. We believe it is an appropriate opportunity to continue to strengthen the safeguards, nuclear supply and peaceful uses provisions of the treaty, to build further momentum towards universal membership, and also, for the first time, to lock in the post-Cold War disarmament achievements and to ensure the most propitious environment for future nuclear disarmament. As I said before, that means extending the treaty indefinitely. Anything less would only provide arguments to those who wish to see the disarmament process go no further. It would undermine the normative effect of the treaty, create uncertainty in nuclear trade and send wrong signals to the threshold states about the commitment of NPT parties to this important treaty.
I hope to see the requirement commitment first-hand when I visit New York. Hopefully, I will be accredited, albeit for just a few hours, to the NPT extension conference.
The coalition supports this legislation, with the caveats that I referred to briefly a moment ago. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is debating the Weapons of Mass Destruction (Prevention of Proliferation) Bill 1995. We do so at a time when, for the first time in the world's history, we have experienced the use of a weapon of mass destruction by a terrorist group. I am talking about the use of chemical weapons in the Tokyo subway system which resulted in 10 or 11 deaths and more than 5,000 injuries. It is therefore very pertinent that this House and this parliament considers this legislation, and that this government puts on record its very firm commitment to the elimination of weapons of mass destruction and its intention to prevent the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this bill is to supplement existing controls, such as customs controls, on the export of material which could be used in the production of weapons of mass destruction and to restrict the provision of services or the export of ordinary commercial goods which might be used to make, develop or store weapons of mass destruction. When we talk about weapons of mass destruction, we are talking about nuclear weapons, biological weapons and chemical weapons.

It is also important for the House to understand that, although we do not possess any one of those three types of weapons, Australia has taken a leading role in negotiations around the world to achieve the limitation and ultimate elimination of those types of weapons. Australian Foreign Affairs officials and disarmament negotiators have taken a very strong and leading role in achieving finalisation of treaties and agreements, of regulations and legislation, both here and in other countries, so that we can achieve a world regime under which these weapons no longer exist. It is a tribute to this government that we have taken such a leading role.

In 1993 the chemical weapons convention was finally signed after some 26 years of negotiation. We thought it would never be completed but it was finalised because of the intervention of Australian officials who came forward with a set of words that those UN member countries which actually possessed chemical weapons, or which were involved in their production, could agree with.

Australia played a key role in finalising that chemical weapons convention. That weapons convention has not yet been ratified by the whole world. For the treaty to be ratified, we need to get some 60 or 70 countries to sign. This legislation and previous legislation that this House has carried are Australia's legislative fulfilment of its obligations. We are hopeful that by next year this chemical weapons convention will be able to come into force. But that is a sign of the very important role Australia has played for many years in trying to achieve disarmament across all of these types of weapons.

My friend and colleague the member for Groom (Mr Taylor) has outlined the important work that is now under way with regard to the extension and review conference for the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. The government fully supports the indefinite extension of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. We agree—and I personally agree—with all the comments that the member for Groom made about the importance of having an indefinite extension.

There are problems with the nuclear non-proliferation treaty and I will be talking a bit about them. I want to make it clear to this House that I, personally, and the government fully support the indefinite extension of that treaty. That is the only signal we can afford to send to the nuclear weapon states, the non-nuclear weapon states and some of those rogue states that want to seek to develop nuclear weapons. The world community does not support the proliferation of nuclear weapons. What the world community wants is the end of nuclear weapons. That is why an indefinite extension is a very important signal.

Like the member for Groom, I also hope that through the indefinite extension we can convince those countries, those nuclear weapon states that are not signatories to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, to come on board. I refer to the states of Israel, India and Pakistan. They are the only three states where it is clearly acknowledged that they have nuclear weapons.

There were a number of other countries which were in the process of developing them—Argentina and South Africa were two of them—but they have come on board the nuclear non-proliferation treaty and have ended their development of nuclear weapons. A number of other countries that are signatories to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty did commence the development of them: North Korea and Iraq. However, the world community intervened very strongly and made sure that those two countries ended their development of nuclear weapons.

In discussing the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, it is important to understand that there are some weaknesses in that treaty. I am hopeful that in the extension review conference that is held at the end of April and early May in New York—and I am pleased to hear that the member for Groom will get an opportunity to observe that process—we can tighten up the review procedures.

As the member for Groom outlined, one of the weaknesses of the treaty is that it is discriminatory. It protects the nuclear weapon states and maintains their status and leaves all the non-nuclear weapon states in a separate and discriminated status. That is important, because we do not want to see any more countries becoming nuclear weapon states. However, there has been a bit of unfairness in the application of the treaty. A lot of countries that have interests in developing nuclear weapons have had the pressure put on them to cease that development and production.

Similar pressure has not been effectively applied to the nuclear weapon states to stop their further development and enhancement of nuclear weapons and their increasing of stockpiles. It has been acknowledged in this House that the nuclear weapon states now have more than twice as many nuclear weapons as they did when this treaty was ratified in 1970. They have not actually fulfilled their obligations under the treaty.

The treaty was developed in an era of the Cold War. I recognise that and there was, of course, a different political dynamic than we have today. But, because we now have a new world political dynamic, it gives us a real opportunity to put into effect review requirements that set much firmer targets and guidelines for the nuclear weapon states. Only two of the nuclear weapon states are actively involved in disarmament: the United States of America and Russia. Countries such as France, Great Britain and China, which are the other large recognised parties to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, have not engaged in any disarmament negotiations at all. There are no disarmament treaties or arrangements applying to their nuclear stockpiles.

It is about time those three parties came on board and joined with the United States of America and Russia in cutting down their stockpiles and meeting their obligations under the treaty. If you read the actual treaty, it makes it clear that the nuclear weapon states are supposed to be part of an active program of disarmament and reducing their nuclear weapon stockpiles. Those three signatory states are not fulfilling their obligations.

What I personally would like to see, and what a number of my parliamentary colleagues would like to see, is a much tougher regime of review so that each five years, when we are reviewing what is happening, we look back over the previous five years and ask, `What have each of the parties done to fulfil their obligations?' Then, when we report back and determine how they have gone, we set very clear targets for those countries about what we expect to happen in the next five years. We should make it very clear that, as signatories to that treaty, we expect all parties to fulfil their obligations under the treaty in that regard.

That does not diminish in any way the effectiveness of the treaty. What it does seek to do is fulfil some of the obligations of the treaty and make all of the parties to the treaty fulfil their requirements. I think we should be setting some targets for the next five years. We need to conclude a comprehensive ban on all nuclear test explosions. This should come into force completely.

There are agreements and arrangements occurring at the moment. People are saying, `No, we won't.' Bill Clinton has outlined that the United States will not be testing. France has suspended its testing. China, unfortunately, has not suspended its testing. There is no binding agreement on all the states to cease testing. If the United States wanted to change its mind tomorrow, it could. Bill Clinton, as President, has said that he will not, but there is nothing binding in place. There is no regime to effect that decision. We need a comprehensive test ban treaty in place with everybody as signatories and the full force of law.

We need to commence and conclude negotiations for a ban on the production of special fissionable materials for weapons purposes and the entry into force of such an agreement. At the moment, there is still a significant production of special fissionable materials occurring around the world. Stockpiles of that material are being made available. We need a complete ban on that production.

We also need an agreement from all nuclear weapon states that they will cease producing new nuclear weapons. At the moment we have some 70,000 nuclear weapons still stockpiled in all the nuclear weapon states, which would mean that we could blow up the earth completely at least 10 times over if we had the desire to. We do not need any more nuclear weapons being added.

We have now had the end of the Cold War. We have had the end of the dividing of our world between two different groups, where each side had approximately equal numbers of nuclear weapons and forces. We have ended that. There is no need for any member state to have nuclear weapons. Over the next 10 years, every nuclear weapon state should be engaged in a process of destroying their nuclear weapons. It is in the best interests of all member states to do that. Removing those weapons not only ends the tension and the threat to all civilisation but also saves countries money. It enables them to have funds to invest in their people rather than in the production of nuclear weapons.

It is for that reason that I also support and am involved with another group in this parliament, and it is being active as well. Parliamentarians for Global Action, which I convene in this Australian parliament, supports a project called the World Court project, which is a case before the International Court of Justice to declare nuclear weapons illegal. That case does not have the support of the Australian government but it does have the support of many other countries and many parliamentarians and people around the world. We are very hopeful that, through the World Court decision, we can get a declaration that nuclear weapons are in fact illegal, that they should cease production and that all member and nuclear weapon states should immediately commence disarmament and destruction of all of those weapons.

There is broad international agreement that we need to put in place a comprehensive test ban treaty. The first target that I have set for the nuclear weapon states and the non-nuclear weapon states for the next five years should be achievable. There are concerns around the world about the proliferation of fissionable material. So there should be sufficient goodwill in this world community to achieve a ban on the further production and distribution of fissionable nuclear material.

Within the world community, and within the communities and populations of the member countries that have nuclear weapons, there is a desire to end the threat that nuclear weapons pose to their welfare. It is in the best interests of those countries to also cease further production, further enhancement and further improvements to their nuclear weapons. `Save the money. Invest the money in your people' is the message I would like to give those countries. The community, government and people will certainly benefit from such a decision.

I had the opportunity to attend the final preparatory committee meeting of the extension and review conference for the nuclear non-proliferation treaty in January in New York. It was a great pleasure for me to meet and work alongside Mr Ian Cousins, who is the First Assistant Secretary of the International Security Division of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, who heads the Australian delegation in negotiations on the extension review of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. He is a very impressive negotiator for and representative of Australia. I congratulate him and his team on the work they are doing. It was quite a matter of pride for me as an Australian parliamentarian to see how well the Australian negotiators put forward our views when negotiating and discussing matters with a whole range of member states and their representatives.

Australia has an enormous influence on this process, even though we are a non-nuclear weapon state. Ian Cousins was listened to and taken quite seriously by the representatives from the United States, Great Britain, China and a lot of the senior representatives of the non-aligned movement who are very influential in these negotiations.

Australia can be very proud of the work that our representatives are doing. I wish to express my congratulations to Ian Cousins and the DFAT team for the negotiating they will be doing on Australia's behalf in April. I sincerely hope that they succeed in getting a clear and strong vote in favour of an indefinite extension of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. If it does occur, Australia can take some significant pride in that achievement because we can claim that we contributed greatly to that result.

I wish the member for Groom well in his participation in that conference, and I ask him to pass on my congratulations and best wishes to our negotiating team. I think he will also be impressed by the work they do and the way in which they represent Australia's interests in those negotiations.

I will conclude by highlighting the international importance of legislation such as this. Australia takes its international obligation seriously. It is ensuring that no Australian companies are involved in any way in the distribution of materials that could be used for the production of any sort of weapon of mass destruction.

As I said at the beginning of my contribution, in light of the recent terrorist attack in Tokyo where chemical weapons were used—and I believe this is the first time a weapon of mass construction like that has been used in a terrorist attack—which is something we all should be incredibly scared about, it is very important that we have legislation like this in place which restricts and confines companies from being able to produce the necessary goods that make chemical, biological or nuclear weapons. I certainly hope that the other countries in the region will follow our lead and similarly legislate to prevent the distribution and production of such material.
Debate (on motion by Mr Bruce Scott) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1995

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.
Explanatory memorandum presented by Mr Gear; leave granted for second reading to be moved forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear The Hon G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to introduce amendments to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemical Products (Collection of Levy) Act 1994, the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987, the Farm Household Support Act 1992, the Northern Prawn Fishery Voluntary Adjustment Scheme Loan Guarantee Act 1985, the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Act 1987 and the Rural Adjustment Act 1992. In addition, this bill will repeal the Livestock Diseases Act 1978.

PARA.TAB: The Livestock Diseases Act 1978 is to be repealed to remove the Commonwealth's responsibility for exotic disease eradication activities in the Australian Capital Territory and remove the Commonwealth's liability for payment of compensation to ACT producers whose property is destroyed or damaged as a result of exotic disease or associated eradication activities. In addition, the proposed repeal of this act will allow the ACT to join in the Commonwealth-state cost sharing agreement for sharing the costs of exotic animal disease eradication campaigns on an equal basis with the states and the Northern Territory.

The amendments to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemical Products (Collection of Levy) Act 1994 are to address the National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals, the NRA, commencing registration activities in 1995 and not 1994 as was originally intended. The amendments will enable the collection of levy act to apply for 1995-96 and thereafter.

In addition, experience with the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemical Products (Collection of Interim Levy) Act 1994 has identified the requirement for a number of minor amendments which will improve the administrative efficiency of the collection of levy act and hence benefit industry. These amendments include changing the date for payment of the levy from 1 June to 31 July each year. This will remove the necessity for industry to pay both the interim levy and main levy during the 1994-95 financial year. In addition, the NRA will be able to approve levy payments by instalments, thus spreading the cost to industry over a period of time.

The proposed amendments to the late penalty payment provisions will allow for those payments to be set by primary legislation, rather than prescribed by regulations. The Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987 provides the framework for the operations of the Australian Horticultural Corporation, AHC, and its subsidiary product board, the Australian Dried Fruits board.

When the AHC was established, provision was made in its enabling legislation for the chairperson to report to the annual general meeting of the eligible industry body representing a levy paying industry. In the first few years of the corporation's operation, when there were only a small number of industries participating in the corporation, this approach worked well. However, with nine industries now participating in the corporation, the chairperson of the corporation has been required to undertake a significant additional workload. This workload is likely to increase again in the short term as a number of other industries have signalled their intention to commence levy contributions to the corporation.

It is therefore proposed to amend the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987 to enable other members of the corporation's board to provide the annual report of the corporation's activities to the annual general meetings of eligible industry bodies. This will reduce the burden on the chairperson while at the same time maintaining the accountability linkage between the board of directors and its levy paying constituents.

When the Australian Dried Fruits Board was established, provision was made in the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987 for product boards to convene an annual general meeting for the purposes of reporting on their activities to their levy paying constituents. Two such meetings have been held by the Australian Dried Fruits Board—the first in June 1993 and the second in June 1994.

Following representations from the dried vine fruits industry, the government has decided to remove the need for product boards to convene an annual general meeting. The government has accepted the recommendation from the Australian Dried Fruits Association, which is the eligible industry body for dried vine fruit producers, that the chairperson of the Australian Dried Fruits Board report to the annual general meeting of the association. This will replace the need for the Australian Dried Fruits Board, and other product boards which may be established under the act, to hold an annual general meeting. This approach is consistent with the accountability arrangements for the parent body, the Australian Horticultural Corporation, which also reports to the annual general meetings of its eligible industry bodies.

The repeal of the annual general meeting provisions of the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987 will have a retrospective effect from 1 July 1994. The chairperson of the Australian Dried Fruits Board will be required to present the report of the board's 1993-94 activities to the 1995 annual general meeting of the Australian Dried Fruits Association. This arrangement has the total and unqualified support of the Australian Dried Fruits Association, the Australian Dried Fruits Board and the Australian Horticultural Corporation.

The Horticultural Research and Development Corporation is a statutory body which was established in 1988 with the responsibility for the coordination and funding of horticultural research and development, R&D. Horticultural industries which participate in the corporation contribute through statutory levies and export charges and voluntary contributions. Expenditure of industry funds on R&D is matched by the Commonwealth on a dollar for dollar basis up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production of the industry.

It is a requirement of the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Act 1987 that the chairperson of the corporation report each year to the annual conference, or a meeting of the executive, of each eligible industry body representing a levy paying industry. As the number of industries now participating in the corporation has increased to 11, the chairperson of the corporation has experienced a similar increase in workload as the chairperson of the Australian Horticultural Corporation. Accordingly, it is proposed to amend the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Act 1987 to enable other members of the corporation's board to provide the annual report of the corporation's activities to the annual conference or meeting of the executive of each eligible industry body. This is consistent with the approach being proposed for the Australian Horticultural Corporation.

The amendments to the Farm Household Support Act 1992 will extend farm household support to farmers who have reached the pension age. This will provide a further option for farmers who are unable to receive the age pension, or who receive a reduced pension, because they have a relatively high level of farm assets which they are not able to realise. Access to farm household support for this group of farmers will enable them to meet basic living expenses while they arrange for the sale of their property or work to place the farm on a firmer footing.

In addition, the Farm Household Support Act 1992 is being amended to provide for the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to authorise payments to a RAS authority that has incurred costs in connection with the issue of drought exceptional circumstances certificates. These certificates are used by farmers applying for drought relief payment, or who wish to have their farm assets excluded from the assets test normally applied to farmers for Austudy, as evidence that their farm enterprise is located in an area affected by drought exceptional circumstances.

The issue of amending the Northern Prawn Fishery Voluntary Adjustment Scheme Loan Guarantee Act 1985 arose because the Queensland parliament passed a new act covering fisheries management which was brought into effect in January 1995 before the implications flowing from Commonwealth legislation had been dealt with.

Because the Queensland Fisheries Management Authority is a new agency constituted under the new act, the Commonwealth guarantee to the Queensland treasury now has no effect as the Commonwealth act which establishes the loan guarantee refers to the old act and the old agency, namely the Queensland Fish Management Authority.

By changing the definition to reflect the current situation in Queensland state legislation, the Commonwealth guarantee for the northern prawn fishery voluntary adjustment scheme can be restored. Many of Australia's entrenched rural adjustment problems are regionally concentrated. A number of rural regions are currently faced with substantial challenges of economic, social and environmental adjustment.

The Rural Adjustment Act 1992 is being amended to allow the rural adjustment scheme, RAS, to operate at a regional level. This will allow RAS to better address the structural adjustment needs of specific regions.
The amendments to the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill No. 3 seek to do three main things:
.to provide for a regional component to the rural adjustment scheme, RAS;
.to provide flexibility in relation to the provision of support for regional and other elements of RAS; and
.to make it an explicit requirement for Commonwealth support under all elements of RAS to be subject to Commonwealth-states agreement.

A regional approach to RAS would not replace the existing individual based approach. Direct delivery to individual farmers through the state RAS authorities will continue with the two approaches operating in a complementary manner. The proposed changes will allow the Commonwealth the flexibility of dealing directly with farmer groups and organisations involved in rural adjustment, and is an important step in the overall implementation of the regional approach to the scheme.The amendments provide for payments to be made directly to beneficiaries, for payments to entities other than farmers under all elements of RAS and for flexible cost sharing arrangements under all elements of RAS, subject to Commonwealth-state agreement.

The ability to make direct payments and payments to organisations and groups will allow greater efficiency and effectiveness in program delivery. It will allow, for example, one cheque to be paid directly to a training course facilitator, rather than multiple cheques being paid to individual farmers that attend. It will also allow closer linkages to other programs with direct payment elements such as rural counselling, Landcare, and agribusiness.

Activities for support within the framework of regional RAS may include the identification and development of appropriate training courses across the region to address local needs. This may include training on issues such as productivity enhancement options for farm business enterprises, financial management, environmental management, and marketing. Support may also be available for possible further funding of farm exits, and re-training schemes for those leaving the sector.

The flexible cost sharing arrangements allow provision for states or the Commonwealth to make greater funding contributions to regional projects should they so wish. This flexibility is essential to permit RAS assistance to be tailored to regional and community needs. RAS regional initiatives will be implemented consistently with principles for rural regional development developed by the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand, ARMCANZ. Many communities are already working cooperatively on a range of issues and governments can help foster this locally driven initiative through regional RAS.

Amendments to the Rural Adjustment Act 1992 were initially considered by the Senate on 9 February 1995 as part of the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill No. 3, PIELAB. The proposed amendments were referred to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee for further consideration.
In considering the proposed amendments, the committee generally supported a regional approach to the RAS, but raised a number of concerns, in particular:
.the constitutional validity of the amendments;
.administrative arrangements to be established to implement the regional approach to the RAS; and
.consultation with the states in developing the regional approach to the RAS.

The committee's report on its deliberations made a number of useful observations on the proposed amendments. The amendments now proposed respond positively to the committee's report and accommodate the committee's substantive concerns.

The Attorney-General's Department has provided clear advice that the proposed amendments are constitutionally valid and that this validity is not affected by any administrative arrangements that may be put into place.

The Commonwealth's ability to enter into agreements with persons other than states, and to make direct or indirect payments to farmers and persons other than farmers, for the purposes of rural adjustment, is supported by the appropriations power in section 81 and the incidental power in section 51(xxxix) of the constitution.

In a regional context, the Commonwealth funding is intended to be provided for community based activities relating to rural adjustment. The activities would be driven and undertaken by the states, local government, community and industry. In addition to its funding role, the Commonwealth will also monitor the expenditure of such funding ensuring that it is spent for the purpose for which it was allocated, a role which the Attorney-General's Department advises is within the constitutional powers.

With respect to the committee's concerns as to the lack of clarity on administrative arrangements, on 3 March 1995 ARMCANZ endorsed in principle the implementation of integrated and community based regional approaches involving the linked implementation of rural programs such as the RAS, NAP, agribusiness programs, and rural communities access program.

ARMCANZ also agreed in principle to the early implementation of a rural partnership program, RPP, based on a model incorporating input from the case studies report undertaken by SCARM which focused on south-west Queensland and Sunraysia.

The framework supported by ARMCANZ involves a competitive bidding process, extensive community consultation, and joint development of regional strategies with the states and the community. The suggested approach is consistent with that developed by the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council, RASAC, and discussed between Commonwealth and state RAS officers in May 1994.

The south-west Queensland regional strategy is a pilot project for the development of a regional approach to rural adjustment. The strategy is generally consistent with the ARMCANZ approach, incorporating an integrated package of adjustment measures, including RAS, landcare, and rural counselling. The strategy was initially proposed by community based organisations which recognised the need for rural adjustment within the SWQ region, and is a real partnership between the community and governments at local, state, and Commonwealth levels.

Amendments to the original proposed amendments to the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill No. 3, PIELAB, address concerns that the RAS may not be implemented in full consultation with the states. They put in place a requirement for all Commonwealth RAS assistance to be the subject of Commonwealth-state agreements, including regional initiatives.

It has always been the Commonwealth's intention that, within the broad framework discussed with the states, the detailed administrative arrangements under a regional approach would be developed in consultation with the states on a case by case basis and with their full cooperation and consultation. A successful regional initiative can only be effectively and most efficiently implemented with the full cooperation of all parties, Commonwealth, state and local governments community and industry.

The states were consulted on the proposed approach to a regional component to the RAS, including on the nature of each of the proposed amendments to the act, at a meeting of state-Commonwealth RAS officers in May 1994. The states have been consulted in detail on these additional amendments and support the proposed approach.

In conclusion, I believe that the proposed amendments to the Rural Adjustment Scheme Act 1992 will facilitate the achievement of the overall goals of the scheme. I believe that support on a regional basis will encourage the development of a more profitable farm sector that is able to operate competitively in a deregulated financial and market environment, and improve the competitiveness of the farm sector in a sustainable manner. I commend the bill to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —After that dissertation, I wondered how long it would take to read the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995 in total. The Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), who is leaving the House at this moment, certainly gave us a very lengthy explanation as to what the amendments to the bill will mean.

PARA.TAB: The coalition previously supported the majority of this bill but was concerned that amendments to the Rural Adjustment Act 1992 might mean that the federal government could decide land use for an area without consulting the states which have the constitutional power for land use. Listening to the minister, our concerns had basis.

The federal government has been actively trying to whip up local support for restructuring—and I refer to two areas of New South Wales, the western and central west—in a way which looks to the outsider as a bottoms-up approach. But when you take a closer look at it, it is really a tops-down approach and being driven more from the federal government. The coalition does not object to the concept of the rural adjustment scheme being used on a regional area basis, but it wants to ensure that the states are in agreement with the plan and that restructuring is not imposed on an area which does not want to be restructured.

The minister in his explanation a moment ago pointed to the south-west Queensland strategy, which is a pilot scheme that was developed by the people of the south-west Queensland mulga lands. As they are all my constituents, I have taken a very close interest in the development of the south-west Queensland strategy. I believe that the people of south-west Queensland were the driving force behind the development of a regional approach to rural adjustment.

In last week's Country Life, the President of the Warrego Graziers Association, Mr Rigby, when reporting to his association in Charleville, said that the wheels have fallen off the south-west Queensland strategy. This is a practical grazier who has been grazing sheep and cattle in those very harsh mulga lands in south-west Queensland for more than 20 years. The president of that association has to be a pretty tough nut. He is going to have to stick up for those people out there and understand the problems of the community. I would like the House to bear in mind that the Warrego Graziers Association has always been behind a regional approach to the rural adjustment package. In his report last week, Mr Rigby said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the South West Strategy has been "fooled about with" by every conceivable government department.
When you listen to the minister's explanation of the amendments to this act you can understand the concerns of Mr Rigby. He said:
. . . it was no longer recognisable and was being used as "carrots" to encourage graziers into areas like property management and planning.
In my view, our right to implement our own management decisions is under very grave threat.
He continued:
. . . help was not available unless landholders had an approved property management plan, or signed property enterprise agreement.

For these enterprise agreements or property management plans to be understood by people in capital cities, they must understand that the south-west Queensland area is a very large part of Queensland, that towns are not just dotted every 20 or 30 miles, and that the people who could approve these plans are not every 20 or 30 miles down the road. That is what he is referring to when he said that he believed that this had been fooled about by every conceivable level of government and is at grave risk of running off the tracks. Mr Rigby said:
I remain very hesitant about the scheme.
While I fully support and commend the effort and expertise that has gone into establishing the scheme, and while I
most totally support our original aim of property build up in the mulga lands of south west Queensland, the scheme has gone much further and I believe to its detriment.

The concerns of the President of the Warrego Graziers Association—we should bear in mind that this was the pilot scheme for a rural approach to rural adjustment in this country—bears out our concerns on this side of the House, and that is why we had this bill sent up to a Senate committee to be investigated. The coalition's decision to send the bill to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee resulted from the lack of information about how the rural adjustment scheme and the regional plans would work, how they would be funded, and whether they would be constitutionally acceptable.

PARA.TAB: These concerns have been borne out by the committee's report, as the minister suggested in his explanatory memorandum. Whilst recommending that the bill be passed without amendments, the Senate committee recorded its concerns that the explanatory memorandum, and in particular the second reading speech, did not contain detailed information on the proposed amendments to the Rural Adjustment Act 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were our concerns.

—Absolutely. The honourable member for Wakefield, coming from South Australia with a rural constituency, certainly understands the concerns that we had and the concerns his constituents had. The Attorney-General's Department had concerns. Its report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The administrative arrangements to be undertaken by the Commonwealth in relation to the new non-state-based component of the RAS are not clear from the available material. It is this lack of information which appears to be of concern to the Parliamentary Research Service. In the absence of that information, it is not possible to form a view whether the proposed administrative arrangements would be valid.

That is the Attorney-General's Department in scrutinising this bill. The committee concluded that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the minister must provide information that will allow the parliament to make informed judgments when considering legislation.

PARA.TAB: During the inquiry, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy said that funding for rural adjustment scheme regional plans would come from the underspends of each state—in other words, the underspent amount of each state's rural adjustment funding. The coalition is concerned at evidence given by Mr Malcolm Smith from the Rural Finance Corporation of Victoria who said that the federal government wanted to impose a levy on states on top of the underspends, which would create a larger pot of money. Mr Smith correctly pointed out that the Victorian government would not be happy to provide finance for a regional restructuring plan in Queensland. He is quite correct. Quite rightly, any state that puts money into a scheme must receive the benefits for its own citizens. As I said earlier, it is the right of the state to manage the land administration arrangements of the state. The Victorian concerns were also of concern to the coalition.

The coalition is aware that the regional restructuring area in Queensland—which is in my own electorate—appears to be welcomed by the people in that area. They were originally very supportive of the scheme. They continue to be supportive of the scheme, but they do not want to be run over by a federal government trying to impose unnecessary conditions on this very important approach to regional adjustment. They want it to be driven from the bottom up—at the grassroots level. These are the people who are out there in the paddocks in the south-west Queensland areas. No-one better understands the problem of the mulga lands or of any rural area than the people who are working it on a day-to-day basis. For this reason, the coalition is pleased that the government has finally agreed to put forward an amendment in line with the Senate committee's dissenting report which says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . as a minimum, the legislation should be amended to require the Commonwealth to consult with the States on regional adjustment initiatives, fully recognising that the States have the responsibility for land management.
The government's amendment ensures that a regional restructuring program cannot go ahead without the agreement of the particular state or territory.

PARA.TAB: If it were not for the concerns of members on this side of the House, a bill would have been passed through this parliament which would have seen the federal government gaining greater control over the rural reconstruction packages out there in rural Australia. Thank goodness the people on this side of the House understand the concerns of those people out in rural Australia. This bill demonstrates yet again the lack of understanding or the lack of knowledge of the problems confronted by people in rural Australia. Whilst this is a small example, it is another example of the arrogance not only of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) but also of those people who would have had a say in the bill when it was brought forward to their caucus committees.

The other government amendments are to the Farm Household Support Act 1992. These amendments are to allow the Commonwealth to reimburse the states for the costs incurred by state rural adjustment scheme authorities in issuing drought exceptional circumstances certificates. These certificates play a very important role. They are certainly being widely used in my own electorate and in many parts of New South Wales. Unfortunately, they are not being issued in Victoria or in some parts of New South Wales which are in desperate need of a declaration of exceptional circumstance.

These certificates are used for the purposes of drought relief payments and concessions under the Austudy assets test as evidence that farm enterprises are affected by drought exceptional circumstances. The expected cost to the Commonwealth is $240,000. At this point, I would like to congratulate the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee which today reported to the Senate its finding on the impact of Austudy on rural families.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another coalition initiative.

—Absolutely. I commend the chairman of that committee, Senator Brownhill, a member from the central regions of New South Wales. He is one of those from a drought declared area who is not carrying an exceptional circumstances declaration. In that report to the Senate the committee recommended to abolish the assets test on farm assets. Some of the evidence in that report highlights the lack of understanding of the plight of those families in rural Australia. The great tragedy of the assets test, as it is applied and as it is still being applied in this country, is that the children out there in rural Australia are being denied an education. The assets of parents are stripping their children from being able to receive Austudy and gain secondary or tertiary education.
—And they have to be boarders.

—Absolutely. This is another matter that those opposite do not understand. There is not a university on every corner of our electorates. In many cases, there is not even a complete secondary education out there in rural Australia. I draw on the experience of my own electorate. Many towns have educational opportunities to year 10. People living in many of those rural towns have to send their children away to a regional centre to complete even secondary education. When it comes to university or tertiary education, they usually have to go to a capital city. I would like to know how on earth the government thinks that assets in a drought declared area or assets in a farm situation will constitute an ability to pay for children's education. So often we see that education and access to it in capital cities is taken as a right, but out there in rural Australia it seems as though the government thinks it can apply different rules.

PARA.TAB: The interesting thing in that report is that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy identified that 5,400 students would benefit from the removal of the assets test. They would have been eligible under the income test but were being tripped out because of the assets test. On this day, 5,400 students are being tripped out of any assistance in terms of Austudy support because of their parents' assets. Their parents' income clearly means they can qualify, but their parental assets trip them out of assistance from the federal government. I welcome that report, and I congratulate the chairman of that committee for bringing forward that report. Quite clearly, the evidence received out there by committee members was evidence that they listened to. They have certainly understood the plight of those many rural families.

The government's approach has been to issue these exceptional circumstances certificates which means that, with the students out there in these drought areas, their parents' on-farm assets will not be considered in terms of Austudy eligibility. I would ask the minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) and the Minister for Schools, Vocational Eduction and Training (Mr Free) to look at that report very carefully and to consider it in the context of the removal of the assets test on farm assets.

It is just a deplorable situation that, in the 21st century, a report of a parliamentary committee presented to the Senate today identified 5,400 students in rural Australia who are being denied federal government assistance because of a very unfair assets test that has been applied by this Labor government. If this government does not take notice of that report, it will demonstrate yet again the arrogance not only of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) but of the Labor Party as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: The other aspect of the bill that I want to comment on briefly is the Northern Prawn Fishery Voluntary Adjustment Scheme Loan Guarantee Act 1985. To assist with the restructure of the northern prawn fishery, the Commonwealth government guaranteed a loan obtained from the Queensland Treasury Corporation to a maximum of $40.9 million. The loan was paid to the Queensland Fish Management Authority.

PARA.TAB: The Queensland government has since dissolved this authority and established a new body, which took over the previous body's assets, rights and liabilities from 27 January this year. Because of the name change the Commonwealth guarantee no longer legally applies. The Queensland government wants it reinstated to the newly-named body to cover the $13.3 million still owed. Quite clearly, that scheme is working well because the original loan for $40.9 million is now down to $13.3 million.

The northern prawn and fishing industry plays a very important part in providing job opportunities in northern Australia, particularly in the Gulf of Carpentaria. The industry has entered this restructuring scheme on a voluntary basis; in other words, it is being driven by the fishermen and the people involved in the industry. It is good to see that it has paid off some of that debt.

The coalition has no objections to the government's amendments. We are pleased to see that, on this occasion, the government has listened to the Senate recommendations on this bill and accepted these amendments. I feel that, if the government can listen to and read very carefully that Austudy report that was introduced into the Senate today, if it can listen as well as it has listened on this occasion, then perhaps we can progress things for those people out there in rural Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wakelin Mr B.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), who preceded me, has laid out the case very well. He was appreciative of the efforts of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee in making valuable additions to this Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1). I will concentrate on two or three issues in the bill.

PARA.TAB: Before I do that I would reiterate my belief—as I said yesterday in my speech on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (Drought Relief Measures)—that the rural adjustment scheme, and the farm household support as part of that, can only ever be a very poor second-best to sound economic policy. The point I made yesterday was that when Peter Walsh abolished the old IED scheme he should have put something in its place—as he acknowledged in December of last year. While I was angry yesterday when I remembered that and I expressed that anger in my speech, and I still feel that, at least he was honourable enough to acknowledge that he should have put something in its place.

For a decade we have had an agricultural industry that has been exposed more than it has ever been, or had been in the last 70 or 80 years, I suggest, certainly since the Great Depression. So the rural adjustment scheme, which, I guess, parliaments and politicians from time to time make great play of, can only ever be second-best to sound economic policies and policies which encourage individuals to be able to take good care of them selves.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that the speech given by the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) talks about a regional component; it talks about flexibility; and it talks about the Commonwealth-State agreement. When I look at farm household support, I just want to emphasise flexibility. I know there are hangovers, if you like, preceding this current round of federal government drought legislation where the household support is being held over people's heads. I would just encourage the government to look at any outstanding issues of household support. I hope that this legislation picks it up; I am not sure that it will.

PARA.TAB: The point is made that people have to `arrange for the sale of their property or work to place the farm on a firmer footing'. In some of these drought situations around the country, quite frankly, the properties are unsaleable. I really emphasise to the government: please allow the flexibility that you talk about in your speech here tonight. The regional component of the rural adjustment scheme is one that we must handle with great care.
On Saturday of this week, a committee set up by the South Australian Minister for Primary Industries, Mr Dale Baker, under the chairmanship of the Hon. Caroline Schaefer of the Legislative Council—

TALK.START.PARA: —A good grain grower herself.

—Absolutely. That committee will meet at Kimba on Saturday morning to look at the region of Eyre Peninsula. I am sure that we in this House would wish the committee well in its deliberations. The reason I am cautioning great care upon the government is that careless words create unnecessary headlines. Two or three months ago we saw headlines running in both the Adelaide Advertiser and a South Australian farm paper which talked about fairly significant inducements to remove people from their farms. The wave of resentment, anger and frustration that went around Eyre Peninsula was something that I would not care to see repeated.

PARA.TAB: I welcome the efforts of the Senate rural and regional affairs committee in trying to bring a greater sense of balance to this legislation. Here we are not just dealing with markets, rationalists and export income; we are dealing with people's lives. These people have come from a great tradition over many generations. They are under great pressure, and probably have not been under greater pressure since the Great Depression—and some would say it is even greater than that. I am sure that we would wish the committee under the chairmanship of Caroline Schaefer all the best in planning for the future and developing a vision for Eyre Peninsula. We hope that this legislation will give the appropriate umbrella so that people might see a little bit of light at the end of the tunnel.

In the spirit of flexibility, which this legislation talks about, I encourage the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) in the other place to consider the application from that small section of Jervois county, under the district council area of Cleve, to look at the application with sympathy because I understand that the rainfall statistics are certainly within the guidelines of RASAC. Those people would very much appreciate an opportunity to participate in that program.

To highlight my personal involvement in the industry, in the 12 months from January to December 1994 the rainfall I experienced on my own farm was two inches below anything that I had ever experienced and, I would suggest, this century. My area will not be able to participate in the program—and I am certainly not asking that it should be—but I mention the fact that I had rainfall of 350 points or just under 100 millimetres. If people understand agriculture, they will realise that that is not very much rain.

TALK.START.PARA: —That makes education pretty tough.

—Yes, indeed. It is very difficult to give a regional approach, but I do welcome it because in 1988, when we were at a low ebb, it was impossible to get government of any kind to recognise a regional approach to these issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) is an omnibus bill which amends several primary industry acts. The coalition sent it to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee because there was a fear that the government may use the rural adjustment scheme to interfere in land use without consulting the states and to force people out of farming in a regional restructure, against the wishes of the local community.

PARA.TAB: As a result of that Senate committee's dissenting report, an amendment is required. The government has moved other amendments which now have to be considered. It is these other amendments I want to talk about because one of them is anti-Victorian. The government amendments to the Farm Household Support Act 1992 are to allow the Commonwealth to reimburse the states for the costs incurred by the state rural adjustment scheme authorities in issuing drought exceptional circumstances certificates.

Victoria cannot get these certificates because the federal Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) and RASAC have not visited the area, nor will they provide drought relief for north central Victoria, which is experiencing the absolute worst drought in its history. I understand that RASAC, the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Committee, will be visiting the area next Saturday under the chairmanship of Neil Inall. It will be met by the state Minister for Agriculture, Mr Bill McGrath, at Wycheproof, in the Mallee just north of Bendigo, and it will inspect the areas.

The declaring of north central Victoria as a drought relief area under the exceptional circumstances provisions has been delayed and the government has provided drought relief to Queensland, New South Wales, South Australia but not to Victoria. I can tell you that this is an anti-Victoria stance. It has adopted a regional approach in terms of drought, but the whole region of north central Victoria is gripped by the most dreadful drought in its history. These exceptional circumstances certificates are used for the purposes of drought relief payments. My constituents in central Victoria cannot get these certificates because the Commonwealth government—the federal Labor government—will not declare the area a drought area.

The bill also gives concessions under the Austudy assets test as evidence that farm enterprises are affected by drought—exceptional circumstances. I can tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that it is certainly an exceptional drought. I do not know what circumstances they want, but people are buying water because they have no water in their dams, their properties are dust bowls, they are losing their stock and they have been handfeeding sheep and cattle for months. I deplore the government's lack of action on this.

I am pleased that the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) is at the table and I am disappointed that the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) left the House after reading that glib second reading speech which made everything look rosy and wonderful in the country and which said that we are going to have this grand recovery. What recovery? These people have not even got water for their own domestic use. They have not got water for their stock. They have got the high costs of borrowing to handfeed all of their stock.

I think the Minister for Justice is a pretty fair and honourable minister. If there is any sense of justice and equity in his soul, he should run across to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and tell him to get down to Victoria and have a look at what is going on there with the drought because it is in a shocking condition at the moment. I have had a great deal of correspondence from constituents in my area who are running out of water and are having to buy it at $80 a tank load. This is lasting no time at all because of the circumstances that they are going through—trying to feed stock and trying to keep them going.

The Red Cross in north central Victoria has been supplementing the farmers with financial assistance to buy water, and the other welfare agencies have been providing food packs to them. They are really in desperate trouble. On Saturday RASAC will inspect the Mallee at Wycheproof and work its way down through the Bendigo area. Bill McGrath, the state minister, has been very supportive. The state has provided financial assistance from its limited resources; but, without the Commonwealth coming in and declaring that area an area of extreme drought, they cannot get the benefit of Commonwealth support that is so urgently needed.

I want to elaborate on what I believe are exceptional circumstances in north central Victoria. They are in the middle of a drought at this moment. The previous year they had a mouse plague, which wiped out most of the grain crops, and the previous year was so wet that many of the crops produced very poor yields. As I indicated to the House, I have received a lot of correspondence on this. I have one letter from Raywood, which is just north of Bendigo, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Reid,

PARA.TAB: I am just writing to see if you can do something for us, drought stricken farmers in this area—North Central Victoria. Our main house dam is dry, so we are carting water, feeding sheep, hay and grain every day. Our neighbours are in the same situation. The paddocks are getting barer and barer. We are not eligible for Austudy allowance because of the asset test which makes us so cross.
Only hope you will be able to present a case at Parliament next week and we will be able to get some assistance for keeping our farm going until the rain comes.
Please do all you can for us.
Yours sincerely
Clare . . .

SPEECH.PARA: That is just typical of many of the farmers in my area. Another letter says:
Dear Mr Reid,

PARA.TAB: I'm writing to you as an attempt to get a message across to the people in parliament. I'd like to ask them to go without their income for 12 months but still have to pay bills, feed and clothe kids who are growing. My teenage son grew out of 3 pairs of school shoes last year and when he now takes a size 12 shoe you have to pay men's prices.

I cry every time we have to kill our sheep. I'm sick to my boots when I have to help my husband clean out the green rotting stinking dams. I look out of our windows and the ground looks grey, like it's dead.

If we fight it's twice as bad as the fights are over money. I used to get $250 a week to feed my family and to buy clothes for them and any other needs that may arise. I now have to try and do the same on $100. I have had to go to work to try and make ends meet and that means my children are home by themselves after school. I feel I'm failing them as I'm not there to help them with their homework and other problems. I know Mr Keating could not give a fig about us but I hope someone will listen soon before it's too late.

SPEECH.PARA: That is why I mentioned the Minister for Justice, who is at the table, because he has got feeling for these people. I would want him to take the message from north central Victoria that we are in very severe drought. People are having to buy water and handfeed stock. I can assure the minister that all these letters are genuine. They have got signatures, but I do not wish to embarrass those people. They are a proud people. They do not want to have to get on their hands and knees to beg. But I can assure the minister that things are extremely grim in that area.

PARA.TAB: The summary of the bill and the explanation which the Assistant Treasurer gave tonight paint a glossy picture of all these wonderful things the government is doing and the support it is supposedly giving. That might have been given in parts of Queensland and New South Wales and in parts of the area of my colleague the member for Grey (Mr Wakelin), but nothing at all has come from the Commonwealth to assist the people of north central Victoria.

That is discrimination against the people in that area. They are feeling the effects of this drought, and there is no sign of a break. They are going into another season. They have to borrow yet more money to ensure that they can plant for next season. All the costs are up-front. They have to buy fuel, seed and superphosphate. They have to borrow the money. They have to make the decision now to borrow the money, to go to the banks to seek additional financial support, and put themselves further and further into debt.

This bill is about the Farm Household Support Act 1992. It says it will do all these wonderful things at an expected cost to the Commonwealth of $240,000. That does not seem a lot of money to me. If some of my farming constituents could get their hands on $240,000, plus the certificate to get drought relief under the exceptional circumstances provisions, it would certainly help them greatly.

I appeal to the minister at the table. I would have taken the opportunity to appeal to the Assistant Treasurer, because he has a role in this. It is time the Assistant Treasurer, the Treasurer (Mr Willis), the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy did something. It should not take until May. That is the time the government says it will take to get drought relief, even if it is approved by the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Committee. If they went down this weekend and had a look at the area and saw the condition it is in, surely they could make a decision within seven to 14 days—not let it run on until May. It is decision making time for these farmers now. They have to decide whether they will borrow that additional money and put in a crop for next year in the hope that they will have a decent season.

I appeal to both ministers in this chamber to go to Senator Collins and get some action out of him, because it is absolutely desperate. Without the assistance of the Commonwealth, the state can only do a limited amount, and it is doing that to the best of its ability and financial resources. The Minister for Agriculture in Victoria, Bill McGrath, has been a very valuable ally to these farmers. He has been pushing and doing everything possible to assist them by providing whatever relief he can from the state's resources. It now requires the assistance of the Commonwealth.

Without that financial assistance—a whole farming community, where there are third and fourth generation farmers, is talking about leaving the land—we could lose a whole generation of farmers, and that would be an absolute tragedy. They are all efficient farmers. They produce high quality products which go to export markets, but without the assistance of the Commonwealth and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy those people will pack up and leave the land in central Victoria.
