TALK.START.PARA: —As all other speakers have indicated, we are dealing tonight with government amendments in the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1994. Coalition speakers are prominent on the speakers list for this bill because we are proud that the coalition has been largely responsible for the amendments which have occurred in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: When the original legislation came before the House, while the coalition welcomed much of it, we expressed concern about the lack of regional input into the rural adjustment scheme as it was to be amended by the legislation. In the Senate the coalition sought the referral of this legislation to a Senate committee, and it is to the credit particularly of coalition senators Crane and Panizza that the changes that we have before the House now were recommended by the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee. The Senate committee of inquiry had its genesis in the enthusiasm the coalition had for greater cooperation between regional bodies and the government in the implementation of any form of rural assistance.

Lest those introductory remarks seem a little too partisan, I should add that concerns about the way this legislation has been structured were not only expressed by the coalition. The Attorney-General's Department also said that it felt that the administrative arrangements laid down in these legislative changes were not clear. The amendments that are being considered tonight, referred to this chamber by the Senate, call for greater consultation between the Commonwealth bodies, the state bodies and regional bodies.

In the administration of the rural adjustment scheme and in the RAS act arrangements, there is enthusiasm now, as a result of this call for consultation, for cooperation between the regional bodies and the administrators of the RAS act and consultation with the state governments, as they administer this form of rural assistance. This level of consultation is entirely appropriate, and the coalition believes that it should never have been necessary for the coalition to seek these amendments in the first place because the need for this sort of consultation should have been apparent to the federal government.

Land management, which is fundamentally what rural adjustment is all about and which gives people the opportunity to make changes in their farming lifestyle under the RASAC scheme, is a state issue. Had this legislation proceeded without the changes that the coalition and, more accurately, the Senate committee sought, then this state authority in land management would have been further unwittingly eroded by this Commonwealth act.

Instead, we now have a situation where, thanks to these amendments, there will be consultation where the concerns that the Attorney-General's Department had expressed are now cleared up and the administrative arrangements that were once cloudy are now much more transparent and satisfactory from the point of view of both the government and the coalition.

All speakers dealing with this legislation have emphasised that these changes to rural assistance deal with people in need. In fact, the amendments currently being considered by the House provide an opportunity for reimbursement to the state governments where drought exceptional circumstances certificates are issued to farmers in particular need. These drought exceptional circumstances certificates allow farmers who are in need and in drought declared areas to access both drought relief payments, which they clearly need in order to put food on their tables, and, significantly, Austudy payments regardless of their assets.

The member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) has already made it perfectly plain, and has been quite unequivocal, that one of the major problems facing farmers in his area, in my area or in drought declared areas of Australia is their inability to access tertiary education for their teenaged children, principally because they do not have the income. They have the assets. Frequently these assets in drought declared areas cannot be sold. The assets prevent them accessing Austudy. Under the arrangements that are currently considered for drought exceptional circumstances certificates, it will be possible for them, in spite of their assets, to access Austudy. This recognises that their income is so low that, were those assets in any form other than farm assets, they would have been able to access Austudy.

The absurdity of the Austudy arrangements is that many farmers who have assets of over $1 million cannot access Austudy. If those assets were in a house in Double Bay or in a house in West Lakes in South Australia, they would have the capacity to access Austudy. It is a capacity which has been denied to them, unless they are eligible for drought exceptional circumstances certificates.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is grossly unfair.

—It does seem to be grossly unfair. I recognise, as does the coalition, that the government appreciates the fact that farm assets are relatively unproductive and has doubled the asset level for farmers. In the circumstances in which much of Australia currently finds itself, as the member for Maranoa said, that does not allow a large number of farmers to access tertiary education for their children. Without that tertiary education, their children are doomed to a lesser standard of living.

PARA.TAB: A part of my electorate is drought stricken, but it is not drought declared. I do not stand here tonight pleading that it should be drought declared, because the circumstances are not as dire as those outlined by the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid). It is an illustration of just how capricious climatic conditions can be that within one hour of the city of Adelaide is country that is currently occupied by people who see this land as land that has a capacity to be subdivided to offer accommodation for commuters to Adelaide. That land is probably overinflated in value.

A number of those farmers, because of the shortage of rain, are unable to make ends meet in this financial year. It is a very narrow strip of country. It probably starts about where the city of Gawler is and ends at about the town of Tarlee. This land runs through the centre of South Australia and is in my electorate. It is some of Australia's prime grain growing country and certainly is South Australia's prime grain growing country. It is just north of Adelaide. It is decidedly dry. The farmers are finding it very difficult to make ends meet. They will not qualify for drought assistance. As their representative, I do not think that I can stand here and realistically claim that they should qualify. I can claim that, had the government recognised just how unpredictable farming can be, it would have taken action to maintain the income equalisation deposits scheme that the Fraser government put in place and so allow these farmers to make preparations for years such as these. My farmers are not coming to me pleading for government intervention, but it is obvious that their capacity to budget and to prepare for the downturn that they are experiencing now has been frustrated by the government's inability to provide the same sort of IED scheme as the Fraser government once had in place.

As the member for Bendigo said, the amendment would allow those farmers who are, as my farmers are, in sufficiently difficult circumstances to qualify for the drought exceptional circumstances certificates to access Austudy. That amendment alone would cost the government a mere quarter of a million dollars, which is very little in terms of the total drought outlay and the total losses being faced by farmers who currently cannot make ends meet simply because there has been too little rain. In taking into consideration just what drought has done to Australia and how slow the government has been to respond, it is rather chastening that much of the initial work done to assist farmers was by volunteers like the CWAs across Australia and by public figures like prominent television personalities such as Ray Martin.

What is little known is that in my state last week an initiative was launched by the premier of South Australia, Mr Dean Brown. In cooperation with the chairman of John Shearer Ltd, Andrew Gwinnett, Mr Brown launched a campaign to be known as `Seeds of hope'. The South Australian government made available $10,000. It is hoped that through public funding this $10,000 will grow to allow the John Shearer organisation to administer a fund that will enable drought stricken farmers to get, without any cost to them at all, the seeds they need to sow this year's crop. I commend John Shearer for this initiative. They are offering all the administrative arrangements without charge. I also commend the Premier of South Australia for his preparedness to be identified with the program and to make $10,000 available as foundation funding. This will mean that farmers whose situation is so desperate that they cannot afford the seed to sow this year's crop will have access to free seed and will be assured not only of a harvest his year but also of the opportunity to once again be proud and independent Australians who are able to look after their land without being dependent on handouts either of the charitable form or from governments. I think that deserves a mention and deserves commendation.

As I deal with the legislation before the House and the changes that will occur in drought stricken Australia, let me say that the government—I could say the parliament but I guess it is fairer to say the government—in making drought assistance available to Australian farmers has probably committed Australian taxpayers to some $270 million or $300 million. If we were generous we could say $400 million. That includes funding for rural councils and all other assistance, which is difficult to measure. That seems like a reasonable sum. When you consider that it takes only the smallest movement in interest rates to cost Australian farmers billions of dollars, you begin to see not only how relatively insignificant this total package is—I do not mean that in an ungracious way—but also how essential responsible, total economic management is. If farmers had a predictable economy they would be much better able to cope with the fluctuations in weather that characterise Australian farming. My plea once again is for the government to recognise the desperate situation of farmers. They need some predictable economic circumstances and the opportunity to access an effective IED scheme. They are anxious to be independent and proud Australians.

A matter which has not been referred to in the debate tonight because the focus has tended to be entirely on the drought is that the original bill—the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill—also included a change to the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987 and changes to the administration and meeting obligations of the Australian Dried Fruits Board. I mention this because what is currently widely mooted in the dried fruits community and the grape wine community is the proposal advocated in the recently released draft report of the committee of inquiry into the wine and wine grape industry which suggested a change in the way in which the wine industry is taxed.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you may be aware—I know the member for Mallee is well aware of the proposal that came out; it has an immediate impact on the dried fruit industry—that there is to be a change in the taxation on wine so that a volumetric tax is imposed. The three commissioners of inquiry into the wine grape and wine industry came out with a divided report.

One commissioner brought out a minority report advocating a sales tax of 32 per cent and a volumetric tax or excise of $4 a litre. The other two commissioners brought out a majority report advocating a sales tax of 10 per cent and a volumetric tax of $4 per litre of alcohol. I mention this in the closing stages of this debate because it is significant that the one person who advocated a minority report did so recognising that a volumetric tax would impact most unfairly on what are called non-premium varieties of grapes. The dried vine fruits industry, which is covered by a part of this bill, is the principal grower of what are called non-premium varieties. I refute the term `non-premium' because it implies inferiority. That is not true at all. They are superior dried vine fruit varieties but are inferior in the eyes of winemakers; important, but inferior.

The House needs to appreciate two things. Firstly, any form of volumetric tax, any form of excise, per litre of alcohol means that premium varieties put into, for example, a red wine at $22 a bottle, containing a certain amount of alcohol at $4 a litre, may result in an increase in the cost of that $22 bottle of, say, $4. But a cask made from the non-premium varieties also has a similar amount of alcohol in it and this would result in the price of a $5 cask increasing by $4. Clearly, that is a very inequitable way to go about taxing this industry.

I raise this point because, if the government were to entertain any form of excise at all, it should look at what the change in excise did to the brandy industry. A graph of brandy production in Australia indicates that as excise rose across the graph brandy production fell. There is a real risk for the wine industry in the application of an excise and what it may do to the industry. But should such an excise be considered? It should not be considered unless there was an opportunity to relieve the excise on brandy and so allow some of the non-premium varieties to go back into the brandy industry because they would no longer be in demand in the wine industry. These are the very varieties that the dried fruit industry currently depends on for its export market and it sees the brandy industry as a safety valve for that industry.

I am pleased to commend the government for the changes that it has made in adopting the coalition's recommendations to ensure there is greater consultation in the application of its drought assistance.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Johns) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: WEAPONS OF MASS DESTRUCTION (PREVENTION OF PROLIFERATION) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker Vaile, before I start, could I say how grateful I am to see how fresh and enthusiastic you are in the chair tonight after your exercise. It just goes to prove that you should get more of it!

PARA.TAB: In speaking to the Weapons of Mass Destruction (Prevention of Proliferation) Bill 1995, it is very important to define weapons of mass destruction. It is a term used to describe nuclear, biological and chemical weapons which are capable of resulting in mass destruction of a population. Australia is a party to three international treaties concerned with the control and reduction of weapons of mass destruction. The Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, which was ratified in Australia on 23 January 1973, is substantially implemented by the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987.

The Convention on the Prohibition of the Development, Production and Stockpiling of Bacteriological (Biological) and Toxin Weapons and on their Destruction, which was ratified by Australia on 5 October 1977, is substantially implemented by the Crimes (Biological Weapons) Act 1976. A Convention on the Prohibition of the Development, Production, Stockpiling and Use of Chemical Weapons and on their Destruction was ratified on 6 May 1994, but has not yet come into force internationally. It will be substantially implemented by the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act 1994, which will come into force on a date to be proclaimed or upon the convention coming into force. I think it is very useful to let the parliament know just where we stand as far as our adherence to the treaty is concerned.

I have before me a research paper published as late as March this year, entitled `Crunch Time for the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty'. In annex C, there are a few facts and figures about the NPT. The paper states that 173 countries are members of it and that Taiwan and Yugoslavia are not counted. It is a pity that recognition was not given to Taiwan in the United Nations, but the following 14 countries have not yet acceded to the treaty: Angola; Brazil; Chile; Comoros; Cuba; Djibouti; Federated States of Micronesia; India, which has a population of some 800 million; Israel, which is a small nation in the Middle East; Oman; Pakistan; Palau; United Arab Emirates; and Vanuatu. It is important to recognise that those 14 countries have not yet acceded to the treaty.

This legislation implements our adherence to the treaty and, in endorsing it this way, is fully responding to our full obligations. I have also received some letters from Greenpeace. Annex D in the research paper has suggested a 25-year timetable for achieving complete nuclear disarmament. The point being made by Greenpeace is that this legislation does nothing to implement that timetable. The concern is that, without that implementation, our legislation itself could be deficient and the treaty certainly could be. Greenpeace's news release states:

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, though, the Nuclear Weapons States have not kept their part of the "bargain". Since the NPT came into force in 1970, the arsenals of the Nuclear Weapons States have increased massively. 75,000 new nuclear weapons have been deployed and hundreds of nuclear tests conducted.

A member of Non-Nuclear Weapon State signatories, such as Indonesia and Mexico, now want to strengthen the disarmament commitments in the NPT by introducing a timetable or set goals for the elimination of nuclear weapons. Their proposals would see the NPT extended for fixed periods, such as five years, with disarmament goals to be met within these periods.

It goes very much back to the timetable within that. It does highlight a particular point on disarmament right across the world in that, as circumstances vary over time, we adopt one standard and then move on to another. Certainly, the big variance in this regard is the ending of the Cold War, the pulling down of the Berlin Wall and the fragmentation of the USSR into many smaller nations, Russia still being the most predominant. It allows a different set of circumstances.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, some of the 13 nations that previously were part of the USSR—I will not say all of them—now have access to nuclear weapons. Also, we know there is a problem in that, in the disarming of some of those nuclear weapons, they might be transferred to other countries which might be non-signatories or signatories. The important point to make is that, as I understand it, the signing of a treaty does not necessarily commit a country to adhering to the principles of a treaty. Clause 7 sets out the constitutional basis of the bill. It relies on the following constitutional powers:

SPEECH.PARA: . the external affairs power (s.51 (xxix)) to the extent that it gives effect to the Biological Weapons Convention, the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and the Chemical Weapons Convention, or to the extent that the matters are external to Australia or matters of international concern;

PARA.TAB: . the defence power (s.51 (vi));
. the corporations power (s.51 (xx)); and
. the trade and commerce power (s.51(i)).

SPEECH.PARA: It is very important to note that it is the external affairs power of the constitution that enables us to adhere to our treaty commitments by virtue of this bill. It might seem very grand that 173 countries are members of the NPT but, of those 173 countries, how many have individually legislated—as Australia has—through their external affairs power to actually put this into force?

PARA.TAB: I think it is very important that, while a lot of people see a treaty signed as being cast in concrete and having particular powers, it does not have the power until it is legislated in the government of the member country. While we are adhering to it, how many of these other countries that are signatories are yet to do it? My particular concern—and I think it would be the concern of everyone—is the manner in which the nuclear weapons of mass destruction in the former areas of Russia are being treated. I am particularly concerned because we know there are countries throughout the world that are very anxious to increase their nuclear weapons. I mentioned India, which is a non-signatory. There is also Iraq and a number of other countries, including North Korea, which was a crisis point last year. The Greenpeace document says that Indonesia and Mexico have a particular interest in this.

I was fortunate to be selected by this parliament, along with the honourable member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples), to represent the Australian parliament at the 49th General Assembly. I was not involved in the discussions, but it gave me a lot of pleasure to be able to sit in on some of the discussions of the Western nations, of which Australia forms a bloc, where these matters were treated seriously.

I suggest that Australia very strongly support the Indonesian and Mexican situation to ensure that a timetable is there. The protagonists of such a move were some of the present nuclear states. We mentioned five of the nuclear states. I believe that some of those were resistant to the lodging of a timetable. I agree with Greenpeace that we need a definite timetable within the treaty and all countries to become partners to that obligation by legislating, as we have done here.

As far as treaties are concerned, my experience with the United Nations is that you can sign treaties but they are not binding outside the UN. The UN has no power of enforcement. I think it is very important to realise that some countries—for example, France—will sign and endorse all treaties. But France does not adhere to any of the treaties of the United Nations. Again I ask: to what extent has France legislated to make it enforceable on itself?

On the other hand, the United Nations can give many examples of countries that will not sign treaties but will adhere to most of them. To put that in context, while we are legislating to bind Australia, its citizens and its corporations to this treaty, it does not necessarily mean that there is a grand world out there where the UN has an enforcement capacity. It does not. The only enforcement capacity comes from the inside.

I have mentioned the Cold War. Just this year, the Public Works Committee was privileged to examine the Maralinga site with a view to approving work there to reduce the danger that still exists from plutonium-contaminated sand and other material. At the time it all happened, science was not even able to experiment with these devices, let alone treat the consequences of them. When you go out there now, you appreciate that somebody is trying to do something in a modern context with modern technology to ensure that the situation is controlled. I do not think we should look over our shoulder and cast all the blame on the Brits, the French, the Americans or anyone else who worked on this technology at that earlier time.

For their part in the discussions held at the 49th assembly, I have to pay particular tribute to Richard Starr and the other members of the Australian team who came over from Geneva. They put their hearts and souls into it, working almost 24 hours a day while they were there to get an agreement on adherence to a timetable for the Mexican-Indonesian situation. I have to say that Australians are regarded almost as a neutral factor in a lot of the things that happen at the United Nations because, although we are attached to the Europeans, we are isolated in the Southern Hemisphere. Everything on which Australia takes a view is listened to. We are regarded as one of the arbitrators within the United Nations, getting agreement between different factions. In the discussions on weapons of mass destruction and in the agreements drawn up, Australia was a lively and well-briefed participant and our views were well regarded.

The dangers posed to our modern society are very evident. I have already mentioned countries, such as North Korea, Iraq and former USSR states, that do not know what to do with their nuclear weapons. I also mention the more recent chemical weapons attacks on the Kurds in Iraq and the nerve gas that was released in the Japanese subway as examples of terrorist activity.

One of the first lessons that the member for Jagajaga and I received at the United Nations mission was that, for all the work it does, the UN requires the almost unanimous approval of 184 nations in order to bring forward a convention. I regard it as the system of the lowest common denominator: you keep dropping your standards until you get agreement.

It was also interesting to see that the UN is very lively now that the Republicans have the majority in the US Congress and are renewing the call for sovereign rights. That is something that is applicable to Australia. I have no problem with the use of the external affairs power in this instance, but the Americans are asking how far they can let their sovereignty go to organisations within the UN. While I was there it was suggested that America's share of the UN budget, which is currently 30 per cent, be dropped to 25 per cent. That was causing a lot of concern within United Nations circles. The World Trade Organisation and GATT are not creatures of the UN, but it is typical of the Americans' new claim to sovereignty that they have said they will enter into the new World Trade Organisation with this caveat: in 12 months time they will revisit the situation to ensure that what they have signed away will not affect their sovereign rights. That is a very important change in an era of change.

This year sees the 50th anniversary of the United Nations. Out of the respect in which it is held by Australians, Richard Butler, the Australian mission head, will share in the celebrations. It appears to me that over those 50 years the UN has extended its activities quite considerably. Where it once had expertise in certain limited areas, it has since expanded its activities and its public service to the point where it is today a kind of jack of all trades and master of none. For example, while it has developed techniques of peacekeeping, its peacekeeping efforts are not coordinated; its peacekeeping does not flow the way it should. While the UN is held to be the authority on peacekeeping, it is not doing all that well in that respect.

One of the major concerns of the UN—in fact, one of the world's major concerns—is the destructive capability of the landmines that have been sown in their millions throughout warring countries in the Middle East, Africa and elsewhere. This poses a significant problem because in their collective entirety they could be regarded as a weapon of mass destruction. A question was asked about that this week during question time. It is something that should be given serious consideration because like the plutonium at Maralinga—which is there, which will stay there, and which will be a problem for the next 24,000 years of its half-life—these landmines will be active for many years to come. There is a need for the United Nations, working in consultation with its member nations, to come to an agreement on the supply of these weapons—all Western nations, even though they are members of the United Nations, are guilty in that respect—on the control of their proliferation, and on the way to fix the situation.

My experience of the UN makes me feel that there is a need for major reconstruction and a major look at its activities in this its 50th year. I hope that will be the case. Australia is the voice of experience, and I believe we are held in respect by other member nations.

PARA.TAB: This raises very serious points. I have opened this letter because it was addressed to me, just as my colleague the member for Barker opened some mail that was addressed to him. Even though the government had ensured, through its own mechanisms, that this mail was sent to him and that he should open it, the government feels he should be held responsible for the fact that this was not meant to be directed to him.

It is a very real embarrassment because it was sent to a number of members of the opposition. That it has been sent to me offering me a medal for my service during World War II when I was not even alive shows that the government has made what can only be described as a complete mess—a complete stuff up. Since the minister is now present, he really has to give a very serious explanation as to how he has allowed this to happen and how this is different from the treatment that the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has given my colleague. TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I wish to bring to the attention of the House concerns an act of extreme bravery and courage on the part of the members of the Kirki salvage operation, which ultimately saved Australians from a multimillion dollar oil spill clean up operation. It was an act of bravery above and beyond their normal duties that saved the coast of Western Australia from an environmental disaster, and one that has been recognised as being worthy of the Star of Courage medal for conspicuous bravery.

PARA.TAB: It is also an act of bravery that this government has seen fit to cash in on. This government has actually taxed the money paid to these men as a reward for their bravery. On 28 July 1991 the Greek oil tanker Kirki broke up in heavy seas just 30 kilometres off the coast of Western Australia near Jurien Bay. She carried a cargo of 82,000 tonnes of crude oil. Most members will be aware that this part of the coast has a worldwide significance as a marine conservation area. The area around the Ningaloo Reef has been declared a marine park to protect it.

The bow of the Kirki had broken off and she had lost about 20,000 tonnes of her cargo. The decision was taken to tow the crippled tanker out to sea and to transfer the remaining cargo to the 90,000 tonne Flying Clipper which would dock alongside her. A constituent of mine from Boyanup, Mr Kevin Hurley, was the man who made that spectacular leap in huge seas—watched by millions of TV viewers—from the Tender Lady Kathleen to the Kirki. Mr Hurley carried a tow line which allowed the Kirki to be towed out to sea away from the coastline and further damage. The Kirki was so badly damaged that her cargo of oil was spilling into the ocean. She was on fire and there was every likelihood that the ship would break up and the entire 82,000 tonnes would be washed up on WA beaches.

Had my constituent not taken that heroic leap onto the Kirki, the outcome would have been considerably worse. Mr Hurley's actions during that rescue operation went way beyond his normal day-to-day job. His Star of Courage medal is testimony to that. He would have been quite within his rights to say, `This is too dangerous,' and no-one would have thought less of him. Naturally, when he received his reward of $28,000, Mr Hurley and his young family were delighted. They did not realise that this government would assess the $28,000 reward as income and tax him for it. The government had put its hand out for a share of the reward money. I took this matter up with the Australian Taxation Office on 15 February 1994. The Deputy Commissioner said:

It is recognised that Mr Hurley made a significant contribution to the salvage operation. However, the payment he received is remuneration for personal services rendered and is assessable income in accordance with the Income Tax Assessment Act.

SPEECH.PARA: I raised the matter with the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) and was told there is no discretion to waive the tax assessed. The Assistant Treasurer told me:

PARA.TAB: Mr Hurley is an employee of P&O Maritime Services and the payment of $28,373 is clearly incidental to that employment as it represents remuneration for services rendered on the Lady Kathleen, the vessel on which Mr Hurley was employed.

SPEECH.PARA: I can assure the Assistant Treasurer and the House that Mr Hurley's response to that decision has been one of total outrage. Constituents have called my office and told me they simply cannot believe any government could stoop so low as to actually tax a man's bravery.

PARA.TAB: The message this sends out from the government is quite plain. If you carry out some brave, courageous deed for the benefit of your fellow Australians, you can expect to be taxed on any reward money. Clearly, this government places a different value on these actions. This government treats income as income—even if it is a reward for conspicuous bravery. It also puts into question the actions of our police officers, firemen and emergency services personnel, whose actions go above and beyond their normal duties.

The Assistant Treasurer has said in regard to this case that there is no discretion to waive the tax assessed. Clearly, there is only one sensible course of action open to the government—to change the system so that the Assistant Treasurer can, at his discretion, waive the tax assessed. No-one is paid as part of his or her normal employment for acts of extreme bravery. Mr Hurley might well have said, `My life is more important than the marine environment.' But he did not, and we should all be grateful to him. We should praise his actions and encourage others to put their fellow Australians first. We should not slap a tax on their bravery.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am having problems with Mr John McKechnie, the Director of Public Prosecutions in Western Australia. I noticed today in the West Australian a letter to the editor from Mr Robert Smith QC. The letter needs to be taken with the knowledge of Mr Robert Smith's background and his close past association with Mr McKechnie. He headed his letter `DPP independence at risk'. The truth is this: John McKechnie and the DPP represent power without responsibility, power without limit and power that has corrupted.

PARA.TAB: Mr Robert Smith suggests in his letter that I should have gone to the official corruption commission and let it handle this matter. That of course is, as Mr Robert Smith QC knows, an absolute joke. Mr John Porter sits on the official corruption commission. Had I gone there, my complaint simply would have been handed back to CIB, which would put it right back in the hands of Mr Les Ayton. Mr Ayton would have then called in Mr Trevor Porter, the son of John Porter—whom he called, I might add, to investigate claims by policemen that they were harassed over Mr McKechnie's recent actions.

You have here a closed loop which is impossible to break. Rather than attacking its independence, I propose to protect the independence of the DPP. To do this, it is quite simple. All one has to do is implement the policies that have been put in place by Mr Kennett in Victoria. I think that people on both sides of this House would agree that Mr Kennett is hardly a radical.

Mr Kennett has put in a regime where, if he believes there is not significant evidence for the defence counsel, he sends his brief to an independent committee comprising two independent QCs and the Solicitor-General. They look at the evidence—they do not communicate with the lawyer at all—and go straight to the prosecutor and say, `On investigation, we don't think you have the evidence here to prosecute. We're not saying you can't prosecute, but if you prosecute be aware that it's against our advice and the cost to the states will be on your head.' I would go one further and say that where a prosecutor takes prosecutions, as Mr McKechnie has, where people are put to great expense and, although they have eventually won, have been finally ruined the states should be liable for those costs.

The West Australian had its usual sanctimonious editorial, and it too is simply out of touch with reality. It might suit it to have this comfortable alliance with the powers that be in the legal and police systems in Western Australia, but I tell the West Australian that no matter what it does its editor will say, `The day of retribution is coming.' I believe that before Christmas I will show the shabby tactics and the absolute corruption of the DPP and the Deputy Commissioner of Police. I will show their collusion beyond any doubt at all, not just beyond a reasonable doubt. I believe they will be swept away. I believe the government will eventually address this problem. The government will eventually be forced to put in some sort of check and balance on this DPP using, say, a body that has power unprecedented in the British legal system since the days of the Star Chamber.

I have been overwhelmed with the support I have had from people and with the stories of hardship people have suffered. Some people have criticised me for naming the prosecutor's daughter, a girl of almost 18 years. What about a little remorse for the many much younger children who have been named, often Aboriginal, without any sort of criticism at all from the West Australian or from those other sanctimonious people who have been so critical of me in this issue? I say to this House: there was no other way I could have drawn this very serious matter to the attention of the state without making it clear that it was in relation to the prosecutor's daughter.
Motion (by Mr Johns) agreed to:
That the question be now put.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 29 March, on motion by Mr Simmons:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment briefly on the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration entitled Taxing relaxing. If some of its recommendations were a little stronger, the report could be called `Relaxing taxing'. That aside, it is a very important report that has come out at a very important time for the tourism industry.

PARA.TAB: The tourism industry in Australia is a young industry. It is in its early growth stages. That industry has the potential to provide a great deal of income to the Commonwealth of Australia in the future. I commend the report. However, I also commend the recommendation at the end of the dissenting report from the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite).

The honourable member recommends that a comprehensive review of the indirect taxation arrangements should be undertaken to develop options for reform which address the need for simplicity, equity and efficiency. It is important that we note that recommendation in the dissenting report.

We all know—and the government should know—that the indirect taxes levied in this country are an impediment, not only to the tourism industry, but also to a lot of other small businesses and manufacturing industries. If we are serious about helping those industries grow and about helping the development of greater employment prospects for the nearly one million people who are unemployed in Australia today, we need to pay attention to that area.

There are some good recommendations in the report. For example, recommendation No. 3 says that all vehicles which are used exclusively for earning assessable income should be fully depreciable. That is a commonsense recommendation. All the recommendations in the report, as far as I can see, are aimed at assisting the industry to get up and get going, thus generating more income for the country and generating more employment.

Another recommendation which I highlight is recommendation No. 5. It says that net capital gains tax should be deferred on the capital gain realised on the sale of a trading business which is rolled over into another trading business. No doubt government members would be aware that that was part of our policy at the 1993 election. That ties in with part of the recommendation of the honourable member for Dawson in his dissenting report about providing fairness and equity, and incentives to continue to invest in Australia. It is a very important recommendation. I urge the government to take it on board.
The next recommendation I had highlighted—and it goes to the heart of a bit of a problem that I have had with a couple of tourism operators in my electorate of Lyne—is recommendation No. 11, that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a sales tax exemption be granted for tourism buses and four wheel drive vehicles of 12 seats and under and that the Transport Ministers Council be consulted for their assistance with the implementation of this exemption.

This is a terribly important recommendation and one that should be flagged to the government and indeed to the Minister for Tourism (Mr Lee) to act upon. The lack of exemption is causing a great deal of hardship in the tourism sector in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Over the last couple of years—and indeed prior to the incumbent minister taking on the portfolio—ecotourism has been promoted and developed at a very rapid rate in all parts of Australia but in particular on the eastern seaboard. It is one element of growth that we are creating, a little bit of a niche market, in my region of New South Wales. We have the advantage of being close to the coast, close to the beaches, as well as having operators such as those that I am talking about who are providing day trips or overnight trips to the hinterland, into our forests, into our national parks, using these exact vehicles.

These operators cannot get sales tax exemption unless they pay a hell of a large price for a vehicle that seats more than 12 people. Those vehicles that seat more than 12 people are not suitable for the type of job that they are doing. A couple of such operators are Richard Morocco from Port Macquarie, who had a vehicle specially built because he needed to have it under that size to operate in the forestry areas and the steep country that he goes into, and Wayne Whitford in Wingham, who is in the same predicament as he attempts to become established in the market.
It was interesting to read the particular paragraph under the heading of `Vehicles under 12 seats including small buses, courtesy buses, four wheel drive vehicles':

SPEECH.PARA: Buses of 13 seats or more are exempt from sales tax under a concession introduced in 1961—
that is 34 years ago—

to allow for competition between government run transport services and those operated privately. Sales tax is imposed on vehicles of 12 seats or under, even when these vehicles are used entirely for commercial purposes. This had led to the situation where operators using larger vehicles may have a lower tax liability than their industry colleagues who use small buses, stretch limousines and 4WD vehicles.
It is the four-wheel drive vehicles that I am talking about. The next paragraph states:
One operator, working within the specialist ecotourism market, described his dilemma when purchasing a new vehicle:

Ideally we would have liked an 8-10 seater 4WD but found that to have any less than 13 seats we would have to pay 21% sales tax. For example, a specially made 4WD coach built by Noosa Coach and Body would cost $121 000 with 8-10 seats and only $100 000 with 13 seats!
It is just a ridiculous situation, and the committee noted in its report:
The Committee regards this situation as undesirable and has sought suggestions for implementing sales tax exemption on tourism vehicles where they are used to generate assessable income.

Therefore, the committee came up with its very simple recommendation on exemption. In all areas of Australia these vehicles need to be specially licensed. In New South Wales people have to be specially licensed by the Roads and Traffic Authority as tourism operators and tourist bus operators. That licence should surely be the criterion for the provision of exemption from that 21 per cent sales tax, which is an added burden in establishing these businesses.

PARA.TAB: The government keeps telling us that it is all about helping small business get established. We are pouring lots of public dollars into that section of our community trying to get small businesses going through such schemes as the NEAT program, yet we are hitting people who are trying to start up a small business in the ecotourism area with a 21 per cent sales tax on their major item of capital expenditure. It is ridiculous, so I urge the government to take on board that recommendation in the report.
The other recommendation I want to discuss this morning is recommendation 21, which is in my mind a little bit soft:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in conformity with the equity criterion of good taxation, the accommodation sector not be singled out for taxation.

I think that is probably code for telling the government that in the 9 May budget there should be no bed tax. But the report does not come out clearly and say that, I suppose because the government members on the committee could not be so forthright as to come out and say, `No bed tax.'

PARA.TAB: The prospect of a bed tax and the public discussion that has taken place with regard to the implementation of a bed tax in Australia in the budget in May have caused a great deal of heartburn and concern in the accommodation and tourism industries. It goes right to the heart of whether the government is really serious about developing an industry such as the tourism industry and assisting the accommodation industry to stay afloat and stay viable.

These industries have been belted around the ears over the last number of years since 1986-87, when the government introduced the FBT. When it was introduced, the FBT collected $535 million. In 1994-95 the FBT is expected to raise $3.23 billion—$3,230,000,000. This represents an increase of 500 per cent in nine years, and that is coming out of the productive sectors of Australia. You can argue all you like about the equity of an FBT; we believe that it should be completely reviewed. We believe that there should be a tax on non-cash remuneration, but it has gone miles too far. It has absolutely gone miles too far. There is no question that it has cost jobs in this country.

Coming back to the bed tax, the prospect of a bed tax has not been ruled out. There was an interesting article in the Financial Review on 28 March which was headed `Tourism industry relieved as bed tax fails to figure'. It seems as if that might be just a little bit of a beat-up because it was not recommended in this report that a bed tax be introduced. The article reads:
The tourism industry has grasped at a new parliamentary committee report for reassurance that a bed tax will not be introduced in next month's federal budget.
A bed tax, which has the tourism industry running scared, was not recommended in the report from the House Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration entitled Taxing relaxing.

The committee found no evidence of unfair taxation measures for the tourism industry, but the chairman, Mr David Simmons, said that as a young industry it was `disadvantaged by not having access to taxation benefits available to better established industries'.

SPEECH.PARA: That is absolutely correct. But the report still does not dispel the possibility of this government introducing a bed tax in the budget in May. I have been contacted in my electorate by all the tourism operators, and particularly the Hotels Association, who are very concerned about the prospect of that bed tax.

PARA.TAB: There has been plenty of debate about it and, if the government does go down that path, it will surely reap another backlash like it did in the Canberra by-election from that section of the community. It is again talking about taxing incentive, taxing the development of a young industry and putting more impediments in the way of the prospect of future employment in what the Minister for Tourism always promotes as one of Australia's major growth industries. We want to keep it that way.

I would like to urge the government again, as has been done on numerous occasions by members from this side of the House, not to consider a bed tax. It would be a very regressive tax. I also urge the government when dealing with this report to seriously consider recommendation No. 11, that a sales tax exemption be granted for tourism buses and four-wheel drive vehicles of 12 seats and under and that the Transport Ministers Council be consulted for its assistance with the implementation of this exemption. It is a very important recommendation for the continued development of this important industry throughout Australia. I certainly hope that the minister is a little bit quicker in dealing with this report than some of his colleagues have been in dealing with a number of other reports.

In closing, I must say that a report that is very important to the tourism industry in Australia and, certainly, in my electorate is the Industry Commission's report on the petroleum industry, which the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) has had for in excess of six months now and has not responded to. We think he has put it in the too-hard basket. It is one for which a lot of people throughout Australia, particularly in the tourism industry, are screaming out for a positive and constructive response from the government. I just hope that, when the Minister for Tourism is getting ready to respond to this report, he does it in a speedier fashion than that in which the Assistant Treasurer has dealt with the report from the Industry Commission on the petroleum industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are looking at the second report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Native Title, and it is on the National Native Title Tribunal Annual Report 1993-94. The second report has been tabled more than 12 months after the tribunal began in January 1994. The tribunal has received well over 100 applications, as recorded in the annual report. During that time, seven non-claimant applications have been determined, yet in not one case has native title been declared. That has come as a tremendous blow to Aboriginal people, whose expectations were raised very much by the Native Title Act and the rhetoric that went with it. They had expectations of the awarding of native title over sections of unclaimed crown land. Yet, to date, after well over a year, there has actually been no determination in favour of Aboriginal people.

PARA.TAB: In fact, the only determinations that have been made—seven in all—have been made in favour of non-claimants. In that situation, we might feel that perhaps it is because of the backlog of 100 or so applications in the system and that, when they go through, we may see some positive determinations on behalf of Aboriginal people. But, when we turn to the actual annual report, which this report is examining, we find this phrase by Justice French, and I think it is one that should disturb everybody. On page 3 of the annual report, Justice French says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is too early at this stage to say that the Tribunal will succeed in its objective of finding resolutions to many or any of the claims lodged with it during the reporting period.

Although that, at the first glance, seems to be a fairly benign statement, when one actually looks at what it means, Mr Justice French is saying that he is not optimistic that any of the claims before him will reach a resolution in favour of native title. That is very sobering and an absolute blow, as I certainly know, to the aspirations of Aboriginal people on the basis of what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and others have said on the advent of the Native Title Act.

PARA.TAB: As to the hundred or so applications that are still in the pipeline, we have to expect that at least another hundred will come up this year. If, in that period there have only been seven determinations, and there are a hundred applications outstanding and an estimate of a hundred more to come up this year, there will be an enormous backlog sitting there, waiting. We will understand the difficulties in resolving those determinations if we look at the claim around Kununurra, where there are over 220 claimants and non-claimants who have to go through the mediation process. It would be a nightmare to try to mediate amongst 220 different claimants and non-claimants. The record shows that there is little hope for Aboriginal people in regard to native title and that the hopes that they did have are not being met.

On other matters, although the process is moving slowly, the tribunal reports that it is happy with the way that it is running. As to the tribunal's threshold in regard to the claims process, the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Native Title found that the process is consistent with the Native Title Act. It was found that the threshold was at about the right level, that the claims are not automatically accepted, and that there has to be a clear case for those claims to be put on the agenda. The threshold is high enough to stop hopeless cases from being accepted and bogging down the tribunal's process, but also low enough to enable many claims to reach the mediation stage.
I will move to the key amendment to the Native Title Act, suggested by Justice French in the tribunal's annual report. His proposed amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . would enable an inquiry to be held, on a discretionary basis, at any point after acceptance of the application to determine whether there is a prima facie case and in that context to allow for important points of law which may affect the negotiation process to be referred to the Federal Court.

The committee considers that this is a reasonable recommendation and would support such an amendment to the act. The committee also notes that in his report Justice French said that he did not want to make any more recommendations until there was some decision from the High Court as to the validity of the Native Title Act. That validity has now been determined and we would expect that Justice French will bring forward further suggested amendments to the act.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I believe that the workings of the Native Title Act are important for Aboriginal people and Aboriginal affairs, and I would like to express my disappointment that no member of the government is here to comment on this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to comment on the second report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Native Title. The report is a relatively short one and it deals with the so-called annual report for 1993-94 of the National Native Title Tribunal. In fact, that annual report was not an annual report at all, because the tribunal was only established on 1 January 1994. It is really a report on six months of operation and even that six months of operation has to be seen in its proper context. From 1 January until 2 May there was only an interim president: the president of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal was the acting president of the native title tribunal. Until even beyond the reporting date, 30 June 1994, there was no registrar; there was only an acting registrar, who, again, was the registrar of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

PARA.TAB: As Justice French took office as president on 2 May, the report deals only with a period of about two months during which he was in office. The report was delivered in September; it is now relatively out of date in terms of the history of that body.

Almost as soon as he took over, it became readily apparent to the president that there were difficulties under the legislation that needed addressing. These were picked up in the submissions made to the parliamentary joint committee, which has a statutory obligation to consider and report on the Native Title Tribunal annual reports. The committee invited submissions, took viva voce evidence and has prepared a written report.

In that report the committee highlights two difficulties that arise in relation to the legislation. It is to be borne in mind, in considering those matters, that the tribunal does not deal with or determine in any finite way any application for native title which is opposed or, for that matter, any application by a non-claimant which is opposed.

The principal functions of the tribunal are to act as a registry for claims—that involves a formal acceptance procedure—and then to act as mediator in relation to opposed claims. The first difficulty highlighted in the report is in relation to the actual acceptance of applications. In the first instance, under section 63 of the Native Title Act, the application is dealt with by the registrar. The registrar must accept it, unless he or she is of the opinion that the application is frivolous or vexatious, or that prima facie the claim cannot be made out. The provision relating to the prima facie status of the claim is in section 63(1)(b) of the act.

If the registrar is of the opinion that the application is frivolous or vexatious, or that prima facie the claim cannot be made out, it is then referred to a presidential member. However, the presidential member does not apply the same test. The presidential member is directed by the legislation to consider whether a prima facie claim can be made out, so that, instead of the negative ruling that a prima facie claim could not be made out on the face of it, the presidential member proceeds to consider whether a prima facie claim can be made out. That is a cause for confusion on the part of those involved in applications.

The second issue dealt with by the committee relates to events after acceptance. If an application is unopposed, then, under section 70 of the act the tribunal may make a determination along the lines sought by the applicant, if it is satisfied that the applicant has made out a prima facie case for a determination in those terms. In addition, it must be determined that it would be just and equitable in the circumstances. If the application is opposed, it then goes to mediation.

Before making a determination that the tribunal is satisfied as to the prima facie case, the tribunal must hold an inquiry. However, with regard to opposed applications it has no power to hold an inquiry before mediation. So it may be obliged to conduct mediation in relation to an application for which no prima facie case could be made out if the matter were examined. The president has proposed an amendment to the parliamentary joint committee that would rectify the difficulties arising in that situation.

My principal purpose in rising to speak on this matter is to highlight the situation that has arisen since the Native Title Act started to operate and, in particular, the difficulties that have been seen and commented upon by the president.

Events have moved since 30 June 1994. As the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) pointed out, there has been no finding of native title in any case. A number of cases have been referred by the tribunal to the Federal Court but the Federal Court has not completed the hearing of any single case as yet.

At the time of the debate in the parliament concerning the Native Title Bill at the end of 1993, many speakers warned of the possible unworkability of the procedures that were set out in the act. They also warned the government that the time that the government anticipated it would take for the completion of applications for native title to be heard by the Federal Court and finally determined would be much longer than the government anticipated. That seems to have been borne out. We do not know how long it is going to take because as yet no claim has been completed.

Since 30 June 1994 we have also had the resolution of the constitutional challenge to the Native Title Act and the constitutional challenge to the Western Australian legislation. That has not in itself highlighted any particular difficulties in relation to the procedures, although one provision of the Native Title Act was held to be unconstitutional.

The principal event to occur since 30 June 1994 to which I want to draw attention is that Justice French has progressed in his understanding of the procedures under the act and has developed his thinking in relation to some of the problems that have arisen with the legislation. On 14 March 1995 he issued a discussion paper entitled Discussion paper on proposed changes to Native Title Act 1993. I urge the government to give very serious consideration to what is set out in that paper.

Justice French has made a proposal which can only be regarded as fundamental in relation to the role of the tribunal. He has identified that there are significant tensions between the role of the tribunal as a decision maker, where it appears to be exercising judicial or quasi-judicial power on the one hand, and the role of the tribunal as mediator on the other hand, where it is seeking to have the parties come to an agreement rather than determining for parties what the rights and obligations are.

In commenting on that tension, His Honour has pointed out that the designation of the tribunal as a tribunal and the involvement of serving judges gives rise to a belief that the tribunal is a species of court which can deliver binding and conclusive decisions about the existence of native title. That is not the case at all. He says that those two matters adulterate the tribunal's role as a mediator. He points out that the role of the tribunal as a decision maker gives rise to second order litigation in relation to tribunal decisions.

What he is pointing out there is that, although the Native Title Act contemplates that the tribunal will act as a registry and as a mediator and that decisions will be made in relation to native title claims by the Federal Court, the role of the tribunal is itself subject to second order litigation in the form of judicial review of its decisions in relation to its role as a registrar and its role as a mediator.

He also draws attention in this paper to difficulties that arise out of the decision of Brandy v. Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. In that case the High Court held that the commission was purporting to exercise judicial power in breach of section 71 of the constitution in seeking to make enforcable determinations after hearings.

This gives rise to questions as to whether the Native Title Tribunal also is acting in breach of the constitution in relation to some of the decisions which are committed to it. The judge also points out that the tribunal has the unenviable task perhaps of being seen only as a place where native title claims will fail, since it has no role in relation to the finding of native title, unless there is no opposition. The usual course of events for an application before the tribunal will be that it will fail because any application that survives the prima facie claim test, in the face of opposition and in the absence of any successful mediation, will be referred to the Federal Court.

The issues that are raised by Justice French in his discussion paper are very important and very serious and warrant the urgent attention of the government. Justice French sets out a process which he believes would single out the Native Title Tribunal as a mediator and eliminate the confusion of its role in relation to native title applications where it has power to make decisions. In effect, his procedure would be a court based one in which the tribunal would not act as the registry but would simply act as a mediation service. He recommends that serving judges not be involved.

On the face of it, what he proposes appears to me to have considerable merit. Any confusion of judicial roles on the one hand with administrative roles on the other hand is something that ought to be avoided not only because it is in breach of the constitution but also because when a body that is committed to making judicial determinations has other roles the parties perceive it in a different way. They do not necessarily accept that it is a body which is committed to making determinations after a contested hearing. They see it as a body which is also involved in, in this case, mediation. In other cases, it may be conciliation or arbitration or some other alternative dispute resolution mode. But it is important, I think, that public confidence in bodies which make judicial decisions be preserved to the utmost extent, and that involves keeping those bodies involved only in judicial decision making. I commend the discussion paper to the consideration of the government.
Debate (on motion by Mr Gibson) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 8 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the market situation for coking coal and what price increase arising from the current negotiations between Australia's coking coal producers and Japanese steel mill operators for coal contracts in the year beginning April 1995 would reflect that situation.
(2) Will he veto a price settlement that is below market expectations.

(3) Has a large number of members of the public contacted him in writing or by telephone asking that action be taken to ensure that coal companies work together to get the best deal for Australia's largest export industry.
(4) How many letters or other forms of correspondence has he received on the matter since May 1994 and what were his responses.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the Honourable Member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Coking coal supply/demand appears to be finely balanced.
The negotiations with Japan for coking coal for JFY95 are prolonged because of different perceptions held by sellers and the Japanese steel mills (JSM) about supply/demand.
Due to technological change, the JSM requirement for hard coking coal is declining whereas the demand for the lower priced semi soft and pulverised coal injection coal (PCI) is rising.
Australia is facing increasing competition from Canada and China for sales of hard coking coal to Japan and from Indonesia, in particular, for lower quality coals.
Market fundamentals support a price increase for JFY95.

I have indicated publicly that restricting price increases for raw materials, including coal, will not improve the competitiveness of the Japanese steel mills—as Japanese price variations flow directly to Korean and Taiwanese steelmakers.
I am also on record as saying that unless the price increases significantly there will be inadequate investment to meet future demand.
Australian suppliers have adopted a firm stand in the negotiations.
(2) It would be inappropriate to speculate on how I might react to a settlement that has not yet occurred.
(3) Yes, a number of letters on this issue have been received.
(4) Approximately 1100 forms of correspondence were received on this matter since May 1994.

In general, the responses outlined the Commonwealth's view that a price controlling body would not be in the long-term best interests of the Australian coal industry, and that this issue along with others, were to be examined by an independent study for the Australian Coal Industry Council, a body which includes the union.

The Coal Industry Council has now reached agreement on the Taylor proposals affecting the major areas of establishing market confidence, industrial relations and competitiveness, and market diversification. The agreement represents a substantial turning point in the relations within the industry.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: SBS Television Transmissions to Regional Western Australia

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 31 January 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Which regional areas of Western Australia do not receive SBS TV transmissions.
(2) Will the Government fund SBS TV transmissions to all regional areas referred to in part (1); if not, (a) which areas will be funded and (b) when will they be funded.
(3) What is the (a) size of the potential SBS TV audience and (b) cost of extending SBS TV transmissions to each regional area referred to in part (1).
(4) Which regions of Australia receive SBS TV transmissions.
(5) What is the (a) estimated SBS TV audience and (b) cost of providing the service to each region referred to in part (4).

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) There is no SBS television in Western Australia outside the Perth area (some communities close to Perth access the service via self help facilities, however, not in local time). Perth services are provided via a high power "spot" beam of the satellite transponder which serves south east Australia.
(2) The Government will consider cost effective options for the provision of SBS television to rural and remote Western Australia, and the claims of other areas in Australia, in future Budgets.
(3) (a) An estimated 290,000 people (based on the 1991 Census) in rural Western Australia are unable to access SBS services through self help or on a direct to home basis.
(b) The provision of a zonal service on the Optus satellite that would provide the SBS television signal to all of Western Australia in correct local time is estimated to cost $2-3m per annum.

The full cost of terrestrial extensions varies from area to area and would be affected by such factors as topography, the size of the area to be covered and the quality and reliability of the signal required. Based on estimates for current extensions, the cost to provide the service to each television coverage area would range from about $1.5m to $3.5m in capital costs plus an annual operating cost of from $0.23m to $0.85m.
(4) SBS television is received by about 75% of Australians including the following regions:

Adelaide (SA); Ballarat (Vic); Bendigo (Vic); Brisbane/Gold Coast (Qld); Cairns (Qld); Canberra (ACT); Darling Downs (Qld); Darwin (NT); Hobart (Tas); Latrobe Valley (Vic); Melbourne (Vic); Newcastle (NSW); North Eastern Tasmania (Tas); Perth (WA); Spencer Gulf North (SA); Sydney (NSW); Townsville (Qld); Wollongong (NSW)
In addition, the Wide Bay and Richmond/Tweed areas are scheduled to receive the service in 1995/96.

Also, some communities outside the above areas have set up their own facilities to access SBS television via satellite. Satellite coverage of the SBS television signal encompasses Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, parts of the Northern Territory and South Australia and Perth and surrounding districts.
(5)(a) It is estimated that about 75% of Australians are able to receive SBS television via a Government provided transmission facility.

(b) The National Transmission Agency (NTA) manages and operates facilities for the transmission of ABC and SBS services. The NTA has advised that the cost of the operation and maintenance during 1993-94 of the transmission facilities for SBS television was in excess of $9 million.

The NTA has further advised that it does not hold historical data on the cost of the transmission facilities constructed for transmitting SBS television since 1980 when the service was inaugurated. In recent years, the cost of providing transmission facilities to make SBS television available to the public to areas included in the Government extension program has ranged widely—between about $1.7 million, where a main transmission facility alone was required to provide signal coverage, to over $3.0 million where one or more translators were needed in addition to provide adequate coverage throughout the designated area.

In relation to current extensions, the estimated cost of providing SBS television transmission facilities to the Wide Bay area is $3.05m for capital and $0.60m for operation and maintenance, and to the Richmond/Tweed area $1.85m for capital and $0.29m for operation and maintenance.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 31 January 1995:

PARA.TAB: Is it a fact that, under amendments to section 90 of the National Health Act 1953, in demonstrating the meeting of a definite unmet public need to the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority pharmacists are unable to include anticipated and existing need; if so, why.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Guidelines in relation to new approvals to dispense pharmaceutical benefits are specific in that no new pharmacy will be permitted to open within 5 kilometres of an existing pharmacy or within 5 kilometres of a site where a closure grant has previously been paid. If the distance is greater than 5 kilometres, an applicant must also demonstrate to the Authority that there is a definite unmet public need.
The Pharmacy Restructuring Authority, when assessing these applications, does consider:
1. proven existing need; and
2. concrete evidence of short term anticipated need.
'Anticipated' need is measured on a short term basis only (approximately 6 months to allow for `normal planning principles and time horizons'), and concrete evidence needs to support applications.
The Pharmacy Restructuring Authority also uses its discretion, based on previous experience at the AAT and Federal Courts, when considering unmet public need and `anticipated' need.
However, `community need' must not be confused with `community want'.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 6 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has her attention been drawn to medical opinion that anal intercourse is damaging to the rectum and likely to cause a number of diseases.

(2) Did the Government sponsor a safe sex guide in the December 1994 issue of Cleo magazine which advocated and explained the practice of anal intercourse; if so, (a) how is the Government's sponsorship of the guide consistent with its HIV/AID strategy (b) what sum did the Government spend on the guide, (c) does she endorse the contents of the guide and (d) why did the Government fund the guide.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) As Minister for Human Services and Health, I am well aware that there are risk factors associated with anal intercourse.
Advising people who chose to engage in this behaviour of those risks was the purpose of the article.

(2) The Government commissioned Cleo to produce a Safe Sex Guide in the December 1994 issue of Cleo magazine. One of the articles in this guide explained the risks associated with anal sex. The article is not intended to advocate anal sex. Whilst explaining how to have anal sex safely, the article also makes it clear that if a person does not wish to have anal sex they should not do so.
(a) The National HIV/AIDS Strategy has as its two goals elimination of the transmission of HIV and minimising the personal and social impact of HIV infection.

The Strategy identifies women as a target group for education and prevention programs. It is imperative that health authorities provide frank and factual information, in a non-judgmental manner, to those people who have elected to become sexually active and are therefore most at risk of being infected with HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases.
Recent Australian research has highlighted that one in five Australians are likely to have a sexually transmitted disease by the time they are twenty-one.
(b) The breakdown is as follows:
$200,000—Australian Consolidated Press, Cleo.
$50,000—development, launch, and distribution.

(c) I endorse the Guide's approach to safe sex. Supporting the need to communicate with young adults in a way that is meaningful to them does not necessarily mean a personal endorsement of either the sexual behaviours discussed, or the style in which the articles are written.

The sexual preferences and practices of consenting adults are their business. My concern is that people have appropriate information easily available to them so that, whatever their sexual practices, they engage in them in the safest way possible. The Guide provides this information.

Under the arrangements with Australian Consolidated Press editorial control remained with Cleo. Cleo journalists wrote the articles in a style which they knew would be attractive to the target audience of young people between 18 and 35 years of age.
An advisory committee consisting of appropriate experts was established by the Department to oversee the process.

(d) The Department funded the Guide following recent research indicating that the majority of young people aged eighteen years and over are sexually active. Research evidence further indicates that young people are engaging in a wide variety of sexual behaviours, including anal intercourse. It is essential therefore that these young people be presented with information that is factual and accessible.
The guide is consistent with the promotion of safe sexual practices which has been a theme of all Australian Governments in recent years.
