TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 9 February 1995:(1) How many private hospital beds has Medicare purchased since 13 March 1993 to reduce hospital waiting lists.

PARA.TAB: (2) What sum has been allocated to post-acute and palliative care patients in private hospitals since 13 March 1993.
(3) Has Medicare coverage been extended to emergency and basic dental care for health care card holders since 13 March 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) In December 1993, the Department of Human Services and Health wrote to all private hospitals and day surgeries inviting them to submit proposals to treat public patients waiting for elective surgery.
No proposals were submitted from Western Australia, South Australia and the Northern Territory.

Joint Commonwealth-State selection committees met in March 1994 to review the proposals from New South Wales and Victoria. Subsequently, the NSW, Victorian and Tasmanian Health Departments informed the Commonwealth that they did not support the proposals submitted. Among the reasons for this lack of support were that:
most prices quoted were not cost effective;
the procedures proposed were not the key procedures for which patients were waiting; and
in some areas, medical staff in public hospitals did not support the practice of transferring patients from public waiting lists to private hospitals.
Consequently the program did not proceed in those States.
The one ACT proposal was not supported by the medical profession, and did not proceed.

The program is being implemented in Queensland. The Commonwealth has approved $550,000 in 1994-95 for the provision of cardiac angiography services at the John Flynn Hospital at Tugan, and for general surgery and orthopaedic services at the Gold Coast Surgicentre.
Negotiations are proceeding with the Queensland State Government on a third project relating to cardiac surgery also at the John Flynn Hospital.
The expected throughput for the first year is:

at John Flynn—100 cardiac angiography; 50 cardiac valve procedures; 100 coronary artery bypass grafts; and at the Gold Coast Surgicentre—60 to 90 general surgical procedures; and 80 to 120 orthopaedic procedures.
Under this initiative Queensland is to receive up to $7.38 million.
(2) The Commonwealth does not provide funding direct to private hospitals though, of course, Medicare benefits are paid to patients in private hospitals for medical services.

Before 1993-94 post acute and palliative care funding was provided by way of combined identified grants to the States and Territories under the Medicare Agreements. The State and Territory Governments are responsible for distribution of this funding to Area Health Services, individual hospitals, etc.

Following a 1993 Election commitment to allocate $55 million over the four year period to 1996-97 specifically for palliative care services, the post acute and palliative care funding component of the Medicare Agreement was divided nominally, with the approval of the States and Territories, into two separately identified post acute and palliative care components. This separation of the Medicare Agreement funding will continue until 1996-97.
Funds allocated to the States and Territories for post acute services was of the order of $21.4 million in 1993-94. This figure is expected to increase to around $22.2 million in 1994-95.

The objective of this funding is to promote public hospital efficiencies by the encouragement of post acute early discharge initiatives (eg home nursing services) as more cost effective alternatives to in-hospital care. It was never intended that post acute funding under the Medicare Agreements be directed to the private hospital industry.

Whichever source the palliative care funding comes from (either under the Medicare Agreements or "new" money arising from the Election commitment), it is the responsibility of the States/ Territories to allocate it within their jurisdictions. There is no direct Commonwealth funding of patients in private hospitals (or public hospitals). Under the Program, there is an emphasis on expansion or enhancement of networks of community based care as opposed to institution oriented services. However, institutions do receive funding to maintain ongoing services. Patients who have been treated in either private or public hospitals have access to services funded under the Program.
Palliative Care Program funding to the States and Territories in 1993-94 amounted to $24.0 million and in 1994-95 will be $24.8.

(3) The new Commonwealth Dental Health Program commenced on 1 January 1994. The Program provides improved access for Health Card holders and their adult dependants, and holders of the Commonwealth Seniors Health Card, to a package of basic dental services. State Dental Services have been contracted to provide the services on behalf of the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth will be providing a total of $278 million over the four years to 1996-97 for this purpose.

With the exception of persons aged under 25 years and living with their parents, Rent Assistance is available to all pensioners, allowees, beneficiaries and additional family payment recipients who pay rent above minimum threshold levels. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 27 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the drug RITALIN being considered for inclusion in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme; if not, why not.

(2) Is it a fact that families whose children need to use the drug because they suffer from Attention Deficit Disorder pay $45 for 100 RITALIN tablets; if so, what assistance will the Government give those families.

TALK.START.PARA: —the answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Ritalin is a brand of the drug methylphenidate hydrochloride. Methylphenidate hydrochloride tablet 10 mg was recommended for listing in the Schedule of Pharmaceutical Benefits by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee at its meeting in August 1994.

The Committee recommended that the drug be available as a pharmaceutical benefit for use in attention deficit and hyperactivity disorder, in accordance with State/Territory law. [Methylphenidate hydrochloride is a schedule 8 drug which requires the pharmacist to record the sale and forward the record to the relevant State Department of Health.]

The advice of the Committee which accompanied the recommendation was that methylphenidate hydrochloride tablet 10 mg was of similar safety and efficacy to dexamphetamine sulfate tablet 5 mg (which is currently listed as a benefit for the same use with a dispensed price for 100 tablets of $12.14).
Based on this advice, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Authority recommended an appropriate price for methylphenidate tablet 10 mg and my Department has been negotiating with the sponsor.
To date, these negotiations have been unsuccessful.

(2) The Commonwealth subsidises the cost of pharmaceuticals through the operations of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. However, the National Health Act makes no provision for exceptions in individual cases and thus there is no direct subsidy for drugs which are not listed as benefits.
Based on the prices listed in the Pharmacy Guild price list, the dispensed price for 100 Ritalin tablets for a private prescription would range between $55.63 and $67.91.
The Commonwealth has no jurisdiction over prices charged at pharmacies for private prescriptions.
